fields.headline: Can Virgin woo stay-at-home consumers?
fields.standfirst: Few customers have bothered to change their power supplier. Jessica McCallin looks at Branson's plans to turn them on
fields.trailText: Few customers have bothered to change their power supplier. Jessica McCallin looks at Branson's plans to turn them on
fields.body:
There's no stopping some people. Sir Richard Branson, not content with airlines, railways, music, pensions, ISAs, cosmetics and wine, now wants to sell you gas and electricity. Virgin Energy, launched this week, will take over your cooking and heating bills, with a price guarantee that if, after the first year, you have not saved money, it will refund the difference plus 20%.

Virgin is also offering £1 for every 1% reduction in your energy bill, subject to a maximum of £20. So, if after your second year, you have cut your bill by 5%, you can claim £5 from Virgin Energy.

The service aims to undercut the market by operating solely over the internet. Each customer will have an account, accessible through the website www.virgin.com/energy, which will detail their payment history, meter readings and bank details.

Customers will also receive their bill by email although a 24-hour customer service line is provided.

The website is up and running now and potential customers can apply any time, although Virgin will not actually start to supply the energy until September.

Once it has received your application, it will take about six weeks to negotiate the transfer of your account from your existing provider, but Virgin says that if your current supplier drags its heels, it will email your account letting you know - giving you the option, presumably, of harassing your existing provider.

Sir Richard is not the first to enter the market in this way. The venture, which is 25% owned by London Electricity, comes hot on the heels of similar services such as Servista (www.servista.com), which launched in May, and Amerada (www.amerada.co.uk), which launched in December 1999.

The three are slightly different. Servista operates as a one-stop shop for energy and phone bills, combining payment for all three into a monthly e-bill. It also has a facility for providing environmentally friendly energy from wind and water power for an extra £1.40 a month.

Amerada, on the other hand, offers only gas, although it plans to offer electricity by September. Its perks include the ability to pay by credit card as well as direct debit and the opportunity to collect air miles on your bill.

However, the principle behind the three operations, of internet-based accounts which combine utility services, is the same.

The three services have been launched to take advantage of the de-regulated energy industry. Since the gas industry was deregulated in 1998 and the electricity industry last year, only one in four people has changed supplier despite estimates from government watchdog Ofgem, the office of gas and electricity markets, that the average household could save £35 to £40 a year by switching.

This apparent complacency is probably due to customer confusion. In the past, British Gas supplied gas and a regional electricity company supplied electricity. However, since deregulation, more than 20 companies have entered the market, some offering both gas and electricity and some offering just one of the services.

On top of that, regional electricity companies can now supply electricity anywhere in the country. So someone in Edinburgh could conceivably buy their electricity from Swalec or Seeboard, companies which, in the past, supplied only electricity to the southern regions of the country.

Ofgem has produced factsheets designed to help people who are thinking of changing energy supplier. These, and price comparison tables, can be found on its website at www.ofgem.gov.uk or by calling 0800 88 77 77.

When looking for a new provider, Ofgem recommends that you don't just consider price. Service is also important, it says, adding that some of the cheaper operators have had a raft of complaints made against their service.

Ofgem also says that not all companies offer a variety of payment methods. If, for example, you have a pre-payment meter, you may find a lot of the companies are closed to you.

Standing charges, it says, should also be considered and added to any calculations you make of how much you are currently paying.

 Have you swapped gas and electricity suppliers? Was the transition smooth and have you saved money? Email us with your experience at jobs.and.money@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Impossible act to follow
fields.standfirst:
Hermeto Pascoal ***
Barbican, London
fields.trailText:
Hermeto Pascoal ***
Barbican, London
fields.body:
A great way to start a gig: from the loudspeakers by the darkened stage came tumbling figures on a button accordion - not folk music, not concert music, not jazz, but something rhythmic and melodic. Eventually, the performer, Brazilian multi-instrumentalist Hermeto Pascoal - appeared, squeezebox strapped to his chest, adding wordless vocals to the mélange. He modulated into a quieter melody, then a virtuoso riff, as if all the musical elements that inform Latin music were colliding.

The programme notes (by the Guardian's John Fordham) observed that Pascoal is an impossible act to follow, proved when the rest of the 21-piece band came on. They were good, premier league blowers and a crack rhythm section plus Brazilians Fabio Pascoal (percussion) and Jovino Santos (piano). Pascoal, 64 and looking like Father Christmas on holiday in Rio, waxed lyrical about the guys in Portuguese, but it rarely felt like Pascoal's team, more a hybrid of every British big band.

Stuart Hall's peppery guitar and soulful violin seemed closest to the oblique spirit of Pascoal's world. The composer occasionally joined in, improvising anarchic concoctions of DX7 and voice, but his personality emerged more clearly when solo in the 5/4 boogie for piano, or a simultaneous bass flute and voice cadenza that incorporated tunes by the Beatles, Monk and Brubeck.

The overlong concert included bravura sections for brass, overlapping melodies and countermelodies and jazz, with interludes in which Pascoal might play a balloon pump, or a kettle, which sounded like a flugelhorn until he added water for a soggy rendition of Round Midnight.

Despite attempts to subvert the big band format - with synchronised shouting and massed toy squeaking - the concert never quite ignited. But it is a treat to see Pascoal - and his admirers, including many musicians, turned out in force to show their devotion, joining in the eight-bar wordless refrain he taught the audience to sing.

fields.headline: Simple plea ignored by government
fields.trailText: The government has been attacked by Opas, the pensions advisory service for being "unable or unwilling to simplify the pensions system".
fields.body:
The government has been attacked by Opas, the pensions advisory service for being "unable or unwilling to simplify the pensions system".

While the government and pensions industry exhort us to save more for retirement, Opas chief executive Malcolm McLean "strongly believes the complexity of pensions rules and regulations remain a major barrier to the ordinary citizen's understanding of their pensions position".

He adds: "People will always be suspicious of something that perplexes and confuses them and of providers who are incapable of explaining it to them... this will remain a major issue for the pensions industry as long as the government seems unable or willing to simplify the system."

Opas, which operates a free advice service through a network of unpaid but professionally qualified volunteers, tries to help people through the pensions minefield. And in its latest review of cases, it reveals that 32,174 people contacted it over the year to March 31, a record number.

It deals with both personal pensions, where nearly half the inquiries concerned mis-selling, and company schemes where problems were more widely based.

Opas says delays are a growing problem, with employers, trustees, administrators and insurance companies all bearing their share of the guilt. It is not always successful in pushing matters along. It quotes one case where, despite its intervention, a pensioner who joined a scheme in 1989 and has since retired has still not received any acknowledgement of his membership, let alone received any pension payments.

"You might suspect some of the parties deliberately ignored letters in the hope the complainant would go away," says Mr McLean.

Opas, which has no legal powers, does not name and shame the guilty parties.

However, it does say that the government is also guilty of delays. It has been calling on it for some time to give statutory protection for pensions on bankruptcy and for laws to force employers to hand over personal pension contributions deducted from wages. In one case, neither the employer's nor the employee's contributions had been paid for four months. Because the scheme was a group personal pension, the victim could not complain to the pensions ombudsman, who deals with individual personal pensions, or to Opra, the occupational pensions regulatory authority.

"While we managed to rectify the situation, this is another example of a regulatory black hole," says Mr McLean.

Opas also tried to help a personal pensions mis-selling victim whose independent financial adviser went bust in the four month gap between the introduction of personal pensions in April 1988 and the start of the Investors Compensation Scheme in August 1988. It failed, due to rigid rules.

The OPAS helpline is on 020 7233 8080.

webTitle: IF keeps its head with intelligent deals

fields.headline: IF keeps its head with intelligent deals
fields.trailText: A low-rate flexible mortgage that trumps Standard Life Bank's hugely popular offering was launched this week by Intelligent Finance (IF), the Halifax's internet and telephone bank.
fields.body:
A low-rate flexible mortgage that trumps Standard Life Bank's hugely popular offering was launched this week by Intelligent Finance (IF), the Halifax's internet and telephone bank.

IF (www.IF.com) opens on Friday, July 14 and its standard variable mortgage rate will be 6.8%, substantially less than the 7.74% charged by most high street banks. It has just one mortgage on offer, but it's a good one: a flexible loan with a discount of 1.5% for the first six months, giving an initial rate of 5.3%.

That compares well with Standard Life Bank, currently offering a 1% discount off its 6.95% rate for six months. And, unlike Standard Life, the IF mortgage is penalty-free. The minimum deposit is 5% with flexible features - you can make overpayments, pay lump sums and take payment holidays.

Ray Boulger at mortgage broker John Charcol says the IF loan is competitive but there are cheaper deals if you are prepared to switch your mortgage every two years or so, or are not bothered about flexibility.

Mortgages are just part of the IF story. It has a current account paying 5% on credit balances, a savings account paying up to 6.25%, a credit card at 10.8% and a personal loan rate at 10.5 APR. Each is available separately but to tempt you into taking more it will have a "connectivity" system, offsetting savings against borrowings. So if you have £20,000 to pay on an IF mortgage and £21,000 in savings, you pay no interest on your home loan.

fields.headline: Over here, over played
fields.standfirst:
All My Sons **
Cottesloe Theatre, London
fields.trailText:
All My Sons **
Cottesloe Theatre, London
fields.body:
There is nothing radically wrong with the Howard Davies revival of Arthur Miller's first major play. I just wonder what it is doing on the stage of the Cottesloe. The play has had two excellent London productions in the past 20 years, and becomes the third American show in a row at our increasingly bland National, a venue that, under Trevor Nunn, seems as Europhobic as the British press.

Miller's 1947 play does have its virtues. It deals with the divorce between action and re sponsibility: in particular with Joe Keller, a thriving businessman, who shifts the blame for producing cracked cylinder heads in wartime on to his partner and sends 21 airmen to their deaths. Joe's ultimate defence is that he did everything for his family. But one son, Larry, has gone missing in action; the other, Chris, finds his prospective marriage to Larry's ex-fiancée blocked by his obdurate mother and tainted by familial guilt.

Miller's play is not just an at tack on war-profiteering: it also becomes a fierce assault on a "practical" morality that places money, success and family above individual conscience. But, though it expresses important truths, the play lapses into melodrama: everything hinges on the production of a letter kept hidden for three years by Larry's ex-fiancée Ann. Any Victorian dramatist would have blushed at such a device; it also casts doubts on the whole of the preceding action, including Ann's subscription to the myth of Joe's innocence.

Davies seems to recognise that the play is as much melodrama as moral indictment. He begins with a violent storm that sends the wind rushing through the willows of William Dudley's set and has lightning illuminating the clapboard porch and traverse lawn: we seem to be in the world of The Omen as much as early Miller. Davies also sanctions some feverish over-acting, especially from Julie Wal ters who, as Mrs Keller, signals her own secret guilt by pointing an accusatory finger at everyone in sight in the manner of a berserk traffic-cop.

Fortunately, there are quieter performances from James Hazeldine as the blustering, hollow Joe who seems like an early draft of Willy Loman, from Duncan Bell as a neighbourly doctor and, most especially, from Catherine McCormack who lends the strangely motivated Ann a tremulous, thoroughbred sensitivity. But I'm still puzzled as to why the National is reviving this now. If they want a play about the sacrifice of public safety to private profit, Ibsen's Pillars of Society is both rarer and more telling. Little chance of that, however, at our safety-first National Theatre.

In rep until October 18. Box office: 020-7452 3000 .

webTitle: Rates move turns up heat on lenders

fields.headline: Rates move turns up heat on lenders
fields.standfirst: HSBC's latest promise never to go more than a percentage point above the Bank of England base rate is good news for borrowers and puts the cat among the pigeons. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: HSBC's latest promise never to go more than a percentage point above the Bank of England base rate is good news for borrowers and puts the cat among the pigeons. Rupert Jones reports
fields.body:
A full-scale home loans price war is set to break out after banking giant HSBC upstaged new-fangled rivals by slashing its standard variable mortgage rate by almost one percentage point - a move that will cut monthly bills for thousands of borrowers by an average of £600 a year.

HSBC (formerly known as Midland) this week cut its mortgage rate from 7.74% to 6.75%, and has introduced a guarantee that, from now on, its rate will never be more than one percentage point higher than the Bank of England base rate.

Its decision is likely to put pressure on other lenders to reduce their mortgage rates too, and shows just how rattled the banking old guard are in the face of ever-increasing competition from new entrants.

It came on the same day as the Halifax's new internet and telephone bank Intelligent Finance turned up the heat even further by announcing highly competitive rates on mortgages and savings. It also coincided with the latest Moneyfacts survey of the mortgage interest charged by the UK's 35 largest lenders which - surprise, surprise - showed that building societies and the new entrants beat the high street banking giants hands down when it comes to lower home loan rates.

HSBC's announcement means its standard mortgage rate is now way below the UK's 10 largest lenders, which charge between 7.29% and 7.75%. In fact, only a small handful of lenders can boast lower standard rates. They include Egg (6.69%) and Hinckley & Rugby building society's telephone banking arm (6.64%).

The move is particularly good news for HSBC's 300,000 existing borrowers because they will automatically be transferred to the new lower rate. The 100,000 or so borrowers on the standard variable rate will be switched over on September 24, while the others, who are predominantly on fixed and discounted rate deals, will go on to the new rate when their current fixed/discounted period comes to an end. HSBC says the average standard variable rate borrower with a £70,000 loan will save about £50 a month - £600 a year - at current rates.

The move is also designed to help HSBC attract new mortgage customers. By guaranteeing you will never pay more than 1% above the bank base rate, it has effectively created a tracker mortgage which is one of only a few to meet the government's CAT standards on charges, access and terms. There are no lock-in early redemption penalties, you're not required to buy their insurance, early repayments can be made at any time, and interest is calculated on a daily basis.

So what are the downsides? There are some. Those borrowing more than 90% of the property's value have to fork out an extra 0.15% over the standard rate for the first three years, which lifts what they pay to 6.9%. Another is that the deal technically isn't a fully-fledged CAT mortgage yet because it won't be available to existing customers until September.

Also, while it's a very good low standard rate, there are no special discounts on offer to tempt people to take it out - if you're looking for a good upfront deal you could do a lot better, says Phillip Cartwright at brokers London & Country Mortgages.

For example, Britannia building society is offering a 2.1% discount off its base rate for two years, giving a current payment rate of 5.54%. When the two years are up you go on to the society's standard rate - currently 7.64% - but as there are no redemption penalties at any time, there is nothing to stop you from walking away.

However, HSBC says that what it is offering is "a long-term highly competitive rate to give people the security of knowing they are not going to have to chase rates forever and a day". In other words, if you're the sort of person who cannot be bothered to keep changing your mortgage every couple of years to take advantage of the very best rates, it is well worth a look.

This week's survey from financial data specialists Moneyfacts shows the total interest paid on a £50,000 standard variable rate mortgage between 1 July 1999 and 30 June 2000, and also shows how much someone has coughed up over the past three years.

It reveals that the difference between the cheapest and the most expensive lender over 12 months is a whopping £691. Standard Life Bank comes out cheapest, with a total interest bill over 12 months of £3,225. Two societies, the Cheshire and the Coventry, came second and third with £3,276 and £3,319 respectively, though these figures are based on borrowers who have been members for at least five years and therefore qualify for a lower rate.

The table provided further proof that mutual organisations tend to offer consistently lower mortgage rates - of the top 10 lenders, all but one is a building society or owned by a mutual. Again, the big high street banks and converted building societies have performed dismally.

Halifax, Abbey National, Barclays, NatWest, Alliance & Leicester and Woolwich are all near the bottom of the table, with total annual interest repayments of between £3,647 and £3,652. However, it is worth bearing in mind that for many people their lender's standard variable rate is pretty irrelevant because they are on a fixed or discounted rate.

Also, while it's a very good low standard rate, there are no special discounts on offer to tempt people to take it out - if you're looking for a good upfront deal you could do a lot better, says Phillip Cartwright at brokers London & Country Mortgages. For example, Britannia building society is offering a 2.1% discount off its base rate for two years, giving a current payment rate of 5.54%. When the two years are up you go on to the society's standard rate - currently 7.64% - but as there are no redemption penalties at any time, there is nothing to stop you from walking away. However, HSBC says that what it is offering is "a long-term highly competitive rate to give people the security of knowing they are not going to have to chase rates forever and a day". In other words, if you're the sort of person who cannot be bothered to keep changing your mortgage every couple of years to take advantage of the very best rates, it is well worth a look. This week's survey from financial data specialists Moneyfacts shows the total interest paid on a £50,000 standard variable rate mortgage between 1 July 1999 and 30 June 2000, and also shows how much someone has coughed up over the past three years. It reveals that the difference between the cheapest and the most expensive lender over 12 months is a whopping £691. Standard Life Bank comes out cheapest, with a total interest bill over 12 months of £3,225. Two societies, the Cheshire and the Coventry, came second and third with £3,276 and £3,319 respectively, though these figures are based on borrowers who have been members for at least five years and therefore qualify for a lower rate. The table provided further proof that mutual organisations tend to offer consistently lower mortgage rates - of the top 10 lenders, all but one is a building society or owned by a mutual. Again, the big high street banks and converted building societies have performed dismally. Halifax, Abbey National, Barclays, NatWest, Alliance & Leicester and Woolwich are all near the bottom of the table, with total annual interest repayments of between £3,647 and £3,652. However, it is worth bearing in mind that for many people their lender's standard variable rate is pretty irrelevant because they are on a fixed or discounted rate.

fields.headline: A credit to your cause
fields.trailText: When I first went to Paris, as a teenager at the beginning of the 80s, I can remember my surprise at seeing begging accepted as part of everyday life. I'd thought that begging bowls and outstretched hands belonged to the middle ages, not a modern capital city.
fields.body:
When I first went to Paris, as a teenager at the beginning of the 80s, I can remember my surprise at seeing begging accepted as part of everyday life. I'd thought that begging bowls and outstretched hands belonged to the middle ages, not a modern capital city.

Of course, that's all changed, and for young people in London now, it's hard to realise that begging was once almost unknown in our capital. There were always a few chronic boozers cadging the price of a drink but widespread public begging did not exist.

But somewhere in the mid-80s, on the back of unemployment and a brutalisation of public culture, begging moved into London and then spread out across the country, so that almost every high street now has someone rattling a bowl.

If begging has become institutionalised, so too has a parallel culture of giving. Forget old-fashioned door-to-door collections and jumble sales; charities have stepped up into far more sophisticated operations, with targeted advertising, mailshots and corporate sponsors.

An increasingly popular way for charities to raise funds is to have their own credit cards, with a donation being made for every transaction. These have a definite feel-good appeal, letting us believe we're giving to a good cause even when we're being utterly self-indulgent. We might be treating ourselves but we're also doing something for charity.

It might be convenient and the only way that we'd ever have time to give anything, but is it a good deal and an efficient way of donating? At the risk of sounding uncharitable about charities, the honest answer is: not really.

Interest rates charged by charity credit cards are generally higher than for conventional cards. If you have an Amnesty International card there is an 19.8APR, while Oxfam and the NSPCC have cards charging 19.9APR, 9% above the best rates available.

Now this won't matter if you pay off your credit card bills within the interest-free period, but most of us end up carrying forward a balance (the average credit card balance is £675), which means paying extra interest charges. This wouldn't matter so much if the extra interest went to the good cause, but it goes to the credit card company. The donation to the charity is a percentage of how much money you spend on the card, typically 0.25%.

It has to be said that this isn't hugely generous - £1 for every £400 spent. The calculation you need to make is whether the donation is larger than the amount you're paying extra in interest because if it isn't, you'd be better off getting a cheaper credit card and setting up a standing order for the charity. Otherwise, your main donation will be to the credit card company.

If you use a Help the Aged card, there is a donation of 0.25% of purchases and an interest rate of 19.8APR. This means that if you had a balance of £1,000, the monthly interest charge would be £15.20, while the donation to charity would be £4.

But if you had an Egg credit card, currently charging 10.9APR, there would be a monthly interest charge of £8.69 - more than £6 cheaper than the charity card. And if you don't pay off the balance, you could be paying the £6 extra every month, while the £4 donation will only be paid once.

Another form of donation is a flat payment for each transaction. The National Trust's card offers 5p per purchase, which would mean you'd need to make 200 purchases before the Trust received £10.

The majority of cards also make an initial payment to the charity when you sign up for a card. These range from £2.50 for the British Dental Health Foundation up to £10 for the Cancer Research Campaign (which also has the best interest rate for a donation card of 16.7APR).

There's no doubt that the expansion in the charity card market reflects its success in fundraising. For the recipients it's a regular and uncomplicated income and for the donors it's a hassle-free way of supporting a cause.

And if we follow the example of the United States, where the affinity card concept has already reached much further, we can expect almost every organisation, cause and profession to have its own credit card.

But we should also expect the rates on offer to improve, because wanting to be generous shouldn't be interpreted as wanting to pay over the odds.

Although at present, it's interesting to note that among the most expensive cards available are those supporting the Battersea Dogs Home, Elvisly Yours and Mensa. No comment.

Email: coughlan-sean@hotmail.com

fields.headline: House prices begin to slide
fields.standfirst: London, which led the country into boom, leads the way out with falls of 2.4%
fields.trailText: Average house prices in Britain are at a standstill for the first time in five years and have begun sliding in London, Scotland and Yorkshire, the Halifax said yesterday.
fields.body:
Average house prices in Britain are at a standstill for the first time in five years and have begun sliding in London, Scotland and Yorkshire, the Halifax said yesterday.

London, which led the country into a boom, is now leading the way out with a 2.4% fall in house prices over the past three months. The average price in the capital has fallen by more than £1,000 per month from £148,672 at the end of March to £145,104 at the end of June.

Nationally, house prices were unchanged in the second quarter of the year, the first time that prices have not risen since the third quarter of 1995. But the sharp rises earlier this year mean that the average house price, £84,422, is still 11.3% ahead of a year ago.

Four successive interest rate rises and the abolition of mortgage tax relief have caused the market to grind to a halt, according to Halifax. "It now looks likely that the first quarter of the year marked the peak in the current housing market cycle," said group economist Martin Ellis.

However, the Halifax figures highlight continuing "hot spots" and "cold spots" across Britain. Scotland showed the biggest fall, down 5.9% over the past three months, in contrast to the south east of England outside London, where prices rose 4.5%.

Halifax now expects prices to remain broadly flat for the rest of this year, but adds that in certain hot spots, there is a significant risk of further price falls. But it rules out another property crash. "The economy is still doing well and there aren't the conditions for a crash. Prices nationally have not gone up far enough for them to fall back much," said Mr Ellis.

The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors two weeks ago forecast that prices in London will decline slightly over the next three months.

In a remarkably rapid turnaround, queues of buyers have been replaced by a surge of property for sale. "Earlier this year we had three or four buyers fighting over every property and sales had to be agreed in a couple of hours," says Guy Foster, an agent for Friend & Falcke in Clapham, formerly one of the hottest of London hot spots.

"Now I've got twice as much property on the books as I would expect for this time of the year, and more than we've had for several years." Prices in Clapham are down by between 5-10% from their peak earlier in the year, he said.

In London's prime residential areas, prices levelled out some time ago. In Primrose Hill, where four-bedroomed Victorian terraces have jumped in value from an average of £700,000 two years ago to £1.2m, today, local estate agent David Birkett said: "Prices started to plateau out last summer. My guess is that they will remain level for the rest of the year. They simply can't go any higher because no one can afford it - they haven't got these sort of rises in their salaries."

But "gazundering" - buyers demanding price cuts just before completing a purchase - has yet to be felt, say estate agents. "Buyers are a lot more cautious, but gazundering hasn't crept back yet. There's still healthy demand and we are certainly not in a property meltdown," said Mr Foster.

But while affordability limits have been reached in London, Halifax blames the high level of sterling and the squeeze on manufacturing industry for price falls elsewhere.

"The fall in prices in London appears to have been largely caused by the preceding period of sharply rising prices, which has made it increasingly difficult for potential purchasers to enter the market.

"The falls elsewhere may re flect the difficulties that manufacturers are experiencing, largely as a result of the high level of sterling. The current weakness of the manufacturing sector is acting as a significant drag on the economies of many of those regions outside the south of England," said Halifax's Mr Ellis.

Price falls are a big threat to the viability of brownfield de velopments in urban areas, the House Builders Federation warned yesterday.

"With brownfield sites there is such a fine line between what's financially viable and what's not. Price falls will put a lot of urban regeneration projects at extreme risk," said a spokesman, who added that visits by buyers to new developments are down.

fields.headline: Are you getting your share?
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange's third annual Share Aware week takes place in London this year, aiming to drum home the message that shares are a good long term investment for everyone.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange's third annual Share Aware week takes place in London this year, aiming to drum home the message that shares are a good long term investment for everyone.

Between September 17 and 23 investment gurus, such as the American Alvin Hall and Barclays Stockbrokers' director Justin Urquhart Stewart, will host a variety of workshops and seminars on all aspects of stock market investment for the individual. The week culminates in a two-day private investor event and exhibition in London Olympia, where you will be able to get advice on how to value companies, how to read their accounts and how to find a suitable stockbroker.

Since its launch in 1998, Share Aware weeks have been held in Leeds, Birmingham, Scotland, Cardiff and Manchester, attracting 4,500 people. Celebrities such as Charlie Dimmock and Angus Deayton have also been enlisted to raise the events' profile.

The week comes after months of turmoil and burnt fingers on the stock market in the wake of the technology stocks crash, so the Exchange will be keen to assure investors that the market is still a good and safe long term bet. Celia Glynn-Williams at the London Stock Exchange said: "There is still interest in the market, although clearly there is more caution. The week is a good opportunity for learning about the fundamentals of investing."

Register now and you may get £10 off the two-day event registration price and a free investment guide book.

For more information call 020 77974444 or visit the website at www.londonstockexchange.com

webTitle: Location is the key to market's wild swings

fields.headline: Location is the key to market's wild swings
fields.standfirst: Is the property boom dead or is it still showing signs of life? Rupert Jones and Liz Stuart consider the contradictions
fields.trailText: Is the property boom dead or is it still showing signs of life? Rupert Jones and Liz Stuart consider the contradictions
fields.body:
The housing boom is very definitely over, if you believe the latest figures from the Halifax, which indicate that the market is not just flat but has started to slip back.

The UK's biggest mortgage lender declared this week that UK house prices have fallen for the fourth time in five months. It says the average property now costs £83,903 - some £1,341 less than in January, when the figure was £85,244 - as a result of prices falling by between 0.4% and 0.9% in February, March, May and June. That's in stark contrast to December and January, when they were shooting up by well over 2% a month. Prices are now just 9.2% higher than they were a year ago, well down on January's 16% annual rate of growth.

The figures followed a report from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS), which said house price rises were "grinding to a halt," and that all the signs were that the cooling of the market would continue over the coming months.

The Halifax data would seem to indicate that after 18 months of impressive growth, the market has embarked on a modest downturn. But nothing is ever simple and clear-cut in the world of property. Two days before the Halifax issued its figures, Nationwide building society published a report showing that house prices rose by 0.4% in June. And a survey from the TEAM network of independent estate agents found that prices are still rising in 14 out of 16 regions of the UK (only Devon and South Wales saw price falls between May and June).

Confusion also reigns over the north-south divide. Bradford & Bingley Estate Agents claims that "the gap between the north and south is closing, with house sales speeding up in the north". It adds that homes in the north of England and Scotland are selling faster than in February this year (in nine to 10 weeks on average), whereas in the south-east the selling time has remained constant at eight weeks.

Compare this with a recent report from Cheltenham & Gloucester, which shows a widening gap between the north and south in terms of property affordability, with homes becoming markedly more expensive in the south.

So whom do you believe? Speaking to individual estate agents and surveyors can give a clearer picture, and they all make the point that these surveys are very generalised.

But even looking at one region in isolation can still leave you none the wiser. For example, while the RICS paints a bleak picture of the property market in East Anglia, saying that house price growth there has suffered a sharp slowdown, sales are weak and new buyers' inquiries are falling, the TEAM network says the region's market "remains reasonably strong overall", with a shortage of good-quality period property in all price ranges, for which there is still strong demand.

Part of the explanation is that even within a particular area, price movement can vary wildly depending on the type of property and its location. In Sussex, one of the areas outside London that's seen the strongest growth, one-bedroom flats in converted houses shot up in value by 71% between April last year and now (from £35,000 to £60,000), while three-bedroom detached houses saw an increase of only 12% (from £124,000 to £140,000), says estate agent Fox & Sons.

Jobs & Money rang a selection of estate agents around the country to find out what had happened to prices of three-bedroom semis in their area over the past year.

Oxshott in Surrey is seeing a level market. There are few semi-detached three-bedroom properties in the area, but those available sell for around £300,000, compared with £280,000 a year ago, says Peter Haynes at estate agents Trenchard Arlidge. "There are enough properties coming on and good houses are selling quickly, while overpriced properties are not selling. The froth has certainly been blown off and there is no panic."

Keith Spencer at estate agents and surveyors Rennies in Abergavenny says that in Monmouthshire the market has levelled off following a mini-boom at the end of last year and the beginning of this year. "I think the stabilisation is due to a number of small factors which, in themselves, would not be enough to affect buying patterns but together have an impact. These are this year's two quarter point interest rate increases, the increase in stamp duty on larger properties, the end of mortgage interest tax relief and perhaps even the fall in dot com share prices."

A three-bedroom house in Abergavenny goes for around £85,000 - a year ago the figure was closer to £77,000.

In Devizes, Wiltshire, a three-bed semi that would have sold for £90,000 a year ago is now likely to sell for around £110,000.

Other figures: Dunfermline now, £65,000; 12 months ago, £60,000. Harrow, north-west London now, £200,000; 12 months ago, £145,000. Huddersfield now, £58,000; 12 months ago, £55,000. Southport, Lancashire, now, £75,000; 12 months ago, £68,000. Wolverhampton now, £72,000; 12 months ago, £65,000.

webTitle: Stakes are raised in the low-cost scheme

fields.headline: Stakes are raised in the low-cost scheme
fields.standfirst: A whole new market has been opened for the latest retirement plan - but, says Tony Levene, this could be at the expense of established company provisions
fields.trailText: A whole new market has been opened for the latest retirement plan - but, says Tony Levene, this could be at the expense of established company provisions
fields.body:
Stakeholder pensions were boosted this week when the government caved in to pensions industry pressure to allow most people in occupational pensions to sign up for stakeholder plans as well.

This increases the potential market by eight million and should help counter recent Mintel survey figures which claim that 58% of people have not heard of the low-cost pension scheme aimed at those on low to average earnings.

But this is bad news for company additional voluntary contribution (AVC) plans. Most AVC payers (unless your company pays into the plan as well) will be better off transfering to a stakeholder.

The government is to allow anyone in an occupational pension to pay up to £3,600 free of basic rate tax a year into the stakeholder plans when they start next April providing they do not earn more than £30,000 a year or are controlling directors of the company.

Stakeholder payments, which are not linked to earnings, would be on top of the 15% of salary maximum contribution into a company final salary scheme and any associated AVC or a Free Standing AVC - the largely discredited high cost plans sold by some life companies.

Being in two schemes is known as "concurrency". But because the government plan excludes around one in 10, it has been dubbed "partial concurrency." Excluding higher earners could save the treasury around £250m a year by 2010.

Treasury economic secretary Melanie Johnson says the £30,000 limit was chosen "because it is nice and easy to remember". It is around £2,000 below the level at which higher rate taxes start and also below the line at which Children's Tax Credit, also due to start in April, begins to taper out.

And she warned it would not go up each year in line with rising prices or wages so more would be excluded as time passed.

But once in a stakeholder, a plan member can stay in for a further four years irrespective of any change in status or salary. This five year total also applies if they give up work (assuming they can afford it) although stakeholder demands a minimum of only £20 a month and you enjoy automatic upfront tax relief whatever your earnings level that year.

"Partial concurrency could be an adminstrative nightmare," says Steve Bee, the Scottish Life pensions expert who has been leading the lobby for concurrency ever since the government appeared to rule it out a year ago. He says: "You can imagine all sorts of anomalies and dodges for those prefering to add stakeholder to their existing plans."

But whatever its reputation elsewhere, the Inland Revenue says it will take a light touch approach to policing these stakeholder limits - which do not affect those in money purchase schemes such as personal pensions.

One problem could be someone on track to earn £29,000 who picks up a large bonus at the end of the year. This will be solved by reference to an applicant's previous year's salary.

Equally, perks such as company cars which are more common at the £30,000 level than at the original stakeholder £10,000 to £20,000 target area will be ignored.

The Inland Revenue line is that it wants to make stakeholder simple so it will ignore cases at the margin. But although someone earning £20,000 - roughly the national average - might, if they could afford it, put as much as £3,000 into a final salary plan and £3,600 into stakeholder and earn tax relief on the whole £6,600, pensions expert believe the most likely stakeholder use will be to replace AVCs or to persuade those not topping up their pensions to do so.

"Concurrency spells the end for AVCs and especially for FSAVCs with their charges," say pensions consultants William M Mercer. "Stakeholder is a competitive alternative featuring low fees, a wide range of investments and companies, and the simplicity that earnings only have to be certified every five years."

But the biggest advantage of stakeholder is that it offers 25% of the final pension pot as a tax free lump sum, a facility withdrawn from AVCs started after March 1987.

"The tax free lump sum is a big draw but you should weigh up other factors before deciding to switch," says Bee at Scottish Life.

Mercer expects stakeholder to be bought by those on above average earnings. "It remains to be seen whether stakeholder will make much of an impact on the lower paid who were the original target audience for this product," says partner Peter Thompson.

fields.headline: Life in the basement
fields.standfirst:
Infinitude
Glasgow GOMA
fields.trailText:
Infinitude
Glasgow GOMA
fields.body:
Video art in Glasgow's GOMA? Surely some mistake. This infamously populist gallery, initially filled by Julian Spalding, has rightly been maligned for including the work of Beryl Cook but not work by the city's hottest young stars working in new media and installation, such as Douglas Gordon and Christine Borland.

But now there is a new team of curators in this post-Spalding era, trying to turn the gallery's fortunes around with cringe and blush-free contemporary shows. Infinitude is the most startling of these, by virtue of foregrounding everything GOMA has to date left out: video, digital works, interactive photography, computer-generated loveliness. There is strong work here, important beyond novelty.

Beverley Hood's Asex is a suggestive screensaver, based on digital representations of the body; Steve Hollings-worth's chairs (one made out of neon as a ghostly trace of a seat) sit well here; Daniel Reeves's three channel video installation, Try to Live to See This, encompasses all of life and more.

Dalziel + Scullion, best known for their site-specific public works, are showing a new video projection, Another Place, for the first time. It's as seductive in its own way as Hood's curvy, supple screensaver: portraits of people against an craggy coastline in ever-so-slightly slow motion. Every blink becomes a languorous moment, every flutter of wind through their hair seems a choreographed, beautiful movement; it is hypnotic yet avowedly simple.

There are limitations, mostly to do with the gallery space. It's the basement gallery, presumably for reasons of lighting: already a dark, black and red tinged space. It's an awkward area, with permanent exhibits simply covered up, and people, not unreasonably, were having trouble navigating them, expecting them to be part of the show. If GOMA wants to be taken seriously as a contemporary art venue, it will need to look more professional.

Stephen Hurrel's LED display unit, Threshold, greets you as you step into the gallery. "What did you dream last night?" it asked me. Answer: that this kind of work, in a gallery that has soaked up Glasgow's art budget for a decade, wouldn't be such a novelty.

Until October 22. Details: 0141-229 1996.

fields.headline: Johnson sparkles beneath the lights
fields.standfirst:
West Indies 232-7
Zimbabwe 233-4
Zimbabwe win by six wickets
Scoreboard
fields.trailText:
West Indies 232-7
Zimbabwe 233-4
Zimbabwe win by six wickets
Zimbabwe last night achieved their first victory against West Indies at international level when they won the first floodlit one-day international in England.
fields.body:
More than 20 years after Kerry Packer's rebel TV circuit became the pioneering force behind floodlit cricket, the first one-day international under lights in England was belatedly staged last night when Zimbabwe and West Indies launched a ground-breaking NatWest triangular series.

There was even a note-worthy outcome. Zimbabwe's six-wicket victory, fashioned with five overs to spare by Neil Johnson's skilfully paced unbeaten 95, was their first against West Indies at international level after eight limited-overs and two Test defeats stretching back to 1983.

There are sound reasons to suggest that England's little bit of floodlit history came many years too late, at the wrong time of year, between the wrong teams, and on the wrong ground, but after so many years of vacillation all that really mattered was that it had happened at all. English cricket will one day become grateful for that.

Floodlit one-day cricket is now so firmly established worldwide that to talk of innovation would be parochial. The first snatch of music to blare out during a floodlit game in England might well have been Abracadabra, by the Steve Miller Band, but nobody could claim that it had happened as if by magic.

Had the England and Wales Cricket Board been invited to resuscitate the ailing motor industry, it would have agonised so long about modern trends that the Morris Minor would be scheduled to roll off the production line in about 2020.

The courageous way to introduce the floodlit game to England would have been to pit England against West Indies at the Oval in mid-August (forget all this exaggerated talk of dew-affected pitches), when the nights would be darker and the atmosphere more boisterous.

To begin yesterday at Nevil Road, before a neighbourly gathering of 7,000, was an exercise in gradualism, as if it was politic to make history without too many people noticing. England's entrance is delayed until this weekend, with back-to-back matches in London against Zimbabwe and a chastened West Indies side.

Adrian Griffith, the West Indian opener and the first batsman dismissed, departed to the strains of Blinded By The Light, which encouraged two thoughts: first, how on earth could Manfred Mann appear in something that is designed to be vaguely contemporary? Second, the most blinding light was the sun as the weather showed a nice line in English irony by delivering one of the clearest days of the summer. Until the clouds thickened up around seven o'clock the lights were on only for show.

It all went agreeably. The crowd were treated to some uplifting strokeplay, especially in the later stages of West Indies' 232 for seven. Wavell Hinds struck a robust half-century, Ricardo Powell biffed 36 from 21 balls when acceleration was urgently required, and Brian Lara, with 60 from 63 balls, exhibited a freedom that England will fear might persist when the Test series resumes next month. Grant Flower, with wickets, catches and run-outs, was involved in just about everything.

Lara's 14 off one over from Gary Brent was climaxed by a six towards the Grace Rooms. What would WG have thought of it all? He would probably have quite liked all the flamboyance and the fuss, especially if he could have had a share of the profits and fiddled the television replays in his favour.

Floodlit cricket has also been introduced piecemeal into the county game, but with no compulsion for the fearful. Sussex are the only county to have installed permanent floodlights, although Warwickshire will follow if they quash protests from the sort of people who buy houses next to sports grounds and then complain about the noise.

webTitle: South Africa floored by flawed process

fields.headline: South Africa floored by flawed process
fields.standfirst: One delegate decided not to vote and Germany won the cup 12-11
fields.trailText: One delegate decided not to vote and Germany won the cup 12-11. Even they could not have expected to win a shootout because somebody refused to take a penalty.
fields.body:
Even Germany could not have expected to win a shootout because somebody refused to take a penalty. By abstaining from the final vote to decide who would host the 2006 World Cup, Charlie Dempsey, the 78-year-old New Zealander who represents Oceania on the Fifa executive, effectively sat in the centre circle while South Africa's last hope disappeared along a familiar autobahn.

The result was known some time before Sepp Blatter, the president of Fifa, made a great show of keeping everyone in suspense before announcing the winning bid. Either Franz Beckenbauer was being hugged because Germany had got it or he had just become the father of quins. But when the name of Deutschland appeared from within the sealed envelope there were boos from the body of the hall.

It was not merely a question of South Africa being disappointed, the whole process seemed flawed and quite possibly corrupt. Originally Oceania had wanted Dempsey to support the Germans with its one vote but he had always insisted on backing England so long as the campaign director Alec McGivan's little ship of optimism was still afloat. It was what he intended to do next that appears to have brought the poll into disrepute.

If Scotland's David Will, who provided England's only other vote in the second round, is right in saying that Dempsey was subjected to "unsustainable pressure" from other bidders from five o'clock yesterday morning, so much so that he feared his personal integrity would be compromised - and there is mounting evidence that he was - then this was clearly not a free and fair ballot.

From the moment Dempsey announced, before any vote was cast, that he intended to abstain once England had been eliminated, South Africa's hopes had been holed beyond repair. Dissenting African votes did not help; nevertheless Danny Jordaan's campaign deserved a cleaner denouement.

These Fifa ballots are cynical affairs at the best of times but yesterday, when Will condemned the pressure put on Dempsey in one breath and in the next said that he had always intended to switch his vote from England to Germany because he belonged to the European federation (Uefa), the rest of whose votes were always going to be cast for Germany, it became clear that the last thing taken into account was the ability of any candidate to run a successful World Cup.

Maybe the South Africans realised this more than England, who had a marketing team when the situation required something more than strident sales talk. Even so South Africa's disappointment easily outweighed Germany's jubilation and was obviously shared by Blatter, who gave an audible sigh before announcing the winners.

Blatter will need third world votes when he comes up for re-election two years from now and wasted no time reiterating his support for the principle of Africa staging a World Cup. He hoped that Fifa would eventually "have the courage to trust a new continent instead of staying with an established footballing power".

Gary Bailey, the former Manchester United goalkeeper, and Terry Paine, once a fixture on the wing for Southampton, were both members of the South African delegation. "I don't know if we can make another bid," said Bailey. "Much of the money raised this time was from businesses, not taxpayers, and to run the thing again will not be easy.

"A successful bid meant everything in terms of jobs, tourism, families and so on. This morning our share prices shot up because everyone was so confident we would win. This has really been a bitter blow."

Paine was scathing about Dempsey. "How can you sit on an executive, vote in two rounds and then not vote in the third?" he demanded. "I'd rather have lost by 13 votes to 11 or, if the votes had been tied at 12-12, let the Fifa president cast the deciding vote." In that event Blatter would have gone with South Africa.

Jordaan's was the most heartfelt comment. "Africa is part of a world football family," he said, "and no family should feed one child and leave the rest to starve."

Europe, nevertheless, holds the baby yet again and if Will has his way this will not alter. Blatter might want the tournament to go around the member continents in rotation, which would mean England forgetting about another bid until 2022, but Will believes Europe should have every third World Cup.

It may take England 20 years to repair the bridges with Fifa and Uefa damaged by what has been a tactless and fruitless campaign. McGivan might blame the hooliganism in Brussels and Charleroi during Euro 2000 for influencing wavering voters within Uefa but Blatter said this had nothing do to with the way the voting went.

Germany commanded the vote they did because, whatever went on behind the scenes, they struck the right note with a carefully tempered bid, and Beckenbauer's final presentation on Tuesday was a masterpiece of understatement. Now Germany need to start remembering how they used to win the cup.

webTitle: Enter Schiffer in little black number, exit Banks with his Dinky

fields.headline: Enter Schiffer in little black number, exit Banks with his Dinky
fields.trailText: England's bid was fatally flawed from start to finish... It spoke volumes that Blair preferred to stick with a prerecorded video message rather than personally attend the final presentations.
fields.body:
It will be some time before we know the full story behind yesterday's activities in Zurich - if, indeed, we ever do. The only thing that is clear through the cloudy lens of accusation and recrimination is that England's bid was fatally flawed from start to finish.

Tony Banks, Sir Bobby Charlton, Sir Geoff Hurst, the campaign director Alec McGivan and the Football Association chairman Geoff Thompson (and, to a lesser extent, Prince Charles, Tony Blair, Hugh Grant and Garth Crooks) wined and dined the great and the good.

But the one noticeable absentee from the schmoozing has been the sports minister Kate Hoey, who has distanced herself from the entire proceedings. She spoke yesterday of "disappointment" at the news while acknowledging that perhaps the England campaign team could "learn a few lessons".

Clearly Hoey did not - and still does not - want to tread on the dainty toes of her predecessor Banks, who became the prime minister's special envoy to help the campaign team play an astute political game. His pressure to persuade Manchester United to enter that nonsense of a world club championship in January, in the belief that non-participation would lose favour with Fifa, led to United withdrawing from the FA Cup.

It also spoke volumes that Blair preferred to stick with a prerecorded video message rather than personally attend Wednesday's round of final presentations. Politics and sport mix only when one is on to a winner. Just ask Silvio Berlusconi, after Dino Zoff's resignation as manager of Italy this week.

The key delegates have been round the world twice over the past two years, hosting events in far-flung places such as Cameroon, Japan, Singapore, Mali, Paris and Hampton Court Palace.

The nearest estimate is that the England bid has cost £10m, with £3m from lottery funds and the rest from the FA and the Premier League. The lottery money was spent legitimately on administration and promotional material and, frankly, £10m seems a piffling amount when put into context with Newcastle's signing of Carl Cort from Wimbledon this week for £7m. If the campaign team had spent treble the amount it could have been justified.

Hoey will want to know why England's bid appeared to fail on so many fronts. Some Fifa members felt England adopted a certain arrogance in their international dealings and Banks was allowed to mouth off at the most inappropriate times. Having announced our bid late, we also probably began the campaign too early.

Our aggressive approach to our nearest partners has also ensured that we have moved from the slow lane of the European game to the hard shoulder.

Hoey will also want to question if our bid was based on brawn rather than brains. We globe- trotted and pressed flesh rather than adopt a more cerebral approach that might have yielded a better result.

We also ignored at our peril that "gentleman's agreement" struck between the former FA chairman Bert Millichip and the Germans for England to allow our European rivals to go for 2006 alone if they backed us for Euro 96; and we backed Sepp Blatter, rather than Uefa's Lennart Johansson, in the race for the Fifa presidency.

Above all Jack Straw, the home secretary, must take a large chunk of the blame, having failed to implement zero-tolerance action to prevent the violence in Charleroi and Brussels. His announcement this week of legislation to stop potentially troublesome fans from travelling abroad was too damned late. We all knew chaos would ensue, yet we were screaming in the dark.

The tireless McGivan ran a highly professional campaign from start to finish but some of those around him seemingly sang from a different hymn sheet. A tad more modesty, and less time spent on delivering spin to the English media, might have produced a different result.

But had England won yesterday's politically puerile vote in Zurich none of these reservations would have been expressed. The team would have been saluted for their dynamic determination and McGivan guaranteed a knighthood. However, we did not win. We did not get close.

England spent their last few pennies on giving the 24 Fifa executive members limited-edition model London taxis decorated in the bid colours and they even supplied them with "England 2006" cushions to sit on during the presentation.

South Africa handed out beaded bracelets, while Germany provided as much draught beer as anyone could drink in the press-centre bar in Zurich. It was Claudia Schiffer and a pint of lager versus Tony Banks and a Dinky.

webTitle: Trapattoni handed the reins by Italy

fields.headline: Trapattoni handed the reins by Italy
fields.trailText: Giovanni Trapattoni, who coached Juventus to six Italian titles in the 1970s and 80s, will succeed Dino Zoff, his goalkeeper in four of those campaigns, as coach of the Italian national team.
fields.body:
Giovanni Trapattoni, who coached Juventus to six Italian titles in the 1970s and 80s, will succeed Dino Zoff, his goalkeeper in four of those campaigns, as coach of the Italian national team.

Zoff resigned on Tuesday, two days after coming within seconds of an unexpected European Championship triumph. He had been criticised by Silvio Berlusconi, the Milan owner and leader of the opposition in the Italian parliament, who described Italy's 2-1 defeat by France as "dishonourable".

Trapattoni, at 61 three years Zoff's senior, was most recently in charge of Fiorentina but resigned in May after a disappointing season. With Juventus he also won two European Cups, including the 1985 meeting with Liverpool at Heysel stadium, and four years later he landed an unprecedented seventh scudetto with Internazionale. In 1997 he won the German title as Bayern Munich coach.

As a defender with Milan Trapattoni won two European Cup winners' medals and scored once in 17 internationals. He has signed a two-year contract to take him up to the next World Cup.

The 28-year-old striker Hakan Sukur completed his move from Galatasaray to Internazionale yesterday. The "Bull of the Bosphorus", who has scored 28 goals in 55 games for Turkey, had a brief and unhappy spell with Torino in 1995. He is believed to have cost about £2m.

The Barcelona captain Luis Figo, under contract until 2003, may make a remarkable move to Real Madrid. Florentino Perez, a candidate for the Real presidency, is reportedly ready to meet the £36m buy-out clause in Figo's contract and has an agreement with the Portuguese player, but the deal would depend on Perez defeating Lorenzo Sanz in the election on Sunday week.

According to reports in Yugoslavia Dragan Stojkovic will replace Vujadin Boskov as national team manager.

webTitle: Bradford break the bank for Hopkin

fields.headline: Bradford break the bank for Hopkin
fields.trailText: Bradford City yesterday agreed to pay a club-record £2.5m to Leeds United for their 29-year-old Scottish international midfield player David Hopkin.
fields.body:
Bradford City yesterday agreed to pay a club-record £2.5m to Leeds United for their 29-year-old Scottish international midfield player David Hopkin. The City chairman Geoffrey Richmond is planning to tie up the deal by the weekend.

The fee will surpass the £1.4m Bradford paid, also to Leeds, for David Wetherall last summer. "Paying this kind of money is something we have got to do if we are going to compete in the Premiership," said Richmond.

Chelsea and Aston Villa are understood to be chasing the 30-year-old Juventus captain Antonio Conte, who has fallen out with his club coach Carlo Ancelotti. Conte, who played in three of Italy's Euro 2000 games, is a former team-mate of the Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli and would cost about £6m.

Middlesbrough hope to sign the Lens striker Joseph-Désiré Job, a member of the Cameroon side that won the African Nations Cup in February.

Southampton's manager Glenn Hoddle, who bought the former Manchester City striker Uwe Rösler from Borussia Berlin this week, has returned to his former club Monaco to sign the teenage French striker Patrice Tano on a free transfer.

Fulham have had planning permission for the £70m redevelopment of Craven Cottage rejected by Lord Bingham, the Lord Chief Justice. Plans for the 30,000-seat stadium did not comply with European rules on environmental impact.

fields.headline: Butcher prevails in the soup
fields.standfirst:
Sussex 192-9
Surrey 196-3
Surrey win by seven wickets
fields.trailText:
NATWEST

Sussex 192-9
Surrey 196-3
Surrey win by seven wickets .
fields.body:
Mark Butcher yesterday eased Surrey to a home quarter-final against Lancashire in the NatWest Trophy, pacing himself in the soupy, airless Oval to reach Sussex's modest target with 14 balls to spare.

There is always a sense of anticlimax when a one-day match spills over into the reserve day, with most of the potential crowd dutifully back at work, and the overcast atmosphere gave a sleepy, slow-motion feel to proceedings.

Once Ally Brown had made a desperate charge at Robin Martin-Jenkins, Butcher formed a brother-in-law alliance with Alec Stewart, adding 85 at a stately four an over. It was Martin-Jenkins who once more brought Sussex into the game, producing a toe-tingling yorker to discomfit Stewart.

Mark Robinson was the best of the rest for Sussex and on 69 Butcher muffed an attempted drive that just eluded the Yorkshireman's grasp. But he stood firm, finishing on 87 as Adam Hollioake lofted Michael Bevan over extra cover to confirm the win.

In the morning Sussex had resumed their interrupted innings, which had lasted only two overs on Wednesday. Chris Adams soon snicked a lively rising ball from Alex Tudor but, after Tony Cottey had sliced to slip, Bevan and Richard Montgomerie added 104 in 24 overs without ever looking in real command.

On his day Bevan is the most murderous of limited-overs batsmen but yesterday he had to settle for harassment instead. His innings of 60 was bullying Sussex towards a competitive total when Ian Salisbury found the edge of his bat and soon Montgomerie's cautious marathon ended with a flat-batted attempt at a pull off Hollioake.

Martin-Jenkins offered Sussex the best hope of further progress until beaten by a Salisbury throw from deep mid-wicket and, even in these sapping conditions, the visitors seemed some 20 short of a challenging target.

 In the other rain-affected games Middlesex crushed Somerset by 169 runs at Southgate, bowling the visitors out for 58 with Tim Bloomfield taking four for 17, and at Canterbury Glamorgan beat Kent by five wickets, with the opener Keith Newell finishing unbeaten on 62.

fields.headline: The best bleeding scene
fields.standfirst: Jesus' son
fields.trailText: Jesus' son
fields.body:
Iowa City, 1971. FH (Billy Crudup) arrives at a rambling detached house on the outskirts of town. He waves jovially at one of the residents, Dundun (Michael Shannon), standing outside pumping water.

"Hey!"

Dundun grins amicably.

"McInnes isn't feeling too good today."

FH takes a step backwards.

"McInnes is here? OK... maybe I'll come back later."

"Oh, don't worry. I just shot him."

There's a small pause as FH takes in what Dundun has just told him.

"You mean you killed him?"

"I didn't mean to shoot him."

"Is he really dead?"

Dundun beams serenely.

"No, he's sitting down in the front room."

fields.headline: Breathless (A Bout de Souffle)
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A movie to be compared with Songs for Swinging Lovers, and yet with intoxicating intellectual dash and sophistication. A treat
fields.body:
This time last year, The Third Man was the plucky little classic chosen to run against Phantom Menace; now Jean-Luc Godard's Breathless (A Bout de Souffle) is the what-have-we-got-to-lose contender against M:i-2. Revisiting this sublime essay in urban romance is to experience a skateboard-rush of fun.

Jean-Paul Belmondo is a battered, damaged sexy presence as Michel, the dodgy ex-airline-steward and car thief who cruises into Paris to persuade his girl to run away to Italy with him. That is Patricia, the gamine Jean Seberg, making a few francs selling the Herald Tribune in the streets. Breathless riffs gloriously on literature, life, Paris, love, music, the police, sex and, naturally, the movies. A movie to be compared with Songs for Swinging Lovers, and yet with intoxicating intellectual dash and sophistication. A treat.

fields.headline: Children of Heaven
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a pellucid and gentle film, made with the simplicity and grace of a children's tale and yet its humour, emotional clarity and directness speak directly to adults and children alike
fields.body:
There could hardly be a more charming or a more persuasive example of the new "fabular" cinema emerging from Iran than Majid Majidi's Children of Heaven, a vivid tale of a small brother and sister, Ali and Zahra, who have to share one pair of trainers when Ali gormlessly manages to lose Zahra's.

The performances from Amir Forrikh Hashemian and Bahare Seddiqi as Ali and Zahra are wonderful: Seddiqi sweetly thoughtful and loving, Ali tremulously bright and sensitive, habitually on the verge of tears. This is a pellucid and gentle film, made with the simplicity and grace of a children's tale and yet its humour, emotional clarity and directness speak directly to adults and children alike - and the pre-teen principals shoulder an adult burden of performance. It is a film whose images and scenes - particularly the running race Ali finally enters to win a new pair of trainers - linger in the mind.

fields.headline: Love and Basketball
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A sentimental film, with some simplistic characterisation
fields.body:
Co-produced by Spike Lee, Love and Basketball stars bright up-and-comers Omar Epps and Sanaa Lathan. Epps is Quincy, a basketball-crazy boy, and son of an NBA pro, who cannot quite admit he has an intense crush on Monica (Nathan) the equally ball-crazy tomboyish girl next door. Their mutual hero, Magic Johnson, makes a fleeting cameo appearance, perhaps conveying a subliminal message about HIV, and the importance of responsible, stable relationships.

This is a sentimental film, with some simplistic characterisation, perhaps showing director Gina Prince-Blythewood's background in television. Yet the film does not have the misogyny that disfigured Malcolm Lee's The Best Man, and also has an excellent performance from Sanaa Lathan as Monica, perpetually furious that ourbursts of temper from male players are indulged or even lauded as virile, but when she does it, she gets penalised.

fields.headline: Flamenco
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It is all slightly worthy [and] it is not especially interestingly choreographed or photographed
fields.body:
Carlos Saura's Flamenco is a minor film from 1995 which arrives here in a print which looks past its best, and lacking any subtitles. Perhaps this is because it is almost solely a music and dance piece. But the introductory voiceovers and the lyrics to the many plaintive songs are surely important?

At any rate, Spanish-speakers and non-Spanish speakers alike can appreciate some splendid, brauvura dance sequences and virile classical guitar playing. A group of singers and dancers recreate the classic music styles of the flamenco, the highpoint being a showstopping turn from Joaquin Cortes. But it is all slightly worthy; it is not especially interestingly choreographed or photographed.

fields.headline: Feeling Sexy
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An attractive, if undemanding short feature... there are nice performances in this engaging two-hander
fields.body:
This year's London Australian Film Festival begins with Feeling Sexy, an attractive, if undemanding short feature from the debutante director Davida Allen.

It is about the early married life of Greg (Tamblyn Lord) an uptight hospital doctor, and his dreamy artistic wife Vicki (Susie Porter) who yearns for the excitement of an affair - and winds up getting it on with a bohemian art student in the back of his nasty van. There are nice performances in this engaging two-hander.

fields.headline: Mission: Impossible 2
fields.standfirst: Flashy, slick and sweat-free, the second Mission: Impossible romp is plenty of fun but has few surprises, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A pretty good ride, but so flashy, so empty, so utterly devoid of real risk, real sweat or real danger that in the end it's just Mission: Improbable or Mission: Untenable
fields.body:
The sequel to Mission: Impossible has streamlined itself into a nifty little techno-key abbreviation: M:i-2, a cool metallic contraction that enacts this picture's elision and omission of all ordinary human motivation, characterisation and, indeed, the banal requirements of physics and gravity.

Once again, Tom Cruise is Ethan Hunt, the impossibly daring agent of the Impossible Missions Force, or, ahem, IMF - to whom we must go cap-in-hand if we want them to save the world. We see him first on holiday - holiday! - doing some ridiculously dangerous free climbing on the edge of a gigantic rock face. Which would be breathtaking were it not for the fact you suspect Tom is actually dangling off the edge of his sofa somewhere and his pert form has been cut and pasted into the relevant locale. The producers insist that this is the real thing, albeit with a concealed safety harness. I can only say that the production's insurance brokers must have been very understanding.

At once it is clear that director John Woo is making very different demands on his leading man than Stanley Kubrick or Paul Thomas Anderson. This is pure action, action quite devoid of the conventional solvents of thought or conversation, and mostly devised on the computer keyboard.

Like the first Mission, the traditional opening is used, one of the very few things from Bruce Geller's original show still in the film. (But one of the disappointments, incidentally, is how little M:i-2 uses Lalo Schifrin's fantastic theme tune.) A 'copter shows up with the details of Ethan's mission and various audio-visual features microchipped into a cute little Ray-Ban-style gizmo.

The mission proposal, or should that be mission statement, bears the familiar rider "If you decide to accept it" - as baffling now as when Peter Graves's Jim Phelps heard it in the mid-60s. (What's the form if the answer is no? Does he throw the now smouldering buff envelope with the spool of tape and the eight-by-six photos in a bucket of water and just wait for something more congenial? Is he on a retainer?)

Ethan has to combat the global villainy of a desperate man with access to a devastating biological weapon. He is played by Dougray Scott; he is a cool dry Scot, and his name is Sean, and short of actually giving him the surname "Connery" it could not be clearer whose dark, brooding machismo John Woo wishes to clone into the movie's bad-guy role. Sean is the ex-lover of Miss Nyah Hall, played by the heart-stoppingly beautiful Thandie Newton, who is, of all the wonderfully old-fashioned things, a jewel thief.

Part of Ethan's job is to get Nyah to insinuate herself back into Sean's affections and infiltrate his dastardly set-up. It hardly needs to be said that Tom himself has formed a tendresse for Nyah and so has no relish for this. But as the controller (Anthony Hopkins) drily informs him, in one of the few droll moments in Robert Towne's screenplay: "It's not Mission: Difficult, is it?" And so another hi-tech, plotless romp kicks off, so stroboscopically flashy it could trigger epilepsy.

Some of the locations are in Spain, but most of the filming was done in Australia, a continent chosen by co-producer Cruise perhaps because of low production costs, perhaps in a uxorious and gallant tribute to the motherland of Nicole Kidman. Either way, it allows Sydney to play host to the glitzy urban sequences - the invasion of hi-tech skyscrapers and the like - while the scrubby bush serves for the big set-piece, a motorbike chase sequence followed by a full-on martial arts punch-up with Tom getting a cut to those exquisite chops, the thin red line of blood presumably intended to give him an edge of Bruce Lee madness.

A device incessantly used in the film is the business of wearing a latex mask of someone else's face. People are always peeling off these things, a supply of which Cruise and his enemy presumably keep stuffed in their knapsacks. It is a very eccentric "disguise" convention, coming straight from the original TV show. In its old-fashioned reliance on impersonation, it could almost be a stage comedy from another century altogether, were it not for the fact that it does not serve to advance or complicate the plot in any normal sense - merely enforce little stand-alone moments of astonishment.

There aren't many actual gadgets here, and even the lap-top computer, a staple of the first film and of techno thrillers throughout the 90s, isn't flashed about that much. It is as if Cruise is conceding that there isn't anywhere obvious for hi-tech innovation to go now, unless the top of Tom's Rolex is to flip up and he is to tap something out on a qwertyuiop keyboard the size of a matchbox.

The main gadget is Tom Cruise himself: swervy, bendy, agile - his longish hair sometimes prettily disarrayed. Throughout it all, Tom maintains his taut, genial self-possession. At one stage, Sean tells him: "That's the hardest part of playing you - grinning like an idiot every 15 minutes!" A perfectly fair assessment of Tom Cruise's performance, and that grin becomes more disconcerting once you see that his upper row of teeth is not quite square on his face, and the gap between his two front teeth clearly to the right of his nose. Is it some sort of genetic thing?

M:i-2 is a pretty good ride, but so flashy, so empty, so utterly devoid of real risk, real sweat or real danger that in the end it's just Mission: Improbable or Mission: Untenable.
