fields.headline: Well-off 'should face higher university fees'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Allowing universities to charge different rates for degree courses amid a huge expansion of scholarships and loans would solve the long-term problems in higher education brought out by the Laura Spence affair, says a long-awaited report out today.
fields.byline: Will Woodward and Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Allowing universities to charge different rates for degree courses amid a huge expansion of scholarships and loans would solve the long-term problems in higher education brought out by the Laura Spence affair, says a long-awaited report out today.

The report, commissioned by the Russell Group of 18 elite universities, says differential fees for institutions and courses would provide the injection of money needed to solve the funding crisis in British universities, which it says the public will not allow to be paid for by tax increases.

The report has already received a cool welcome from ministers and a mixture of cageyness and criticism from vice-chancellors.

The Spence case, where a Tyneside sixth former was denied a place at Oxford and took up a place at Harvard, illustrates the "stark contrast" between the US and UK systems. Harvard is an elite but also socially inclusive university, the report says. "Those whose family circumstances allow them to do so pay full fees; those from less fortunate backgrounds receive scholarships. Oxford does not have that kind of financial flexibility. No British university does."

The authors, economists David Greenaway and Michelle Haynes of Nottingham University, say that while numbers in higher education have soared, funding per pupil has declined by nearly 50% and university lecturers have had no real increase in earnings in 20 years. The US invests almost three times as much of its GDP in higher education. To increase spending per student to the OECD average would require annual spending of £3.1bn.

They argue: "Under present funding arrangements, it is simply not possible for government to deliver a sector which is both socially inclusive and internationally competitive."

Universities should be able to charge higher fees for students from richer families to help pay for scholarships for those from poorer ones, the report says. More than half of Harvard students receive some form of financial aid.

The authors reject the claim that fees would discourage poorer students. Despite the increase in British higher education numbers, the number of entrants from lower income groups has changed little and pales in comparison with other countries. "If differentiated fees damaged access, that alone would make the case against them. Higher education is already socially exclusive."

Graduates are better paid and the current system therefore "redistributes income from low income to high income taxpayers". Even modest differential fees "have the capacity to make a real difference" - up to £1.02bn for universities a year even if fees were capped at £4,000.

Baroness Blackstone, the higher education minister, last night reiterated the government's opposition to top-up fees, and government sources ruled out Labour including any top-up fees plan in its manifesto.

Number 10's education adviser, Andrew Adonis, has told vice-chancellors the government would only countenance extra fees if they could show they were improving intakes of students from poor backgrounds.

Colin Lucas, the vice-chancellor of Oxford, joined with other university heads in welcoming the report as a contribution to the debate, but like most refused to commit him self to its findings. "We believe that the only acceptable system would guarantee access to higher education for all students who could benefit from the opportunity."

Cambridge said it would not lobby for the recommendations.

Ivor Crewe, vice-chancellor of the University of Essex and convenor of the 1994 group representing 16 small research-intensive universities, adopted a wait-and-see policy.

Geoffrey Copeland, vice-chancellor of the University of Westminster, said the proposals "would probably lead to a higher education system inaccessible and at the very least daunting for the students from the lower socio-economic groups which the government is so keen to attract".

Owain James, president of the National Union of Students, said: "The hypocrisy of the Russell report is incredible, the vice-chancellors behind this report have used the case of an individual student to dress up differential fees as a solution to elitism."

webTitle: 'You see huge figures - I am going to come out of school thousands of dollars in debt'

fields.headline: 'You see huge figures - I am going to come out of school thousands of dollars in debt'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: When Alice Love chose her university she thought about the course and the college. But she also thought about the cost.
fields.body:
When Alice Love chose her university she thought about the course and the college. But she also thought about the cost.

In high school in Rochester, New York state, she took four course credits to help ensure she could complete the university part of her degree in three years rather than four.

And then she turned down places at Colombia in New York and Smith in Massachusetts and opted for the American University in Washington DC. "Both of those are slightly better schools but they were significantly more expensive. It really was a factor in choosing where I went." If the report to the Russell Group is put into practice in Britain, her experience will become typical here.

Alice was keen on going to Washington, and she liked its journalism course. And Washington also offered her a scholarship which paid around $5,000 (£3,300) for two years of her degree.

But that still left the rest of her university fees of more than $15,000, plus living costs. Her parents, an engineer and a teacher, had saved for the college fees for her and her brother and sister. "Our parents made us aware when we got into high school that we were definitely going to college; they couldn't afford all of it and we would pay some of our expenses."

Alice was entitled to join a work study scheme, where she was paid by the university for working in a student health centre and a biology laboratory. She had various summer jobs, and also two student loans. When she left college in 1991 she owed about $12,000.

Yes, it was worth it, she thinks, but it was a lot to start paying off at the out set of her working life. Now aged 30, she still owes $2,000 of her loan.

And that would be pretty much the end of the story except for Alice's decision to throw in her job at the AP news agency in Washington and train as a nurse. She has chosen a three-year course at Yale, one of the best and most expensive and designed for people like her who are changing career.

Alice is taking out new loans to fund $27,000 a year fees, plus living costs, and with no scholarships and no parental support, she expects to still be paying them off in her mid-40s.

"When you see these huge figures you think 'gee, I am going off to do something that's going to benefit society as a whole and I am going to come out of school tens or thousands of dollars in debt'. But I am so sure that this is what I want to do and it's going to make me happy."

In high school in Rochester, New York state, she took four course credits to help ensure she could complete the university part of her degree in three years rather than four. And then she turned down places at Colombia in New York and Smith in Massachusetts and opted for the American University in Washington DC. "Both of those are slightly better schools but they were significantly more expensive. It really was a factor in choosing where I went." If the report to the Russell Group is put into practice in Britain, her experience will become typical here. Alice was keen on going to Washington, and she liked its journalism course. And Washington also offered her a scholarship which paid around $5,000 (£3,300) for two years of her degree. But that still left the rest of her university fees of more than $15,000, plus living costs. Her parents, an engineer and a teacher, had saved for the college fees for her and her brother and sister. "Our parents made us aware when we got into high school that we were definitely going to college; they couldn't afford all of it and we would pay some of our expenses." Alice was entitled to join a work study scheme, where she was paid by the university for working in a student health centre and a biology laboratory. She had various summer jobs, and also two student loans. When she left college in 1991 she owed about $12,000. Yes, it was worth it, she thinks, but it was a lot to start paying off at the out set of her working life. Now aged 30, she still owes $2,000 of her loan. And that would be pretty much the end of the story except for Alice's decision to throw in her job at the AP news agency in Washington and train as a nurse. She has chosen a three-year course at Yale, one of the best and most expensive and designed for people like her who are changing career. "When you see these huge figures you think 'gee, I am going off to do something that's going to benefit society as a whole and I am going to come out of school tens or thousands of dollars in debt'. fields.headline: The high cost of learning
fields.standfirst: Economists argue that universities should be allowed to set their own tuition fees. But the arguments fail to convince, and are unlikely to solve the social access problem facing universities. Lee Elliot Major on the furore surrounding the Greenaway-Haynes report on the future of university funding.
fields.trailText: Economists argue that universities should be allowed to set their own tuition fees. But the arguments fail to convince, and are unlikely to solve the social access problem facing universities. Lee Elliot Major on the furore surrounding the Greenaway-Haynes report on the future of university funding.
fields.body:
Why should those who do not benefit from higher education pay for the degrees of those who do? This argument is at the heart of the much anticipated Greenaway-Haynes report on the future funding of universities. The current funding arrangements in the UK, according to Professor David Blanchflower, a British economist now based at Dartmouth College in the US who advised on the report, are "outrageous" - equivalent to a state subsidy paid for by the general taxpayer and allocated to the middle classes. The views of the principal authors of the report, Professor David Greenaway and Michelle Haynes from Nottingham University, may not be as forthright, but their proposals are nothing short of radical.

Commissioned by the 19 Russell group elite research universities, the report presents compelling evidence of the current problems facing UK universities. Average spending per student in the UK was 60% of the average for OECD countries in 1995, and below the average for countries in the EU. Just to bring spending on academic staff back up to the OECD average would require an extra £900m a year. And to return to the student funding levels in the UK a decade ago an extra £5.9bn in annual grants is needed - roughly an extra 3p in the pound in income tax for all taxpayers.

The academic record on social inclusion is more depressing. Despite a massive expansion in student numbers over the last 15 years, universities remain an enclave for the middle and upper classes. Four out of five 18 year olds from senior managerial and professional backgrounds go to university; barely one in ten make it from unskilled and partly unskilled backgrounds. This, argues the report, must be seen as a major failing of the UK university system. It is also means that £3bn of government funds each year is redistributed from low income taxpayers to high income taxpayers "an outcome difficult to justify in terms of social justice".

What is needed then is more money and greater access. The economists consider four possible solutions: more government grants, a graduate tax, student vouchers, and differential fees. The first of these they conclude is unrealistic; the second too long winded; the third ineffective.

They opt instead for the free market solution to a social problem: allowing universities to break away from current state controls and set their own fees, and expanding the scholarships and loans available to students.

But here the details become vague. Will fees be £50,000, £40,000 or £20,000 for a degree? In the free market world no one knows what the forces of supply and demand will conjure up. Some of the economists argue that the elite UK universities will eventually charge the rates seen in the US - often £17,000 a year. Others say that fees could follow the levels already set for overseas students, varying from to £5,000 a year to £20,000 a year. Others claim that fees would remain much smaller in most cases, perhaps £2,000 a year.

The problem with this though is that Greenaway and Haynes can give no detailed figures on what money would be made available under such a system for scholarships and loans. How would we ensure that more not less students from poorer backgrounds were not alienated from higher education? By its own criteria the report fails to convince.

This is not to say that radical solutions are not required. The report is spot on with its diagnosis. The middle classes continue to dominate the student populations of the elite universities. Head of the Sutton Trust, Peter Lampl, calls it a scandal. But it is also a scandal that it has taken a private charity and an ill-founded remark by the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, to raise the access issue higher up the universities' agenda.

Still the majority of Oxbridge educated vice-chancellors chose to remain tight-lipped over their real views concerning fees. Access is still seen as a threat to standards, rather than an opportunity to tap into currently wasted talent. It is also treated as someone else's problem - schools, or society at large. Much of the problem is cultural. And to change such attitudes, initiatives should have been in place 20 years ago - before Laura Spence was even born.

The Greenaway-Haynes report is available for download in pdf format from the School of Economics at the University of Nottingham.

fields.headline: Adoption
fields.standfirst: The government wants to take more children out of care homes and into families. Patrick Barkham explains why its plans for a national adoption register might help
fields.trailText: The government wants to take more children out of care homes and into families. We explain why its plans for a national adoption register might help.
fields.body:
What is the problem with adoption?
A government survey recently found that 2,000 children in England and Wales were waiting to be adopted and 1,200 families wanted to adopt them. Yet under the current adoption structure, a third of those children waiting for a new home languish in the care of local authorities for more than three years. It seems a wasteful human and emotional cost, as well as a monetary one. Among those to point this out recently include the Archbishop of Canterbury.

What is the government doing about it?
In February, the prime minister announced that he was taking personal charge of a review of adoption policy - a direct response to the revelations of sexual and physical abuse at children's homes in north Wales. The result is today's announcement that the government is now to set up a national adoption register, in an attempt to better match children with potential parents. The register will establish national standards, which clearly establish adoption criteria for local authorities and set deadlines for them to make assessment decisions on those who want to adopt children. An "adoption and permanency" taskforce will also be set up to try to clear the huge backlog of children waiting to be adopted and help enforce national standards across England and Wales.

What was wrong with the old system?
 Length in care: There has been considerable criticism of how children have been left in local authority care longer than necessary. On average, children adopted in 1998 were 14 months old when they went into care and two and a half years old before they were placed with their adoptive families. Although adoptions rose by 10% that year, only 4% of all those in care were adopted.

 Lack of national consistency: Government research found wide regional variations in the proportions of children passed for adoption by local authorities. In south London, while Sutton passed 20% of the children in its care for adoption, some boroughs, including Barnet in north London, Ealing in west London and Lambeth in south London had adoption rates of less than 1%.

Will the reforms work?
The government hopes its plans will increase adoptions by 1,000 a year. The response of care experts has been positive. The British agencies for adoption and fostering have been pressing for an adoption register for some years. On the issue of equalising differences in adoption criteria and aid across local authorities, Barbara Hutchinson, the agencies' northern and central director, said: "Anything that gives us some national consistency is to be welcomed."

But as with increasing the efficiency of asylum applications, it may take several years for improvements in the adoption figures to show. Care experts are suspicious of fast fixes which could undermine a proper scrutiny of the suitability of adopters. They have warned that moving children from one local authority to be adopted in another could also pose practical problems if it is not clear which local authority's social services department will pay for assisting particularly troubled children.

What controversies remain?
Even if the government erases the inefficiencies of the adoption system, some controversies surrounding it will prove more difficult to resolve.

 Race: Department of Health statistics show that nearly one in five of those waiting to be adopted are of ethnic minority or mixed-race origin - that is more than three times their percentage in the national population. To make matters worse, just 130 ethnic minority families have been approved as ready to adopt children. Local councils where the ethnic minority population is the highest are the worst at finding homes for children in their care. The percentage of children adopted in the London boroughs of Lambeth, Southwark and Newham ranges from 0.61% to 1.52%.

 Sexuality: It is legal for gay people to adopt children in Britain. But in unmarried couples only one partner can legally become the adopter, which prevents gay couples legally adopting children together. Social stigma and suspicion, over zealous checking procedures, and the differing responses of local authorities conspire to discourage gay couples from adopting children.

Barnardo's
The Local Government Association

fields.headline: Adams recovers as Turner totters
fields.trailText: GOOD FORM
fields.body:
GOOD FORM

Chris Adams Sussex

He was the experiment that went wrong on England's tour of South Africa, but after passing 50 just twice in his first 14 innings this season, Chris Adams has hit form. He notched up five half-centuries and one hundred (a 95-ball rout of Northants) in his next nine knocks, before scoring eight in the NatWest against Surrey. It was his first single-figure score since May 24.

First-class runs since May 31 212 at 70.67
One-day runs since May 31 339 at 56.50
Total runs since May 31 551 at 61.22

BAD FORM

Rob Turner Somerset

Last year, Rob Turner was being talked about as the new England wicketkeeper. He finished the season with 64 dismissals - more than anyone else in the country - and scored over 1000 Championship runs at just under 50. He was the answer to Alec Stewart's problems. But at the beginning of 2000 his batting started to fall to pieces - and it's getting worse. His 35 in the Championship against Kent was the only time he had passed 20 in his last 14 innings, which include seven single-figure scores. There's still time for Turner to turn it around, but the prospects of an England cap are fading fast.

webTitle: The BBC's white knight can't rescue the Dome in distress

fields.headline: The BBC's white knight can't rescue the Dome in distress
fields.standfirst: The BBC's plans for the Dome are attractive - but the corporation's bid comes too late, says media correspondent Matt Wells
fields.trailText: 7 July, 5pm: The BBC's plans for the Dome are attractive - but the corporation's bid comes too late, says media correspondent Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Perhaps more than anything else, the Millennium Dome has symbolised Labour's triumph of style over substance. After a year of hype and a glitzy opening ceremony, the gloss was soon tarnished by its disappointing content, poor visitor figures and disastrous financial performance. Now, it seems, a white knight has been found.

The BBC and the Tussaud's Group, both among the most successful and imaginative organisers of visitor attractions, have teamed up with an offer that, if the government has the guts to take it seriously, could turn the Dome from an electoral liability into a vote winner. Under the Tussaud's Group's proposals, 70% of the Dome would be taken up by BBC@Dome - showing life-size exhibits from popular BBC productions such as EastEnders and Walking With Dinosaurs. The rest of the site would be turned into an urban entertainment centre called DomeTown Greenwich, featuring bars, restaurants and shops. The corporation would not put any money into the Dome, but it would be offered a share in the profits in return for lending its programme ideas.

Cheekily, the consortium has asked the government to hand over the Dome (cost: £758m) for nothing, in return for up to £50m of the profits and a promise that £150m would be invested in the site.

The problem is that the formal bidding process is almost complete, with two plans on the final shortlist. Dome Europe, backed by the Japanese finance group Nomura, says it will to invest more than £100m in the site, developing the present attractions and installing new ones. It believes it can attract 15m visitors over four years. The second group, Legacy, wants to transform the Dome into a community of new businesses. It plans to invest £150m converting the Dome into a new living and working place. The Dome would become a "24-hour city" with shops, cafeterias, restaurants and bars.

But if either plan fails, there would be nothing to stop the site's new owner from bulldozing the Dome and turning the land into a giant office park. The challenge for the government is to hand the site to the project with the most chance of success.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has the power to reject the current two bidders and bring the BBC/Tussaud's plan into play. Tussaud's - which runs Madame Tussaud's and Alton Towers among other attractions - has a good track record, and the BBC Experience in London is one of Britain's fastest-growing visitor attractions. However, the word this afternoon from the Department of Culture, Media and Sport is that the project has little chance of being accepted. So the question has to be asked: why did the BBC leave it so late?

webTitle: No march, no talks, says Orangemen's leader

fields.headline: No march, no talks, says Orangemen's leader
fields.trailText:
The leader of the Portadown Orangemen today ruled out talks with nationalists unless the loyalists are allowed to
march down the Garvaghy Road.
fields.body:
The leader of the Portadown Orangemen today ruled out talks with nationalists unless the loyalists are allowed to march down the Garvaghy Road.

The Portadown district master, Harold Gracey, said there would be no future talks with local residents through the South African mediator, Brian Currin, if there was no parade on Sunday along the Garvaghy Road, a mainly nationalist enclave in loyalist Portadown.

He refused to condemn the violence that has taken place for five nights in loyalist areas across Northern Ireland in protest at the government-appointed Parades Commission's ban on the annual Orange Order march down the Garvaghy Road. "I am not going to condemn violence because [Sinn Fein leader] Gerry Adams never condemns it," he said at Drumcree.

"I am not saying I am happy with violence. I never have been and anyone who knows me knows that but this country, the Protestant people of this country and the loyalist community are sick to death what is happening to this country and have been over the past 30 years."

The RUC announced today that 37 of its officers and two soldiers had been injured in the recent violence. The injuries were sustained during 145 attacks on the security forces, including 12 gun attacks over five nights of trouble. There had been 140 petrol bomb incidents and 268 primed petrol bombs had been seized by the security forces.

Mr Gracey told BBC TV News that if Sunday's march was allowed to go down the nationalist Garvaghy Road, then "anything is possible". But he said he had warned Mr Currin, who has been attempting to establish a talks process between the rival sides, that if the loyalists were barred from marching, then he should leave.

"If they let us down [the road] on July 9, then anything is possible but if they don't, I told him he may as well pack his bags and go back to South Africa."

He denied he had incited people by calling for loyalists to come out on to the streets in support of the Portadown Orangemen and claimed the Parades Commission was responsible for the violence.

Mr Gracey was speaking as a last ditch bid was launched by the Portadown District, through its mediators, to reverse the march decision. A dossier was submitted to the commission on behalf of the district by first minister David Trimble's chief of staff, David Campbell, and solicitor, Richard Monteith.

The Parades Commission also had separate meetings with the Garvaghy Road residents and their spokesman, Breandan Mac Cionnaith, SDLP minister in the Stormont executive Brid Rodgers, and Sinn Fein.

Meanwhile Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson insisted that the loyalists must end their protests and start negotiations with nationalists it they want to regain the right to parade past nationalist neighbourhoods.

webTitle: Series five, Page three and Number one

fields.headline: Series five, Page three and Number one
fields.trailText: THE F FILES
fields.body:
THE F FILES

Allegations of bribery were levelled. Intimidation was rife. And the levels of scheming were such that even Peter Mandelson might have blushed. All in all, a typical World Cup vote - or so everybody thought. But two things weighed heavily on agent Fox Fiver's conspiracy-attuned mind last night, and it troubled him. First, there was the spooky German fax sent to Fifa delegates offering a "small gift" if they favoured Franz and co. And, equally bizarrely, there was the strange abstention of a 78-year-old New Zealand delegate named Charles Dempsey. Had he been nobbled, or was there an alien influence?

Fox Fiver wasn't the only one voicing doubts in monosyllabic tones. Fifa also had their suspicions, and early today announced an internal enquiry, revealing they were in possession of "material" believed to be the aforementioned fax. It all looked rather series five episode 18, until the German satirical magazine (and you thought it was a contradiction in terms) Titanic admitted they were behind it. Those jesters!

Satisfied with that, Fox turned to the case of old man Dempsey. Earlier today, New Zealand Sports Minister Trevor Mallard described the septuagenarian as an "international embarrassment", while Mark Burgess, New Zealand's representative on the Oceania Football Confederation, attacked him for not following instructions to vote for England and then South Africa. "I can't believe he has done this intentionally to shoot himself in the vote back here," he added.

It was a rather unfortunate comment, because Dempsey later revealed he'd faced death threats before yesterday's vote. He told BBC Radio 5 Live: "I did not do it lightly. I do not make decisions like that lightly. I was under intolerable, unbearable personal pressure." Asked if he meant death threats, he replied: "If you want to interpret it that way I would not disagree with it." There's obviously more of this sinister tale to be told, but Fox is sure the truth is out there.

THANKS TO YOU, THESE MEN CAN LEARN TO LIVE AGAIN

Yesterday, we asked you to help us cheer up the hapless Alec McGivan, Bobby Charlton and Tony Banks, who are all covered in tears and snot because England failed to land the 2006 World Cup. And, by God, did you respond. You truly are a caring lot.

"A nice way to cheer them up might be to get a large map of the world," suggests Matt Farrand. "They can colour in the favourite countries they visited and then vote for their favourite hotel." Speaking of things you do while alone in a hotel room, James Beattie suggests a quick click around page3.com: "It always brings a smile to my face - pass it on to the 2006 bid team." James is obviously not the Southampton player, by the way - the Saints man looks like a Starbirds type of guy to us.

Mick Stead from Manchester thinks McGivan should relax with "a bottle of eight-year-old Scottish malt along with a strategically-placed noose". But Mark Jay reckons keeping them busy is the answer: "Mark Lawrenson is doing a lovely job running the Hoover round my house two mornings a week, so it is with regret that I must inform you I have no vacancies for Messrs McGivan, Charlton or Banks at the present time. I will, however, keep their details on file for any future opportunities that may arise."

Tim Allen also counsels positive action. He thinks we should make good use of the hopeless trio's experience to bring other major sporting events to these shores. "Why not put them in charge of England's bid to host the 2001 Wimbledon tennis tournament?" he suggests. "It's a competition which Britain is very keen to host, and a strong presentation from Alec's lads would be sure to hold off any flanking manoeuvre from Morocco and keep the Big W in SW11 for the foreseeable future. Keep up the good work lads!"

And we're sure you'll join the Fiver in saying amen to that.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"In my eyes it is war and that is how strongly I feel" - Julian Joachim goes over the top when speaking about his relationship with John Gregory.

HAPPY VAN GAAL

Louis Van Gaal has done many things in his life of which he can be proud. He's won Big Cup for Ajax, jumping around at the side of the pitch in a manner which would put Martin O'Neill to shame. He's turned the Nou Camp into another Dutch colony. And he once shouted "It's rounder!" after parking up in a van with a load of blokes in the back. All impressive stuff.

But the one ambition he hadn't realised was becoming coach of the Netherlands. Until today, that is, when he was unveiled as the man to replace Frank Rijkaard, who resigned after Holland's farcical exit from Euro 2000. "You see before you a very happy person," Van Gaal said today, presumably with a smile on his face, although we wouldn't bet on it.

"I've always said I want to be the national coach of Holland," he continued. "At first I wanted to take a sabbatical year, but I've always thought that if the opportunity came for me to become national coach I would grab it with both hands." Having done a spot of grabbing, he then set out his hopes for his six-year reign: "My ambition is to make this team world champions." Now that's more constructive than encouraging Edgar Davids to blow up a skyscraper, isn't it?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Southampton have bid £3.7 m bid for Widzew Lodz's Polish international Marek Citko, according to Teamtalk. But Planet Football claim they will instead sign Tenerife ace Sergio Martinez Ballesteros for a fee of almost £2m.

Dutch side Groningen are interested in Liverpool's Icelandic reserve striker Haukur Gudnason.

Manchester United are set to take a £2m loss on Massimo Taibi, who will sign a three-year deal with Reggina for £2.5m

NEWS IN BRIEF

Southampton have signed French striker Patrice Tano from Monaco on a free transfer. Glenn Hoddle said: "He is only young and should improve a lot. At the moment he is one for the future but he looks a prospect."

Blackburn full-back Callum Davidson has completed a £1.75m move to Leicester.

Everton will hold talks with Don Hutchinson next week in a fresh bid to resolve the unsettled midfielder's future.

Steve Archibald has been told he must do more to convince provisional liquidators KPMG he is the man to save Airdrie from folding. A KPMG statement today read: "Some progress has been made, however there are still a number of outstanding issues that must be resolved before his bid can be tabled to creditors."

Sheffield Wednesday's young midfielder Alan Quinn has signed a one-year extension to his contract, pledging his future to the Owls until 2002.

Sunderland pair Mark Convery and Michael Proctor are to spend four months on loan at Danish side Hvidovre Fodbold, the club owned by Peter Schmeichel.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm)

That old man football, he just keep on rollin'.

webTitle: Is there a designer in the house?

fields.headline: Is there a designer in the house?
fields.standfirst: Adrian Clark  goes in search of the names behind the labels at the Milan and Paris menswear collections.
fields.trailText: Adrian Clark goes in search of the names behind the labels at the Milan and Paris menswear collections.
fields.body:
Why is it that, with the best intentions in the world, taxi drivers, while trying to show a welcoming interest, always manage to wind you up? "I've never understood why people would want to pay so much money for clothes with a designer label. Let's face it, you're only paying for the name, aren't you? Although that Hugo Boss does know how to make a decent suit." If I had a penny for every time I have kept the meter ticking over while arguing the toss on that one, during two weeks of continental city-hopping for the menswear catwalk collections in Milan and Paris, I would be a wealthy man by now. Twenty minutes into my ride home yesterday morning and we are on to the same old chestnut. The only difference being, this time I didn't have the enthusiasm, or the armoury, to disagree with my driver's questioning - in fact, I think he has a point.

Two years ago, I would have argued fervently that it isn't just the name you are paying for - it is the extension of a creative personality. In the same way you would eat at your favourite restaurant because you liked that particular chef's cooking, you would buy a designer label because you sympathise with that particular designer's aesthetic. Sadly, however, times are changing. As fashion empires grow stronger, snapping up less affluent designers in the way you and I might buy a round of drinks, the personality behind those designer names is being drained away.

Ironically (considering this is the one label every taxi driver thinks is worthy) and to illustrate my point, Hugo Boss isn't a he. Hugo Boss, the man, doesn't exist, nor has he ever. Instead Hugo Boss is a faceless fashion empire without a single front man, designed by a studio of anonymous designers who all have an input. The outcome is compromise, not conviction, and sadly this situation is becoming the norm.

Jil Sander, which has always been considered at the edge of forward-thinking fashion, is now without Jil Sander. The first collection to be shown without the label's founder at the helm, following a creative disagreement with the Prada group which purchased the company last year, had all the edge of a blunt razor. The subtle detailing that set the label apart from the competition had gone and in its place, a palatable but nondescript collection of tailoring and Ivy League basics was presented as the way forward. Patrizio Bertelli, who heads up the Prada group, commented after the show that he was not actively looking for a strong personality to guide the label into the future; instead, he thinks it can run smoothly without a "name" heading it up.

How wrong can you be. The spring 2001 collection looked as if it had been put together following a blueprint laid down by its founder. Byblos, which over the previous four seasons improved greatly under the guidance of American designer John Bartlett, presented its first collection without Bartlett as creative director, following what has been described as an "acrimonious split". The collection lacked any foresight: surely a road to nowhere.

In contrast, those labels that did cut the mustard all have a strong personality or personalities leading the way. Dolce & Gabbana, in both their mainline show and with their diffusion line D&G, gave their all, presenting sharp and sophisticated tailoring mixed with Mexican- inspired embroidery and beading, patchworked leather and suede for the more expensive line and a beer blast of Balearic-inspired customised jeans and sportswear for the funkier D&G label.

Gianni Versace (soon to be renamed simply Versace) was the best collection of the season. Big hair, Portofino dressing, Wall Street-inspired angular pinstripe tailoring and pool party knitted trunks were worn with Medusa medallions, instant tan, mirrored aviator shades and white loafers. This was a vintage collection which will inspire and radically shape things to come: it's all about metallic leather catsuits unzipped to below the navel and Florida Keys pastel baroque prints, and nobody does it better than Donatella.

Luxury goods house Fendi followed suit. Wide lapelled suits, jacquard tailoring that featured cinched waist jackets and pants that kicked out over python boots were pure gigolo dressing.

Both Jean Paul Gaultier and Milan-based design duo D-Squared opted for club class holiday dressing. Gaultier began in a nautical mood, using soft and muted layers of rayon in naval shapes, before venturing into washed-out, delicate scarf prints for kaftans, beachwear and blouson suits. D-Squared took to the isle of Mykonos, showing in a nightclub on the outskirts of Milan dripping with marble, black lacquer and intentionally tasteless gilt. The designer twins Dean and Dan Caton dipped the hems of flared white jeans into wet sand, delivered Adonis-style metallic sportswear and, to the gravelly tones of Barry White, declared that the time was again right to show out. Roberto Cavalli was also in holiday mood, with bathrobes in deckchair-striped mink, washed silk shirts, jeans that featured drizzles of sunshine-coloured paint and Capri-style accessorising to the max.

Nicole Farhi and Giorgio Armani both presented strong classic collections, Farhi mixing rose-coloured iridescent tailoring with steel grey suits, Armani using ultraviolet shades to update his covetable and wearable clothes. Romeo Gigli and Missoni introduced some of the strongest prints for the season, Gigli opting for retro jacquards, Missoni matching shorts and shirts and sleeveless safari suits, in a return to 70s styling.

Both Prada and Gucci were a little disappointing. Ford used kimono silks and karate trousers for his "Howard Jones" 80s pop star look, supposedly inspired by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, while Prada was very American bourgeois with blazer tailoring and small-scale silk prints. Louis Vuitton, like Gucci, looked to the 80s for inspiration, though Marc Jacobs' vision was far too literal, with peach sportswear, pleated trousers and fluorescent leather accessories. Comme des Garçons played with colourful blocks of print in oversized polka dots and checkerboard patterns, Paul Smith was fresh and looked stronger than ever with tutti-frutti suits, tangerine and mint gingham, and his own brand of Hawaiian shirts in oversized bi-coloured prints worn with humbug-striped casual trousers.

Hermès showed a particularly smooth collection, with wet sand shades of linen and leather for upmarket resort dressing, while Dries van Noten went sporty with old school washed-out rugby stripes, suede trainers and striped knitted ties - a masterclass in colour co-ordination. Rykiel, more in tune with what was shown in Milan than Paris, used testcard rainbows of brights splashed across knits decorated with diamanté.

The touch of edgy and directional fashion needed to drag menswear into the new century was provided by Kostas Murkudis, Warren Kade and Daniel Margolin. Murkudis mixed military tailoring with handpainted oriental silk prints, Warren Kade (showing for the first time in Paris) delved into the culture of Thailand for inspired prints and slick sportswear, while Margolin, drawing on Paganini, used sober tones of beige and black with delicate cream and lavender for some exciting and masterfully detailed tailoring.

 Adrian Clark is fashion director of Loaded

Murkudis mixed military tailoring with handpainted oriental silk prints, Warren Kade (showing for the first time in Paris) delved into the culture of Thailand for inspired prints and slick sportswear, while Margolin, drawing on Paganini, used sober tones of beige and black with delicate cream and lavender for some exciting and masterfully detailed tailoring.  Adrian Clark is fashion director of Loaded

fields.headline: Hedi Slimane
fields.trailText: Before you even begin to wag your tongue about the biggest Bright Young Thing in fashion since Tom Ford, you've got to get the guy's name right. Not easy.
fields.body:
Before you even begin to wag your tongue about the biggest Bright Young Thing in fashion since Tom Ford, you've got to get the guy's name right. Not easy. The spelling is simple, Hedi Slimane, but try saying it with anything but a guttural Gallic accent and you'll be rumbled. So it's Ee-dee Slim-arn not Heidi Slimarny. Either way, Ee-dee is a genius. The line is, Ee-dee has done to menswear what Yves Saint Laurent did to womenswear back in the 60s: androgynised it to create a new elegance. Where Yves invented the trouser suit, Slimane has softened men's silhouette to make it appear (wait for it) graceful. And timeless and classic.

Just like Mr Saint Laurent - surprise, surprise, as it was him who gave Slimane the job of menswear designer of YSL. A brave move and one that worked: the fashion world fell at the young designer's feet, claiming him the bearer of a new, luxurious slimline look; less technical than Prada, more sophisticated than Gucci, far less flashy than Versace. He may have designed gold trousers once (see above) but they appeared only in the finale of his black January 2000 collection.

The 30-year-old soon became so feted that other companies began courting and rumours of Slimane on the move were quickened by Gucci's buyout of YSL last November (they installed Tom Ford). Talks were held with Gucci about giving Slimane his own label but the smart money was on him eloping to LVMH, the Gucci group's bitter rival in the carve-up of the fashion industry. Some said Jil Sander would snap up the boy wonder, others whispered Prada. But it was those who put their money on Dior who came away chuckling. For, as of July 17, Slimane will be the LVMH-owned company's menswear and accessory designer. As, of course, you'd been saying all along. And wasn't it you who spotted his talent in college, too? Don't try it: Slimane is so good, he never even went to college.

fields.headline: Aloha, boys
fields.standfirst: It's here, it's now, it's hot.  Simon O'Connell pays homage to the Hawaiian shirt
fields.trailText: It's here, it's now, it's hot. Simon O'Connell pays homage to the Hawaiian shirt
fields.body:
Hawaiian shirts and dress down Friday seems an unlikely combination at first. After all, a canary-yellow shirt emblazoned with waves, flowers and dancing girls might raise a few eyebrows in even the most forward-thinking business. But with menswear trends suggesting the Hawaiian shirt is making a comeback, it's worth noting that Hawaii is the home of casual workwear. Offices everywhere, get ready.

Accepted wisdom dates dress down Friday to the early 90s, when open-necked button-down shirts swept the US. But its seeds can be traced to Hawaii in 1947, when the first Aloha Week took place, intended both to revive the culture of the Hawaiian people and to break away from the strict formal dress businessmen were required to wear at the time, which was unsuitable for the climate. In Aloha Week, city employees were allowed to wear to work the traditional print, short-sleeved aloha shirts.

The boost this gave to the indigenous fashion industry was doubled by the growing popularity of the Hawaiian shirt in the US in the 50s, after the two million US servicemen stationed there returned with tales of paradise and a suitcase full of shirts. The growing popularity of surfing and beach life in California added to the shirt's allure and soon Hollywood stars such as Montgomery Clift, Frank Sinatra and Elvis adopted the look.

For 20 years, however, a Hawaiian shirt has meant "wacky". (See: almost any Jim Carrey character.) But step into any menswear store this summer and you'll notice that colour and print are back in a big way. Despite the traditional British male insistence on adhering to a wardrobe of navy, black and beige, men seem eager to broaden - and brighten - their horizons. The pressure for a more casual style of business dress is building all the time and despite recent reports from America that it encourages laziness and flirting, the trend shows no sign of abating.

Nick Barnes runs Stateside Clothing in London's Camden Town and deals in vintage Hawaiian shirts, which he has collected for seven years. "The market has gone crazy," he says. "I get all sorts buying shirts now - doctors, lawyers, film stars. The most wanted are Kamehameha originals with dragon or tiger prints, or wacky stuff such as footprints. The quality from the 40s is a million miles from anything you get today - these shirts were made in tiny runs with meticulous printing processes."

Celebrity collectors of the shirts - invented by Ellery Chun, who died last month aged 91 - include Bill Cosby, Jack Nicholson, Steven Spielberg and Robin Williams, who bid against a global network of collectors prepared to pay up to $5,000 for an original. Those shirts designed between 1945 and 1956 are the most highly prized.

Lloyd Johnson, who ran Johnson's vintage clothing store on London's King's Road for three decades before closing it last month, says Hawaiian shirt aficionados are a disparate bunch. "The largest group are the Rockin' Crew, into rockabilly and hot rods. Then there are people into the 50s Hawaiian cocktail lounge thing."

Collectors need to be able to tell originals from fakes and this is an imprecise science. Although the shirts are known as "silkies", the 40s originals are mostly made from rayon. Before that cotton was dominant; after came silk and a brushed cotton "barkcloth". "Almost all the 40s originals are rayon," Johnson says. "I can recognise them by the shape of the collars, the prints and fabric, plus details such as bamboo buttons." If you can't afford the originals, labels such as Sun 'n Sand and Confused make high quality versions today.

Probably the biggest collector in the UK today is Elliot Lewis. "I'm a bit of a shirt junkie," he says. "I don't want to say what's the most I've paid but let's just say I have shirts that would sell for well over a thousand pounds. They have such a fantastic history and the more you get into it, the more you appreciate the incredible quality and design."

Real collectors care little that the shirts are back in fashion this summer. Johnson gives the purist's response. "Hawaiian shirts are stylish but they're not fashion - not just anybody can carry them off. They're sometimes in fashion but they're always in style.

 For more information, Linda Arthur's Aloha Attire has just been published by Schiffer.
Weblinks: www.cosmicoutfitters.com; www.islandhemp.com; www.rainbowhawaii.com

fields.headline: Most everywhere
fields.standfirst: Bar football
fields.trailText: Bar football
fields.body:
No, not playing football in bars, that would be silly. We're talking the table football game with players on sliding poles. Also known as "fussball" or "babyfoot", it is popping up in more cool locations than customised jeans.

Britain's premier field-based schmoozefest, Glastonbury, had bar football backstage to amuse the VIPs, PR poseurs and random liggers - and there were queues for it all weekend. There was more backstage action at this year's Brit awards, while those without VIP passes have been honing their skills on the tables in Top Shop and Nike Town, and even Auntie Beeb's got in on the act, using table football for its graphics during Euro 2000.

Not to be confused with fiddly Subbuteo, bar footie is sturdier, a lot more lairy and, played properly, leaves your arms aching worse than a pinball marathon. Despite its retro-laddish connations, it requires little soccer skill, meaning it is suitable for the sportingly challenged. And you can play singles, doubles or even triples, so it's sociable.

Bar footie is singlehandedly making pub sports acceptable again. When was the last time you saw someone in cringe-free clothes playing darts, snooker or dominoes? Like, never. So next time you see a table, put your prejudice aside and give it a go. You'll be using phrases like "reverse rollover" and "front pin dinks" in no time. Just remember: no spinning. That's the sign of a drunk or a doofus.

fields.headline: Cork, CricInfo and commentary cock-ups
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle reveals why this summer is turning into one to remember for Dominic Cork, the identity of the new director of cricket operations at CricInfo, and how TMS cocked-up at Lord's
fields.trailText: Cork to tie the knot - between Tests
fields.body:
Cork to tie the knot - between Tests

Despite his Man of the Match performance at Lord's, the biggest moment in Dominic Cork's season is yet to come. Next month Cork, 28, will marry his long-standing girlfriend, Donna Lynch, a hairdresser, who is also divorced. It was to Lynch, leaping to her feet in the crowd at Lord's last Saturday night, that Cork made that mysterious three-finger victory gesture after hitting the winning runs in the second Test against West Indies.

There won't be time for a honeymoon: the fifth Test at the Oval starts little more than 48 hours after the couple's celebrations finish. If selected, Cork will have to rush down the M1 motorway to join the England party, quite possibly 24 hours after they have started preparation for what could be the series decider.

It's unusual for a player to marry during the season, but the couple have seized on a day - Bank Holiday Monday, August 28 - when neither Derbyshire nor England are in action. A service of blessing at a church near their home will be followed by a reception for 120 or so at a secluded hotel in the Midlands. Bob Louis, Cork's agent, says it will be a "quiet affair" - though not so quiet that a team from Hello! magazine may not be there to bring the festivities to a wider audience.

The day will be another happy ending for Cork, whose troubles with England were partly caused by the break-up of his first marriage, which produced a son, Gregory, now aged five. He started seeing Donna after separating from his first wife, and in recent interviews he has been quick to pay tribute to the happiness and stability she has brought him as he spent 18 months fighting to regain his Test place - not to mention keeping Derbyshire's warring factions under control in his job as county captain.

And that gesture? "Dominic hasn't even told me why he made it," says Louis firmly.

CricInfo finally finds a captain

After a long search, CricInfo has found someone to head up its fast- expanding coverage of the game. Ralph Dellor, the BBC broadcaster, has been signed as the company's first director of cricket operations. He made his debut on the website's new ball-by-ball audio commentary service, launched yesterday at Britain's first day-night international, between West Indies and Zimbabwe.

Dellor, who was approached only a fortnight ago, arrives at a key moment in the seven-year history of cricket's oldest and most popular website (www.cricket.org). Not only was CricInfo recently valued at $US 150 million - having registered its billionth hit last December - but it has just added yet another national board to its collection of partners, signing an agreement with the ECB and MCC to manage their joint website (now renamed ecb.co.uk) for the rest of the season.

Why did Dellor, aged 52 and with 30 years' broadcasting experience, take the job? "It's a very exciting challenge," he says, "to get in at the start of something which could be very, very big. There's a big future for on-line cricket commentary, not least for fans in Australia, America and other places who can't otherwise listen to our international games." In time, he hopes to be involved in bringing video coverage of big matches to computer screens.

Once the audio side is up and running, Dellor will turn his attention to strengthening the editorial team and giving CricInfo's written output "a bit more editorial direction". But don't expect too much criticism of ICC's stance on match-fixing. In recent months Dellor has been in the thick of the action, as ICC's part-time media consultant. Although he'll be replaced by ICC in due course, he will wear both hats for the time being.

As we speak, Dellor has more pressing matters on his mind: for example, finalising his line-up for England-Zimbabwe at the Oval tomorrow, when he is likely to be joined by Jack Bannister, Tony Cozier and Jed Pitman, with summaries from Colin Croft - hitherto CricInfo's only well-known contributor - and former England seamer Neil Foster. Says Dellor: "Neil could become very good."

A cock-up at Lord's for TMS

The twists and turns of an extraordinary Test were not the only reason for taut nerves in the BBC's Test Match Special commentary box at Lord's. Several commentators felt they were not getting a fair crack of the whip: run-of-play duties were divided between an unprecedented five broadcasters - the three regulars, Jonathan Agnew, Henry Blofeld and Christopher Martin-Jenkins, plus Tony Cozier and Donna Symmonds from the Caribbean.

Whereas a five-day Test is often carved up between three commentators, this time a three-day game was split five ways. "Commentators are like bowlers," says a TMS source. "If they only do 20 minutes a session, as most of our people were doing at Lord's, they can lose their rhythm. The ideal line-up has three people sharing run-of-play." Agnew was particularly irritated, though he did have the consolation of describing the winning runs; and Blofeld and CM-J, who are each missing two Tests in order to accommodate both West Indians, weren't best pleased either.

So what happened? A four-strong roster was drawn up long ago by Peter Baxter, the producer, on the basis that Symmonds would be taking a Test off, to cover Wimbledon for the BBC (she started her broadcasting career in tennis); however Symmonds eventually had to be given the game because, unknown to TMS, she had been promised all five Windies Tests by someone higher up the BBC hierarchy.

"It was a cock-up, " says our source. "There was no rancour, but we never want to field five commentators again."

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). E-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

For the mid-week Grapevine, featuring stories on Garry Sobers going missing at the 100th Lord's Test, how the England side had a Caribbean Ball both on and off the field, and Paul Franks passing 50 before getting on the field, click here

webTitle: How Euan fell foul of the law

fields.headline: How Euan fell foul of the law
fields.standfirst:
Downing Street plea for understanding over escapade
Blair shows strain after son's arrest
Audio: Blair's emotional reaction
Comment by Michael White
Downing Street's full statement
Policing 'yob culture'
fields.trailText: As heaving bars prepared to turf out groups of tipsy teens and twentysomethings, the police officer patrolling Leicester Square came across a familiar scene.
fields.body:
As heaving bars prepared to turf out groups of tipsy teens and twentysomethings, the police officer patrolling Leicester Square came across a familiar scene.

A teenage boy lay sprawled on paving stones near a plaque honouring the actor Richard E Grant. He had been vomiting, was barely conscious, and was apparently alone. The concerned officer radioed for an ambulance, which arrived within minutes, around 11pm. When paramedics asked him what he had been doing, the boy mumbled that he had been out drinking with friends, who had apparently left him to take the tube home. The teenagers, it later emerged, had been out on a post-GCSE bender.

Eyewitness Ritchie Parrott, 31, said: "There wasn't anybody with him. I saw a group of about seven or eight boys standing nearby all huddled together.

"I couldn't work out whether they were his friends or not, but they looked quite anxious and kept looking towards him.

"He was just still. Being Leicester Square you see that all the time. There's always somebody being sick."

Another witness, Julie MacDonald, 23, saw him lying prone near the railings, on the east side of the square, which fence off the grassy central enclosure.

"He was just lying there, totally motionless. He was stretched out on his front with his head turned to one side. There was no one else with him."

The paramedics checked his breathing and asked him to repeat a sentence, a standard test of drunkenness. It was clear from this that he was completely inebriated. Still unaware they were dealing with the prime minister's eldest son, police officers who had gathered at the scene advised him that he was being arrested.

The teenager was taken to Charing Cross police station, where after waiting in line with petty criminals and other drunks he saw the custody sergeant, who asked him for his age, name and address and warned him again that he was being formally arrested.

Euan gave his first names - Euan John - and an old address. Officers then searched his pockets and found some ID - thought to be a cashpoint card - which was initialled E Blair. The custody sergeant asked him if his name was Euan Blair, and then it clicked: "Hold on a minute. Aren't you Tony Blair's son?"

The custody sergeant rang special branch while Euan sat waiting in a cell near the custody suite. Scotland Yard notified Downing Street, and a special branch car took him back to the Blairs' No 11 flat at around 1am, where the prime minister was waiting alone for him.

Cherie Blair was in Portugal with baby Leo and her mother, and Mr Blair had been working late on his speech for yesterday's Faith in the Future conference. He had been beginning to worry about his son's whereabouts when police called.

Meanwhile, news of the arrest had already leaked to the Sun newspaper. Following a tip from a police officer a Sun reporter rang Scotland Yard at 1.15am asking for confirmation of the arrest.

Within a quarter of an hour, the head of corporate affairs at the Yard, Dick Fedorcio, was briefing the commissioner, Sir John Stevens. Scotland Yard officials then liaised with Downing Street to "sort out a few well chosen words".

At 2am Scotland Yard confirmed that a 16-year-old had been arrested in Leicester Square, but the story did not appear in the late editions of the Sun, or the Times, which had also been tipped off.

Video footage from local businesses' security cameras around Leicester Square was seized yesterday by plain clothes police officers from Scotland Yard. A waiter at Haagen Daz said: "They just came in and took the film. There was no explanation but everybody guessed why they wanted it - to stop embarrassing pictures of the prime minister's son getting into the papers."

Bars, pubs and nightclubs line the square and, as expected, every venue that serves alcohol yesterday denied knowledge of having served 16-year-old Euan.

Flouted

As every establishment denied it served under-18s, or in some cases anyone under 21, regular visitors to the square spoke of how the law was regularly flouted.

Busker Tom Cogswell, 20, said: "Sometimes the bouncers ask for ID, but some people who get in are obviously under age. If it's a group of young girls who look hot, they'll get in."

Downing Street's press strategy yesterday was to issue an apology and a plea for understanding on Euan's behalf, while shoring up the Blairs' concern to shield their children from intrusive publicity.

While it was made clear that his parents viewed the matter seriously, the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, also noted: "Euan will not be the only teenager out last night celebrating his exams, he won't be the only one who got worse for wear but he will be the only one splashed all over the papers and the television."

The Blairs have gone to great lengths to protect their children from the media spotlight, knowing that at least the two older boys would go through the difficult adolescent years in Downing Street.

Last December Tony Blair took the Daily Sport to the Press Complaints Commission after it published a picture of Euan, then 15, kissing a girl at the Ministry of Sound nightclub.

The Blairs believed it was a breach of the Press Complaints Commission's code that says journalists must not interview or photograph children under the age of 16 "in the absence or without the consent of a parent" and papers should not use material about a child simply because his or her parents are famous.

Privacy

The complaint was upheld. But yesterday the PCC's chairman, Lord Wakeham, drew a distinction with the latest episode, saying that as Euan was over 16 and was not at school at the time there was no restriction on reporting. However, he urged journalists to bear in mind the Blairs' commitment to their family's privacy.

Commentators yesterday viewed Euan's adolescent escapade as just that. The psychologist and writer Dorothy Rowe said: "It is very normal. If he has just sat his GCSEs there is an enormous release of pressure, and the pressure is doubled because his parents expect so much of him. This is what kids do."

Despite concern about under-age drinking, particularly since the advent of sweet-tasting but intoxicating "alcopops", government figures show a slight decrease.

In 1998 21% of children aged 11-15 said they had drunk alcohol in the past seven days - compared with 27% in 1996.

Euan attends the London Oratory school in Fulham, where school rules exhort pupils to "behave in an orderly, civilised and well-mannered way at all times, both in and out of school". But the headmaster, John McIntosh, said yesterday the boy would not face the music on his return in September.

Euan will, however, have to return to Charing Cross police station, to deal with having given police a false name and address. He will be accompanied by his parents, and can expect to undergo this trip in the glare of the nation's media.

Problems with the younger generation

David Lloyd George's children dissented from both the family and the prime minister's Liberal party line. Son Gwilym sat in a Conservative cabinet, and daughter Megan won a seat as a Liberal only to switch to Labour.

Stanley Baldwin's son, Oliver, disowned his family and converted to socialism in 1923. He became a Labour MP in 1929 and relished attacking his father, three times Conservative prime minister, across the house.

Sir Winston Churchill had five children, two of them notorious drunks. Randolph, who became an MP in 1940, was described by his assistant, Sir John Colville, as "one of the most objectionable people I had ever met".

Jim Callaghan's daughter, Margaret, was married to Britain's ambassador in Washington, Peter Jay, at the time he was Labour prime minister. In 1978 she had an affair with the Watergate journalist Carl Bernstein.

Margaret Thatcher tolerated son Mark's antics, though they were a constant embarrassment to the Conservative party. "Mum's a bit worried about me," he once said. In 1982 he got lost for six days in the Sahara. He also shamelessly exploited his mother's contacts in his business ventures.

John Major's son, James, was named in the divorce of a woman 10 years his senior in 1995. He went on to marry a former gameshow assistant, Emma Noble.

Sir David Steel's son, Graeme, was jailed in 1995 for growing £30,000 of cannabis. The former Lib Dem leader confessed: "I was the classic absentee father."

Jack Straw's son, William, then 17, in 1998 caused the tough-on-crime home secretary, embarrassment after he agreed to supply a tabloid reporter with cannabis. He was given a police caution.
Simon Bowers

The concerned officer radioed for an ambulance, which arrived within minutes, around 11pm. When paramedics asked him what he had been doing, the boy mumbled that he had been out drinking with friends, who had apparently left him to take the tube home. fields.headline: A Shayler timeline
fields.trailText: October 1991: David Shayler joins MI5. Quits six tears later.
fields.body:
October 1991: David Shayler joins MI5. Quits six tears later.

August 1997: Shayler's first tranche of allegations published in the Mail on Sunday. Claims MI5 had spied on current Cabinet members including Peter Mandelson.

September 1997: Girlfriend Annie Machon arrested on arrival at Gatwick airport. She is released after six hours of questioning by Special Branch.

November 1997: Shayler alleges MI5 had forewarning of the 1994 bomb blast at the Israeli embassy in London and failed to act.

August 1998: Alleges security service plot to assassinate Libyan dictator Colonel Muammar Gadafy. Makes the claim from jail in Paris where he is held for four months without charge. Government rubbishes his claims.

November 1998: British government's pursuit of Shayler is dealt a blow when French court rejects extradition request.

January 1999: Shayler lives with girlfriend Annie Machon in a French farmhouse.

February 2000: Government sues Shayler for breach of confidence, contract and copyright.

March 2000: Dossier detailing alleged Gadafy plot delivered to Special Branch headquarters. Court order granted against the Guardian and Observer newspapers requiring the handing over of documents, notes and e-mails relating to Shayler following articles in both papers.

May 2000: Guardian and Observer appeal hearing against court order starts.

21 July 2000:The high court rules that the Guardian and Observer are not legally obliged to hand over their Shayler documents and emails.

fields.headline: Morals and molluscs
fields.standfirst: Teetotal traps, pigeon-fanciers on parade, a principled player and a hostile hotel
fields.trailText: Teetotal traps, pigeon-fanciers on parade, a principled player and a hostile hotel.
fields.body:
Inebriated invertibrates
Saudi Arabia's strict licensing laws are proving the last barrier to riches for a Midlands gardening firm which has won a trial order to sell slug and snail traps to Riyadh.

While beer has long been the gardener's secret weapon against roving molluscs, the Saudi sultan's garden centre will not be able to accept the alcoholic traps that the Kidderminster-based firm supplies.

The company is exploring the possibility of using an alcohol-free beer such as Kaliber. The managing director, Inge Beaumont, said: "Normally we put the cheapest and strongest type of beer we can find in the traps. Slugs like the smell and come to the trap, fall in and drown in the beer, or wait around and dehydrate."

Mrs Beaumont insisted that, booze or no booze, the Saudis should snap up their traps. "It is quite a pleasant way to die," she mused. "And it is environmentally friendly. No chemicals are used and the dead slugs can be thrown out on to the garden for the birds to eat. "The slugs love it," she added.
This is Staffordshire

Pants off for pigeons
Crewe council's plans for a cull of the town's pigeons has triggered a furious nude protest from bird-lovers.

In an act reminiscent of Naomi Campbell and other supermodels' naked protest against the fur trade, three members of the bird welfare group Save Our Pigeons disrobed outside Crewe municipal buildings as a council committee voted for a scheme to reduce pigeon numbers - by shooting them.

But Crewe and Nantwich borough council's environmental services committee was undaunted by the townsfolk's stark opposition and decided to go ahead with the scheme.

In a further blow against pigeondom, the council plans to put up signs around the town asking people not to feed the pigeons. A damning council report left the pigeons virtually friendless, saying numbers had increased "dramatically". "Their droppings pose a threat to public health," it added, darkly.

When Saturday comes
First, it was Chariots of Fire. Now, a career in ashes, as Symon Burgher, a Seventh Day Adventist, has been axed by Bilston Town Football Club because playing matches on a Saturday clashes with his religion.

Bilston's player-manager, Joe Jackson, said: "I am just trying to get a group of lads together who are all going to be available on a regular basis."

Symon joined the sect around five years ago while playing for the Southern League side Bromsgrove Rovers. But the playmaker was so highly-rated that Bilston signed him anyway to play in occasional midweek games.

Jackson added: "Although he didn't play very often for us, I think we only lost one game when he did play and that record speaks for itself. "

The club secretary, Jeff Calloway, said of Burgher: "He would break his back for a game of football. He always turned up for training, and would play wherever the manager wanted him - except on Saturdays, obviously.

"If he had not got his beliefs he could have gone all the way. But he has never been asked to compromise his beliefs by anybody at Bilston."

Unwelcome guests
A Berkshire hotel has dug a moat around its gardens to keep out unwanted visitors.

The move came after scores of travellers invaded the open grounds of the £155-a-night hotel - called the Moat House - in Sindlesham.

Ramshackle caravans, vans and lorries were driven onto the hotel's carefully landscaped gardens, blotting the scenic view for paying guests.

Furious senior hotel staff called in contractors to dig a 3ft by 2ft trench to stop the squatters getting back onto the lawns after they were evicted.

A spokesman for the Moat House said: "This hotel is the first we've added a moat to since King Arthur's time."

But he added: "We don't have any plans to fill it with water or build a drawbridge at this stage."
M and Y news agency, Portsmouth

Letter of the week
The report on the elaborate (and no doubt costly) efforts being made not to disturb great-crested newts in the brooks south of Lewes suggests to me we are being had.

Whenever any work is done to ponds these days, whether near a river, on a farm, or even on the dewponds of the Downs, precautions have to be taken not to discommode these newts because they are said to be rare.

Rare? The wretched things seem to be everywhere! What is more, East Sussex county council has appointed a newt licensing officer.

A newt licensing officer - I ask you! Did they make the appointment with a straight face, or did the good councillors have a very good lunch and come back as inebriated as newts?
John O'Rilley
Downs View Road, Hassocks

webTitle: Win tickets to the NFT crime festival screenings

fields.headline: Win tickets to the NFT crime festival screenings
fields.trailText: We have five pairs of tickets to give away to the Guardian interview with Morgan Freeman and a preview screening of his latest film, Under Suspicion, five more for crime spoof Do Not Disturb, and five pairs for the Director's Cut of Blood Simple
fields.body:
On 14-16 July, London's National Film Theatre plays host to a major new festival of crime films and literature. There will be three days of film previews, retrospectives and special TV events as well as a unique convention featuring some of the greatest crime writers from around the world.

International guests include Morgan Freeman, star of the Opening Night Gala Under Suspicion, as well as Robert Crais (former Hill Street Blues screenwriter), and Inspector Morse creator Colin Dexter.

Among the films on offer are Morgan Freeman and Gene Hackman's Under Suspicion (which will be followed by a Guardian interview with Morgan Freeman), Do Not Disturb, and the director's cut of Blood Simple.

We have five pairs of tickets to give away to Film Unlimited readers for each of the above three films.

 Under Suspicion (Friday 14 July, 6.30pm), set on a small Caribbean island, tells the story of a middle-aged lawyer (Hackman) who is accused by the local police detective (Freeman) of the murder of a teenage girl. The two stars, making the most of the meaty roles, are terrific opponents, engaging in verbal fisticuffs and psychological warfare. Directed by Stephen Hopkins with style and verve, Under Suspicion also makes the most of its beautiful exotic locations. Following the screening, Morgan Freeman will be on stage to take part in the Guardian Interview, talking about the film and his distinguished career, from Driving Miss Daisy to Shawshank Redemption, and more recently as Brad Pitt's mentor in Se7en. Enter the competition to win tickets to the screening and interview.

 Do Not Disturb (Saturday 15 July, 8.50pm) is a deliciously enjoyable comedy spoof thriller that wonderfully satirises a whole host of crime and thriller movies and pokes fun at some of the worst cliches of the genre. Its storyline - about a mute rich kid being pursued by criminals because she has witnessed a murder - is simply a launch pad for a hysterical series of chases. Fabulous tongue-in-cheek performances from the starry cast and amazing stunts and action sequences, on and around the canals of Amersterdam. William Hurt and Jennifer Tilly star. Enter the competition to win tickets to this event.

 The director's cut of Blood Simple (Sunday 16 July, 8.50pm) - the Coen Brother's contemporary classic noir movie - will be closing the festival. With its byzantine plotting, outrageous black comedy and OTT violence, Blood Simple reinvented the crime movie and paved the way for directors like Quentin Tarantino. This 'new' version is not exactly a major reworking of the Coen's startling deubt, more a clean and polished version, with digital soundtrack. The screening will be introduced by George P Pelecanos, crime writer and producer of Blood Simple. Enter the competition to win tickets to this event.

All entries must be received by midday, Thursday 13 July, and winners will be notified by 5pm, Thursday 13 July. The winners will be able to pick their tickets up from the NFT box office.

You can also enter the competition on Books Unlimited to win a pass (worth £50) to the entire weekend.

 Find out more about the festival on the BFI's official site.

fields.headline: FBI halts $5.5bn takeover
fields.standfirst:
Japanese bidder becomes target for cyber security concerns
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: National security concerns have prompted a US government investigation into the proposed takeover of an internet infrastructure company by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan.
fields.body:
National security concerns have prompted a US government investigation into the proposed takeover of an internet infrastructure company by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan.

The investigation, which has forced the telecoms group to delay completion of its $5.5bn takeover of Verio, a US hosting company, underlines the efforts being made by the American authorities to maintain control over law enforcement in the internet age.

Takeovers in the communications industry by non-US companies have always been sensitive for authorities such as the FBI. Such concerns are expected to mount as the in ternet makes surveillance more arduous and the number of corporate transactions increases.

The FBI is understood to have called for the inquiry into the Verio acquisition, concerned that it would not be able to carry out adequate surveillance at a company owned by a group operating outside its jurisdiction.

Law enforcement agencies can access any telecoms network to tap wires or garner information for criminal proceedings. The FBI, which has neither commented on nor confirmed any investigation, is understood to be concerned about its ability to carry out such undercover inquiries.

Its fears have been taken on board by the little-known com mittee on foreign investment in the US, a multi-agency group headed by the treasury department. The committee has up to 45 days to clear the deal under a special amendment of the Defense Production Act of 1950 which allows the president to ban any foreign takeover "that is determined to threaten the national security of the United States".

NTT confirmed the US concerns over law enforcement but added that it "believes the proposed transaction does not raise national security concerns". It has delayed its tender offer for Verio until the middle of July.

A spokesman for NTT said: "The FBI and the department of justice asked us to make a commitment to cooperate in securing public safety and law enforcement. We naturally agreed to observe US laws and to follow industry practices in the US, but simultaneously we stated that we do not believe that we should be subject to any more stringent requirements than those imposed on any other telecommunications company."

The investigation, which has forced the telecoms group to delay completion of its $5.5bn takeover of Verio, a US hosting company, underlines the efforts being made by the American authorities to maintain control over law enforcement in the internet age. Takeovers in the communications industry by non-US companies have always been sensitive for authorities such as the FBI. Such concerns are expected to mount as the in ternet makes surveillance more arduous and the number of corporate transactions increases. The FBI is understood to have called for the inquiry into the Verio acquisition, concerned that it would not be able to carry out adequate surveillance at a company owned by a group operating outside its jurisdiction. Law enforcement agencies can access any telecoms network to tap wires or garner information for criminal proceedings.
