fields.headline: Harry Potter
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the boy wonder of literature on the net
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the boy wonder of literature on the net.
fields.body:
1. If this weekend you encounter hordes of crazed kids escorted by hysterical parents battling it out at bookshops all over town, you will have found the latest manifestation of Pottermania.

2. Unless you've been keeping company with evil master Lord Voldemort for the last six months, you'll know that the mayhem has been caused by the publication on Saturday of author JK Rowling's latest instalment of Harry Potter's adventures, entitled Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.

3. The contents of the new book are a closely guarded secret. What we do know is that puberty kicks in as Harry finds a girlfriend at the Hogwarts school of wizardry; a central character meets an untimely death; and Harry goes to the Quidditch World Cup.

4. For the release of the fourth book in the Harry Potter series, publisher Bloomsbury plans to recreate the Hogwarts Express - the magical train which whizzes wannabe wizards and witches away to wizardry school.

5. Britain's brightest brains have declared the success of Harry Potter to be based on Rowling's many references to magical myths past and present.

6. The novels, which many parents claim have helped their children to learn to read, have enabled Bloomsbury to pull off the biggest marketing coup this year.

7. But a Muggle backlash against Harry has been brewing for some time. The books have been accused of contributing to the "dumbing down" of society through their unchallenging prose and conventional narrative. There has also been a copyright dispute and objections from religious groups that Harry Potter's adventures glorify the occult.

8. But what are a few slights to Rowling, who was transformed from struggling single mother in Edinburgh to multi-millionaire in the space of a few months? She is rumoured to have another three episodes of the Potter saga mapped out, but after that she's expected to move on to writing pastures new.

9. Even Steven Spielberg wants a piece of the action and is planning to shoot the first instalment of the series under its US title, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. With Chris Colombus in the director's chair, casting is now under way for would-be Potters.

10. To find out how much you really know about the celebrity sorcerer, try the wizard trivia quiz.

fields.headline: Fifa delegate 'received death threats'
fields.standfirst:
Video from Channel 4 news
Special report from Channel 4 news
fields.trailText: A Fifa delegate received a death threat before the vote which handed the 2006 World Cup tournament to Germany, it was claimed today.
fields.body:
A Fifa delegate received a death threat before the vote which handed the 2006 World Cup tournament to Germany, it was claimed today.

The claim was made by New Zealander Charles Dempsey, at the centre of an internal Fifa inquiry launched today into sleaze allegations surrounding the decision to accept Germany's bid.

Mr Dempsey told the Fifa president, Sepp Blatter, and other delegates at yesterday's executive committee meeting in Zurich that he and his family had been threatened.

Keith Cooper, a spokesman for world football's governing body, told BBC Radio 5 Live that Mr Dempsey had faced "intolerable, unbearable personal pressure". Asked if he meant death threats, he replied: "If you want to interpret it that way I would not disagree with it."

Glasgow-born Mr Dempsey has refused to explain his decision to abstain in yesterday's third and final vote, so ending favourite South Africa's dream of hosting the tournament. He said: "I have very strong reasons for making the decision, but I'm not going into them. I didn't do it lightly. I don't make decisions lightly."

His decision led to Germany winning the ballot 12-11 and meant there was no need for Fifa president Sepp Blatter to cast the deciding vote - one that was widely expected to go South Africa's way.

A Fifa spokesman claimed that the German Football Federation (DFB) and the organising committee will assist the inquiry into bribery allegations. Fifa said it was in possession of "material" - believed to be the photocopy of a fax - received by voting members of the executive committee, the spokesman said.

The New Zealand prime minister, Helen Clark, said she was upset by Mr Dempsey's action, as she had promised her country's support for the South African bid. Mr Dempsey's actions put his position at the head of the Oceanic federation into question after 34 years at the confederation.

The South African bid chairman, Irvin Khoza, said Dempsey had "betrayed the South African people". "I do not see how a man can vote in the first two rounds and then not vote in the third and final round," he said.

Channel 4 News reported that Mr Dempsey said he had received a letter from the secretary of the German bid team, offering a gift in return for the guarantee of his vote. A source also said between five and 10 other delegates had said they too had received such letters, also pushed under their doors.

The source told Channel 4 that Trinidad's representative Jack Warner and Scottish Fifa member David Will urged Fifa president Sepp Blatter to inform the police, but Mr Blatter said he would not.

The England bid chief, Alec McGivan, said the letters did not look authentic, and Germany's football federation dismissed them as a hoax.

fields.headline: Blair announces national adoption register
fields.trailText:
A national adoption register is to be set up, matching children with potential parents in a bid to speed up the adoption process,
prime minister Tony Blair announced today.
fields.body:
A national adoption register is to be set up, matching children with potential parents in a bid to speed up the adoption process, prime minister Tony Blair announced today.

The register, covering England and Wales, will coordinate current systems, which critics say have left too many children languishing in care rather than being placed with adoptive parents.

New national standards will also be laid down, setting deadlines for making decisions about children and criteria for assessing potential adopters.

Mr Blair announced the plans after a report into adoption, published by the government's performance and innovation unit, called on the government to do more to increase the numbers of children adopted from local authority care and to ensure some of the country's most vulnerable youngsters are protected. There has been criticism of the way different local authorities assess potential adoptive parents and of the time it takes for children to leave care homes.

Mr Blair said: "For some of the most vulnerable children, who, for whatever reason, cannot live with their birth parents, adoption provides the chance for a fresh start and the opportunity to enjoy the kind of loving family life that most of us take for granted.

"The PIU report presents a range of options for promoting greater use of adoption and for speeding up the whole process.

"We will be consulting widely on these options before publishing a white paper before the end of the year outlining our new approach, including proposals for new legislation to be introduced next year."

But "forward action" would be taken to introduce the national register and standards for adoption, he added.

An adoption and permanency taskforce will be set up to try to clear the huge backlog of children waiting to be adopted. The taskforce will conduct a "rapid scrutiny" of cases in a bid to match youngsters with adoptive parents. It will also try to spread "best practice" among local authorities.

Health minister John Hutton said: "The government is committed to modernising adoption.

"We need to ensure that children's needs come first. And we need to better meet the aspirations of the many prospective parents who want to adopt.

"This report represents the first step in a long-overdue task of reform."

The issue has been given a high profile by the government after Mr Blair announced in February that he would take personal charge of a review of adoption policy.

At present, it can take nearly three years for a child to be adopted because of long assessment and processing procedures.

A survey by the Cabinet Office found that more than 2,000 youngsters were waiting to be adopted and 1,200 families were waiting to adopt.

Campaigns are to be launched to recruit more potential adoptive families and to speed up the whole process. Around two-thirds of children who were eventually adopted had to wait more than a year between going into care and being placed with their adoptive family.

And a third of adopted children stay in care for more than three years before they are given a permanent home. On average, children adopted in 1998 were 14 months old when they went into care and two-and-half years old before they were placed with their adoptive families.

More than 55,000 children were in the care of local authorities, mostly with foster parents, with around 2,200 adopted each year.

webTitle: Mike Myers faces breach of contract lawsuit

fields.headline: Mike Myers faces breach of contract lawsuit
fields.trailText: Producers Imagine Entertainment are suing Mike Myers, alleging that the comedian breached a separate deal with the company when he pulled out of the Universal Pictures comedy last month
fields.body:
The fallout over Mike Myer's aborted Dieter project continues (see our earlier reports). Producers Imagine Entertainment are suing Myers, alleging that the comedian breached a separate deal with the company when he pulled out of the Universal Pictures comedy last month. Imagine are seeking damages of $30m (based on estimated gross profit participation) for Myers' alleged breach of contract.

The company mocked Myers' statements that he didn't approve the script for Dieter because of his artistic integrity. "He claimed he had not approved the screenplay. Who wrote the screenplay? Myers."

Imagine goes on to declare that Myers "has followed a pattern and practice of breaking his promises, betraying the trust of others and causing serious damages to those with whom he deals through selfish, egomaniacal and irresponsible conduct."

Attorney Bert Fields, who represents Imagine, said, "It's about time somebody stood up to this guy. I think the jury and the public will be stunned when they hear the things he said and did."

Martin Singer, representing the Canadian-born Myers, commented: "The claims made by Imagine are fictional and without merit. Ironically, Mike Myers has substantial claims against Universal, Imagine and Brian Grazer, but he has refrained from filing those claims for several weeks because of discussions that have been taking place between Universal and Mike Myers' representatives. Mike Myers has lost the most by not making this movie, which he has worked on for approximately 20 months without receiving one penny from Universal."

Universal declined to comment on the Imagine litigation.

fields.standfirst: All today's rumours, taken on a six hour bender and left drunk and incapable in Leicester Square
fields.trailText: All today's rumours, taken on a six hour bender and left drunk and incapable in Leicester Square
fields.body:
Antonio Conte could sign for Chelsea or Aston Villa. Yesterday the Juventus midfielder seemed happy to stay in Serie A, but after a row with coach Carlo Ancelotti he admitted: "I have received a couple of definite offers from England. They are extremely interesting, both in football terms and contractually."

Belgian international Joos Valgaeren will seal his proposed £4.5m move to Celtic this weekend according to the president of Roda JC, his current club. Everton have launched a bid £3m for Barnsley's Craig Hignett, who they see as a perfect replacement for Nick Barmby.

Tottenham expect to clinch the £5m signing of 24-year-old Ben Thatcher later today. Spurs' director of football, David Pleat said: "We were determined to get an orthodox left back. We have agreed a figure and hope that he will be wearing a Spurs training top on Monday."

Middlesbrough are on the verge of cutting their losses on Paul Gascoigne. They want to buy out the last year of his £1.5m contract and sell him on a free transfer. So far they've had no takers.

Lens striker Joeph-Desire Job could move to Middlesborough in a £3m deal. The Cameroon international will arrive on Teesside for a trial next week.

Meanwhile his Lens team-mate Alex Nyarko could also be heading to England. Middlesbrough, Aston Villa, Manchester City and Fulham are all reportedly interested in the Ghanaian international midfielder, who will cost £4.3m.

Charlton are interested in Belgium striker Toni Brogno, who scored 30 goals for lowly Westerlo last season - however they face competition from French side Metz.

Glenn Hoddle is poised to sign French teenage striker Patrice Tano from Monaco on a free transfer. Southampton assistant manager John Gorman said: "He has great control and technique and an excellent first touch."

fields.headline: Peugeot 'shocked' by strike threat
fields.standfirst:
Peugeot UK
Transport & General Workers Union
fields.trailText: Peugeot has said it is "shocked" at the threat of a strike by thousands of workers in a row over hours, and is urging unions to reconsider the action.
fields.body:
Peugeot has said it is "shocked" at the threat of a strike by thousands of workers in a row over hours, and is urging unions to reconsider the action.

Up to 3,000 workers at the company's Coventry factory are set to launch a 24-hour stoppage on 27 July, followed by an all-out strike from 21 August if the dispute is not resolved.

The action follows rejection in a ballot of proposed changes to working hours which would have seen a reduction from the present 39 a week to 36 and three-quarters.

Union leaders had recommended the deal to their members but it was turned down because of concerns over compulsory Friday night shifts.

A spokesman for the company said: "We are shocked, surprised, and disappointed that action has been called after such long and thorough negotiations which went on for months and ended in acceptance by union officials."

The spokesman said the decision was a "setback" and he urged union leaders to reconsider the strikes. "We are slightly bemused. To be in this position now is bizarre, particularly when the offer was so positive for us and for the workers."

Peugeot said the proposal would have given its workers the shortest working week in British car manufacturing.

Some employees who work over the weekend would have seen their hours increase under the deal but they had been offered a pay rise of 17% to compensate, said the company.

Tony Woodley, chief negotiator for the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "Obviously I am disappointed but there were elements of the deal that were unacceptable and we cannot ignore our members' views. They voted in great measure to say no and we have now given the company some time to review its position."

The last strike at Peugeot was 22 years ago and unions had described industrial relations at the factory as a "model" for the industry.

webTitle: Drug rape nurse gets seven life sentences

fields.headline: Drug rape nurse gets seven life sentences
fields.trailText: A male nurse showed no emotion as he was given seven life sentences for rape, drugging women patients and the manslaughter of nursing sister Susan Annis.
fields.body:
A male nurse showed no emotion as he was given seven life sentences for rape, drugging women patients and the manslaughter of nursing sister Susan Annis.

Kevin Cobb, 38, from Yateley, Hanpshire, abused his position to trust to prey on vulnerable women who went to the casualty department of St Peter's Hospital, Chertsey, Surrey, for help.

Cobb was convicted on May 17 of seven offences following a four-week trial. He was remanded for reports after the jury found him guilty of the manslaughter of 31-year-old Miss Annis; guilty of four charges of drugging women with intent to rape; and guilty of two offences of rape at the hospital's casualty department.

Judge Martin Stephens at the Old Bailey said Cobb drugged his victims with a anaesthetic and assaulted them in the knowledge that they would not remember what had happened to them.

"It would be difficult to envisage a greater breach of trust," said the judge.

He told Cobb that the attacks on women took place after he had inadvertently killed Susan Annis who was drugged so the male nurse could rape her.

The judge said this showed he was a danger to women as well as someone who had brought the much-loved nursing profession into disrepute.

The prosecution told the court that Miss Annis, from Crawley Hospital, West Sussex, died at a nurses' home at the Royal Brompton Hospital, west London, in November, 1996, when her drink was spiked by Cobb.

Cobb was arrested in January 1999 after patient Miss Janine Cuddington complained she blacked out on a hospital trolley and came round to find herself being raped by a smirking nurse. Miss Cuddington has waived her right to anonymity

During his trial, Cobb denied using a fast-acting "date-rape" style drug - available for use in minor surgery in casualty departments - to stupefy his victims and create memory loss.

The prosecution told the court that Miss Annis, from Crawley Hospital, West Sussex, died at a nurses' home at the Royal Brompton Hospital, west London, in November, 1996, when her drink was spiked by Cobb. Cobb was arrested in January 1999 after patient Miss Janine Cuddington complained she blacked out on a hospital trolley and came round to find herself being raped by a smirking nurse. Miss Cuddington has waived her right to anonymity During his trial, Cobb denied using a fast-acting "date-rape" style drug - available for use in minor surgery in casualty departments - to stupefy his victims and create memory loss.

fields.headline: Most wanted
fields.standfirst: Manolos for men
fields.trailText: Manolos for men
fields.body:
Manolo Blahnik's arch-snapping stilettos are beloved by the likes of Kate Moss, Bianca Jagger and the Sex and the City girls. Madonna claims they are better than sex. But did you know he makes shoes for men, too?

After discontinuing his men's range in the 70s, Blahnik then re-introduced it to his small but grateful male following. As with his shoes for women, they combine handcrafted quality with a lightweight feel and are just as hedonistically expensive (£250-£450). But now that men are expected to look devastatingly stylish and gloriously fashionable, thanks to Beckham, the Fiennes brothers and the like, there is no need to feel guilty about hoovering up your bank account for the sake of your wardrobe.

Blahnik's shoes are consistently innovative, appealing and fun - a true rarity in the world of men's shoes. Only eight styles are produced each season: alongside the staples (loafers and brogues, around £300), he adds a touch of his characteristic originality. Last year's blue linen shoes (£275) and boots made from cowskin (£450) were particularly popular. This year, the tie-up slip-ons are already appearing on the most elite feet. Such quality, though, cannot be mass- produced: both pairs of this season's monk shoe in purple ostrich skin have, sadly, already been snapped up.

Be warned, though: Blahnik's shoes are notoriously habit-forming. To buy a pair of Manolos (enquiries 020-7352 3863) is one step along the heady road of shoe addiction. Whether they'll make you say "Hi, sailor" to every man you see, as Joan Rivers says hers do, I couldn't possibly say.

webTitle: Orson Welles' Ambersons set for remake

fields.headline: Orson Welles' Ambersons set for remake
fields.trailText: Mexican director Alfonso Arau (Like Water for Chocolate, A Walk in the Clouds) is to helm a remake of Orson Welles' classic film The Magnificent Ambersons
fields.body:
Mexican director Alfonso Arau (Like Water for Chocolate, A Walk in the Clouds) is to helm a remake of Orson Welles' classic film The Magnificent Ambersons.

The 1942 film tells the story of a stubborn man who loses his family fortune and social prominence through his unwillingness to change in the age of the automobile, and Arau plans to instill his remake with Welles' vision by using the great director's original 165-page script. During the filming of Ambersons, Welles was apparently appalled to discover on returning from a holiday that RKO Pictures executives had cut an hour of the film - and burned the excised footage, so that Welles could not fight to have it restored.

"The idea of a remake is absolutely fascinating and terrifying at the same time, because you risk criticism," acknowledged Arau. "But this is different. Welles didn't get to finish the movie himself, and the studio made changes he didn't like and left a work he hardly recognised. There's this fantasy that doing it the way he wanted it to be done would please him, wherever he is. It's a romantic thought, anyway."

Arau will embellish Welles' script with scenes from the 1918 Pulitzer Prize-winning Booth Tarkington novel from which Welles adapted his script. But the Mexican director intends putting his own stylistic stamp on the $16m project.

"I'm not planning to do a shot by shot reproduction like [Gus van Sant's] Psycho", he said. "I'm planning to take that original script and make a current film, a family drama with some humour," said Arau.

He will start casting the leads next week, and begin shooting in August on a turn-of-the-century Minneapolis set that has been constructed in Ireland.

webTitle: Comic book mutants hit the x-spot

fields.headline: Comic book mutants hit the x-spot
fields.trailText: Last night the first press screening for X-Men was held in California, and early word suggests people won't be disappointed
fields.body:
Last night the first press screening for X-Men was held in California, and early word suggests people won't be disappointed, despite the huge levels of anticipation surrounding Bryan Singer's movie.

Coming Attractions has three reviews of the long-awaited adaptation of the classic comic book about a band of mutants who possess unique powers.

"I'm a huge fan of comics and I went in praying to God that this wouldn't turn into another Batman and Robin. But it didn't disappoint. . . This movie is damn near flawless," writes the first.

"It was AWESOME! It had unbelievable special effects and great characterisation. Wolvie's claws were so realistic that you stopped watching for the effect and just believed it!" says the somewhat overexcited second (anonymous) reviewer, and a complaint - of sorts - from the third, "I wish it was longer".

The self-styled Big Hairy Monster has posted a poetic review to Ain't It Cool News. X-Men, he writes "is like a pot of fine honey. It can be a bit messy, but overall is very sweet and satisfying. First, let me assure you, all the geek-lords will not be let down. There were parts of the movie that kicked ass so hard, I almost couldn't take it. And then there were parts which were kinda hot and cold. Nothing too special."

 X-Men opens in the UK on 18 August.

fields.headline: Showboats cruise into top gear
fields.trailText: They're the side everyone loves to hate, the Manchester United of county cricket. Last season they were dubbed showboats by Mike Atherton. And already this season they have been accused of throwing their metropolitan weight about when Derbyshire, who had just beaten them in the Championship, were docked eight points after a visit from the pitch inspectors. They combine the aggression of the Australians (well, their captain was born in Melbourne) with the self-belief of the South Africans. They're the reigning champions. They are of course Surrey. And they're back.
fields.body:
They're the side everyone loves to hate, the Manchester United of county cricket. Last season they were dubbed showboats by Mike Atherton. And already this season they have been accused of throwing their metropolitan weight about when Derbyshire, who had just beaten them in the Championship, were docked eight points after a visit from the pitch inspectors. They combine the aggression of the Australians (well, their captain was born in Melbourne) with the self-belief of the South Africans. They're the reigning champions. They are of course Surrey. And they're back.

This may not sound like earth-shattering news. But Surrey's title defence did get off to a low-key start. Somerset had the better of a rain-ruined draw in April, then Durham pulled off a shock trouncing at the Riverside. Bad weather turned promising positions against Kent into two draws, and after four games they had cobbled together just 26 points. It was relegation form, and Surrey needed a slice of luck.

What they got was a whopping great chunk. Hampshire, chasing 266 at The Oval, looked out of it at 173 for 9. But Dimitri Mascarenhas and Simon Francis (who goes in below Alan Mullally) chipped and chiselled until, with three needed, Mascarenhas was caught and bowled by Alex Tudor. He celebrated like a man who had just won the lottery, and bingo!, Surrey were back on track. Since then they have won eight games out of nine in all competitions, with only the debacle at Derby preventing a perfect sequence. Going into today's crucial clash with Leicestershire, they were third in division one of the Championship and joint-top of the National League's second division.

And it gets worse for their rivals. Surrey finish with a flourish. Towards the end of last season, they won eight matches in a row to seal the Championship. Now they're on a roll and nicely tucked in behind perennial chokers Yorkshire, and Lancashire, whose last outright title came when Cyril Washbrook was just establishing himself in the England team.

Surrey's model of success is loosely based on the formula used by the best Test sides of the last decade, who won't take the field without an attacking wrist-spinner or a top-drawer pace bowler. But Surrey don't just hunt in pairs. They hunt in pairs of pairs.

Salisbury bowls legbreaks and Saqlain Mushtaq uses every joint below his elbow to find turn other offspinners can only dream about. Last summer they played seven games together. Surrey won the lot, and the spin twins took a total of 88 wickets at 12.44. And as the pitches become drier and harder - and in England they don't get drier and harder than The Oval - they should come into their own again, just as John Emburey and Phil Edmonds (and later Phil Tufnell) used to for Middlesex. Saqqy, whose 1999 haul of 58 victims came at a rate of one every five overs, had claimed 17 wickets at 15.12 in the two Championship matches before today's game, and Solly, who took a career-best 8 for 60 against Somerset recently, already had 25 in the bag.

The quicker stuff comes from Martin Bicknell (27 wickets at 21.96 this summer) and Alex Tudor (24 at 25.16). Tudor has got an England career to play for, and Bicknell is bowling better now than when he won two caps against Australia in 1993. As county opening pairings go, only Allan Donald and Ed Giddins of Warwickshire come close - and they've been disrupted by injury and international duty.

The batting has been mediocre, but at least it has depth. Before today, no-one averaged more than Mark Butcher's 37.63, while eight others weighed in at over 20. Like South Africa, the tail often bails out the top: Tudor (32.83) and Bicknell (30.00) could beef up the middle order of several counties. And Graham Thorpe is only just running into form.

There have been disappointments, which is why Surrey aren't top - yet. Ben Hollioake is the most worrying. His top-score in 14 innings in all competitions this season was 44 (average 14.14), while his 11 wickets had cost 37 each. But compare him to the quality of the passengers most sides carry, and it's almost a nice problem to have.

Crises don't last long at The Oval these days. Because when the weather permits and Surrey are on top of their game, there isn't a side in the country that can live with them.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read his previous County View, on the need for centrally contracted groundsmen,click here

fields.headline: Obituary: Joan Tate
fields.standfirst: Translator who worked with Scandinavia's greatest writers
fields.trailText: Joan Tate, who has died aged 77, was an outstanding and prolific literary translator. She only started in the early 1960s, but worked on more than 200 books from the Scandinavian languages. The list of authors she translated from Swedish was a roll-call of the major names in contemporary Swedish literature. Almost the same could be said of her work in the other Scandinavian languages.
fields.body:
Joan Tate, who has died aged 77, was an outstanding and prolific literary translator. She only started in the early 1960s, but worked on more than 200 books from the Scandinavian languages. The list of authors she translated from Swedish was a roll-call of the major names in contemporary Swedish literature. Almost the same could be said of her work in the other Scandinavian languages.

Tate had the ability to get under the skin of a novel and to strike a rapport with the writer - becoming friends with the cream of contemporary Scandinavian writers.Of her many awards, the one she treasured most was from the Swedish Academy: typically, she used most of the money to finance the translation of novels she admired, but which had not found an English-language publisher.

Born into a schoolmaster's family in Tonbridge, Kent, Joan Eames used to claim her greatest achievements at school were sporting. In 1939 she began a three-week visit to Sweden, and found herself stranded by the outbreak of war. She learned Swedish by reading magazines, and took a series of jobs - she was especially proud of having qualified as a gymnastics teacher and physiotherapist before returning to England in 1943.

The next year she married Clive Tate, an agricultural adviser and conservationist, and they eventually settled in Shrewsbury with their son and two daughters.

In the postwar years she wrote books, mainly for children and young people, and developed an interest in puppet theatre, specialising in south-east Asian shadow theatre and writing a scholarly book on the subject, which was close to completion on her death.

It was easy to be scared stiff by Joan, but behind the daunting exterior was a kind, generous and hospitable personality. She held open house to authors, publishers, artists of all kinds, students, and, not least, translators. She was a founder member of the Swedish-English Literary Translators' Association (Selta), and especially liked to address students with a budding interest in literary translation. "Don't even think about it unless you can write," she would say. "And to write properly, you must read - not just in the foreign language, but more espe cially in English. Knowing the foreign language is only the first step, and a short one at that."

Students were particularly impressed when she produced the computer printout of her public lending right royalties: she explained she could estimate her annual earnings by standing at the top of her stairs, letting the printout unroll, and seeing how far down the hall the last page came to rest.

Her awards were invariably accompanied by thanks for her promotion of Scandinavian literature and culture. "I have never promoted anything," she replied. "I just translate books." But she knew what they meant, and was secretly proud.

She is survived by her husband and children.

Cleodie Mackinnon writes: In the late 60s and early 70s, bookshops were closing in most of the English provinces and Shrewsbury was no exception. Almost single-handed Joan Tate enlisted volunteers, negotiated a deal with a benevolent wholesaler, and secured a room (in the building shared by the local arts centre, adult education classes and university extra-mural department).

The bookshop beat conventional rivals to win a national prize for its speciality on environmental issues, became a meeting place for Shrewsbury's literati, and kept the book-buying habit alive in the town until independent bookshops and Waterstone's opened there.

Three of the volunteers later opened their own bookshops - typical examples of Joan's enabling and liberating powers.

 Joan Tate, translator, writer and publisher's reader, born September 23 1922; died June 6 2000

fields.headline: Obituary: Gustaw Herling
fields.standfirst: Writer whose humanity survived Stalin's gulag
fields.trailText: Gustaw Herling-Grudzinski, who has died of a cerebral haemorrhage aged 81, was one of Europe's greatest contemporary writers, but is best known for A World Apart, one of the most dramatic accounts of the power of totalitarian systems over individuals - but also of the power of humanity and dignity.
fields.body:
Gustaw Herling-Grudzinski, who has died of a cerebral haemorrhage aged 81, was one of Europe's greatest contemporary writers, but is best known for A World Apart, one of the most dramatic accounts of the power of totalitarian systems over individuals - but also of the power of humanity and dignity.

When it first appeared in 1951 the Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin was at the height of his power and many intellectuals on the left did not want to acknowledge the existence of Soviet labour camps - or tried to minimise their impact. Bertrand Russell prefaced the book by describing it as one of "the most impressive and the best written" accounts of Soviet power.

The Times Literary Supplement argued that in its intensity the book surpassed Dostoevsky from whose novel, The House of the Dead, Herling borrowed the title phrase. The Observer labelled it a masterpiece which should be read for its humanity.

In the eastern bloc meanwhile his book remained unpublished. In the Soviet Union and Soviet-dominated Poland possession of a copy was punishable.

Apart from its artistic value, A World Apart is important as a document of life in the gulag but even more as a document of humanity, a chronicling of what becomes of a man from whom everything is taken and who is transformed into a hungry bag of bones. Like few people in this world, Herling understood the power of hunger.

"Hunger is a horrible sensation," he wrote, "which becomes transformed into an abstraction, into nightmares fed by the mind's perpetual fever. The body is like an over-heated machine, working at increased speed on less fuel, and the wasted arms and legs come to resemble torn driving-belts. There is no limit to the physical effects of hunger beyond which tottering human dignity might still keep its uncertain but independent balance. If God exists, let him punish mercilessly those who break others with hunger."

Herling was born in Kielce in southern Poland and studied Polish literature at Warsaw University, where he was interested in neo-Thomism and aesthetics. After the German invasion of Poland on September 1 1939, he and his friends founded one of the first underground anti-Nazi organisations in Warsaw. Then, on September 17, the Soviet Union attacked Poland and the country was divided between two totalitarian powers.

In 1940 Herling fled to the Soviet-occupied part of Poland but there, in March, he was arrested by the Soviet secret police, the NKVD. He was thrown into prison and accused of being a German spy; the surreal pretext was that "Herling", when transcribed into Russian, sounded similar to the name of Hitler's deputy, Herman Goering. Interrogated under torture, Herling was sentenced to five years hard labour in a forced-labour camp at Kargopol, near Archangel on the White Sea.

Then, in June 1941, came the Nazi attack on the Soviet Union. Stalin agreed to an amnesty for Polish prisoners yet Herling was still not released - until he went on hunger strike. Before leaving the camp he dared to steal his own prisoner photograph as Labour Inmate Number 1872 from his dossier.

In 1942 he enlisted in the Polish army and went through Kazakhstan, Iran, and Palestine to Libya. He eventually arrived in Italy, where, as a soldier of the Second Polish Corps, he took part in the battle of Monte Cassino and was awarded Virtuti Militari, the highest Polish military honour.

After the war Herling lived in Rome, London and Munich, where he briefly worked for Radio Free Europe. After his first wife died in 1952 he settled in Naples where, in 1955, he married Lidia Croce, daughter of Italian historian and philosopher, Benedetto Croce.

In 1946 in Rome, Jerzy Giedroyc and Herling had founded the emigré journal Kultura. It was to become one of the most important Polish intellectual forums of the postwar period, and played an invaluable role in preserving an authentic Polish culture of free speech and in educating the generation which founded Solidarity in 1981.

Herling's contribution to Kultura included critical essays and excerpts from his Diary Written at Night, which he composed over the past 30 years. He also wrote The Living and the Dead (1945), Phantoms of the Revolution (1969), The Second Coming (1963), and The Island: Three Tales (1967), as well as critical essays on literature and art.

He received many awards, including the Italian Permio Viareggio, the Prix Gutenberg and an award from the French Pen-Club. Polish awards include the Jurzykowski Prize (1964), the Koscielski Prize (1966), and a literary prize awarded by Wiadomosci, a London-based Polish emigré journal (1981).

In the last scene of A World Apart a former prisoner confesses to Herling that he had denounced four other prisoners who were eventually executed. The prisoner had to choose between his own life and the lives of four other men. He decided to save himself and wanted to hear from Herling, a man who went through the same world of the camps, only two words - "I understand" - which would somehow justify that one can fight evil with evil, that personal physical survival matters more than retaining one's humanity.

Herling writes: "No, I could not say it." To do so would have meant an acceptance of the morality of the totalitarian world which he never accepted, even in the gulag.

 Gustaw Herling-Grudzinski, writer, born May 20 1919; died July 4 2000

 The following is an extract from Gustaw Herling's memoir A World Apart. The book covers his time incarcerated in a Soviet labour camp between 1940-1942

Juvenile delinquents, like the boys in the cell, are the plague of the Soviet prisons, though they are almost never found in labour camps. Unnaturally excited, always ferreting in other men's bunks and inside their own trousers, they give themselves up passionately to the only two occupations of their lives, theft and self-abuse.

Almost all of them either have no parents or else know nothing of their whereabouts. Throughout the vast expanse of the Russian police state, they manage to lead with astounding ease the typical life of bzeprizornye (the homeless), jumping goods trains, constantly on the move from town to town, from settlement to settlement.

They make a living by stealing and selling goods from government stores, and frequently they steal back what they have just sold, blackmailing unsuspecting purchasers with the threat of laying information against them. They sleep in railway stations, in municipal parks, in tram terminuses; often all their belongings can be wrapped in a small bundle tied with a leather strap.

Only later, I discovered that the bzeprizornye constitute a most dangerous semi-legal mafia, organised on the pattern of masonic lodges, and surpassed only by the more powerful organisations of urkas, or criminal prisoners.

If in Russia anything like a black market exists, it is only thanks to the efforts of these urchins, always weaving in and out of crowds, besieging the spectorgs (special shops supplying exclusively the elite of the Soviet bureaucracy), creeping at dusk towards stores of corn and coal.

The Soviet authorities wink at all this activity; they regard the bzeprizornye as the only true proletariat free of the original sin of counter- revolution, as a plastic mass of raw material which can be moulded into any shape they choose. These young boys have come to look on prison as something like a holiday-camp, and they take advantage of a prison sentence to rest after the exertions of their life outside.

Occasionally, a vospitatel (education officer), with an angelic face, flaxen hair and blue eyes, would come into our cell, and, in a voice which sounded like the gentle whisper of the confessional, call the handful of bezprizornye out for a "lesson": "Come, children, let us go and learn a little."

When the "children" came back from their instruction, our ears burned at the obscenities which they mixed freely with the stock phrases of Soviet political propaganda. Accusations of "Trotskyism", "nationalism," and "counter-revolution" were constantly flung out at us from their corner, then assurances that "Comrade Stalin did well to lock you up," or that "the power of the Soviets will soon conquer the whole world" - all this repeated again and again with the cruel sadistic persistence typical of homeless youth.

Later in the labour camp I met an 18-year-old boy who had been appointed chief of the local Kulturno-Vospitatelnaya Tchast (cultural and educational section) only because once, as a bzeprizornye, he had gone through such a course of instruction in prison.

Like few people in this world, Herling understood the power of hunger. "Hunger is a horrible sensation," he wrote, "which becomes transformed into an abstraction, into nightmares fed by the mind's perpetual fever. The body is like an over-heated machine, working at increased speed on less fuel, and the wasted arms and legs come to resemble torn driving-belts. If God exists, let him punish mercilessly those who break others with hunger." Before leaving the camp he dared to steal his own prisoner photograph as Labour Inmate Number 1872 from his dossier. Polish awards include the Jurzykowski Prize (1964), the Koscielski Prize (1966), and a literary prize awarded by Wiadomosci, a London-based Polish emigré journal (1981). webTitle: Jaws author campaigns to save the shark campaign

fields.headline: Jaws author campaigns to save the shark campaign
fields.trailText: The man who made a fortune demonising sharks, Peter Benchley, the author of Jaws, yesterday launched a global campaign to protect the fish.
fields.body:
The man who made a fortune demonising sharks, Peter Benchley, the author of Jaws, yesterday launched a global campaign to protect the fish.

Humans kill 100m sharks a year, mainly to make shark fin soup for the Chinese, and some species are in danger of extinction, he said.

"In the 25 years since Jaws was first released, sharks have experienced an unprecedented and uncontrolled attack," said Benchley. "Some shark species have been reduced by 90%. We must not allow just one generation of humanity to needlessly eradicate 400m years of evolution."

To help protect the shark Benchley and the international conservation organisation WildAid are calling for an immediate ban on shark finning practices - where the fins are cut off and the rest of the shark is thrown back into the sea, to drown or bleed to death.

Benchley related how he had been appalled to witness graveyards of hundreds of sharks without fins on the sea bed. "Sharks are nature at its most perfect. The most beautiful thing in the water you can imagine. Nature makes so few of them because they are so powerful and effective. Fish have hundreds of millions of eggs, but sharks do not breed until they are 20 and cannot sustain the losses," he said.

The odds of dying from a shark attack are less than being run over on a beach or killed by lightning, he said. Sharks kill only 12 people a year.

Demand for shark fins has soared in south-east Asia, where consumption is seen as a status symbol. The soup is often served at weddings and business lunches and can cost £20 to £60 in Hong Kong restaurants.

In the past sharks caught in fishermen's nets were thrown back alive, but with each fin worth up to £10 they are now killed and the fins sold.

This has wiped out whole populations, causing severe problems for subsistence fisherman in countries such as India, Kenya and Brazil, who depend on shark meat as a cheap source of protein. They are suffering malnutrition from the collapse in shark populations, according to the United Nations food and agricultural organisation. In a report, the organisation says: "Unless efforts are undertaken promptly to halt growing catches, the future of many more shark populations is very bleak."

Despite the fear whipped up by Steven Spielberg's film of the book, Jaws did not cause the shark's problem, according to Peter Knights, WildAid's director. Industrial fishing and a lack of international regulation were to blame.

Being the top predator, sharks eat species that prey on fish caught for human food, so they could be seen as an ally, said one campaigner, Suzy Watts. Most people would only find 12 out of the 1,000 shark species frightening. While agreeing that the great white shark featured in Jaws was "pretty scary", she said most species under threat are far more benign, including British species such as the spiny dogfish and the basking shark.

The spiny dogfish is sold as "rock salmon" in fish and chip shops, and there has been a reported decline of 50% in catches in the past five years.

The dogfish is an example of how vulnerable sharks are to over-exploitation. The fish does not breed until it is more than 20 years old, and is pregnant for 22 months before producing only six to eight young.

Only four countries, the United States, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, have bans on fin removal.

Benchley said knowledge of shark behaviour had advanced to the extent that he could no longer get away with depicting Jaws as a indiscriminate killer. Behaviour originally thought of as aggression is now seen to be simple curiosity. He said most great white sharks decide not to eat human beings after taking an initial bite.

webTitle: Emotional PM talks of faith and family

fields.headline: Emotional PM talks of faith and family
fields.standfirst:
Prime minister tells black church leaders how he turned to his Christian beliefs on the night of his eldest son's arrest
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair came close to tears yesterday as he opened up his heart to talk about the central role played by Christianity in his family life.
fields.body:
Tony Blair came close to tears yesterday as he opened up his heart to talk about the central role played by Christianity in his family life.

Visibly upset by the behaviour of his eldest son, the prime minister abandoned his text at a conference of black church leaders to declare that he had turned to his faith on the night of Euan's arrest.

Mr Blair made no direct reference to his son, but he spoke of how he read Henry Longfellow's poem, The Village Church, on Wednesday night.

His voice almost breaking with emotion, Mr Blair asked his audience at the Faith in the Future Conference in Brighton: "What does faith give us? It gives us strength and that's important. Last night I read a poem by a poet called Longfellow. It says: 'For Thine own purpose Thou hast sent strife and discouragement.' We need the strength when the strife and the discouragement is there."

The raw emotion in his voice, as he spoke about his faith at home, contrasted with the earlier part of Mr Blair's speech when he almost made light of Euan's arrest in his first reference to his son.

As he praised the church's commitment to "tolerance, faith and the family and trying to bring up children properly", Mr Blair grinned and said: "That part was written a short time ago."

His mood turned sombre, however, as he spoke of the strains of combining fatherhood with running the country. "Being a prime minister can be a tough job," he said. "But I think that being a parent is probably tougher. Sometimes you do not always succeed. But the family to me is more important than anything else."

As members of the audience clapped and shouted hallelujah, the prime minister was momentarily distracted when a baby cried out from the back of the audience. "Is that a little baby back there," he asked. "It makes me feel at home."

Mr Blair makes no secret of his faith, which is High Anglican, although he rarely wears his Christianity on his sleeve.

The emotion of yesterday's speech indicated, however, the intense soul searching in the Blair household over the past 24 hours.

Sounding at times more like a preacher than a prime minister, Mr Blair told of how faith helped him to prepare his four children for the challenges of the new century. "Faith, in the end, is the best expression of humility, the best expression that there is something bigger than us as individuals," he told a sympathetic audience from Britain's Black Majority Churches.

"There are challenges my parents and grandparents never dreamed of. If I look at the world my kids are growing up in, there's so much for them in material goods.

"But there are also big problems and challenges there - it is tougher. There are not the same links with family and community which kept people together."

Giving his faith a clear political dimension, he said he believed that faith bound society together to demonstrate that human beings are not "stranded in isolation".

He added: "Faith is not some old-fashioned virtue whose time has gone. So let us emerge unafraid of the future, saying 'bring us those challenges, we are ready for them' and in place of the fear we can often have, the hope we know in our hearts we should have."

The prime minister was clapped and treated to numerous standing ovations throughout his speech as his audience lapped up his message.

At the end of his speech, Mark Sturge, the head of the African and Caribbean Evangelical Alliance, joked: "Who needs a good speech writer when you have a good sermon?"

The audience, whose warm welcome contrasted with the humiliation meted out to Mr Blair at the Women's Institute conference, was encouraged when he spoke of his determination to sweep aside racial discrimination.

Announcing that Gordon Brown is to tackle unemployment among the ethnic minorities, Mr Blair was cheered when he said that Britain would one day have a black prime minister.

"I say to young black people: you perhaps more than anyone can gain from going into politics," he said. "Politics needs people from the ethnic minorities. They used to say Britain would never have a woman prime minister. It happened. One day there will be a black prime minister, too. But it means today's young blacks thinking that politics matters, it is for them, they want to get involved and make a real difference."

However, Mr Blair admitted that black people faced formidable obstacles in pursuing successful careers in, for example, the police. "I appeal to young black children," he said. "I know the sad, difficult history of police relations. But don't rule out a career in the police, because it's important that the police force becomes representative of your community."

As a first step Mr Blair said that the chancellor would commit the government - in his spending review this month - to narrow the gap between unemployment rates among members of ethnic minorities and others.

"We need to tackle discrimination at the gateway into work," he said. "Unemployment among ethnic minorities is 12.2%, compared to 5.8% nationally."

Mr Blair was cheered and given a final standing ovation as he left the stage.

Gilda Rose, from the Bethel United Church in Birmingham, said she was impressed by Mr Blair's commitment to stamping out discrimination, although she doubted a there would be a black prime minister in Downing Street in the near future. "It was a very positive speech," she said."I do not believe there will be a black prime minister, but I was pleased to hear him talk about ending inequality. But there has to be real equality, with an end to people with good qualifications being pushed aside and there must be no tokenism."

webTitle: Blair shows strain after son's arrest

fields.headline: Blair shows strain after son's arrest
fields.standfirst:
PM near to tears after worst month
Audio: Blair's emotional reaction
Comment by Michael White
Downing Street's full statement
fields.trailText: An emotional Tony Blair yesterday displayed a rare public vulnerability after the worst month of his political career culminated in the humiliation of his teenage son being arrested for drunkenness in the West End of London.
fields.body:
An emotional Tony Blair yesterday displayed a rare public vulnerability after the worst month of his political career culminated in the humiliation of his teenage son being arrested for drunkenness in the West End of London.

Faced with the need to reconcile a family crisis with the relentless demands of his daily routine, the prime minister used a speech to a conference of black church leaders to reveal inner turbulence, his religious faith offset by the "strife and discouragement" of his secular battles.

Mr Blair seemed close to tears at several points. Departing from his text, he quoted a fragment from A Village Church, a poem about divine tribulations by the 19th century American Henry Longfellow: "For thine own purpose thou hast sent strife and discouragement."

He added: "We need the strength when the strife and discouragement is there. Faith in the end is the best expression of humility."

Mr Blair revealed that he had read the poem after 16-year-old Euan Blair, who had gone out with friends to celebrate the end of their GCSEs at the Oratory school, had been arrested, drunk and vomiting on the pavement in Leicester Square. He was brought home to Downing Street by special branch at 1am.

The prime minister was quick to realise that there would be legitimate media interest, especially as the incident came a few days after he had argued for fixed penalty fines for drunken yobs.

Appearing on BBC1's Question Time last night, Mr Blair said: "My son is basically a good kid. We will all get through this and see him right. As a politician I cannot say that my family is always going to behave to the very highest standards but the fact that my son has done something wrong will not stop me from speaking out and saying what I believe."

He defended his proposals for fixed penalty fines for loutish behaviour, saying, in reference to his son: "I hope he would be deterred from behaving wrong."

Mr Blair sanctioned a Downing Street statement that said: "Euan was out last night with friends to mark the end of his GCSEs. The police late last night saw him lying on the ground in Leicester Square.

"He was clearly ill and had been vomiting. He was, in the view of the police, drunk and incapable.

"He gave his name during the interview as Euan John. He gave an old address and he gave a date of birth which suggested he was 18.

"The police searched him and established his correct identity. They immediately called the special branch here [10 Downing Street] who immediately went to Charing Cross and identified him. He was then processed, released and taken home.

"Euan is very sorry for the inconvenience he caused to the police, the state he was in, and for the false statement that he made. He is in no doubt of the seriousness of it and the view that his parents take of it."

Euan will have to return to the police station for a reprimand, a formal caution or, highly unlikely, to be charged.

Lord Wakeham, chairman of the press complaints commission, said there were no restrictions on reporting the incident, as Euan is over 16 and was not at school, but reminded the press of the Blairs' desire for privacy.

Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's spokesman,said: "Euan won't be the only teenager out last night celebrating the end of his exams. But he will be the only one splashed over the papers and on TV."

Addressing the Faith in the Future conference of black evangelical Christians, Mr Blair left his audience in no doubt that the arrest of Euan was uppermost in his mind.

"Being a prime minister can be a tough job," he told his sympathetic audience. "But I think that being a parent is probably tougher. Sometimes you do not always succeed. But the family to me is more important than anything else."

The incident, however minor, is likely to be seen as symbolising a family under pressure. Since Leo Blair was born on May 20 the government has been battered on crime, asylum and the euro, Mr Blair was heckled at the Women's Institute conference and his "cashpoints" plan for fining drunken hooligans was widely derided.

With the novelist and Labour fundraiser Ken Follett launching a personal attack on Mr Blair in Sunday's Observer, the prime minister's charmed political life was finally looking battered when William Hague gave him a drubbing in the Commons on Wednesday.

Things only get worse

fields.bodyText: An emotional Tony Blair yesterday displayed a rare public vulnerability after the worst month of his political career culminated in the humiliation of his teenage son being arrested for drunkenness in the West End of London. Faced with the need to reconcile a family crisis with the relentless demands of his daily routine, the prime minister used a speech to a conference of black church leaders to reveal inner turbulence, his religious faith offset by the "strife and discouragement" of his secular battles. Mr Blair seemed close to tears at several points. Departing from his text, he quoted a fragment from A Village Church, a poem about divine tribulations by the 19th century American Henry Longfellow: "For thine own purpose thou hast sent strife and discouragement." He added: "We need the strength when the strife and discouragement is there. Faith in the end is the best expression of humility." Mr Blair revealed that he had read the poem after 16-year-old Euan Blair, who had gone out with friends to celebrate the end of their GCSEs at the Oratory school, had been arrested, drunk and vomiting on the pavement in Leicester Square. He was brought home to Downing Street by special branch at 1am. The prime minister was quick to realise that there would be legitimate media interest, especially as the incident came a few days after he had argued for fixed penalty fines for drunken yobs. Appearing on BBC1's Question Time last night, Mr Blair said: "My son is basically a good kid. We will all get through this and see him right. As a politician I cannot say that my family is always going to behave to the very highest standards but the fact that my son has done something wrong will not stop me from speaking out and saying what I believe." He defended his proposals for fixed penalty fines for loutish behaviour, saying, in reference to his son: "I hope he would be deterred from behaving wrong." Mr Blair sanctioned a Downing Street statement that said: "Euan was out last night with friends to mark the end of his GCSEs. The police late last night saw him lying on the ground in Leicester Square. "He was clearly ill and had been vomiting. He was, in the view of the police, drunk and incapable. "He gave his name during the interview as Euan John. He gave an old address and he gave a date of birth which suggested he was 18. "The police searched him and established his correct identity. They immediately called the special branch here [10 Downing Street] who immediately went to Charing Cross and identified him. He was then processed, released and taken home. "Euan is very sorry for the inconvenience he caused to the police, the state he was in, and for the false statement that he made. He is in no doubt of the seriousness of it and the view that his parents take of it." Euan will have to return to the police station for a reprimand, a formal caution or, highly unlikely, to be charged. Lord Wakeham, chairman of the press complaints commission, said there were no restrictions on reporting the incident, as Euan is over 16 and was not at school, but reminded the press of the Blairs' desire for privacy. Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's spokesman,said: "Euan won't be the only teenager out last night celebrating the end of his exams. But he will be the only one splashed over the papers and on TV." Addressing the Faith in the Future conference of black evangelical Christians, Mr Blair left his audience in no doubt that the arrest of Euan was uppermost in his mind. "Being a prime minister can be a tough job," he told his sympathetic audience. "But I think that being a parent is probably tougher. Sometimes you do not always succeed. But the family to me is more important than anything else." The incident, however minor, is likely to be seen as symbolising a family under pressure. Since Leo Blair was born on May 20 the government has been battered on crime, asylum and the euro, Mr Blair was heckled at the Women's Institute conference and his "cashpoints" plan for fining drunken hooligans was widely derided. With the novelist and Labour fundraiser Ken Follett launching a personal attack on Mr Blair in Sunday's Observer, the prime minister's charmed political life was finally looking battered when William Hague gave him a drubbing in the Commons on Wednesday. fields.headline: Give him a break
fields.standfirst: Pity poor Euan Blair: being the son of the prime minister gives him the worst possible start in life
fields.trailText: Pity poor Euan Blair: being the son of the prime minister gives him the worst possible start in life
fields.body:
In late-night newsrooms, bored reporters on the dog-watch play at fantasy news. What if...Princess Diana found alive, Pope elopes, Baroness Young in lesbian love triangle. And then suddenly it happens - Euan Blair drunk and incapable, vomiting in Leicester Square, arrested and taken to a police cell. On cue, to deadline, it's the very day his father has been battered in the Commons for that speech promising to give police "powers to deal with drunken anti-social behaviour which causes offence and misery in too many towns and cities". Did young Euan also oblige by "throwing traffic cones around the street or hurling abuse into the night sky", loutish behaviour his father threatened with spot fines at the cashpoint? We know little. All we know is that here is a story to make heathen newshounds believe there is a God after all. (And may cause Tony Blair doubts on the same score.)

Any chortles from enemies of left or right are strictly private. (Yes, private jokes abound referring to the government's largely unused child curfew orders. Might the Blairs be ordered on to a course for failing parents on one of the new parenting orders?) But in public the amalgamated union of professional politicians wisely closed ranks: there but for the grace of God go any of the children of Westminster's denizens. Is there a sane parent anywhere who does not sympathise? Is there a teenager anywhere who doesn't view with horror what adolescence must be like inside Number 10? The best hope is that this was just a case of a kid getting drunk after exams as most others do - an almost obligatory rite of passage that, with luck, leaves most of them so horribly sick they are determined never to get that out of control again. As Alastair Campbell said acidly at his daily press briefing, "Euan won't be the only one who got the worse for wear but he will be the only one splashed all over the papers and the television". End of story.

But other things loom and lurk behind all this, a multitude of uneasy unpleasantness. To start with, can the god of perfect news stories really have gone completely unaided by human agency? Was this just a divine coincidence? Or is the boy from Number 10 too vulnerable? Consider the monstrous way Jack Straw's son was set up by an agent provocateur from the Mirror, flattering and urging him on to buy some cannabis for her. How much should the boy from Number 10 trust "friends" when the chance to make spectacular fun of the prime minister is right there, begging for it? It probably doesn't take Rohypnol or any other artificial means to encourage a boy over the edge on an end-of-exam spree. But why, according to one eye witness, was he found vomiting alone in Leicester Square? Where were these friends? And who tipped off the press? Whoever it was behaved disgracefully, whether it was a friend or - far more likely - the police, who are never sacked for taking backhanders for stories about celebs' minor infringements that would never otherwise see the light of day.

And then there is our old friend the press code of practice, fine words honoured in the breach every day of the week. Out Lord Wakeham duly popped yesterday, Fleet Street's noble figleaf, quick to assure the hacks that of course it was perfectly OK to pillory the boy in print - he was 16, out of school, underage and drunk. So much for the protection of minors, or for allowing a judge to decide whether naming a boy isn't too grave a punishment for such a minor crime. It is probably irrelevant. Some stories are just too stupendous to be held back by any code and Downing Street very wisely didn't even try. But that doesn't make it right or fair on someone who is still a child.

Then comes the awful spectre of what life must be like in Number 10 for any normal London boy, dragged off to the stately boredom of Chequers at the weekend. Alastair Campbell revealed yesterday that the prime minister had been up late working on his boxes, already worried that his son wasn't home by 1am. Cherie was away with the baby in Portugal. Campbell added the chilling reassurance that the Blairs are "strict disciplinarians" and you just hope against hope it's not true. But it makes you wonder if the boy is bursting with anger at restrictions unjustly imposed upon him by his parents' public careers. He was allowed no alcohol for his 16th birthday party - presumably because if anyone got drunk it would have hit the front pages instantly. Was getting drunk this week a resentful son's dream revenge on his father - the father of the nation? (Pyrrhic victory - it's even worse for Euan.) Any half-way successful parent knows the onus that success puts on their children: there is no protection. Add to that a new baby: what adolescent wants to be reminded that their parents still have a busy sex life (yuk), when they are just starting to get their own together?

As for parenthood, no prime minister (or any other big banana) could ever be much good at it. Yesterday's prime ministerial diary meant unveiling a police memorial and making a key speech to 6,000 black religious leaders in Brighton, hastily rewritten to include remarks about the travails of fatherhood (remarks whose diffident charm probably went down better with the religious than with his hungover son). Then he was off to do a whole gruelling television Question Time on his own with David Dimbleby, again talking loudly about fatherhood while not actually having time to do much of it. It is not his fault, no overwhelmingly important job is ever family-friendly. The super-famous give their children hell, however good they are, however hard they try. Forget privilege: son of so-and-so is the worst possible start in life, this side of a slum. Just consider the Hollywood "my mama/papa from hell" tales. Is it too unkind to raise the ghosts of Randolph Churchill or Mark Thatcher? Maybe the mega-ambitious shouldn't have children at all. Whatever the truth of this case, who would not feel sorry today for the young boy with a sore head inside Number 10?

For his father, woes tread upon each other's heels. Early-shift PA reporters were just pushing out a rather different story on the wires, before Blair booze-boy broke. Its breezy tone was a political scene-setter for the coming day: "Tony Blair was today hoping two high-profile public appearances will help him to seize the political initiative from the Conservatives and shrug off a turbulent month for the government. Aides hope today's appearances will see Mr Blair finally emerge..." It was not to be. Instead, in the dark watches of the night, he admitted in yesterday's speech to reaching for his copy of lugubrious old Longfellow, quoting: "For thine own purpose, thou hast sent, The strife and the discouragement!" Oh dear, the PM's chosen poem is a wail of wallowing despair. So out of kindness today at least we might resist the temptation to join the chorus of voices offering political lessons to be learned from all this. Poor man. Things can only get better.

fields.trailText: The law says that a boy of 16 found in a public place by a police officer to be "drunk and incapable of taking care of himself" is liable to arrest under the 1872 Licensing Act.
fields.body:
The law says that a boy of 16 found in a public place by a police officer to be "drunk and incapable of taking care of himself" is liable to arrest under the 1872 Licensing Act.

If he were an adult he might be charged and, if found guilty, fined up to £200 - and if he were a repeat offender magistrates have the power to send him to a treatment centre.

But as a 16 year old is "a young person" in the eyes of the law - those aged between 14 and 17 - it would have been open to the police to have arrested the boy and let him go home without further action.

However, the Metropolitan police said yesterday that as Euan Blair had initially told them that he was 18 when he was 16, then under the youth justice powers they could not just drop the matter but would have to take further action. This may take the form of a reprimand if he admits the offence, or a formal warning that would go on his record, or they could charge him with being drunk and incapable.

The reprimand or warning would also mean that the case would be referred to the recently set up local youth offending team who would consider early intervention, such as whether he should take part in a programme designed to prevent him re-offending. A 16 year old who persistently came to police attention is too old to be subject to a curfew order but not old enough to escape the possibility of a parenting order, which requires the parent to attend counselling for up to three months. It also encourages parents to exercise control over the child, for example, ensuring the child attends school or avoids certain places and people.

A Home Office spokeswoman said yesterday that plans for fixed penalty fines for public drunkeness are not being considered for juveniles.

The Met also said it would look into the circumstances of how Euan Blair became drunk. Here again the law is changing as ministers move to close loopholes which enable those under 18 to buy alcohol.

It is most likely that a 16 year old boy in central London was able to drink alcohol legally if he was in a restaurant for a meal. The law says a 16 or 17 year old can buy and drink beer, porter, or cider with a table meal. This is to be modernised to include wine but will only apply if they are accompanied by an adult.

fields.headline: A pious source of comfort
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was the Little Book of Calm of the 19th century, supplier of a bracingly pious quote for every domestic disaster.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was the Little Book of Calm of the 19th century, supplier of a bracingly pious quote for every domestic disaster.

When the prime minister went to bed, alone, he turned for comfort to one of the most popular poets in the world, as almost two centuries of troubled souls have done before him.

Tony Blair apparently read The Village Church, and drew comfort from the pious Longfellow lines "For thine own purpose, thou hast sent/The strife and the discouragement!"

But if he saw only an excerpt from the several hundred line poem in a compendium, he might not have been aware that the verses go on to take some peculiar twists.

Longfellow introduces Lucifer, dressed as a priest, who recites a Satanic version of the Lord's Prayer.

This includes the lines: "Open, open hell's gates!/ Shut, shut heaven's gates! All the devils in the air/ The stronger be, that hear the Black Prayer!"

He could just as well have muttered to himself, as he prepared for a sticky father and son chat: "The greatest firmness is the greatest mercy." Or indeed: "Believe me, every man has his secret sorrows, which the world knows not; and oftentimes we call a man cold, when he is only sad."

Longfellow outsold by millions of books his more critically regarded contemporaries Emerson and Thoreau. His rumty-tumpty rhythm, and clunky but unforgettable rhymes, made his work instantly accessible, recognisable, and parodied. Hiawatha, his most famous work - treated with some respect by scholars as a genuine attempt to cele brate indigenous American culture - has been recreated in sculpture, painting, opera, ballet and innumerable films.

Longfellow was born in New England in 1807, to a family which had emigrated from Yorkshire in the 17th century. He started school at the age of three and was offered a professorship at 22. He earned enough money from Evangeline and later massive best sellers - 10,000 copies of The Courtship of Miles Standish were ordered in London on publiciation day in 1858 - to retire from academia and become a full-time poet and pundit by the age of 40.

His two marriages ended in tragedy. He married his childhood sweetheart Mary in 1831, but she died of fever in Rotterdam only three years later. His second wife died in 1861 of burns from a fire started when she was melting wax to seal up locks of their five children's hair.

Longfellow quotations, still regularly to be found in antique shops, were lovingly worked as illuminated texts or cross stitch samplers to hang on the wall. Should Cherie Blair feel moved to take up her embroidery frame, here's a Longfellow text for Euan's room: "Joy, temperance, and repose/Slam the door on the doctor's nose."

Extracts from A Village Church

The day is drawing to its close;
And what good deeds, since it first rose,
Have I presented, Lord, to thee,
As offsprings of my ministry?

Feeble, at best, is my endeavour!
I see, but cannot reach, the height
That lies forever in the light;

And yet forever and forever,
When seeming just within my grasp,
I feel my feeble hands unclasp,
And sink discouraged into night!

For thine own purpose,
thou hast sent
The strife and the discouragement!

fields.headline: Just an ordinary boy
fields.trailText: Congratulations, Euan Blair, on bringing home to your father far more effectively than could any "expert" the fact that the vast majority of teenagers are not yobs or hooligans but perfectly sensible people who need to let their hair down from time to time.
fields.body:
Congratulations, Euan Blair, on bringing home to your father far more effectively than could any "expert" the fact that the vast majority of teenagers are not yobs or hooligans but perfectly sensible people who need to let their hair down from time to time.

You appear to have done no harm to anyone apart from yourself and as to giving the wrong details to the police, lots of us have done it when we were younger. I am glad that despite all the pressures you're growing up to be so normal.
Mike Clutten
Leicester

Surely it would only be a news story if a 16-year-old didn't go out and get drunk after his GCSEs?
Paulinus Barnes
Rawtenstall paulinusbarnes@hotmail.com

The prime minister memorably said that the Millennium Dome had passed the "Euan test". Having established the success of this approach, he is clearly subjecting all his initiatives to the same, rigorous, process of verification.

London

Since the prime minister's son has been found "drunk and incapable" in public will he hand Euan's piggy bank over to Jack Straw?
Paul Dixon
Sheffield

Euan Blair should have been frog marched to the cashpoint by a police officer and made to withdraw £100. He then should have been dealt with severely by the criminal justice system. Of course not, but it is further proof that pandering to the vile common sense of middle england will always backfire.
John Brookes
Manchester leftdirect@leftdirect.co.uk

I blame the parents.
Mike Ellwood
Abingdon, Oxon Mike@ellwood.freeserve.co.uk

Will Tony now get it that kids will be kids no matter what amount of pious cant is stuffed into their heads.
Kenneth Little
London

fields.trailText: Almost the most interesting aspect of the misfortunes of young Euan Blair was the choice of reading matter to which the prime minister turned in the lonely watches of the night. Longfellow's poem, A Village Church, is a vast Gothic epic, large expanses of which consist of a series of anguished speeches between Prince Henry and Lucifer, cunningly disguised as a priest: "Weakness is wretchedness! To be strong/Is to be happy! I am weak,/And cannot find the good I seek/Because I feel and fear the wrong!" This was indeed an interesting glimpse into Mr Blair's literary tastes.

Almost the most interesting aspect of the misfortunes of young Euan Blair was the choice of reading matter to which the prime minister turned in the lonely watches of the night. Longfellow's poem, A Village Church, is a vast Gothic epic, large expanses of which consist of a series of anguished speeches between Prince Henry and Lucifer, cunningly disguised as a priest: "Weakness is wretchedness! To be strong/Is to be happy! I am weak,/And cannot find the good I seek/Because I feel and fear the wrong!" This was indeed an interesting glimpse into Mr Blair's literary tastes.

His son's behaviour was altogether less remarkable. It is not unknown for 16-year-old boys to celebrate the end of their exams by getting legless. Euan Blair appears to have celebrated too well and not to have much of a head for drink. Once at Charing Cross police station he panicked and gave a false name. By yesterday morning he was doubtless feeling mortified and extremely sick. End of story.

Though, of course, it won't be. Through no fault or design of his own he is the son of the prime minister. He is, moreover, the son of a prime minister in the middle of his rockiest patch since taking office. The son of a prime minister who, as luck would have it, had just made a daft speech advocating draconian penalties for young drunken louts. To borrow the current political jargon, it is tempting to see the prime minister's son as a metaphor.

But Euan Blair is no lout. He lives more uncomfortably in the public eye than any of us would wish for ourselves or our children. That is his misfortune: we should sympathise. Mr Blair, like Jack Straw before him, has been dignified and open about the affair. It is no bad thing that our politicians are not insulated from the difficulties and discomfitures all families suffer. Euan should sleep it off, we should move on, and Mr Blair should get back to his poetry. There is a famous poem by Philip Larkin...
