fields.headline: Cook fuels new euro row
fields.trailText: Downing Street today attempted to quell the latest political storm to break over the government's euro policy, insisting that it was not a foregone conclusion that Britain would join.
fields.body:
Downing Street today attempted to quell the latest political storm to break over the government's euro policy, insisting that it was not a foregone conclusion that Britain would join.

The intervention by the prime minister's spokesman was seen as a direct rebuke to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, after he had suggested British membership was "inevitable".

Mr Cook's unscripted remarks to trade unionists on Thursday night threatened to reopen divisions among cabinet ministers as to how quickly Britain should be moving towards joining the single currency.

The foreign secretary's observation appeared to gain credence after comments by the European Central Bank president, Wim Duisenberg, who said that Britain had now met most of the conditions for joining the euro and was "suffering greatly" by staying outside.

"The United Kingdom satisfies all the conditions for entry, except that of the exchange rate," he said in an interview with the Italian newspaper Il Sole 24 Ore.

"The performance of the British economy is admirable, but it is suffering greatly because it is not participating in the euro. That said, the decision is for the British people."

Mr Cook, together with Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson and trade secretary Stephen Byers, has been pressing to start campaigning for the euro before the general election - a move strongly resisted by Chancellor Gordon Brown.

Downing Street however insisted that while it was still the government's aim to take Britain into the euro, the economic conditions had to be right before it would recommend membership in a referendum.

"It's our objective to join a successful single currency, providing the economic conditions are met. It is not inevitable, but it's our objective," the spokesman said.

Mr Cook's comments came in a question-and-answer session after a speech in which he had stuck rigidly to the official line that the government's five economic tests had to be met before it would recommend signing up.

However, in response to questions, he pointed out that opinion polls showed that the majority of people in the country believed it was "inevitable" Britain would join, adding: "I think they are right."

His remarks coincided with some of the most pro-euro comments to date from Tony Blair during his appearance on BBC Question Time.

The prime minister said that, if the economy continued on its present track, the government would be able to recommend joining in a referendum early in the next parliament.

He warned that if the impression was given that Britain was not prepared to sign up to the single currency, inward investment would start declining "virtually overnight".

Mr Brown, meanwhile, was determinedly standing aside from the latest row, flatly refusing to answer journalists' questions about Mr Cook's remarks at a press briefing today on third-world debt relief.

"I am not here to do a press conference on the euro," he said.

Earlier this week, however, he insisted that the economic tests would be assessed "rigorously" before the government would consider putting the question of British membership to the public in a referendum.

Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo said the government was in a "state of disarray" over the single currency.

"Downing Street spin doctors have launched a panic rearguard action to try to cover up Robin Cook's remarks when he confirmed that the Labour government want to scrap the pound," he said.

"Ministers are not only committed to the euro in principle, but believe membership is inevitable. Their outlook for Britain is defeatist. They ignore the evidence that Britain can survive and thrive outside the euro."

fields.headline: EMU: Acting on a Wim
fields.standfirst: The standoff with super Eurobanker Wim Duisenberg will not                                        force Gordon Brown's hand on Britain's membership of the euro, writes City news editor Randeep Ramesh
fields.trailText: Friday, 1.30pm: The standoff with super eurobanker Wim Duisenberg will not force Gordon Brown's hand on Britain's membership of the euro, writes City news editor Randeep Ramesh.
fields.body:
Few things get under Gordon Brown's skin like Wim Duisenberg. Yet Europe's most important banker managed to do it again today with his observation that the UK has satisfied the criteria for joining the euro - and is suffering economically by not being a member of the club.

Only a few weeks ago Mr Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), took a swipe at the chancellor by saying that the only obstacle to Britain entering the single currency was "psycho-political" rather than economic.

Mr Brown would like to stifle debate on the single currency. He reasons that with more than two-thirds of the public against the euro and with an election looming, ditching the pound might snatch the Tories victory from the jaws of defeat.

Although Tony Blair talks of a referendum early in the next parliament over the issue of the euro, economics carries the casting vote. Mr Duisenberg's ECB is the final arbiter of whether the UK could sign up and will judge its application against the Maastricht criteria.

So how does Britain fare? The UK easily meets the inflation, budgetary and debt levels specified by the ECB.

But the biggest problem would be caused by the exchange rate, after the rapid rise of the pound against the euro. The Maastricht accords say that exchange rates must be kept stable for two years against other European currencies, within "normal" fluctuation margins of Europe's exchange-rate mechanism.

The strength of the pound means that signing up immediately is not on the cards. Here Mr Brown thinks he has outfoxed the wily Mr Duisenberg. For the unions and industry, the simple solution is to join the euro at a lower rate helping to defuse the sterling's strength - which is eating away at the manufacturing sector's profitability.

Mr Brown can bat away this argument with ease. To those who think that a quick devaluation followed by entry into the euro is the answer, the chancellor replies that any advantage would disappear as British costs rise faster than on the continent. The only way to reduce the "real" exchange rate would be higher unemployment or lower wages - and probably both.

So the British disease - that of low productivity - is the issue lurking below the surface of the current euro debate. Mr Brown's dilemma is not unfamiliar to Mr Duisenberg. He emerged as a fiscal disciplinarian and helped fashion the Netherlands' revival after a spell as a tax-and-spend Dutch finance minister in the 70s. The question is, having discovered tough-love policies himself, will Mr Duisenberg tolerate those who have yet to do so?

fields.headline: Cook says euro inevitable
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, last night claimed the British public were right to think membership of the single currency was inevitable.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, last night claimed the British public were right to think membership of the single currency was inevitable.

Mr Cook's remarks, immediately seized on by the Conservatives, came as Tony Blair indicated that on current economic trends he would be in a position to make a recommendation to join the euro early in the next parliament.

Mr Blair's forecast on BBC TV's Question Time appeared to breach the efforts of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to block off all discussion of the issue. Mr Brown has repeatedly said he will not give a running commentary on Britain's progress in meeting the five economic tests set down by the government for joining the currency.

Mr Cook's suggestion that membership of the currency is inevitable came at a meeting of Trade Unionists for Europe.

He said: "I welcome the fact that in those opinion polls that show a majority of people that are in favour of joining the single currency, they all show by the same two-thirds majority that they believe joining the euro is inevitable. I think they are right."

He pointed to the recent OECD survey suggesting Britain's economy was on course to converge with European economies, but added he did not think conditions were right yet.

Mr Blair was more optimistic than ever about the strides Britain was making. He said: "It would be wrong if I tried to bend the economic conditions in Britain to suit joining the euro, but what can I say if we carry on running the economic policy which we are at the moment - clearing up the deficit, the public finances in a healthy state, we've got the lowest inflation in Europe, if we carry on in this way then I believe we will be able to make a recommendation early in the next parliament."

He promised that if he thought the economic conditions were right: "I will lead that referendum fight and recommend British people joining. And even though it is unpopular with certain people, sometimes it is up to a prime minister to tell people what they don't want to hear as well as what they want to hear."

He refused to say he will resign if he loses the referendum, but "obviously if you were to recommend such a thing in a referendum and to lose it would be a pretty serious thing for you".

Mr Blair also intervened in the debate about overseas investment into Britain fuelled by the leak of memos suggesting British manufacturing could hit meltdown if Britain indicated it might not join the euro.

Mr Blair said: "In my view they are coming here in large part because we are part of the EU and part of the single market." He went on, to applause from the audience: "If we rule out the euro, and turn our back on the European Union, we are turning our back on the future of this country."

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, said Mr Cook was talking nonsense and that the euro was no more inevitable than Bolshevism was. "It is a disgrace that Britain's own government is talking down our currency," he said. "Robin Cook and Tony Blair have reignited Labour's internal battles over how to scrap the pound. This is another humiliation for Gordon Brown. It is open season on the chancellor."

Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, yesterday said he favoured an elected president of Europe with the power to choose his or her cabinet. He implicitly rejected a European government formed from national administrations, and suggested the president could be chosen by means of electoral colleges of the sort that existed in the US.

webTitle: Brixton prison first to be privatised

fields.headline: Brixton prison first to be privatised
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Brixton prison is to become the first state run jail to be privatised, it was decided yesterday by the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, and the prison service's director general, Martin Narey. The decision will be formally announced to the Commons early next week.
fields.body:
Brixton prison is to become the first state run jail to be privatised, it was decided yesterday by the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, and the prison service's director general, Martin Narey. The decision will be formally announced to the Commons early next week.

The south London prison, which opened in 1821, will be offered to a prison company after the discovery of a punishment scandal in which mainly young black inmates were locked in their cells for hours on end as part of an unauthorised regime without the knowledge of the governor.

Mr Boateng warned the prison's last governor, Bob Chapman, last November that his jail was officially regarded as a "failing institution" and told him that if it did not improve within 12 months it could face market testing.

Yesterday's decision was taken after the discovery of the punishment scandal and a snap inspection last week by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons.

He found such appalling conditions in the jail's healthcare centre that he immediately rang Mr Narey and asked him to visit the prison.

Mr Boateng, launching the annual report of the prisons ombudsman, said he was determined to ensure that there were changes in race relations inside prisons: "You should be under no illusions about that. Over the year ahead you will see clear and unequivocal markers and building blocks laid down which will show we are determined to get that right." It is believed that disciplinary proceedings are likely against those prison officers involved in running a "prison within a prison" at Brixton.

Stephen Shaw, the prisons ombudsman, highlighted two cases of racism in the prison service in his annual report. The first involved a "race relations officer" in one jail who accused a black inmate of "using his colour as his ace card" and another prison officer who was put on a charge for alleging that other staff were racist.

The decision to market test Brixton is a major blow to the prison service unions, as no existing state prison had yet been offered to Britain's burgeoning private prison industry. The service has also recruited a former private prison director, Stephen Twinn, to take over as Brixton's governor from Monday. Mr Twinn was the director of Group 4's first British prison, the Wolds, but soon went to work in Australia where he was recruited for the job in a telephone call.

It is believed that Group 4 is not bidding to run Brixton but two other companies which run British prisons, Premier Prisons and Securicor, are interested. An in-house bid by the current Brixton management and staff is also likely.

Mike Newall, president of the Prison Governors' Association, said yesterday it had been shocked by the decision: "It is a sad admission by the service that amongst its 40,000 staff and its senior management it does not have the capacity to turn around one failing prison."

webTitle: Man killed after row over hedge

fields.headline: Man killed after row over hedge
fields.trailText: A retired civil servant was shot dead yesterday after arguing with his neighbour over a hedge dividing their gardens.
fields.body:
A retired civil servant was shot dead yesterday after arguing with his neighbour over a hedge dividing their gardens.

The police armed response team was called to the area after neighbours reported shots at the home of Llanis Burdon, 56. A gun was taken from the scene.

Last night a 61-year-old man was being questioned by detectives about the incident.

A police spokesman confirmed that they were investigating reports that the row centred on a boundary dispute between the two neighbours.

Mr Burdon's wife, Pam, his son Craig, 26, and daughter Lynne, 24, were being comforted by neighbours.

The two men, both keen gardeners, lived next door to each other for more than 20 years and brought up their families together. They had also played in the same village football team.

But three years ago they were said to have fallen out after a plan to use part of their plots to build a bungalow collapsed.

Neighbours said they had applied for planning permission but something went wrong and they blamed each other. Despite the row, they had apparently patched up their differences and appeared to be on friendly terms again.

Both were described as being fanatical about their gardens to the point where they appeared to compete over who had the best landscapes. They had both retired early through ill health. Mr Burdon worked for the Environment Agency.

The men's homes, in the picturesque village of Talybont-on-Usk near Brecon, Powys, are divided by a 6ft conifer hedge.

Mr Burdon's widowed father, John Robert, said last night: "I am devastated. I can't believe my son has gone."

The police armed response team was called to the area after neighbours reported shots at the home of Llanis Burdon, 56. A gun was taken from the scene. Last night a 61-year-old man was being questioned by detectives about the incident. A police spokesman confirmed that they were investigating reports that the row centred on a boundary dispute between the two neighbours. Mr Burdon's wife, Pam, his son Craig, 26, and daughter Lynne, 24, were being comforted by neighbours. The two men, both keen gardeners, lived next door to each other for more than 20 years and brought up their families together. They had also played in the same village football team. But three years ago they were said to have fallen out after a plan to use part of their plots to build a bungalow collapsed. Neighbours said they had applied for planning permission but something went wrong and they blamed each other. Despite the row, they had apparently patched up their differences and appeared to be on friendly terms again. Both were described as being fanatical about their gardens to the point where they appeared to compete over who had the best landscapes. They had both retired early through ill health. Mr Burdon worked for the Environment Agency. The men's homes, in the picturesque village of Talybont-on-Usk near Brecon, Powys, are divided by a 6ft conifer hedge. Mr Burdon's widowed father, John Robert, said last night: "I am devastated. I can't believe my son has gone."

webTitle: Embryo cells ban breached by post

fields.headline: Embryo cells ban breached by post
fields.trailText: A loophole in the law on human embryo research has allowed British scientists to order by post from the United States a batch of cells that had artificially grown from a human embryo.
fields.body:
A loophole in the law on human embryo research has allowed British scientists to order by post from the United States a batch of cells that had artificially grown from a human embryo.

The cells are "stem cells", capable in theory of turning into any human body part, from skin to brain.

The transatlantic delivery of human cells, which were transported in dry ice from Wisconsin to Sheffield several months ago by the private postal carrier Federal Express, appears to make a mockery of the tight UK controls on experiments involving human embryos.

It increases pressure on the government to take a clear stance on the future of human embryo research in Britain, amid conflicting accusations that science is being held back or that the sanctity of human life is being jeopardised.

The cells were requested by Peter Andrews, professor of biomedical science at Sheffield University, who wanted to use them to study how human embryos develop.

He was told by the human fertilisation and embryology authority that he would not be breaking the law by importing the cells.

Yet if a British laboratory were to make stem cells available for general research in the same way the Americans did - by cultivating them from a human embryo left over from a donor's IVF treatment - it would be illegal.

"Under the current rules it would appear we are not supposed to produce cells like that, although it's a bit hazy," said Prof Andrews.

"We're certainly not supposed to produce cells for these purposes. What we want is some clarity."

Scientists are growing impatient with what they see as foot-dragging by the government over human embryo research.

Last year the government rejected its scientific advisors' recommendations to relax the rules, and instead it set up an expert inquiry.

The report has been delivered to ministers, but they have failed to make public its findings, or their reaction.

The report also looked at whether to permit limited human cloning, to allow creation of human embryos that would be sacrificed long before they developed into a recognisable precursor of a human being.

The Wisconsin team, led by Jamie Thomson, is the only group of scientists that so far has been able to take the fragile ball of stem cells, sometimes a single fertilised human egg, from which a human body grows, and from it cultivate a "cell line", a set of cells that goes on continually dividing and reproducing itself.

Some scientists believe that the application of a combination of stem cell manipulation and cloning techniques will enable them to grow replacement human body parts, tailored to match an individual person's unique tissue type.

Only one British laboratory, in Edinburgh, is trying to cultivate human stem cells from surplus donated IVF embryos. But the law forbids the embryos being used for anything except research into questions of fertility, whereas Prof Andrews' main research is into the causes of cancer.

Asked about Prof Andrews' importing the cells, a government spokesman said: "The research he has been doing is not illegal and doesn't breach any rules, so we wouldn't have any stance on it."

Paul Tully, general secretary of the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child, which opposes IVF, embryo research and cloning, as well as its more well known concern over abortion, said that the incident showed how few real powers the embryology authority had.

"The lack of a sound moral principle underpinning our embryology laws is bound to lead to all sorts of anomalies," he said.

webTitle: The prime minister's incredible shrinking smile

fields.headline: The prime minister's incredible shrinking smile
fields.trailText: I took myself down to the royal gallery in the House of Lords. It was stuffed with dignitaries, former prime ministers and chaps in medieval costume.
fields.body:
I took myself down to the royal gallery in the House of Lords. It was stuffed with dignitaries, former prime ministers and chaps in medieval costume.

There was a flourish of trumpets. Attendants in knee breeches shepherded us to one side, and down the aisle, marching solemnly abreast, came Black Rod, the Lord Chancellor, Madam Speaker, and Tony Blair. Heavens, I thought, I know we Brits are good at inventing ancient ceremonies, but does this always happen when the prime minister's son is caught by the cops face down in Leicester Square?

The prime minister looked more anxious and twitchy than I can recall seeing him. Gone was the vast crescent smile. (He reminds me of the Joker's line in the first great Michael Keaton Batman film. A politician says: "We want to make this city fit for decent people to live in!" and Jack Nicholson says with his Blair-type grin: "Decent people shouldn't live here. They'd be happier someplace else.")

It was replaced by a sort of oblong smile, like the hole in a pillar box. He seemed taut and nervous.

The occasion was, actually, the ceremony to mark the 100th anniversary of the Australian federation. This was not an enormous deal at the time because it was all so amicable. The Americans had a revolution, with Mel Gibson and imaginary patriotic slaves throwing off the British yoke. The Australians had an act of parliament, and in the Lords Hansard of the day you can see that after Queen Victoria gave her assent, they went on to consider the south Lancashire tramways bill.

As we waited for the speeches, MPs milled around, jockeying for position. Mr Blair will be pleased to know that both Tories and Labour were fully on his side. None of the opposition plans to make political capital out of Euan's misfortunes, except for the most manic, lunatic fringe - so no more than half the party, then.

Margaret Thatcher stood on her own for five minutes. It must be nervewracking to approach someone whose handbag is being auctioned on the net now for £101,000 - literally worth more than its weight in petrol.

As she took her place in the crowd, I could see a familiar figure trying to force himself next to her. It was my dear old friend Michael Fabricant, but just as he got there, disaster struck. Lord Carrington intervened between them.

Barbara Castle was there, glowering at Lady Thatcher and Mr Blair, neither of whom she cares for. It must be like "Mad Dog" Adair being made to choose between Gerry Adams and the Pope.

Bob Carr, the premier of New South Wales, popped over to remind her that he had sent her a case of finest Hunter Valley red to thank her for insisting on Australian rather than French wine at some dinner. "She told me she hadn't finished it yet," he said.

"Bad as that, is it?" I asked. "No, it's a fine wine to savour at length," he insisted.

Mr Blair worked the crowd, chatting to John Major, Lady T, and Bob Hawke. There is a soothing balm in talking to other prime ministers: they have all been there and done that. He looked much cheerier after a few minutes.

Then he and the lord chancellor made graceful speeches saying what a great place Australia was. The Aussie prime minister, John Howard, also made a graceful speech saying what a great place Australia was.

Moments later he was in the crowd, and to my surprise and delight, stopped for a long chat with my old friend.

"Fabricant."

"Yeah, I can see what yer hair's made of. Back in God's own country, we call that a 'platypus rug'."

"No, prime minister, my name, it's Fabricant."

fields.headline: Ethics? No, economics
fields.standfirst:
Too soon to relax this arms sales embargo on arms
Pakistan: special report
fields.trailText: The government's decision to relax the embargo on military sales to Pakistan is misguided and ill-timed. No matter that the 20 arms licences now to be approved exclude offensive weapons. General Pervez Musharraf has done nothing since launching last October's coup, roundly condemned by Britain at the time, to deserve what will be interpreted in Islamabad as a conciliatory gesture.
fields.body:
The government's decision to relax the embargo on military sales to Pakistan is misguided and ill-timed. No matter that the 20 arms licences now to be approved exclude offensive weapons. General Pervez Musharraf has done nothing since launching last October's coup, roundly condemned by Britain at the time, to deserve what will be interpreted in Islamabad as a conciliatory gesture. There is still no parliament, no constitution, no curbing of Pakistan's nuclear weapons, no dialogue with India (with which it nearly went to war last year), no action against terrorist groups linked to Kashmiri separatists and Afghanistan's Taleban, and no political route-map; only an endless vendetta against the elected, jailed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif.

Even when his performance is measured against his stated objectives, Gen Musharraf is all talk and no trousers. He has made little or no progress in prosecuting wealthy loan defaulters who milked the nation's banks, in rooting out bureaucratic corruption, halting tax evasion, or relaxing the anti-blasphemy laws. The firm smack of military governance has not ended sectarian violence nor brought a return of foreign investment. The country's external debt is a staggering $38bn and its takes half the annual budget to service it. Gen Musharraf has meanwhile succeeded in alienating Pakistan's traditional ally, the US, especially after President Bill Clinton's vain, embarrassing visit last March. The US imposed its own arms embargo in 1998, after Pakistan's and India's nuclear tests. Unlike Britain, it is sticking to it.

If this were not enough to give mandarins pause, Pakistan's military cooperation with China is flourishing. Recent US intelligence reports suggest Beijing is still assisting Pakistan's missile-building programme and may provide combat aircraft. This is part of a spiralling regional arms race, with Indian defence spending up a record 28% and deals for Russian T-90 tanks and Su-30 fighters in the pipeline. Britain is arming the Indians, too, hoping to pick up a £1bn contract for Hawk aircraft. On top of all this, the Indian cabinet this week flatly rejected an initiative from the Kashmir state government for greater autonomy, a rebuff likely to strengthen separatist sentiment and put further strain on tense Indo-Pakistan relations. So why, in such circumstances and at such a moment, is Britain resuming military sales to Gen Musharraf? You know why, silly. For the money.

webTitle: Mr Blair needs to calm it

fields.headline: Mr Blair needs to calm it
fields.standfirst:
Panic reactions make things worse
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Just when Tony Blair must have thought his luck could get no worse, it promptly did. While working late into the night on a speech aimed at boosting his beleaguered premiership, and with his wife away on a short break, Mr Blair got the kind of phone call every parent dreads.
fields.body:
Just when Tony Blair must have thought his luck could get no worse, it promptly did. While working late into the night on a speech aimed at boosting his beleaguered premiership, and with his wife away on a short break, Mr Blair got the kind of phone call every parent dreads. We discuss that below, hoping that Tony Blair, the father, will see this latest problem fade away smartly. The problems for Tony Blair, the prime minister, are made of rather more durable stuff.

All year he has seen his government bombarded with troubles. Whether the Dome, the NHS crisis or Ken Livingstone's victory, 2000 has brought almost unbroken cloud. But in the past month, the inclement weather has taken a more personal shape: it has been raining on Tony Blair himself. Since his turkey of a speech to the Women's Institute, Mr Blair has lost the ring of steel that once protected him. Now he is the target of highly personal abuse: whether from his former chief fundraiser, novelist Ken Follett, or from the whisperers in Westminster who fear the PM is losing his once-golden touch. Last week it was the absurd proposal for on-the-spot fines for drunken louts - an idea which looks all the more unfortunate now. On Wednesday it was a hapless performance in the Commons which added to the impression that something is going badly wrong: he looked tired, even scared, stumbling on his words and getting tongue-tied. His friends in the fairweather media have turned on him; the Tories have been scenting blood. Ironically, yesterday's unwanted episode with 16-year-old Euan may actually help: parents who know how hard it can be to raise a teenage boy will sympathise. The Conservatives may have to call off the dogs for a while.

But what explains this run of Blair trouble? Some say it is the pressure of a newborn baby taking its toll. Others note that, in politics, July can be "the cruellest month", the season when Westminster gets tired and tetchy - and Mr Blair is merely paying the price. But there are surely deeper causes at work. Mr Follett's attack hurt because it struck a nerve: too many people agree that the "rent boys" of spin have spun out of control. As one of their number put it yesterday: "Spin has become our sleaze." There is little Mr Blair can say to save himself because so little the government says is believed: its credibility has been eroded. To make matters worse, Labour lacks an army of friends to call up in moments of crisis - in the press and in its own ranks. Labour's national policy forum meets today, yet too many activists regard this body as a poor substitute for the (admittedly creaky) machinery it has replaced. They feel as if the party they once loved is no longer in their control: perhaps it never was, but the feeling is strong all the same. And there is hardly an old-style ideological crusade Mr Blair can ask the troops to rally behind.

What to do? The leader needs to hold his nerve and remain calm. He should refuse to be buffeted by the latest headline-dominating gusts, refuse to come up with instant populist wheezes to match the kneejerk offerings of the Tories. Labour has three big plans to unveil in the coming weeks: blueprints on health and transport as well as the comprehensive spending review. It should stick to these, and offer them in their entirety - without spinning off bite-size, gimmicky proposals for selected papers beforehand. That sort of news management tactic has been tried before: it only serves to undermine the long-term nature of the government's own work. Above all, Labour needs to keep a cool head - and to carry on governing.

fields.headline: Orangemen split on violence
fields.standfirst:
US cancels trade mission as protests continue
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Orangemen were increasingly divided yesterday as violent protests linked to the banned parade in Drumcree continued, causing a high-level American trade delegation to cancel its visit.
fields.body:
Orangemen were increasingly divided yesterday as violent protests linked to the banned parade in Drumcree continued, causing a high-level American trade delegation to cancel its visit.

A call by Harold Gracey, Portadown district master, for province-wide protests against the parade commission's ban on Sunday's annual parade down the nationalist Garvaghy Road sparked a fifth night of trouble. Belfast city centre was virtually deserted by early evening as workers left to avoid roadblocks.

The army patrolled the city for the first time in two years as the RUC came under intense pressure. It reported more disturbances in a day than in the whole of last year.

There were protests in at least seven other towns, and several Catholic families have been forced from their homes. But it was quieter at Drumcree, near Portadown in Co Armagh, and the trouble is less intense than in 1996 and 1998, the two most violent years in the six-year saga.

The Orange Order, also banned yesterday from parading on the Lower Ormeau Road in Belfast on July 12, called for an end to violence. But loyalists engaged in another orgy of car hijacking and burning and once more confronted the RUC at several flashpoints.

The Grand Lodge of Ireland said: "To those within our community who have perpetrated violence over the past 30 years being rewarded whilst the victims are ignored, it is tempting to believe that violence is the way forward. We cannot share that view. We should not stoop to the ways of our enemies."

But Presbyterian moderator Trevor Morrow said the statement did not go far enough, and deplored Mr Gracey's protest call. Street politics was uncontrollable and ripe for terrorist exploitation.

Mr Morrow said: "It is a known fact that many such protests get quickly out of con trol and thus those who call for and organise protests cannot escape responsibility for the consequences of their actions. As the Orange Order is patently unable to control these protests, their leadership should ask that they be called off."

Ulster Unionist MP Willie Thompson, an Orangeman, led calls for a rethink on strategy. He believed there was a danger the Orange Order was being seen implicitly to back violence, even if it publicly condemned the trouble.

The Orange Order did call for an end to protests, but only for today, to facilitate the funeral of motorcycling legend Joey Dunlop, killed road-racing in Estonia last Sunday. The cortege taking his body home to Ballymoney, Co Antrim, was severely delayed on Tuesday because of roadblocks.

Orangemen in Portadown were also coming under pressure to reconsider comments on Wednesday by the Parades Commission chairman, Tony Holland, when he indicated he was committed in principle to a march on the Garvaghy Road. They had earlier rejected his comments.

Johnny Adair, the leading figure within the Ulster Freedom Fighters, caused consternation after again appearing at Drumcree, on Wednesday night. He insisted yesterday he had done nothing wrong and called for peaceful protests.

Some sources fear he is trying to replicate the role played by Billy Wright, the late Loyalist Volunteer Force leader, in 1996. He orchestrated the violence which caused the RUC to relent and allow the banned parade to go ahead.

The US trade delegation pulled out of a meeting with Sir Reg Empey, the minister for enterprise. Its membership included a special adviser to vice-president Al Gore, Democratic candidate for president.

Orangemen in Portadown were also coming under pressure to reconsider comments on Wednesday by the Parades Commission chairman, Tony Holland, when he indicated he was committed in principle to a march on the Garvaghy Road. They had earlier rejected his comments. Johnny Adair, the leading figure within the Ulster Freedom Fighters, caused consternation after again appearing at Drumcree, on Wednesday night. He insisted yesterday he had done nothing wrong and called for peaceful protests. Some sources fear he is trying to replicate the role played by Billy Wright, the late Loyalist Volunteer Force leader, in 1996. He orchestrated the violence which caused the RUC to relent and allow the banned parade to go ahead. The US trade delegation pulled out of a meeting with Sir Reg Empey, the minister for enterprise. Its membership included a special adviser to vice-president Al Gore, Democratic candidate for president.

webTitle: Field thins for Dutch phone licences

fields.headline: Field thins for Dutch phone licences
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The first day of bidding for Holland's third generation mobile phone licences was overshadowed yesterday by the last-minute withdrawal of two contenders.
fields.body:
The first day of bidding for Holland's third generation mobile phone licences was overshadowed yesterday by the last-minute withdrawal of two contenders.

Just six groups are still in the running in the auction for the five UMTS licences on offer. That boosted industry hopes that the auction will prove less expensive than expected.

At the end of the day the Dutch mobile phone group Libertel was well ahead of the other groups, bidding €45.4m (£30m) for one licence.

Other bidders were more cautious with newcomer Versatel offering €200,000 for another of the licences while the top bids for the remaining three were all at the €100,000 level.

Bidding is expected to quicken over the coming days but analysts believe the final tally could fall well short of the 20bn guilders (£5.7bn) which some had expected.

The two companies to pull out yesterday were Hutchison 3G Netherlands and Nogenta Swedish Acquisitions, which is owned by NTL.

NTL said its decision reflected consolidation within the industry. France Telecom owns 25% of NTL and 80% of Dutchtone, another bidder.

The Hutchison move is seen as confirmation that it, Holland's KPN Telecom and Japan's NTTDoCoMo plan to bid jointly for third generation licences across Europe.

"The withdrawals support our view that UMTS costs are unlikely to be as high as ther market had been anticipating. This is very positive for the sector," said Bear Stearns analyst Fanos Hira.

fields.headline: French are talking to Eidos
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Infogrames Entertainment yesterday finally confirmed it is in talks with its British computer games rival, Eidos.
fields.body:
Infogrames Entertainment yesterday finally confirmed it is in talks with its British computer games rival, Eidos.

The French software group admitted it is considering buying the company behind games icon Lara Croft, although it added that discussions are far from concluded. "We are looking at the Eidos dossier in the same way we are looking at plenty of others, but we are not in the conclusive phase," an Infogrames spokeswoman said.

According to Reuters sources, the two companies are in talks about an all-shares offer pitched at 700p by Infogrames for the firm that created the Tomb Raider games.

The talks are said to depend on how the French management deals with bringing Eidos' creative team on to its board.

A series of profit warnings has knocked Eidos' share price, which now stands at 480p. If Infogrames persuades Eidos to accept an offer which could be worth more than £700m it will be buying more than just Ms Croft. Eidos has several other games in development, including spin-offs from animated film Chicken Run and TV show Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

Tomb Raider's success transformed Eidos from a Wimbledon-based video compression firm into a £1bn computer games firm which was named the world's most successful company by the World Economic Forum last year.

webTitle: Clinton wants $60bn missile defence system to fail test

fields.headline: Clinton wants $60bn missile defence system to fail test
fields.trailText: Senior officials in the state department, the Pentagon and the White House itself are opposed to a planned $60bn missile defence system and are privately hoping that a crucial test planned for late tonight will end in failure.
fields.body:
Senior officials in the state department, the Pentagon and the White House itself are opposed to a planned $60bn missile defence system and are privately hoping that a crucial test planned for late tonight will end in failure.

The test involves launching a rocket from a Pacific island and hitting an incoming mock warhead in space. If it succeeds, President Bill Clinton will come under heavy political pressure to give the national missile defence (NMD) scheme a green light before the November election - despite the concerns of some of his top advisers that the system is unworkable and destabilising.

"I think you have to say this is a dilemma, to say the very least," a political aide in the White House said. "And certainly it is possible to argue that a failure, or a mixed outcome, would be politically easier to handle at this time."

President Clinton, a reluctant convert to the NMD project after coming under heavy Republican attack for being soft on defence, had been hoping to pass on a decision on the scheme to his successor.

"He doesn't want to go down in history as the president who violated the ABM [anti-ballistic missile] treaty," said Chris Hellman, an analyst at the Centre for Defence Information thinktank in Washington.

But according to new Pentagon estimates, a decision has to be taken before the election on whether to go ahead with a key radar installation on Alaska's Aleutian islands, for it to be ready by the administration's self-imposed goal of having a basic network with 20 interceptors up and running by 2005.

By that time, NMD proponents argue, North Korea could be ready to launch a long-range missile at the US, armed with a nuclear, chemical or biological warhead. Other "rogue states" could catch up technologically soon afterwards.

But White House, Pentagon and state department officials have dissented from an intelligence report laying out the North Korean threat. They argue that it focuses purely on the communist nation's technological potential, and not enough on political, economic or social factors.

They also believe that the US faces a far greater threat from terrorists carrying a nuclear, chemical or biological bomb into the country in a suitcase. And there are considerable doubts among defence experts and scientists over whether the scheme will work.

Critics of the scheme say its Pentagon backers and contractors have rigged test results to hide the fact that the rocket-launched interceptors have serious problems distinguishing warheads from decoys.

webTitle: C&W and Nokia to develop net for the phone

fields.headline: C&W and Nokia to develop net for the phone
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless, the global telecoms company, has formed a joint venture with Nokia of Finland to develop an internet platform for mobile phones.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless, the global telecoms company, has formed a joint venture with Nokia of Finland to develop an internet platform for mobile phones.

The platform will provide web-hosting facilities that package together a range of software applications for mobile internet, tailored to the needs of a variety of customers.

Cable & Wireless has identified those customers as ranging from second and third generation mobile phone operators, dot.com companies, internet service providers and large corporations.

The announcement sparked some initial excitement from analysts, as it potentially extends Cable & Wireless's revenue stream beyond its core focus of providing data, internet and voice services to businesses.

"If this works out for them it could be very lucrative," said Jim Ross, analyst at ABN Amro.

"Going in with Nokia makes a lot of sense as the standards set for the next generation of mobile services are going to be fragmented and dominated by the big phone manufacturers."

Cable & Wireless and Nokia declined to reveal details of their investment into the joint venture or the likely revenue projections, claiming that the information was commercially sensitive.

Revenues are expected to be generated from access and web hosting charges, transaction fees and the provision of application service products. One analyst suggested the revenues could eventually be as much as £500m annually.

Mr Wallace said the mobile internet platform would be operating by the year end with Cable & Wireless providing the web hosting facilities from its data centres.

The joint venture has already signed several customers to the service.

Mr Wallace, however, said that the launch of the joint venture would have no effect on the company's financial forecasts.

In the next three years 350m people are expected to access internet content via mobile phones.

Market analysts Forrester expect internet revenues will soar from $5.3m to $3.8bn in 2005.

While Nokia claims the number of mobile phone users will reach 1bn by the end of 2002.

Based on these projections, Mr Wallace said it was possible for "loads of money" to be made in the internet mobile platform market.

"You can see this market's size, it's huge," he said. "By combining the strength of our global internet protocol infrastructure and hosting centres with Nokia's innovative wireless internet solutions and leading position in the mobile market, Cable & Wireless is opening up this new market for its customers."

The software applications that Cable & Wireless may provide from its web hosting facilities for the internet platform include news, weather to a service that is able to track a mobile users as they move from country to country and provide them with information that is relevant to their location.

Mr Wallace stressed that content for its mobile internet services would be provided by specialists firms.

Separately, Independent News' priced its flotation of iTouch at 100p-130p a share. iTouch provides international mobile consumer and corporate services and would be capitalised at £325m based on the mid-price of the indicative range.

webTitle: Geo goes for growth in video streaming

fields.headline: Geo goes for growth in video streaming
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Geo Interactive Media says it will consider selling some parts of the company over the next two years to focus on its growth business of video streaming - the technology which sends video signals to PCs and mobile phones.
fields.body:
Geo Interactive Media says it will consider selling some parts of the company over the next two years to focus on its growth business of video streaming - the technology which sends video signals to PCs and mobile phones.

The company said yesterday it was also looking at a trade sale of 6% of its stock to a strategic partner. Shares in Geo tumbled 117.5p yesterday to £10.675, having peaked in March at just over £34.

Eli Reifman, executive director of Geo Interactive, said that the directors - who own a total of 55% of the Israel-based company - would not sell any further shares in the next year to "provide a comfort level" to the market. "We don't believe there should be any other selling now as we don't believe the share price is where it should be," he added.

The strategic partnership is expected to focus on Geo's mobile division which is developing video streaming technology for handsets.

Video streaming compresses video signals - for example coverage of an event such as Wimbledon - and transmits them at high speed to PCs or mobile phone handsets. Geo is widely considered to be a leader in two-way video streaming.

So far, however, Real Networks has dominated the market in video streaming to PCs. This week the American company announced that it had signed a deal with Nokia to target mobile phones - news which hit Geo's share price.Mr Reifman said that Geo was happy with current trading in all its divisions - mobile, broadcasting, messaging and web radio. First-half revenues had exceeded expectations and the cash burn was in line with the business plan.

Analysts have forecast a cash burn of between $1.4m and $1.6m in the first half and twice that for the full year. Geo is expected to make its first pre-tax profit in 2000 of $3.9m, on revenues of $25m.

Darren Lauber, an analyst with WestLB Panmure recommends Geo as a "buy" with a target price of £23. He said the company's ability to focus its strategy and the strength of management had seen revenues leap from $950,000 in 1998 to $7.5m in 1999.

webTitle: Leaked speech reveals Putin's iron fist

fields.headline: Leaked speech reveals Putin's iron fist
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, will paint a bleak portrait of modern Russia in his first state of the nation address tomorrow - highlighting in stark detail the country's weaknesses and the numerous threats it faces, and providing an apologia for authoritarian rule. A draft version of the text of the speech which Mr Putin will make to Russia's lower and upper houses of parliament was leaked to news agencies in Moscow last night - revealing the essence of the new president's vision for the country for the first time since his election in March.
fields.body:
Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, will paint a bleak portrait of modern Russia in his first state of the nation address tomorrow - highlighting in stark detail the country's weaknesses and the numerous threats it faces, and providing an apologia for authoritarian rule. A draft version of the text of the speech which Mr Putin will make to Russia's lower and upper houses of parliament was leaked to news agencies in Moscow last night - revealing the essence of the new president's vision for the country for the first time since his election in March.

Summarising his hopes for the country, Mr Putin will say: "I see a rich Russia, a country where its citizens live well and the state is able not only to defend itself but to inspire respect due to its well-being and sufficiency." But he will make it clear that in order for this vision to be realised, serious problems needed to be addressed urgently.

Mr Putin, who has been criticised for authoritarianism since his appointment as former President Boris Yeltsin's prime minister last summer, will be unabashed about his treatment of the Russian media, several of whose leading voices have been arrested and face continuing investigation on criminal charges.

Mr Putin will claim that anti-Kremlin news outlets are not independent, but are being manipulated by political rivals. "Journalistic freedom has very quickly become a tasty morsel, not only for politicians, but for big financial groups. It has become a con venient tool for fights between clans and for exerting illegal pressure on the authorities."

Vladimir Gusinski, chairman of Media-Most, Russia's only independent media outlet was questioned for the fourth time this week, following his arrest and brief imprisonment on charges of defrauding the government of £7m. Andrei Babitsky, a leading reporter detained after his critical reporting of the Russian bombardment of Grozny, was banned from travelling to Bucharest to receive a prize for his reporting.

Mr Putin will insist again that Russia needs a dictatorship of the law and will claim that this concept does not signal a return to authoritarianism.

Hinting that Russia's position in the world was being challenged by hostile forces, he will say that for the first time in decades, Russia is faced by unspecified bodies who are angling for a radical shake-up of the world order. "This country has come face to face with those who count on separatism and a policy of a 'world without Russia'."

The only way to resist these forces, he concluded, was to strengthen power structures within the country.

Implicitly defending his handling of the war in Chechnya - in the face of international criticism - Mr Putin will detail once again the threat of terrorism, which has always been the Russian government's justification for its harsh military campaign in the separatist region.

He will also focus on one of the universally recognised problems at the heart of modern Russia - its ageing and rapidly diminishing popula tion and plummeting birth rate. "We face the real danger of becoming a senile nation," the speech reads.

Continuing his sombre list of hazards facing modern Russia, Mr Putin is to devote a chunk of the speech to portraying the weaknesses at the heart of the country's economy.

"Many of our companies remain uncompetitive. Many of them survive thanks only to the weak rouble, low energy tariffs, non-payments and barter," he writes. "The Russian business climate remains bad, business risks are extremely high."

He would like to see Russia pull itself from this state of eco nomic chaos without western aid - and will say that the country should not depend on international credits or the goodwill of world economic leaders. In what appears to be criticism of the west for the economic advice given during Russia's transition from communism, he will warn against using "simplistic" economic models and adds: "Nobody has ever succeeded in building his future using somebody else's templates."

To improve the economic situation, the state should ensure that courts became impartial and strong, in order to uphold laws regulating business and to minimise bureaucracy.

webTitle: Inquest into England £10m World Cup flop

fields.headline: Inquest into England £10m World Cup flop
fields.standfirst:
How England's world came to an end
Diary of a failed World Cup bid
fields.trailText: England last night began an inquest into its humiliating and expensive defeat in the contest to host the world's premier football tournament in 2006, which was won by Germany in a close run-off with the favourites, South Africa. However, the vote was marred by claims that delegates had received offers of money in return for votes.
fields.body:
England last night began an inquest into its humiliating and expensive defeat in the contest to host the world's premier football tournament in 2006, which was won by Germany in a close run-off with the favourites, South Africa. However, the vote was marred by claims that delegates had received offers of money in return for votes.

Officials from England's 2006 campaign - which cost £10m, almost twice that of any other country - appeared embarrassed at their exit in the second round of voting, claiming that the hooliganism during Euro 2000 had not helped their cause.

Sepp Blatter, the president of Fifa, world football's governing body, announced that the 24-member executive committee had voted 12-11 in favour of Germany, the closest such vote in World Cup history.

One Fifa executive, Charles Dempsey from New Zealand, abstained from voting in the final round, which killed South African hopes of becoming the first African country to stage a World Cup.

Mr Dempsey, who voted for England in the first two rounds, handed a lawyer's letter to Fifa officials claiming he had come under intense pressure leading up to the vote. According to Channel 4 News last night, Mr Dempsey was one of several delegates who reported having notes pushed under their hotel doors offering presents for their votes.

Trinidad representative Jack Warner, who was said to be one of the members who asked for the police to be called in, was reported as saying last night that the letter was "badly typed and looked rather strange". He took it to be a hoax.

webTitle: Vision of US-style president stirs up Europe debate

fields.headline: Vision of US-style president stirs up Europe debate
fields.standfirst:
French Presidency of the EU
European Union
Government of France
fields.trailText: Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, who electrified the Europe debate with a landmark speech earlier this year, yesterday outlined a vision of the continent's future that will appal Eurosceptics and risks undermining a tentative understanding emerging between Berlin, Paris and London.
fields.body:
Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, who electrified the Europe debate with a landmark speech earlier this year, yesterday outlined a vision of the continent's future that will appal Eurosceptics and risks undermining a tentative understanding emerging between Berlin, Paris and London.

Mr Fischer said he favoured an elected president of Europe with the power to choose his or her cabinet. He implicitly rejected a European government formed from national administrations.

"What one does not want is a weak president...a figurehead," he told the constitutional affairs committee of the European parliament in Strasbourg.

He suggested that the president of Europe could be chosen by means of electoral colleges of the sort that existed in the US and with the broad support of the majority of member states. As for the single currency, Mr Fischer called it the "first step to a federation".

His remarks created a new headache for Tony Blair who last week sent out a stream of positive signals on Europe and announced a keynote speech in the autumn to define Britain's position.

From now on, any move by the prime minister towards closer ties with the European Union risks being portrayed by his opponents as a step towards putting Britain at the mercy of a single, mighty European overlord.

In his earlier speech, on May 12, Mr Fischer appeared to build a bridge to those such as President Jacques Chirac in France and Mr Blair in Britain who are either ideologically unwilling or politically unable to consider a federal Europe. He said he shared the view that "nation states are realities that cannot simply be erased".

"The existing concept of a federal European state replacing the old nation states and their democracies as the new sovereign power...ignores the established realities in Europe," he said. Last month, Mr Chirac responded by endorsing a "United Europe of States", rather than a "United States of Europe". A few days later, on a visit to the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, whose officials had earlier endorsed Mr Fischer's vision, Mr Blair called on the British to see Europe as an opportunity rather than a conspiracy.

Yesterday, Mr Fischer again stressed the importance of the existing states. "The basic constitutional axis will be relations between the nations and Europe," he said. But he made it a lot more difficult for non-federalists to discuss, let alone endorse, his vision.

The ministers in his proposed cabinet, though chosen by the president of Europe, would need to win the confidence of a new, two-chamber European parliament which would have strong links to the member states.

Mr Fischer said there was no conflict between his ideas and the EU's short-term objective of agreeing a new treaty in Nice, where EU leaders are due to meet in December.

Mr Schröder's officials have called for a further round of inter-governmental talks in the EU to discuss "big issues" of the sort raised by the foreign minister. They foresee it starting as soon as national parliaments have ratified the treaty expected to be signed in Nice.

That would put the "big issues" on the table some time between 2003 and 2005. But Mr Fischer yesterday stepped up the pace. "We will have to embark on this discussion very soon after 2002 and take decisions, because otherwise Europe is heading for a major crisis in our view," he said.

Top of the agenda would be the form of a constitution to define the division of powers between Europe's regions, nations and its proposed federal institutions.

fields.headline: People-smuggling gang held
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: An Amsterdam-based human trafficking network, which is said to have spirited hundreds of illegal immigrants to Britain from Iran, has been broken up and 60 people arrested, Dutch police revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
An Amsterdam-based human trafficking network, which is said to have spirited hundreds of illegal immigrants to Britain from Iran, has been broken up and 60 people arrested, Dutch police revealed yesterday.

The move comes barely two weeks after the bodies of 58 Chinese people trying to get to Britain from Rotterdam were found in the back of a lorry at Dover and underscores the Netherlands' role as a key staging post for immigrants.

After a secret 10-month operation which targeted the organisation's Dutch-based leaders and fixers, police arrested 54 Iranians, three Iraqis, two Algerians and one Romanian.

A spokeswoman for the Dutch justice ministry yesterday said that at least eight people had already been sentenced, while 11 more were waiting to appear in court.

"The investigation is still ongoing so we can't say much about it. The people who have been sentenced so far have been convicted for drugs offences and faking passports." Nobody has so far been charged with human trafficking itself.

The authorities are certain that the smugglers were also involved in drug running. In a series of house raids police recovered five-and-a-half pounds of heroin and over two pounds of opium.

It is thought that the main smuggling network had four separate branches. The main network smuggled people from the Iranian capital, Tehran, to the Netherlands, while other offshoots were mixed up in forged passports, faked cheques and drug- running.

"There are several groups and smaller gangs busy with smuggling people. It's not simply about one group of 60 people," the justice ministry spokeswoman explained.

The smugglers do not seem to have been amateurs and were well organised. Some 265 foreign passports, a stash of weapons and a bundle of bogus cheques were also recovered in the raids.

Police yesterday described how immigrants prepared to pay an unspecified sum of money were supplied with visas from the French embassy in Tehran.

The fact that France is a member of the Schengen open borders agreement means that people with a valid French visa could, in practice, travel freely between any of the 10 Schengen countries without being stopped. Britain is not a member of the agreement.

The immigrants were kitted out with fake passports and new identities upon their arrival in Amsterdam and often went to the trouble of disguising their appearance before setting off for their final destination.

The Dutch investigation is likely to be seen as yet another sign that the Dover tragedy was not a one-off and that more needs to be done to thwart human trafficking networks in Europe.

EU heads of state have already vowed to come up with new Europe-wide measures to combat the trade.

fields.headline: Euro-sleuths smash slippery Mafia scam
fields.standfirst:
Subsidies paid for bogus butter
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: European Union fraud-busters have helped smash a huge Mafia-run scheme to sell fake butter and cheat the community budget of millions of euros in subsidies.
fields.body:
European Union fraud-busters have helped smash a huge Mafia-run scheme to sell fake butter and cheat the community budget of millions of euros in subsidies.

Details remain sketchy, but it is seems likely that thousands of tonnes of so-called butter, made in reality largely with oil meant for cosmetics and othert non-food use, ended up in food products. There is no suggestion so far that any reached Britain.

Officials in Brussels said yesterday they were delighted with the role played by Olaf, the European commission's new anti-fraud office, in ending one of the biggest scams of its kind.

Scores of arrests have been made in France and Italy after investigators discovered that more than 16,000 tonnes of supposedly pure butter was sold for more than €45m (£28.4m); EU subsidies were obtained as if the butter was real, and Olaf is still trying to determine the precise loss.

Olaf helped coordinate investigations by authorities in France, Italy and Belgium under its mandate to protect the £55bn community budget from fraud and organised crime.

Officials were bribed in 1997-99 to turn a blind eye to the bogus butter, which was made mainly from chemical additives, beef tallow and oil intended for cosmetics and other non-food uses. Much went into food production but large quantities were seized.

"In one case, a product seized in a Belgian factory which had originated in Italy contained no trace of milk or milk products," Olaf said.

Butter is subsidised in the form of export refunds, when the product is exported outside the union, or with aid towards the processing of butter used in baking and sold in the home market. The investigation began in 1999 when the anti-Mafia branch of the Naples prosecutor's office discovered that a gang of the Camorra, the Naples Mafia, had set up a "holding group" that had become a major producer of butter for industrial use in Italy.

Some 70 searches have been carried out at businesses and homes in Italy, France and Belgium in the past few weeks and there have been numerous arrests in Italy and France.

Created last year to replace a previous anti-fraud body, Olaf operates independently of the the commission under a German prosecutor chosen by Neil Kinnock, the commissioner in charge of administrative reform.

Earlier this year Olaf stepped up cooperation with Italy's elite anti-Mafia unit to clamp down on scams involving tobacco, olive oil and alcohol, where large slices of generous EU subsidies are creamed off by organised gangs.

fields.headline: Drop the debt
fields.standfirst:
There'll be another promise along in a minute
Debt relief: special report
<A
fields.trailText: The public has been fooled into believing the battle to reduce the third world's debt burden has been won, suggests a survey published today.
fields.body:
The public has been fooled into believing the battle to reduce the third world's debt burden has been won, suggests a survey published today.

Repeated announcements by western leaders that they are cancelling 100% of poor countries' loans have convinced more than half the population that debt is no longer a problem, according to Cafod, the Catholic development agency that commissioned the survey.

In reality, since leaders from the Group of Seven main economies grabbed headlines last June with a promise to write off loans worth $100bn from the world's poorest countries, they have delivered just $2bn in extra debt relief.

"Cafod's poll confirms our worst fears," said Henry Northover, the agency's policy adviser. Debt campaigners gathered outside the Treasury in London and in Tokyo yesterday to urge more action from G7 finance ministers preparing for their meeting this weekend in Japan.

"Gordon Brown and the other G7 finance ministers have the power to get the debt process back on track," said Jessica Woodroffe, head of campaigns at the World Development Movement, part of the Jubilee 2000 coalition. "It is time to stop spinning and drop the debt."

Only $25bn of the $100bn which the G7 promised in Cologne last year is new money - the rest would have been cancelled under existing agreements.

Progress through the World Bank and IMF's debt relief programme has been painfully slow. G7 leaders set themselves a target of getting 25 countries through the process by the end of 2000. By the time they meet this weekend, only 10 countries are expected to have started the process and only one, Uganda, will have benefited from any debt cancellation.

fields.headline: No: 1672
fields.standfirst: Chikage Ogi
fields.trailText: Chikage Ogi
fields.body:
Age:
67.

Appearance:
Vacuous.

Occupation:
Daytime TV star and politician.

Like Robert Kilroy-Silk?
Far more modest.

Not difficult.
Let's keep to the point.

Japanese, presumably?
Spot on. She is the leader of the Japanese New Conservative Party and has just been made construction minister.

Fascinating. Look, you couldn't do Claudia Schiffer, could you? I'm sure she clinched it for Germany in the World Cup battle.
Aren't you interested in Japanese politics?

I can think of more compelling subjects.
Such as?

Saxon place names, cricket memorabilia, the collected works of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow . . .
OK, you've made your point. Let's get back to the minutiae of Japanese domestic politics.

You win. So why does Ms Ogi, rather than, say, Ms Schiffer, deserve the accolade of a place in the Pass Notes pantheon?
She is the world's least likely cabinet minister.

Less likely than Mo Mowlam?
It's close, but yes. "Why me?" she said when prime minister Yoshiro Mori told her of the appointment. Since the former dancer, film actor and TV celebrity admits to knowing nothing about construction and has no previous cabinet experience, the rest of the country wondered too.

Well, why her?
Because no one else wanted the job. The previous incumbent, Eiichi Nakao, was arrested last week on corruption charges, and no one else in the notoriously dodgy Liberal Democratic Party would touch the job. Ogi, head of the junior member of the ruling coalition, came with no baggage.

And no knowledge.
While a little knowledge is a dangerous thing, absolutely no knowledge at all is a huge advantage in the corrupt world of Japanese politics.

Ms Ogi's only known bon mot:
"All LDP members have some sort of guilty conscience."

Do say:
"Ogi, Ogi, Ogi, Oi, Oi, Oi" (preferably in very loud Japanese).

Don't say:
"Anthea Turner for chancellor!"

But above all don't say: "Turn to page 16 for the full story."

fields.headline: 'I'm not Crybaby Soo-Fi any more'
fields.standfirst: She says he made her life a living hell. He says she's been brainwashed.  Simon Hattenstone and  Emma Brockes unravel the complex relationship between a teenage prodigy and her driven father
fields.trailText: She says he made her life a living hell. He says she's been brainwashed. Simon Hattenstone and Emma Brockes unravel the complex relationship between a teenage prodigy and her driven father
fields.body:
It is Mrs Yusof who comes to the door, in the hours after her daughter Sufiah is found safe and unhurt, two weeks after disappearing from Oxford. She is holding back tears, inclining her head to convey her relief and letting her shoulders droop, just a little, under the effort of hanging on.

In the background of the family's Coventry home, her husband Farooq can be seen smiling broadly and steering a concerned relative towards the door. When he joins his wife on the porch he seems very upright by her side, still smiling, expertly convivial. She rests her headscarfed brow against his shoulder. "We are very relieved," he says. "Very, very relieved. I just want to put my arms around her."

But Farooq Yusof will not be embracing his daughter just yet. After she was found yesterday afternoon, Thames Valley police took the unusual step of revealing that Sufiah had requested that her whereabouts should remain secret - even from her parents. This detail seemed a damning coda to a vituperative email she had sent her family earlier in the week. Her father had responded to it by suggesting Sufiah had gone off the rails, had suffered a breakdown. Others suggested she had never sounded more sane.

"I've finally had enough of 15 years of physical and emotional abuse," wrote Sufiah. She vowed never to return to the "living hell" of home. "I see you've taken the liberty of running to the national newspapers with the story of how your 'innocent and naive daughter' has run off from a 'happy home' with some nasty socialists and boyfriends . . . anyway, this is a practical email. I want, first thing tomorrow, to read about how I'm safe with relatives or family friends in Scotland or London. Otherwise I'll go to the press with my side of the story first thing tomorrow afternoon, I mean it."

But Sufiah didn't need to go to the press. In the same email she told her side of the story, accusing her father of ruining his five children's lives by hothousing them, of exploiting her older brother's tennis skills for money, of labelling her "Crybaby Soo-Fi" as part of his motivation technique. Worst of all, she said that when she was 11, two years before she started her maths degree at Oxford University and when everything was apparently fine, she had twice tried to kill herself. "Maybe the public will have a different view of you as devoted parents . . . I'm not Crybaby Soo-Fi any more."

Sufiah disappeared just after finishing her exams for a masters on June 22. She failed to board a train from Oxford to the family home in Coventry, where she was expected to return for the holidays. Her email came in response to a disquieting interview her father had given to the Times on Tuesday. "It's highly improbable that we will ever see her again," said the 43-year-old researcher, a former prodigy himself. "The police investigations won't come to anything." He talked of third parties and conspiracies. "They have disengaged her from her strength, which is her family and specifically myself. They have got into her mind. Brainwashing is I think the correct term . . . Even if we get her back it won't be the same Sufiah."

"Barring disaster, she should get a grade A," declared Yusof at the time. By September of that year, there she was at the women-only St Hilda's college, 13 years old and looking forward to life as an undergraduate. She had managed to beat Ruth Lawrence to a mortar board by a few months.

"We felt that the children were growing up in an environment giving them the wrong messages . . . the public is programmed for disposability, novelty and continual change." He never claimed his children were geniuses, not even gifted. It was just that they had been taught properly - primarily by him. He claimed he could teach virtually any child in the same way, and that he would write a book about his methods. There were strict rules - the house had to be cold to improve concentration, Islamic prayers had to be said first thing in the morning, followed by stretching and breathing exercises. Fresh air was essential for a fresh mind. Television and pop music were banned.

For someone so bright, interviews with Sufiah were surprisingly bland. She didn't talk to the press, she gave statements. "I am looking forward to starting my time here . . . I want to join the university tennis team and Oxford has wonderful facilities for this." Her father revealed that at 12 Sufiah had been among the country's top eight junior players.

She was asked how her friends felt about her going off to university. "Of course, I have different friends, so they have different opinions," she reasoned. "But most of them are quite pleased for me and I think on the whole they have expressed very positive reactions."

Laura Paskell-Brown, who spearheaded the tuition fee protest at Oxford 18 months ago, remembers Sufiah as an inhibited little girl. "I always saw her alone. I never saw her with anyone else. By now the family had so many stories to tell that they asked the Northamptonshire News Agency to mediate for them. Every one of Yusof's children seemed to come complete with their very own record, their own headline. "The youngest member of Britain's brainiest family has mastered the mysteries of A-level maths - at the age of five," ran one typical story.
