But even here there were records to be claimed - they became the youngest brother and sister to study together at the same university.

The family faced practical problems, though. They had to divide themselves between Warwick and Oxford. They rented a house opposite the university in Coventry, and Sufiah would go home for holidays.

The Farooqs live in a detached house obscured from a busy road by six fir trees and overgrown foliage, directly opposite the main entrance to Warwick university. "Tarl-Lea" reads the name plate fixed between the green garage door and the frosted glass of the porch through which can be glimpsed the twee furnishings of a comfortable family home: a tasselled lamp, an over-stuffed sofa and a slightly garish carpet.

A neighbour whose children have played with the Yusofs says: "My child is four and Sufiah is 15. But my child is the more sociable. They have never allowed the children to develop socially. When they come and play they want to run around and make a noise, but Halima is very strict with them."

But socialising has never been a priority for the Yusofs. When the two children went to Warwick, Yusof continued to expand on his philosophy of learning. "We offer an opportunity which gives opportunities for self-fulfilment and Aisha cannot have a boyfriend. That would not be considered as being to her optimal benefit." He insisted that there was more to the ethos than achievement. "It's all about love and understanding - praising what they do, giving value to it and taking a pride in it." He added: "Most people's lives are shoddy, shifting and unstable."

The family became role models for accelerated learners. Edward Chitham of the National Association for Gifted Children says, "No family on our books has got anywhere near this sort of record."

Warwick University says it took more than a year to negotiate the arrival of Aisha and Iskander. Peter Dunn, university press officer, says Warwick laid down the law to the Yusofs. "Our edict was that after they started here there would be no media attention until they finished, and the parents agreed to this. We also insisted that the family take up residence near the campus. We didn't think it was appropriate for them to live on campus as normal students."

Dunn believes that university has been good for the two children. After all the publicity of their early years, it has allowed them to recover their anonymity. He says Sufiah's brother and sister are both keeping up with their fellow students but have not raced ahead.

David Robertson, who was dean of the Oxford college from which Ruth Lawrence graduated, thinks, with the benefit of hindsight, that university is the wrong place for prodigies. He says they "can only get through universities by effectively not being there. They do not experience undergraduate life: having been cheated of the joys as well as the tribulations of the later school years, they go on to skip another formative experience."

There have been many problems with the adolescence of Sufiah Yusof, trapped between two worlds, neither an adult nor a child. She seems to have embraced some of the adult experiences - becoming a member of various societies and attending meetings of the Socialist Workers' Party. This, says Yusof, is where things began to go wrong, when she became contaminated by outside influences.

Yesterday, soon after it was announced that she was safe, her mother told reporters outside her home: "We are gathering our thoughts and saying our prayers. At least we know she is alive." It was one of the first times we have heard her speak.

Yusof said he was relieved she was safe, would wait for her to come home in her own time, and repeated that he believed there was a third party involved. "It's in the hands of the relevant authorities... obviously she's scared." Was there any truth in Sufiah's allegation that he had abused her? "There is no validity in any of this," he said.

Has all of this trouble made him rethink his teaching methods? " Our teaching methods," his wife answered abruptly. Halimahton said Yusof has been "out of his mind with worry. He's been wandering up and down the streets looking for her. The other children have hardly known he is here." He held up his hand to stop her going any further. She mumbled to a stop. "...Why should we have to justify ourselves as parents?"

Yusof took over and beamed his big smile. "We are a fun-loving family enjoying life," he said. "What else is there?"

webTitle: Favourites South Africa left out in the cold

fields.headline: Favourites South Africa left out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: South Africa cancelled a nationwide party yesterday as the country tipped to become the first in Africa to stage the World Cup did its best to swallow disappointment after being edged out by Germany.
fields.byline: John Perlman and Reuters in Johannesburg
fields.body:
South Africa cancelled a nationwide party yesterday as the country tipped to become the first in Africa to stage the World Cup did its best to swallow disappointment after being edged out by Germany.

The former president Nelson Mandela, who put the full weight of his international prestige behind his country's bid, was visibly disappointed when the news broke.

"Although our team did an excellent job there were certain finishing touches, because of our inexperience, which we didn't do. I am very sorry that we lost," he said.

Mr Mandela's successor, Thabo Mbeki, vowed that South Africa would win the 2010 World Cup bid.

"It is a tragic day that their message and ours did not succeed to convince the majority on the Fifa executive that Africa's time has come," Mr Mbeki told reporters. "Next time we will win."

Parties planned across the country were cancelled or fizzled out. Waitresses at a VIP function in Cape Town quickly whisked away champagne that had been specially ordered in expectation of victory.

Trading on the Johannesburg stock exchange the previous day had been boosted by optimism from Zurich and shares in construction, retail and hospitality and tourism all climbed. The country's leading hotel chain lost 8.3% on its share price after the news, and the rand slid against the dollar.

Customers in packed bars in the former township of Soweto groaned, while crowds in Durban were stunned into silence.

"I am devastated," said Hendrick, 48, choking back his tears in a Soweto bar.

Howard Krut, a retailer in Cape Town, said: "It just shows that first world European powers will never give away money and opportunity to Africa. To have expected them to be charitable was naive."

South African soccer officials and stars denounced the decision, saying it was unfair for Europe again to hold the competition.

The leader of the bid, Danny Jordaan, said in Zurich: "Africa is a member of the Fifa family and a family can't keep feeding one child and leaving the others to starve, which is what they have done today."

One of the country's top players, Quinton Fortune, who plays for Manchester United, said: "It is very disappointing. I thought it was 100% that we would get it. It's very sad that Europe is getting it again."

webTitle: MPs demand NHS reins in consultants

fields.headline: MPs demand NHS reins in consultants
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: An outright ban on NHS consultants increasing their income through private work was proposed yesterday by the Commons health select committee as the long-term answer to unfairness in the health service.
fields.body:
An outright ban on NHS consultants increasing their income through private work was proposed yesterday by the Commons health select committee as the long-term answer to unfairness in the health service.

The report, pushed through by Labour MPs against opposition from the Conservatives, raised suspicions that some consultants "are driven by perverse incentives into maintaining long NHS waiting lists in order to stimulate lucrative private practice". The MPs said they could not prove this charge, but concluded: "What is indisputable is that NHS patients wait longer than private patients, and that private earnings are highest in those specialties where NHS waiting times are longest."

The tone of the report was a lot more hostile to the private sector than ministers had been over recent weeks. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has said he wants to use private hospitals to reduce NHS waiting lists. He also suggested it was not possible to force consultants to abandon private practice, although merit bonuses might in future be directed to those who worked only for the NHS.

In contrast, the MPs said it was indefensible the system allowed patients of equal clinical need to go ahead of others because of their ability to pay.

"Therefore we believe the government should make it a long-term objective that consultants in the NHS do not undertake private practice...The NHS was founded on the principle of equity: it should put that principle into practice."

The MPs noted an argument from the British Medical Association that a ban on private work might make some consultants leave the NHS. But other consultants might decide it was in their best interests to work solely in the NHS. The government should research the consequences and work out incentives to keep the best consultants in the NHS, the MPs said. Their report was published after a three-week inquiry into the contracts of the 25,000 NHS consultants. It found that their average NHS salary was £68,000, but about two-thirds also undertook private practice.

Last year their average private earnings were £10,790, but there was a huge variation in the income potential of specialities, ranging from £75,413 for plastic surgeons to £5,000 for pathologists.

Since the NHS began in 1948, full-time consultants have been entitled to increase their earnings by up to 10% by taking on private practice.

Those on "maximum part-time" contracts gave up one eleventh of their salaries in return for the freedom to earn as much as they like privately, as long as they fulfilled their NHS commitments. About 70% work on whole-time contracts, the remainder as maximum part timers.

The report said hospital trusts did not enforce the 10% rule for whole-timers and did not collect enough information to keep track of the hours worked within the NHS by maximum part-timers.

David Hinchliffe, the committee's Labour chairman, said: "There would be problems in stopping consultants from working in the NHS and in private sectors, but I think there are generational differences. Medical students and junior doctors I have talked to agree that it is an unfair situation. I think the government has to take a long-term view. What we need to do is write into junior doctors' contracts that they can only work for the NHS, and give them incentives to sign those contracts."

Peter Hawker, chairman of the British Medical Association's consultants committee, said: "Given the shortage of consultants and the long-term investment required to increase their numbers, we think it is unrealistic, even as a long-term objective, to oblige consultants to choose between a wholly NHS or wholly private sector career.

"We believe it is right for patients to have choice, and that it is entirely possible to have the two sectors working alongside each other."

webTitle: How England's world came to an end

fields.headline: How England's world came to an end
fields.standfirst:
They threw the best parties and offered the most lavish hospitality. They also spent twice as much as anyone else. But when it came to football politics, they were embarrassingly outclassed
Diary of a failed World Cup bid
Inquest into England £10m World Cup flop
fields.trailText: They threw the best parties and offered the most lavish hospitality. They also spent twice as much as anyone else. But when it came to football politics, they were embarrassingly outclassed
fields.body:
The English dream of staging the 2006 World Cup was born amid the hype and euphoria of Euro 96, which won praise for its organisation from international football officials. It died amid the mayhem and violence caused by English fans at Euro 2000. But the writing was on the wall long before the first glass was hurled in Belgium.

The last rites to England's dream were administered in Zurich yesterday, but it was always going to be an uphill struggle - raising questions as to why England continued to pursue 2006 over the last three years knowing that it did not have backing from the two main organisations in world football: Uefa, the sport's European governing body, and Fifa, which is responsible for world football.

It was a bit like a political candidate standing for election without the support of their national or constituency party.

From the outset, England entered the race on weak moral ground. Soon after Euro 96, the Football Association said it intended to bid for the World Cup, winning support from Labour and the Tories.

The Germans, who had also announced their intention to bid, cried foul: a gentleman's agreement had been drawn up with England - in return for German support for Euro 96, England had agreed to back Germany for the World Cup in 2006.

The deal had been agreed between Sir Bert Millichip, former FA chairman, and Lennart Johansson, president of Uefa. But English 2006 officials, led by the campaign director Alec McGivan, said there was no written proof of any such agreement and that it had all been a misunderstanding.

Privately, football and government officials agree that there was such a deal. England's decision to back out was to have disastrous consequences for the campaign.

Johansson, who is also a member of Fifa's executive committee which voted in Zurich yesterday, was annoyed at the attitude of the English. He insisted that Uefa, which has eight votes on the committee, should back Germany.

Only David Will, the Scottish representative on Uefa, was persuaded to back England in yesterday's vote but that still meant seven crucial votes were ruled out. A source said: "There was a fundamental weakness from the start of England's campaign. We all knew about the gentleman's agreement and Johansson was part of it. He was in the room when the deal was done and he was virtually being accused by the English of being a liar. It's not a very good idea to alienate someone so powerful within world football.

"It also meant that England were seen as bad sports who could not honour their word. That did not go down too well with Fifa officials."

The sports minister, Kate Hoey, is also said to be annoyed at the backtracking on the gentleman's agreement, one of the main reasons she has not wholeheartedly given her support to the 2006 campaign.

"It's against everything she stands for. It showed that the English campaign lacked moral fibre," said a government source.

In addition to missing out on the crucial support of Uefa, England suffered another blow when Sepp Blatter, Fifa's president, said it was time for a country from Africa to host the World Cup for the first time.

Without backing from football's established organisations, England's 2006 officials pushed on relentlessly, basing their campaign around trying to draw support from Fifa delegates outside Europe.

Sir Bobby Charlton and Sir Geoff Hurst, two 1966 World Cup heroes, were brought in as the public face of the campaign and spent three years travelling the globe visiting dozens of countries.

The former sports minister Tony Banks became the prime minister's special envoy on the campaign and it soon became apparent that nothing would stand in the way of the quest to land the tournament. Lavish dinners were held in London, one in the company of Prince Charles, while expensive parties were thrown at Fifa meetings and other football events.

During the 1998 World Cup in France, England 2006 officials hired a luxurious villa. The most recent party was thrown in Nassau as England attempted to persuade the three north and central American delegates to Fifa to vote for their bid. Fifa delegates also attended matches and enjoyed hospitality in England.

The English bid also focused, at great cost, on developing football in countries where votes could be won. Training ses sions were held in countries such as Trinidad and the former Aston Villa striker Peter Withe was appointed manager of Thailand's national team in an attempt to win favour with their Fifa delegate.

In one of the most cynical chapters of the campaign, Manchester United were allowed to withdraw from the FA Cup to compete in the world club championship in Brazil this year. It was an attempt to win three south American Fifa votes but proved a public relations disaster.

Among all four competing countries and Fifa officials, it soon became apparent that the English hosted the best parties and offered the best hospitality and would do anything to curry favour with delegates. But that counted for little when it came down to football politics.

Former 2006 employees claim huge amounts of money were wasted on ensuring that English officials stayed at the best hotels and travelled in luxury. One said: "There was no doubt that all those who represented the campaign wanted the best. They were not real political animals and could never quite get their heads around the lobbying that such a contest needs but they all had a great time.

"We were concerned at how much money was being spent on hotels, weekends away and during tournaments. I remember during France 98 most of the campaign team stayed in the villa. There was no need for all of them to be there."

The bid cost just over £10m, almost double that spent by any other country. Most of that came from the Football Association and the Premier League but just over £3m came from the national lottery.

A source said: "You have to ask why football, which is the richest sport in the country, was given lottery money. It was obvious that our team lacked the clout of Germany or South Africa."

Questions will also be asked at the involvement of Mr Banks and Mr McGivan in the campaign. Mr McGivan, a former senior official of the Social Democratic Party, has been criticised for his lack of charm and inability to understand the intricacies of international football politics.

Despite relentless campaigning he was unable to win over Fifa delegates and was considered no match to the stature and smoothness of Franz Beckenbauer, head of the German bid, and Danny Jordaan, who ran the South African attempt.

Mr Banks has been criticised for his outbursts against anyone criticising the 2006 campaign and for his comments against Fifa officials last week, when it became apparent that England's bid was doomed.

A source said: "England lacked charismatic figures in their campaign. Bobby Charlton is a great name but does not have the same standing in the world game as Beckenbauer. The team was made up of people who just believed that England is the best. They have been very arrogant."

English officials will look back on the hooliganism at Euro 2000 and Uefa's subsequent threat to throw the team out of the tournament as the moment when the bid went wrong. But for many, the crucial moment came in May when Arsenal and Galatasaray fans fought in Copenhagen before the Uefa Cup final. Pictures of the violence were beamed around the world.

A World Cup source said: "The violence in Copenhagen really shocked Fifa. The feeling was that England had nice grounds, a nice campaign and lovely brochures - but can you really reward a country whose fans behave so badly? That was a real turning point." Soon after, Jack Warner of the Concacaf federation, which represents north and central America and the Caribbean and was considered one of England's main supporters, advised England to withdraw. It was good advice but an early withdrawal would have been too embarrassing.

In the end, the violence proved a convenient get-out clause. Few within international football actually expected England to win the 2006 contest but it give English organisers a chance to use the hooliganism as the perfect excuse for the demise of their bid. In reality, England were never expected to get past the second round - and so it proved yesterday at the end of a costly and heartbreaking campaign that culminated in two sorry votes and another early English exit.

fields.headline: Eurofighter team combats the stereotype
fields.standfirst: Britain's supposedly flexible working practices fail to measure up against the Germans
fields.trailText: In Britain, supposedly the European model for flexible working, they would be aghast: highly skilled German engineers are working six-hour shifts with just a 2-minute "comfort break" to produce ultra-sophisticated components for the central fuselage of the new Eurofighter combat aircraft.
fields.body:
In Britain, supposedly the European model for flexible working, they would be aghast: highly skilled German engineers are working six-hour shifts with just a 2-minute "comfort break" to produce ultra-sophisticated components for the central fuselage of the new Eurofighter combat aircraft.

Germany along with France are reviled among many British politicians as the epitome of a rigid labour market, and this work pattern seems the ultimate in bureaucratic organisation. But at the DaimlerChrysler Aerospace (Dasa) plant here, once home to the Messerschmitt fighters that took on the RAF in 1940, the 1,900 staff are palpably happy. They enjoy a 32-hour week and long holidays - and the management rejoices in productivity and efficiency gains.

The obvious relaxation among the employees, many of them in shorts and baseball caps, and degree of precision engineering emanating from glass-enclosed, robot-controlled machine tools bear out the conclusions of a recent Trades Union Congress survey on the "flexibility myth".

This found that, despite the conservative analysis that Europe's inflexible labour markets, made worse by costly social protection and high employment taxes, are the root cause of continental joblessness, the euro-zone economy "is not the basket case its critics allege". The case is buttressed by the looming dispute at Peugeot's main British plant at Ryton, Coventry, over weekend shift-working.

Workplace productivity in France and Germany is 20% higher than in Britain, while the French have 40% more capital behind them per hour worked. In Germany, where the shock of reunification in the past decade has seen jobs lost outweighed by jobs gained, productivity growth is higher than in Britain, even though collective bargaining covers 92% of workplaces compared with just 47% in Britain.

The German federal labour office said yesterday that moderate wage inreases and modernisation of production processes helped cut the jobless rate to 9.1% in June.

Lutz Bertling, the Augsburg plant's director, has turned the traditional German virtues of hard work and discipline and the new flexibility to his advantage. He has introduced a pattern of four six-hour shifts in order to keep computerised machinery working 24 hours a day six days a week and raise productive "uptime" from last year's 55% to 80% next year.

Apart from that comfort break, his engineers stay on the line for the full six hours. It means working one Saturday in four but, says Mr Bertling, the result is a "win-win situation" for employees and company.

"It enables the staff to plan their day so their partner can go out to work too, and they're home in time to pick up the kids," he says. "They work 32 hours but get paid for 35 hours and we can increase both production and efficiency."

Under his model an engineer can "bank" up to 200 extra hours of work a year and can take at least 120 hours of that in the form of extra holidays and if he or she cannot take all of that they get 15 "free" hours credited to their account. The only snag is that they can't take any of their "time account" in extra cash - unless they quit Dasa.

The effect is to reduce overtime, the traditional source of extra income in Britain, to 2.5% of working time and to enable the plant to notch up a 30% increase in machine operating hours or 6,500 hours per year. So far, however, costs have been cut by just 6%, but Mr Bertling is keen to extend his model throughout the plant and win bigger gains.

"The works council, which is wholly IG Metall (Germany's biggest union), is dead against; but the employees are completely in favour and so are we," he says, pointing to a board showing a production unit's monthly scores against targets for output, waste, accidents and breakdowns.

The new work scheme has been negotiated, not imposed. One effect has been to increase employment at the plant, where the workforce reached 2,250 at the peak of Tornado production before falling back to 1,500. The extra staff are required to keep the plant running 24 hours a day and, as Eurofighter output increases towards its peak of 55 planes a year, even more labour will be hired.

Dasa's experience in Augsburg bears out the growing trend in Germany to negotiate in-house, away from the central bargaining process and the spotlight of publicity, a series of working patterns that offers flexibility and productivity gains. And this within an overall system that offers a relatively high minimum wage, employment rights and organised consultation, all anathema to many corporate executives and politicians in Britain.

The TUC says its own analysis "shows that deregulation has little to offer the European economies and that the further modest advances in employee rights currently being advanced in Europe cannot automatically be dismissed as burdens on business that threaten competitiveness."

At its conference last year even the CBI noted that "there is not a simple UK versus the continent distinction but instead different strengths and weaknesses in each country ... One policy cannot fit all."

Labour MP Denis MacShane and Chris Brewster, professor of management at Cranfield university, said in a recent Fabian Society pamphlet: "The UK is not the leading nation in Europe in any of the flexible working practices - except for the family-destroying practice of excessive overtime."

Britons work on average 12% longer hours than French people.

It is an argument that, as the French take on the EU presidency and Britain begins to debate more fully the merits and demerits of the euro, we will be hearing more of in the months to come.

fields.headline: Abbey National
fields.trailText: Abbey National is securitising another £2.2bn of its mortgages, the largest deal of its kind in Europe. 'What?' and 'So what?' are obvious retorts. But the matter deserves consideration.
fields.body:
Abbey National is securitising another £2.2bn of its mortgages, the largest deal of its kind in Europe. 'What?' and 'So what?' are obvious retorts. But the matter deserves consideration.

First the 'what?' Securitisation is a technical way of describing the fact that Abbey is to take a chunk of its £65bn mortgage book, bundle it up and sell it on in carefully constructed bits to big institu tional investors in Britain, Europe and, unusually, the United States. Customers will never know if the mortgage bundled off is theirs and the Abbey will still manage it.

The 'so what?' is more interesting. It might not be as headline grabbing as the decision by HSBC to lop one percentage point off its mortgage rate, but, in theory, could also lower lending rates.

Gareth Jones, Abbey Na tional's managing director of wholesale banking, explained that the move could result in better deals for customers. "If we didn't do it we'd have to raise more retail funds ... for which we'd have to pay more."

For technical reasons, the securitisation means Abbey is raising money without having to stock up on as much regulatory capital as would otherwise be necessary. "They get to recycle their financial capital," said Bill Young, managing director of securitisation at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, the investment bank handling the deal.

Mr Jones insisted it was very hard to tell how much cheaper this financing would be. Abbey is not the only bank to securitise. Northern Rock, for instance, is receiving half its new funding through such means.

But Abbey's plans are the largest so far. It has already completed a number of other deals and, by the time this one is completed, 7% of its mortgage book will be securitised. There is more to come.

Only time will tell whether the process will lead to better rates. According to Richard Coleman, banking analyst at ABN AMRO, it might not have much impact immediately. However, "in the long run, it is a very big deal".

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was the impact of Vodafone AirTouch and not the decision to keep domestic interest rates on hold that held the key to trading in London yesterday.
fields.body:
It was the impact of Vodafone AirTouch and not the decision to keep domestic interest rates on hold that held the key to trading in London yesterday.

With Wall Street looking unsure of itself ahead of today's key employment report, Vodafone's rise of 15p to 312p singlehandedly kept the FTSE 100's head above water.

Because Vodafone accounts for such a big part of the FTSE 100 - around 12.6% according to index compiler FTSE International - a penny move shifts the index by nearly 2.7 points.

The trigger for Vodafone's gains yesterday was recent subscriber figures and a "strong buy" recommendation from Deutsche Bank - the broker that dominates trading in Vodafone shares.

The FTSE 100 closed the session up 37.1 points at 6,419.6, with other indices mixed.

Technology stocks had a tough day rattled by profit warnings from US peers. Logica declined 130p to £15.50; Misys surrendered 21p to 547p.

Cable & Wireless slipped 56p to £11.90, as expectations of a takeover by Deutsche Telekom started to fade.

But Rio Tinto rose 45p to £10.73, after JP Morgan raised its target price on the mining company and BAe Systems soared 14p to 425p as CFSB advised its clients the stock was "a strong buy".

Reuters was in demand, advancing 72 to £12.82, while Centrica's acquisition of Canadian energy supply business, Direct Energy Marketing, was rewarded with a gain of 6.75p to 227p.

Among mid-cap stocks, transport groups Arriva , up 9p at 219, and Stagecoach , 4p better at 75.75p, were helped by positive comments from investment bank Morgan Stanley.

Morgan Crucible leapt 14p to 238.5p as it bought blocks of stock to satisfy the demand of shareholders that have opted to take dividends in cash rather than shares.

Computer games company Eidos lost 44.75p to 490.25p as Infogrames poured cold water on bid hopes. The French group said that while interested in Eidos it was also looking at a number of other companies.

Chemicals group Hickson was the best performing smaller company share, surging 12.5p to 54p after agreeing to a £96.8m cash bid from US group Arch Chemicals. Automotive design and engineering group Hawtal Whiting rose 13p to 68.5p after it said it had received a number of takeover approaches.

Robert Walters , the recruitment consultant, made a good market debut closing at a 13p premium to its 170p offer price.

Morgan Crucible leapt 14p to 238.5p as it bought blocks of stock to satisfy the demand of shareholders that have opted to take dividends in cash rather than shares. Computer games company Eidos lost 44.75p to 490.25p as Infogrames poured cold water on bid hopes. The French group said that while interested in Eidos it was also looking at a number of other companies. Chemicals group Hickson was the best performing smaller company share, surging 12.5p to 54p after agreeing to a £96.8m cash bid from US group Arch Chemicals. Robert Walters , the recruitment consultant, made a good market debut closing at a 13p premium to its 170p offer price.

fields.headline: Falling Egg faces uncertain future
fields.trailText: Four weeks into life as a publicly quoted company and Egg, the internet-cum-telephone bank, is being fried.
fields.body:
Four weeks into life as a publicly quoted company and Egg, the internet-cum-telephone bank, is being fried.

Its shares, eagerly bought last month by customers, employees and institutional investors, fell even further past the 160p offer price yesterday.

Investment banks Deutsche Bank and Nomura triggered the latest rout by issuing negative comments on the stock. With Nomura advising its clients to "sell" and Deutsche Bank lowering its target price to 90p, Egg's shares fell 7p to 143p.

Egg is feeling the pain of the wider market, pummelled by anxiety about a mortgage and current account war.

The big question exercising the minds of analysts is whether Egg can hold on to its customers once its product pricing becomes less aggressive.

In its one and half year existence, Egg has been credited with revolutionising the British financial industry. Its 1m customers were lured by its trendy advertising and extremely competitive pricing.

Whether they will stay after the rates become less attractive is one issue for the market and is likely to help determine whether the company will make a profit by the end of next year. At the same time, less attractive rates would diminish Egg's chances of persuading customers to buy more than one product, another means by which it hopes to turn its losses into profit.

Nomura analysts Andrei Ilyin and Mike Wheelhouse feel it will be harder for Egg to make money at a time of increasing competition.. HSBC this week cut one percentage point off its standard variable mortgage rate and Halifax will launch its Intelligent Finance next week.

"At this stage, it is practically impossible to tell whether Egg will ever manage to transform itself from a 'bag of deposits' into a 'money machine,' and any analysis that may seem to suggest otherwise is likely to be based on visionary assumptions rather than cold reason," the Nomura analysts said.

Whatever happens, Egg is one of the most interesting experiments Britain's financial industry has seen. It has secured its place in the dot.com hall of fame as the internet business that woke the high street banks from their slumber, the Nomura analysts claim.

With Egg unable to answer its critics as it is in a post initial public offering blackout phase, shareholders are faced with two choices. They can back founder Mike Harris and his management team - or sell out.

For the moment at least, a large number of Egg shareholders are opting for the latter. Prudential, which still owns 80% of the shares, has no such choice.

webTitle: Surprise then delight as German fans hail another miracle

fields.headline: Surprise then delight as German fans hail another miracle
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Germans yesterday greeted the news that they were to host the 2006 World Cup with astonished delight. They had expected the decision to go to the favourites, South Africa, and the outcome reinforced the "miracle worker" reputation attached to Franz Beckenbauer, the former national player and coach who led the German bid.
fields.body:
Germans yesterday greeted the news that they were to host the 2006 World Cup with astonished delight. They had expected the decision to go to the favourites, South Africa, and the outcome reinforced the "miracle worker" reputation attached to Franz Beckenbauer, the former national player and coach who led the German bid.

Hansi Müller, another former player for the national side, said: "I burst into shouts of joy. Franz is the prototype of a winner."

A debate in the lower house of parliament was interrupted for an announcement of Germany's victory.

Beckenbauer said the outcome "should be seen as greater than that of [Germany's] World Cup victories in 1974 and 1990.

"Germany will be a magnificent host."

The tournament will be staged at a psychologically important moment for a country which is once again starting to assert its strength. The final is expected to be played in the new capital of Berlin and by 2006 work on transforming the city will have been largely finished.

Jürgen Röber, the coach of the city's premier side, Hertha BSC, said: "Berlin above all will profit from this decision."

Beckenbauer had argued that the fact that West Germany had hosted the 1974 World Cup was irrelevant because of its subsequent reunification with the former East Germany.

"People in the eastern bloc were not able to come then. This time everybody will be welcome," said the former sweeper.

The main task now is for Germany to build a side that can get into the final stages of the competition. It put on a woeful performance at Euro 2000 and was eliminated at the group stage.

Germany's new coach-designate, Christoph Daum, who is renowned for down-to-earth, Brian Clough-like comments, said the watchword should be: "Celebrate for a day, then roll up our sleeves."

fields.headline: Bank makes boring seem beautiful
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: Setting Britain's interest rates
fields.trailText: Two cheers for the MPC - so far
fields.body:
Two cheers for the MPC - so far

Don't you just love dull - at least when it comes to monetary policy. Yesterday the Bank of England's monetary policy committee left interest rates on hold, for the fifth month in a row. The decision barely raised a flicker in the financial markets.

Little wonder. Yesterday's outcome can have surprised no one. The most recent data from retailing, the housing market and on earnings have all been on the soft side. The pound has steadied on the foreign exchanges after slipping from its May peaks. Not much then for the more hawkish - or more nervous - members of the committee to worry about. Indeed, one of the few talking points from the minutes of this month's meeting is likely to be whether the decision was unanimous or if not just how many were opposed.

It may however be too early to start looking for a rate cut. There are still some in the City who believe the MPC has one more interest rate rise left in the locker. Points of potential concern are the rate at which the economy grew in the second quarter and whether sterling might start wobbling again. There remains a cloud, too, in the shape of the US economy. Will the Federal Reserve be able to engineer a soft landing or will 10 years of growth end with a bump?

But the balance of the debate now appears to lie with those who believe that, although the next move in interest rates is likely to be downward, policy looks likely to remain on hold for some time. The pound may be too high for British manufacturers exporting to the euro zone but the authorities are unlikely to be persuaded there is anything to be gained from an exchange rate target. On the other side of the equation the outlook for interest rates and inflation should be sufficiently stable to suit most corporate economists. A competitive exchange rate against the euro may be beyond the MPC's touch for the time being - though stronger euroland growth and the European Central Bank may help out on that front over the coming months. But two out of three is not bad.

Dutch auction

The outcome of the Netherlands' auction of third generation mobile phone licences which got under way yesterday will be eagerly anticipated. The debate about the best way to allocate such licences has been a topic of furious debate within the industry ever since the British process realised considerably more than the seller, the government, or the buyers anticipated.

The outcome of that process provoked fears that the industry was having to pay too much. That in turn led to concerns the telecoms companies would either slow down the pace of investment in the new networks or seek to pass on the costs to consumers through higher prices.

Not every one has gone the auction route. The French, for example, have opted for a beauty contest approach. Bidders' plans will be studied. The government will decide which companies will get the four licences on offer then each company will have to stump up 4.95bn euro (£3bn). Again, unlike Britain which opted for a lump sum approach to payment (thus making management of the debt market trickier this year than it would have been), France has decided that the successful companies will have to pay half the fee within two years and the balance can be spread over the remaining 13 years of the licence.

Although Holland has gone for the auction approach, it is doing so with rather fewer contenders than entered the British bidding process. In fact, there are just six bidders for five licences after two potential contenders pulled out at the last moment. Some observers believe the bidding - initially expected to last four to six weeks - could be over more quickly than had been anticipated. The thinking is that the five contenders who already have mobile phone businesses in Holland will be able to outbid the only newcomer in the field because their existing operations will mean they will need to put in less investment.

Estimates of the amount of money the Netherlands auction will raise vary widely but if the process ends quickly and the proceeds fall significantly short of the top end of expectations - which is in the region of 20bn guilders (£5.7bn) - it could have a profound influence on other auctions to come, particularly the one with (potentially) the biggest prizes: Germany.

Although the bidding there will be keen because of the size of the market, the German finance ministry will start to feel a tad nervous if it becomes apparent that only a relatively small number of players believe that they have a chance of winning one of the licences on offer and that even those are getting harder-headed about just how much they are prepared to pay.

A few months ago the question was whether companies could afford to stay out of the auctions. No longer. The boot is on the other foot.

fields.headline: Hotels alliance ends feud
fields.trailText: Whitbread and Punch Taverns yesterday called time on their history of acrimony to form an £80m joint venture with plans to develop up to 60 budget hotels alongside pubs.
fields.body:
Whitbread and Punch Taverns yesterday called time on their history of acrimony to form an £80m joint venture with plans to develop up to 60 budget hotels alongside pubs.

The agreement will allow Whitbread to build and manage hotels under its Travel Inn brand using spare land around some of Punch's 5,000 pubs.

Carl Leaver, managing director of Whitbread's Travel Inn subsidiary, said the move was part of his strategy of increasing the chain's total number of rooms from 13,243 to 20,000 by 2004. "This gives us access to some great locations we couldn't have taken advantage of otherwise."

The tie-up comes a year after Whitbread and privately owned Punch locked horns in one of the most bitter takeover battles in recent history, as they competed to buy Allied Domecq's 3,500-pub estate.

At the time, Punch chairman Hugh Osmond described Whitbread as "bland, unexciting and old fogeyish". Punch won the contest with a £2.7bn bid after Whitbread's offer was referred to the competition commission.

Whitbread's hotels boss, Alan Parker, said Mr Osmond's conduct was "irritating at the time - it would be foolish to pretend otherwise". However, he added: "That's all history now, it really is in the past. We're all professionals, in both organisations."

Punch's property director, Marc Jonas, said Mr Osmond had buried the hatchet with Whitbread's chief executive, David Thomas, some time ago.

Mr Jonas paid tribute to Travel Inn's management: "I've been really, really pleasantly surprised about what a professional outfit Travel Inn is. I don't know about all Whitbread's other businesses."

The new Travel Inns are likely to begin appearing within six months.

One of the ways Whitbread distinguishes Travel Inns from the competition is by placing them next to fully licensed restaurants and pubs. Many Travel Inns are alongside Whitbread's Beefeater, Brewers Fayre or TGI Friday outlets.

The market for budget hotels is growing rapidly but is becoming increasingly competitive - the Travel Inn chain competes with Hilton Group's Travelodges and Bass's Holiday Inn Express outlets.

Punch said it had considered deals with several other operators, including Travelodge. Mr Janus said: "We thought the best way to get into lodges would be to team up with someone who knows the business."

fields.headline: Rover rapidly loses buyers' sympathy
fields.trailText: The brief golden period for Rover following the drawn-out debacle of its sell-off by BMW is over, according to new car sales figures.
fields.body:
The brief golden period for Rover following the drawn-out debacle of its sell-off by BMW is over, according to new car sales figures.

Rover, which is under new ownership, suffered a slump, taking only 3.9% of the market last month and seeing sales collapse 21.7% compared with June 1999, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.

By contrast, the controversial sale does not seem to have affected former BMW too badly. Its sales rose 23.5% compared with June 1999.

Much of Rover's sales boom earlier this year was said to be due to a radical price cutting policy, brought in by BMW when it tried to offload a backlog of vehicles. At the height of the row over Rover's sale, publicity and price cuts helped double its March market share to 13.5%.

Overall, new car sales dipped slightly last month but still represented the second-highest June on record. A total of 193,360 cars were sold, 1.6% down on the record 1999 figure.

In total, 1,216,445 new cars have been sold in the first six months of 2000, 2.1% more than in the January-June 1999 period.

The sector has been the focus for much recent price cutting as manufacturers seek to counteract the "rip-off Britain" campaign.

SMMT chief executive Christopher Macgowan said yesterday: "The mix of new models, fantastic deals and the new [twice yearly] plate change system all meant that the first six months of 2000 were very strong."

He said the society's predicted full-year sales figure of 2.2m could be achieved.

Nissan, which last week complained loudly about the strength of sterling, enjoyed a rise in sales of almost 15%. At a time of high petrol prices, sales of superminis rose 17% above the first half of 1999.

webTitle: VW fined £57m for cheap car sales ban

fields.headline: VW fined £57m for cheap car sales ban
fields.trailText: Volkswagen was fined £57m yesterday for preventing its dealers in Italy from selling to customers from other European countries. It is the largest fine ever imposed on a European company for flouting fair competition laws.
fields.body:
Volkswagen was fined £57m yesterday for preventing its dealers in Italy from selling to customers from other European countries. It is the largest fine ever imposed on a European company for flouting fair competition laws.

The European court of justice, based in Luxembourg, told Volkswagen its behaviour was a particularly serious offence because of its status as Europe's largest car maker.

Industry analysts believe that yesterday's verdict could trigger a series of similar cases against other car makers across Europe.

The ruling is a serious blow to VW which has spent two years lobbying ferociously to clear its name and avoid the fine, which was originally imposed by the European commission in 1998.

It is also a reminder that consumers in countries such as Britain - where cars are perceived to be more expensive than in continental Europe - are within their rights to buy in other member states.

Although the court agreed to lower the original fine by £7.5m, it essentially upheld the commission's case, delivering a damning verdict which is certain to tarnish VW's reputation.

The court found that German and Austrian motorists who wanted to take advantage of the lire's weakness between 1993 and 1996 and make big savings by buying their new cars in Italy were repeatedly thwarted by VW, together with its Audi subsidiary and its Italian distributor.

"Volkswagen committed an infringement which was particularly serious, the seriousness being magnified by the size of the Volkswagen group," the court ruled, noting that VW is Europe's biggest car maker.

It is against European law for manufacturers to stop bargain hunters from shopping around the 15 member states to find the best buy. But in Volkswagen's case the court yesterday upheld the commission's original findings - which painted a picture of a highly organised campaign to stop motorists buying its cars outside their own country.

In a series of raids on VW offices around Europe, the commission uncovered evidence that about 50 Italian dealers were told that their contracts would be terminated if they sold to foreign customers.

Some 12 dealers who refused to toe the line were closed down - and any dealer who dared to defy VW had its profit margins and bonuses progressively reduced in retaliation.

The commission said that Italian dealers were instructed deliberately to mislead foreign customers - by falsely claiming that different specifications and warranty complications made a cross-border sale impossible.

Mario Monti, the European commissioner in charge of policing competition policy, yesterday hailed the court's judgment as a victory for the consumer.

"Car makers have some latitude in the way they choose to organise their distribution networks," Mr Monti said, "but the rules also give consumers the unalterable right to buy - either directly or through an authorised intermediary - a car in the member state of their choice."

Earlier this year Mr Monti put the European car industry on notice to expect radical reform in the way cars are sold when the current regulations expire next year, partly because of what he views as a lack of competition.

Brussels is investigating the activities of other car makers - including DaimlerChrysler, General Motors and Peugeot - and is expected to make its findings public this year.

Volkswagen said yesterday that it was considering a further appeal against the court's decision.

fields.headline: Another tower at Canary Wharf
fields.trailText: Another tower is to join London's eastern skyline following yesterday's announcement of the third phase of development at Canary Wharf.
fields.body:
Another tower is to join London's eastern skyline following yesterday's announcement of the third phase of development at Canary Wharf.

The owners of the once bankrupt development in the former West India docks were able to confirm the go-ahead for the next stage of its development after attracting one of London's largest law firms, Clifford Chance, to the site.

A new 30 storey block, which will be two-thirds occupied by the law firm, is expected to need another £250m of financing. It is just one of a number of buildings in the third phase, which is being built to the south of the existing development. Site works are already under way. The development is expected to be completed by 2005, 13 years after the site first attracted the attentions of Paul Reichmann, then head of Olympia & York and now executive chairman of Canary Wharf Group, which floated in April 1999. webTitle: Budgens hopes to double size of chain

fields.headline: Budgens hopes to double size of chain
fields.trailText: New Budgens chief executive, Martin Hyson, wants to double the size of the 208-strong chain of convenience stores but admitted yesterday that he was cooling on the idea of home delivery.
fields.body:
New Budgens chief executive, Martin Hyson, wants to double the size of the 208-strong chain of convenience stores but admitted yesterday that he was cooling on the idea of home delivery.

Mr Hyson took the top job in May when his predecessor, John von Spreckelsen, was poached by the Somerfield supermarket chain.

He said yesterday: "We need to put some scale into the business. There are groups of independently owned stores around which would fit nicely into the Budgens niche."

Mr Hyson calculates that by rebranding stores as Budgens, introducing more fresh food and using the group's distribution network, the company can double the takings of independent outlets.

Annual Budgens profits surged 16% to £14.6m, helped by strong sales of fresh fruit and vegetables - items which are rarely available in independent convenience stores. Prepared meals and dairy products also performed well.

Budgens has been running trials of an online home delivery service, Budgens Direct, in a handful of areas.

The company is extending this into four stores in the Norfolk area but Mr Hyson admitted: "I don't believe it's going to be anything like as important as people say."

Like-for-like sales have risen 4% since the company's year-end in April. The shares rose 1p to 64p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Hermes, the pension fund group with a reputation for shareholder activism, is to try its tactics on the continent with the European equivalent of its Focus Fund.
fields.body:
Hermes widens its Focus

Hermes, the pension fund group with a reputation for shareholder activism, is to try its tactics on the continent with the European equivalent of its Focus Fund.

Alistair Ross Goobey, chief executive of the group owned by the British Telecom pension scheme, said the fund concentrated on companies that had underperformed sector peers for at least three years and there was potential for a break-up of the firm.

Hermes' UK Focus was an investor in the Mirror, now part of Trinity, while Mr Ross Goobey admitted that its holding insurance group, GRE, had been realised for a lower value than it had expected.

Unifi backs Bank six

Members of the finance union Unifi campaigned outside the Bank of England yesterday over redundancy notices to six employees who have refused to sign up to new terms of employment.

The main issue of contention has been the removal of a special fixed rate mortgage package.

The Bank said the subsidised mortgage was "inappropriate" in the light of its role in setting interest rates and the six were the only members of its 2,000 workforce not to accept the new terms.

US approval for Medisys

Health care company Medisys has won approval from US regulators for its innovative safety syringes - which pop back into a plastic casing after use to prevent accidental jabs.

The Aberdeen firm is hoping to begin selling hundreds of millions of the syringes, called Futura, later this year.

The US food and drug administration's decision sent Medisys shares up 12p to 135p.

Medisys is one of a number of companies hoping to take advantage of new laws in the US requiring hospitals to use safety syringes wherever possible, in order to reduce the risk of infection with HIV and other viruses.

Nearly 10bn syringes are used in America every year. A launch in Europe is likely within the next few years, although the company is yet to get a chartermark of approval from EC regulators.

Mirror chief's golden farewell

John Allwood, deputy chief executive of Trinity Mirror, is in line for a £600,000 payoff after his departure from the media group which publishes the Mirror and a string of regional newpapers.

Mr Allwood, 48, was chief executive of Mirror Group, replacing the ousted David Montgomery, when it merged with Trinity last year.

News of his departure accompanied a first half trading statement showing a 2.4% rise in the circulation of the Mirror and Sunday Mirror compared with the first half of 1999.

Trinity Mirror said the regional newspapers, particularly in the Midlands and Liverpool, achieved a 7.3% rise in advertising revenue and an 8% rise in classified advertising on the back of a 21% rise in recruitment advertising. The group said its £150m strategy for the internet was "progressing satisfactorily".

fields.headline: Centrica pays £406m for US foothold
fields.trailText: Centrica, the energy and home services group, yesterday made its first significant overseas foray, paying £406m for Direct Energy, a Canadian business which is expanding into the liberalised gas and electricity markets in the United States.
fields.body:
Centrica, the energy and home services group, yesterday made its first significant overseas foray, paying £406m for Direct Energy, a Canadian business which is expanding into the liberalised gas and electricity markets in the United States.

Centrica hopes to repeat its domestic performance in north America, offering financial and home services as well as energy. The company - which trades in the UK as British Gas - has 14.8m gas and 3m electricity customers, 9.7m AA members and about 1m Goldfish credit card holders.

It also offers home security and plumbing and is moving into telecoms in September.

Direct Energy, launched in Toronto as a unit trust in 1996, has 820,000 deregulated gas and 70,000 electricity customers in Canada.

Through its stake in a joint venture, Energy America, it has 450,000 gas and electricity customers in six US states: Ohio, Michigan, Georgia, Maryland, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

Centrica hopes that the deal, which has to be approved by two-thirds of Direct Energy's unit holders next month, will enable it to penetrate the lucrative eastern seaboard and midwest energy markets totalling 44m households.

National Grid, Scottish Power and Kelda, which owns Yorkshire Water, are among British groups establishing a foothold in the United States, but they have faced serious regulatory challenges.

Direct Energy made £24.9m pre-tax profits last year and Centrica said that the acquisition should be earnings enhancing in 2002. Roy Gardner, chief executive, said: "This provides us with the ideal vehicle for rolling out our strategy into the North American markets."

Centrica already has a joint venture with Essent, a Dutch company which trades wholesale energy in Europe.

webTitle: Runaway prodigy refuses to go home

fields.headline: Runaway prodigy refuses to go home
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The mother of maths prodigy Sufiah Yusof has sent a heartfelt message to her runaway daughter, who yesterday refused to go home after being tracked down by police.
fields.body:
The mother of maths prodigy Sufiah Yusof has sent a heartfelt message to her runaway daughter, who yesterday refused to go home after being tracked down by police.

The 15-year-old Oxford student, who disappeared two weeks ago from St Hilda's college after sitting her final exam of the year, asked detectives to keep her whereabouts a secret when she was found somewhere "in England".

Speaking from the family home in Coventry, her mother, Halimaheon, expressed relief that her daughter was safe and well, but added that she was baffled by Sufiah's behaviour.

The teenager had called her college dean, Laura Newby, the day after she went missing to say she "needed space" and was also understood to have sent her parents an email telling them she did not wish to come home for family reasons.

Sobbing, Mrs Yusof, a 44-year-old chemist, said: "The child I know is a good child and a happy child. We are baffled, but prepared to open up.

"I promise her that if she is not well or has a problem I will be there in the forefront to help her out."

Sufiah began studying for a masters degree at Oxford at the age of 13, entering St Hilda's as its youngest ever student, but remaining under the supervision of her parents.

Referring to reports that Sufiah might be staying away because her Malaysian-born father was too demanding, Mrs Yusof said: "As a family we are close. When it comes to their work, [the children] are independent. We have always said that if it is too much for you, please tell us. We told Sufiah any time she feels she wants to take a break, to please do."

She said Farooq, 43, a mathematician, had spent three days combing the streets in search of his daughter.

Mrs Yusof said she was naturally concerned for her daughter's welfare and was eager for "professionals" to make sure she was physically and mentally healthy.

She added: "If she does not want to see us, that is fine. She is the one now that needs to be thought of. If she wants to settle down in a safe house and go through social services, so be it."

Thames Valley police said social services had been informed and would be looking after the teenager for the next few days.

The principal of St Hilda's College, Elizabeth Llewellyn-Smith, said everyone was very pleased to hear the teenager was safe and well.

She declined to comment on the apparent rift between Sufiah and her family saying: "The college cannot intervene or comment on any dispute between Sufiah and her family which is a matter for other authorities so long as she is a minor."

But she added that the college would co-operate with police and social service inquiries. Ms Llewellyn-Smith said the college hoped to get in touch with the young student, who passed her end-of-year exams with flying colours, to discuss the fourth year of her course, which is due to begin in October.

fields.headline: Titian purchase
fields.standfirst: Ashmolean pays record £2.5m
fields.trailText: The Ashmolean Museum in Oxford has paid a record price of just under £2.5m for a portrait by Titian at the Christie's auction of old masters from the Wernher collection.
fields.body:
The Ashmolean Museum in Oxford has paid a record price of just under £2.5m for a portrait by Titian at the Christie's auction of old masters from the Wernher collection.

The sombre but sumptuous painting of a Genoese merchant was one of many stars in the collection accumulated by Sir Julius Wernher in the late 19th century when South African diamonds made him one of the richest men in the world.

The collection was at the centre of a family saga of tragedy and financial disaster. It was housed in Luton Hoo, the stately home in Bedfordshire which Sir Julius bought and spent a fortune renovating to entertain royalty. The house was opened to the public in 1950, but has since been sold to be a luxury hotel.

Its furnishings and much of the art collection have been scattered at auction since 1991 when the heir, Nicholas Phillips, a godson of the Duke of Edinburgh, was found dead in his car after running up debts.

At the Ashmolean, the oldest public museum in the world, Christopher Brown, the director, said he was thrilled to get the half length portrait of Giacomo di Agostino Doria, who was living in Venice in the 1530s when Titian painted him.

"Although we already have an important group of Venetian 16th century paintings, there has been nothing until now by Titian, the most important of them all," Dr Brown said.

The museum bought it with large grants from the heritage lottery fund and the independent arts charity, the National Art Collections Fund, and funds raised in memory of Francis Haskell, professor of history of art at Oxford and a trustee of the museum, who died this year.

Dr Brown regarded several comments yesterday urging him to take care of his treasure as in extremely poor taste. The Ashmolean was mortified to be the victim of an audacious theft at New Year's Eve, when thieves cut a Cézanne, valued at £3m, from its frame. It has not been recovered.

webTitle: Tribunal over union fraud claim halted

fields.headline: Tribunal over union fraud claim halted
fields.trailText: The tribunal inquiry involving allegations of fraud and expense fiddles against union leader Roger Lyons was brought to a halt yesterday by the chairman, Enid Prevezer.
fields.body:
The tribunal inquiry involving allegations of fraud and expense fiddles against union leader Roger Lyons was brought to a halt yesterday by the chairman, Enid Prevezer.

Lawyers were last night negotiating with the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union to pay a large sum in settlement to Marcia Solomon, the former secretarial assistant to Nelson Mendes, the union's head of finance. She made the allegations and is claiming unfair and wrongful dismissal under the government's whistleblower legislation.

The unexpected halt to the case came after the employment tribunal in central London had heard evidence from John Chowcat, the former assistant general secretary of the union. He told the chairman he had been vilified by Mr Lyons for asking for an investigation into the general secretary's expenses and how up to £160,000 might have been paid out to Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes through false bank accounts. Even after he had dropped the fraud allegations, Mr Lyons instigated disciplinary proceedings against him. He was found guilty of gross misconduct and told he would be dismissed without a penny.

When he lodged an appeal, the union decided to say he had resigned and negotiated a deal, paying him around £250,000 compensation.

Earlier, two witnesses for the MSF, Paul Talbot, national officer for the union, and Laurie Bell, senior manager for Unity Trust Bank, were cross-examined by Jason Galbraith-Marten, lawyer for Ms Solomon.

Mr Talbot, who headed the internal disciplinary inquiry into Ms Solomon's case, said he had never done one before. He said he had been asked to do the inquiry personally by Mr Lyons and had allowed Tony Ayres, who took the union's case against Ms Solomon, to be present while he deliberated on the verdict. He did not ask Ms Solomon's representative, Michael Adkins, to be present.

Mr Bell admitted that the bank had failed to do a "comprehensive" search for the cheques worth over £34,000 which Ms Solomon said she had seen, payable to her boss and Mr Lyons. He also disclosed that the bank had allowed Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes alone to sign cheques for 10 head office accounts. They also had the power to order money to be taken out of branch accounts and paid into head office.

Shown MSF internal documents, he agreed the MSF internal accounts included 22 not listed on the Unity Bank statements for the same month. Others seemed to be under different names. He also admitted the bank had allowed accounts which had not been properly opened to be listed.

Last night, Richard O'Brien, spokesman for the union, said if a deal with Ms Solomon was negotiated it would be made public. He said the union still stood by its view that Ms Solomon had failed to produce any evidence of fraud against Mr Lyons and that the banks and accountants had proved this was the case. He also said the union still regarded her action as malicious.

webTitle: Independent school head takes on 'failing' college

fields.headline: Independent school head takes on 'failing' college
fields.trailText: The headmistress of a top independent girl's school is to take over as principal of a school given a fresh start by the government after being recognised as one of the worst in the country.
fields.body:
The headmistress of a top independent girl's school is to take over as principal of a school given a fresh start by the government after being recognised as one of the worst in the country.

Jill Clough, head at Wimbledon high school for girls, said her new job at East Brighton college of media arts was "a wonderful opportunity".

She will swap a school in south-west London where 100% of pupils gain five or more A-Cs at GCSE level (average over five years 99.75%) for one whose percentage improved from 13 to 17.05 last year. Wimbledon's average GCSE point score per pupil was 74.6 last year; East Brighton's was 20.2.

Tony Garwood, the former principal, was one of three "superheads" put in charge of fresh start schools to quit in five days in March, undermining the government's flagship policy for reviving failing schools.

Shortly afterwards the school, which had a truancy problem, was put back into "special measures" following a critical Ofsted inspection.

Dr Clough had been at Wimbledon as head for five years. She was previously head of the Royal Naval school in Surrey, a girl's day and boarding school, and last taught in the state sector in Birmingham in 1969. "All this is working with a community of teachers and the children and their parents. I have gone from boarding school to day school, from rural schools to city schools - they are all very, very different."

Islington arts and media school, another fresh start school put into special measures after its head teacher resigned, also named its new principal yesterday.

Richard Ewen, who for 10 years was head of Teddington school - a large mixed comprehensive in west London - will take over as principal in September.

Miniature book fetches £2.6m
A book not much bigger than a cigarette packet sold for £2.6m at Sotheby's in London yesterday. The 16th century book of hours, with 18 coloured miniatures by Flemish illustrator Simon Bening, was found in a private collection in the Netherlands.
fields.body:
Miniature book fetches £2.6m
A book not much bigger than a cigarette packet sold for £2.6m at Sotheby's in London yesterday. The 16th century book of hours, with 18 coloured miniatures by Flemish illustrator Simon Bening, was found in a private collection in the Netherlands.

Healthy dogs put down
About 137 healthy dogs are destroyed every day in Britain because their owners cannot be found, according to the National Canine Defence League. A survey by Mori published yesterday found that an estimated 17,000 healthy dogs were destroyed in the UK last year, but the league believes the figure is closer to 50,000.

Star's ex fined for shoplifting
Barbara Windsor's former husband Ronnie Knight, 66, was fined £200 by Hendon magistrates, north London, yesterday for shoplifting £39.74 worth of goods from Waitrose supermarket, Brent Cross. He admitted slipping prawns, salmon and toiletries into a bag placed on his trolley on June 29.

Miss Havisham's home restored
The house that inspired Dickens's Great Expectations, the 1580 Restoration House in Rochester, Kent - Satis House, home of Miss Havisham in the novel - opened to the public yesterday after a six-year revamp.

Excluded more likely to kill
Children who have been permanently excluded from school are 50 times more likely to commit murder than the rest of the population, studies by social and mental health experts at the University of Southampton show.

fields.headline: Dear friends, the Folletts
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Let's be honest. Looking back on it, I admit I was fooled. Yes, I used to receive invitations to the Folletts' homes. And yes, I used to accept them. But remember - things were different then. Those were tough, tough times for New Labour. It was up to each of us to do all we could to oust the Tories, even if it involved drinking champagne and eating plovers' eggs with people we wouldn't normally be seen dead with. I even twice made the long, gruelling trip to their home on the French Riviera, so determined was I to muster all the support we could get in that most marginal of constituencies.
fields.body:
Let's be honest. Looking back on it, I admit I was fooled. Yes, I used to receive invitations to the Folletts' homes. And yes, I used to accept them. But remember - things were different then. Those were tough, tough times for New Labour. It was up to each of us to do all we could to oust the Tories, even if it involved drinking champagne and eating plovers' eggs with people we wouldn't normally be seen dead with. I even twice made the long, gruelling trip to their home on the French Riviera, so determined was I to muster all the support we could get in that most marginal of constituencies.

The two of them possessed, it must be said, a certain louche charm. Ken could play both Rock Island Line and Satisfaction on his guitar, and Barbara was gifted on the hula-hoop. They were both absolutely determined in their support of the common man - employing him in great numbers to hand round the eats and help with the dishes at their parties. And it can't be denied that those fundraising evenings at their Chelsea home served to unite all the various wings of the party in one voice, particularly when the pair of them were out of the room.

So it pained us all greatly when Kenneth chose to reveal his extreme bitterness and sense of utter personal failure in the Observer last weekend. Frankly, I don't know what the explanation is. Is he, perhaps, undergoing a midlife crisis? Sadly, I'm told his novels are not selling as well as they might. Top psychologists suggest this may have sent him into a tail-spin, fuelled by a sense of rejection and despair.

All I can say is that, even at this late stage, the party is still right behind him. We are determined that, if it takes months or even years, he will some day rejoin the New Labour fold. We in New Labour are a broad church, and let's hope we will always remain broad enough to welcome back the most abject of sinners.

The first I heard of it was on Sunday morning. The telephone rang. It was Alastair Campbell. For legal reasons, I am unable to reveal his exact words, but Downing Street has permitted me to give you the gist. "Have you read the Observer?" he asked. "It's Ken Follett. He's a marvellous writer and a lovely, lovely guy but..."

More than that, I am not at liberty to reveal. Alastair then explained that he was anxious to rebut any future suggestions from the Folletts that he was in some way "spinning" against them. He asked me to prepare a statement to the press pointing out, in my own words, that such charges could only come from a sad and foolish couple, vomiting forth the bile of the rejected. But Downing Street itself was determined to appear even-handed.

Within a minute, an official Follett fact-sheet was easing its way through my fax machine from Downing Street. Full of glowing testimonies, it makes it quite clear that Follett's accusations of "smear tactics" from Number 10 were the sad and paranoid fantasy of a yesterday's man, as you can see:

 Ken's hairdressing is personally supervised by top crimper Nicky Clarke, exclusively modelled on the style once favoured by fellow best-selling author Barbara Cartland. Ken pays for his twice-weekly stylings out of his own pocket. "I owe it to the ordinary working guy to look my absolute best at all times," says Ken.

 During her three years in parliament, Barbara Follett has proved herself a born backbencher, bringing to the floor of the House of Commons an expertise in colour-coordination that is second to none. Few would deny that, in the fashion stakes, she can give shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe a run for her money!

 One of the world's most consistently under-rated authors, Ken is a master of the short sentence and the short paragraph, often combining the two. Unsurprisingly, perhaps, he writes all his books himself. They are about a man who escapes, then vows revenge but is captured but then escapes. His spelling, too, is first-class. "I learnt how to spell 'exclaimed' before I was 30 years of age," he says, "and I've been spelling it more or less the same way ever since."

 Barbara has a very normal-sized house in her Stevenage constituency, to which she invites a number of normal constituents throughout the year. When in London, she lives just over the river from downtrodden Battersea, in a house generous enough to ensure that each member of her staff has his or her own sleeping quarters.

 To find the right word, Ken always requires a minimum of help from his publishers. The titles of his paperback bestsellers remain a closely guarded secret from the reading public.

See? I hope that by reprinting this Downing Street factsheet I have cleared the air. Ken and Barbara remain dear friends of New Labour; in fact possibly a little too dear for those in the lower income bracket.

fields.headline: Tory ad agency chief 'repaying debts'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: An advertising agency described as "young, dynamic and thrusting" by Tory officials when it won the £10m contract to give the party an image make over, has been revealed to have more than 20 county court judgments registered against its sister company for unpaid bills totalling more than £42,000.
fields.body:
An advertising agency described as "young, dynamic and thrusting" by Tory officials when it won the £10m contract to give the party an image make over, has been revealed to have more than 20 county court judgments registered against its sister company for unpaid bills totalling more than £42,000.

The company described only two months ago by Tory chairman Michael Ancram as "the Saatchi and Saatchi of the 21st century" was the subject of a winding up petition filed in Leeds on May 11, but the petition was dismissed, according to this week's Economist magazine.

The judgments are recorded against Yellow M Creative Resource and Marketing, based in Newcastle, which is the sis ter company of the Edinburgh-based Yellow M (CS), which won the Tory party's national advertising account. However, both companies share the same owner and chief executive, Mike Dethick.

Mr Dethick said all outstanding bills had since been paid or are "in the process of being paid as we speak". He said the debts were run up two years ago, when the company was struggling to survive.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Sega Dreamcast ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Sega Dreamcast ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
This fine spot consists of a gloriously stereotypical sequence of images depicting Germans and Germany. A blond chap in lederhosen wielding several pints of frothing beer; another munching on a pile of sausages; plus stock footage of hundreds of VW Beetles motoring along a road. Best of all, there's a row of sunloungers with black, red and yellow towels trailed across them at the crack of dawn. The ad ends with a typically Aryan German standing on his national map, holding his Sega Dreamcast controls, as a voiceover mimics the football chant: "Come and have a go if you think you're hard enough" in a cod German accent.

The jargon:
Sega Dreamcast has just launched the first on-line European multi-player game, so gamers in London can play with gamers in, say, Munich for the first time. The ad explains this pan-Euro notion by depicting national stereotypes jokily challenging their European neighbours to a "friendly".

Personality:
You're a 15-25-year-old video-gamer and very probably male. Unlike the sad, introverted bedroom-gamers who play on the darker, more intense Sony PlayStation, you are "upbeat and have a positive outlook on life", says agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

Financial status:
A Dreamcast console costs around £199, and games around £40 each, so you have a high disposable income and like to spend lots on leisure pursuits.

Telling lifestyle detail:
The ad, and ones spoofing the French and the British, were aired alongside all the Euro 2000 matches, exploiting the patriotic fervour surrounding the event, so you're probably quite footie-oriented. You're also likely to be living with mates and playing video games after the pub closes.

Other relevant data:
BBH was nervous of showing the spot to Sega's various continental marketing directors. Particularly the one in Germany. He loved it, apparently, and even laughed.
