fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Ed Wood | All The President's Men | Live Flesh | Fist of Fury
fields.body:
Ed Wood
(Tim Burton, 1994)
8pm, FilmFour

Making a biopic of the world's worst movie director could have been an exercise in condescension. But Burton shows genuine respect for his troubled subject, at least for his energy and determination if not his movie-making skills. Johnny Depp gives the performance of his career so far, playing the cross-dressing director as a likeable, innocent eccentric determined to do things his way. And Martin Landau is superb as a drug-addled Bela Lugosi, sunken into squalor.
Will Hodgkinson

All The President's Men
(Alan J Pakula, 1976)
8pm Sky Cinema

How Washington Post reporters Woodward (Robert Redford) and Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman) traced the Watergate break-in back to President Nixon's office. William Goldman's masterly, Oscar-winning screenplay extracts all the suspense of the investigation and its riveting detail, without getting bogged down in the complexity.

Live Flesh
(Pedro Almodóvar, 1997)
1.55am, Sky Premier

Almodóvar's best film to date. The twisty plot, taken from a Ruth Rendell story and handled adroitly, concerns young Victor (Javier Bardem), imprisoned for the accidental shooting of a policeman. Released, Victor finds the girl he loves married to the now paraplegic cop. The maturer Almodóvar delivers an almost restrained, intimate picture of passion, jealousy and revenge, the vivid characters dignified by real emotion and motivation; all allied to the old Pedro's vibrant visual panache.

Fist of Fury
(Lo Wei, 1972)
3.30am, FilmFour

The inimitable Bruce Lee plays Chen Chen, returning to Shanghai to honour his dead kung fu mentor, and kicking some serious ass - the karate thugs who murdered him. The plot is risible, but Lee's charismatic screen persona, allied to the furious grace of his slow-mo workouts, make him a mesmerising screen presence.
Paul Howlett

fields.headline: Play it again, Spam
fields.standfirst: As a new recipe book dedicated to Spam hits the shelves,  Matthew Fort  traces the history and considers the future of the luncheon meat that was once looked on as a delicacy
fields.trailText: As a new recipe book dedicated to Spam hits the shelves,  Matthew Fort  traces the history and considers the future of the luncheon meat that was once looked on as a delicacy
fields.body:
Somewhere between sole Colbert and steak Diane, some time between the plenty of pre-1930 and the grossery of the 1960s, came Spam. Spam rescued the nation from wartime austerity and the dreariness of rationing - from Woolton pie, corned beef rissoles, savoury tripe, from casserole and smothered sausages. Spam, pink and porky and glorious in its trim, sensible tin, was the definition of American culinary technology.

As Marguerite Patten, whose recipes helped Britons through the war and years of postwar rationing (food was rationed until 1954), writes in the introduction to Spam, the Cookbook: "You can imagine the enthusiasm that greeted extra meat in the form of canned Spam. It was a really meaty luncheon meat. Each can contained a high percentage of pork and so it was a highly nutritious source of protein." In fact, Spam was - is - a quality product: 90% ham and pork, which is rather more than virtually all British sausages.

Whatever its pedigree, sadly, Spam today is the acme of all that is uncool about food. "It's a long, long time since I looked Spam in the face," says Rowley Leigh, the chef of Kensington Place. Lindsay Bareham of the Evening Standard claims to be ravaged by memories of "pink slices like dog's tongues served up with pickled beetroot, by nuns". "Worth eating," admits Shaun Hill, chef/proprietor of the Michelin-starred Merchant House in Ludlow, "but not worth buying." Food and Drink Programme favourite Antony Worrall Thompson confesses to being a Spam fan and to having a case of the stuff in his kitchen. He stoutly defends the qualities of Spam fritters, but even he is forced to admit that Spam is a bit of a cult, which means that it doesn't exactly have a mass following.

Spam may have its own website and its tins may be collectors' items. It may also have its place in social history and be part of the gastro-tribal memory, but the truth is that it is now seen as irredeemably low-rent, best fitted as bait for barbel and carp. "Spam, Spam, Spam, lovely Spam," sang the Monty Python crew in a paean of satirical irony, "wonderful, lovely Spam... superlative Spam, surgical Spam, splendiferous Spam."

But during and after the war, Spam was popular. It was a luxury. Spam, it has to be said, was the balsamic vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil of its day; the dernier cri , if not of fine dining, then certainly of everyday staples. Spam was the symbol of everything we couldn't produce or get hold of. "It was," says my mother, who remembers the high days of Spam with affection, "a godsend. The only other tinned meat of any quality was Argentinian corned beef, and we went off that when a number of people were poisoned by it. Of course, it was only any good when it was made in the USA. The quality deteriorated when they started making it here."

"Innovate - don't imitate" was the motto of George A Hormel, founder of the company that makes Spam to this day. It was a motto that his son, Jay, took seriously when developing Spam in the 30s. It was the time of the depression, of bread queues and dust bowls, Bonnie and Clyde and the New Deal. The high-quality luncheon meat envisaged by Jay Hormel was part of a kind of culinary New Deal. He wanted to harness cutting-edge canning technology to produce a practical staple for domestic kitchens.

By late 1936 Hormel had the product and the production line, but he didn't have a name. Chopped ham lacked magic. Pork luncheon meat didn't trip off the tongue. So he organised a new year's party in 1937 to help find a name. Each guest would be entitled to one drink for each name they suggested, with a prize of $100 for the winner. The lucky guest was Kenneth Daigneau, middle-ranking actor and brother of a Hormel vice-president. Spam was short, sharp, easy on the tongue, and it accurately described the contents of the tin. In retrospect, Daigneau may have felt that he undersold his brainwave.

So, in May 1937, cans of Spam began rolling off the production line in Spam City, better known as Austin, Minnesota, and into history. In some ways Spam was the beneficiary of burgeoning commercial television: Hormel exploited the potential of TV advertisements to promote his "baby". Spam became the first product to have its own advertising jingle, borrowed from the tune of My Bonnie Lies Over the Ocean, and to have its own star endorsement, when George Burns and Gracie Allen were signed up to promote it.

While Spam was well established in America by 1939, it was the war that propelled the product to international stardom. Sales of Spam doubled between 1939 and 1942. By 1944, 90% of all Hormel products were exported. Spam was the staple that Uncle Sam used to feed his own armies (to the extent that American soldiers began to complain about being over-Spammed) and was also sent to keep his European allies in fighting shape. "Without Spam we wouldn't have been able to feed the army," said Nikita Khrushchev.

But it was in Britain that Spam became the biggest hit. Meat was rationed by price to one or two shillings' worth per week. The bacon ration fluctuated between 4oz and 8oz per week, the ration for fats, including butter, marge and lard and cheese between 1oz and 8oz a week, with 8oz to 1lb of sugar and 2oz to 4oz of tea. As George Orwell wrote in 1942, "War and the consequent abandonment of imports tend to reduce us to the natural diet of these islands, which is healthy but rather dull."

Into this sea of universal deprivation was lobbed Spam. Small wonder people like my mother took to it, making sandwiches with it, fritters, Spam rarebits, and baking it with cloves, brown sugar, mustard and vinegar. Spam is both an inspiration and a challenge, as Patten's recipes make clear. Spam and mushroom ramekins, Spam caesar salad, Spam crostini, deep Spam pizza, Spam and fruit stir-fry and even Spam goulash reflect its versatility, if not an unerring sense of taste.

When all's said and done, however, there's no use pretending that Spam is likely to achieve its former glory in the pantheon of the pantry. There may have been 5bn cans of the stuff sold by 1994 - enough to circle the globe 10 times; it may even still be big in Hawaii, where they eat four cans per head per year. But the day of meat pastes and canned meat products in polite society is gone, elbowed aside by vulgar newcomers - salamis and plastic packed exotic hams, vacuum-packed sausages and cooked/chilled conveniences.

Nevertheless, there will always be some kitchen cupboards where the can of Spam will nestle alongside the Bird's custard, Heinz baked beans and Nestlé's condensed milk, ready to be fetched down in times of stress and suffering.

 The recipes below are taken from Spam: The Cookbook, by Marguerite Patten, published today by Hamlyn, priced £6.99.

Mmm . . . some serving suggestions

Spam tortilla

1 tbsp olive oil
1 small onion, finely chopped
1 potato, cooked and cut into 5mm dice
125g Spam, cut into 5mm dice
4 large eggs, beaten
25g (2 tbsp) butter
1 tbsp chopped parsley
Salt and pepper
Snipped chives to garnish

1 Heat oil in a 18-20cm pan. Add onion and cook for 5 mins. Add potato and Spam, cook for 3 mins. Tip the mixture into bowl with beaten eggs. Season with salt and pepper, and mix well.

2 Heat butter in pan. Add egg mixture and parsley, and cook until firm. Slide tortilla on to a plate, cut into wedges and garnish with chives.

Spam scones

250g self-raising flour, or plain flour with 2 tsp baking powder
Pinch of salt
25g/2 tbsp butter or margarine
150g Spam cut into 3mm dice
150ml milk, plus extra for glazing

Filling:

Butter or margarine
Spam
Tomato and cucumber segments

1 Lightly grease a baking sheet or line it with baking parchment. Sift together the salt and flour, or flour and baking powder, in a bowl. Rub in the butter or margarine, add Spam, and enough milk to make a soft, rolling consistency.

2 Roll out the dough on a lightly floured board to 1.5cm thick. Cut into small rounds and brush the tops with milk. Place rounds on a baking sheet and bake in a preheated oven to 220C/450F/ Gas Mark 7 for 12-15 mins, until the scones feel firm when pressed at the sides.

3 Serve the scones hot with butter. Alternatively, leave them to cool, then split them and spread them with a little butter, slices of Spam and tomato and cucumber.

It was a really meaty luncheon meat. Each can contained a high percentage of pork and so it was a highly nutritious source of protein." In fact, Spam was - is - a quality product: 90% ham and pork, which is rather more than virtually all British sausages. Whatever its pedigree, sadly, Spam today is the acme of all that is uncool about food. "It's a long, long time since I looked Spam in the face," says Rowley Leigh, the chef of Kensington Place. Lindsay Bareham of the Evening Standard claims to be ravaged by memories of "pink slices like dog's tongues served up with pickled beetroot, by nuns". "Worth eating," admits Shaun Hill, chef/proprietor of the Michelin-starred Merchant House in Ludlow, "but not worth buying." Food and Drink Programme favourite Antony Worrall Thompson confesses to being a Spam fan and to having a case of the stuff in his kitchen. He stoutly defends the qualities of Spam fritters, but even he is forced to admit that Spam is a bit of a cult, which means that it doesn't exactly have a mass following. Spam may have its own website and its tins may be collectors' items. It may also have its place in social history and be part of the gastro-tribal memory, but the truth is that it is now seen as irredeemably low-rent, best fitted as bait for barbel and carp. "Spam, Spam, Spam, lovely Spam," sang the Monty Python crew in a paean of satirical irony, "wonderful, lovely Spam... superlative Spam, surgical Spam, splendiferous Spam." But during and after the war, Spam was popular. It was a luxury. Spam, it has to be said, was the balsamic vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil of its day; the dernier cri , if not of fine dining, then certainly of everyday staples. Spam was the symbol of everything we couldn't produce or get hold of. "It was," says my mother, who remembers the high days of Spam with affection, "a godsend. The only other tinned meat of any quality was Argentinian corned beef, and we went off that when a number of people were poisoned by it. Of course, it was only any good when it was made in the USA. The quality deteriorated when they started making it here." "Innovate - don't imitate" was the motto of George A Hormel, founder of the company that makes Spam to this day. It was a motto that his son, Jay, took seriously when developing Spam in the 30s. It was the time of the depression, of bread queues and dust bowls, Bonnie and Clyde and the New Deal. The high-quality luncheon meat envisaged by Jay Hormel was part of a kind of culinary New Deal. He wanted to harness cutting-edge canning technology to produce a practical staple for domestic kitchens. By late 1936 Hormel had the product and the production line, but he didn't have a name. Chopped ham lacked magic. Pork luncheon meat didn't trip off the tongue. So he organised a new year's party in 1937 to help find a name. Each guest would be entitled to one drink for each name they suggested, with a prize of $100 for the winner. The lucky guest was Kenneth Daigneau, middle-ranking actor and brother of a Hormel vice-president. Spam was short, sharp, easy on the tongue, and it accurately described the contents of the tin. In retrospect, Daigneau may have felt that he undersold his brainwave. So, in May 1937, cans of Spam began rolling off the production line in Spam City, better known as Austin, Minnesota, and into history. In some ways Spam was the beneficiary of burgeoning commercial television: Hormel exploited the potential of TV advertisements to promote his "baby". Spam became the first product to have its own advertising jingle, borrowed from the tune of My Bonnie Lies Over the Ocean, and to have its own star endorsement, when George Burns and Gracie Allen were signed up to promote it. While Spam was well established in America by 1939, it was the war that propelled the product to international stardom. Sales of Spam doubled between 1939 and 1942. By 1944, 90% of all Hormel products were exported. Spam was the staple that Uncle Sam used to feed his own armies (to the extent that American soldiers began to complain about being over-Spammed) and was also sent to keep his European allies in fighting shape. "Without Spam we wouldn't have been able to feed the army," said Nikita Khrushchev. But it was in Britain that Spam became the biggest hit. Meat was rationed by price to one or two shillings' worth per week. The bacon ration fluctuated between 4oz and 8oz per week, the ration for fats, including butter, marge and lard and cheese between 1oz and 8oz a week, with 8oz to 1lb of sugar and 2oz to 4oz of tea. As George Orwell wrote in 1942, "War and the consequent abandonment of imports tend to reduce us to the natural diet of these islands, which is healthy but rather dull." Into this sea of universal deprivation was lobbed Spam. Small wonder people like my mother took to it, making sandwiches with it, fritters, Spam rarebits, and baking it with cloves, brown sugar, mustard and vinegar. Spam is both an inspiration and a challenge, as Patten's recipes make clear. Spam and mushroom ramekins, Spam caesar salad, Spam crostini, deep Spam pizza, Spam and fruit stir-fry and even Spam goulash reflect its versatility, if not an unerring sense of taste. When all's said and done, however, there's no use pretending that Spam is likely to achieve its former glory in the pantheon of the pantry. There may have been 5bn cans of the stuff sold by 1994 - enough to circle the globe 10 times; it may even still be big in Hawaii, where they eat four cans per head per year. But the day of meat pastes and canned meat products in polite society is gone, elbowed aside by vulgar newcomers - salamis and plastic packed exotic hams, vacuum-packed sausages and cooked/chilled conveniences. Nevertheless, there will always be some kitchen cupboards where the can of Spam will nestle alongside the Bird's custard, Heinz baked beans and Nestlé's condensed milk, ready to be fetched down in times of stress and suffering.  The recipes below are taken from Spam: The Cookbook, by Marguerite Patten, published today by Hamlyn, priced £6.99. Mmm . . . some serving suggestions Spam tortilla 1 tbsp olive oil 1 small onion, finely chopped 1 potato, cooked and cut into 5mm dice 125g Spam, cut into 5mm dice 4 large eggs, beaten 25g (2 tbsp) butter 1 tbsp chopped parsley Salt and pepper Snipped chives to garnish 1 Heat oil in a 18-20cm pan. Add onion and cook for 5 mins. Add potato and Spam, cook for 3 mins. Tip the mixture into bowl with beaten eggs. Season with salt and pepper, and mix well. 2 Heat butter in pan. Add egg mixture and parsley, and cook until firm. Slide tortilla on to a plate, cut into wedges and garnish with chives. Spam scones 250g self-raising flour, or plain flour with 2 tsp baking powder Pinch of salt 25g/2 tbsp butter or margarine 150g Spam cut into 3mm dice 150ml milk, plus extra for glazing Filling: Butter or margarine Spam Tomato and cucumber segments 1 Lightly grease a baking sheet or line it with baking parchment. Sift together the salt and flour, or flour and baking powder, in a bowl. Rub in the butter or margarine, add Spam, and enough milk to make a soft, rolling consistency. 2 Roll out the dough on a lightly floured board to 1.5cm thick. Cut into small rounds and brush the tops with milk. Place rounds on a baking sheet and bake in a preheated oven to 220C/450F/ Gas Mark 7 for 12-15 mins, until the scones feel firm when pressed at the sides. 3 Serve the scones hot with butter. Alternatively, leave them to cool, then split them and spread them with a little butter, slices of Spam and tomato and cucumber.

webTitle: Fox should not count his chickens

fields.headline: Fox should not count his chickens
fields.standfirst:
The new Mexican president has a string of ambitious reform programmes - but it will not necessarily be easy to put them into practice
More about the Mexican presidential election
fields.trailText: The Mexican elections, which this week brought to an end 71 years of rule by the Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI), confirm a steady trend towards democracy and pluralism in Latin America. Despite allegations of fraud in the presidential poll in Peru and coup attempts in Ecuador and Paraguay earlier this year, all 35 members of the Organisation of American States, except Cuba, are now run by popularly elected leaders.
fields.body:
The Mexican elections, which this week brought to an end 71 years of rule by the Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI), confirm a steady trend towards democracy and pluralism in Latin America. Despite allegations of fraud in the presidential poll in Peru and coup attempts in Ecuador and Paraguay earlier this year, all 35 members of the Organisation of American States, except Cuba, are now run by popularly elected leaders.

The Mexican presidential and congressional contests, won by the centre-right Na tional Action Party (PAN), underlined another pan- regional phenomenon: growing confidence in open markets in countries once wedded to central control and state monopoly.

Chile, which this year elected Ricardo Lagos as its first left-of-centre president since Salvador Allende, was first to open up. Argentina and Brazil have followed suit. Their path to greater prosperity has been far from smooth, dogged by job losses, a widening gap between rich and poor, and recession, from which all three are only now emerging. But there is no sign of a concerted return to the old ways.

Vicente Fox, Mexico's president-elect, is in the van of the new thinking. He has promised deregulation, competition, fiscal discipline and a balanced budget, together with an ambitious social agenda that includes a pledge to double education spending, increase subsidies for farmers, and build health clinics.

Inevitably, perhaps, Mr Fox's aspirations have been dubbed a "Mexican third way". He is an ardent supporter of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) which links Mexico with the US and Canada. Nafta is the model for the Clinton administration's ambition of building a global trading system in America's own image.

Mr Fox predicts sustained annual growth of 7% (annual GDP growth was in fact 7.9% in the first quarter of this year); the creation of new jobs at the rate of 1.35m a year; new foreign investment and re-investment of profits by international companies already operating in Mexico; and the boosting of federal and state revenues by reducing tax evasion. It is a tall order. The distance Mexico needs to travel is shown in the chart - its GDP per head is under a third of that of the the US. Some economists fear the economy may overheat if growth continues at present levels. If Mr Fox puts his spending programmes into effect, they say, they will push up wage and price inflation (which after a long battle has been contained at an annual rate of about 10%).

Others predict the very opposite. Mexico depends for a third of its export income on oil. A sudden dip in its international price, an unexpected "hard landing" by the American economy or a crisis in investor and money market confidence (leading to a crash such as that which confronted President Ernesto Zedillo before he took office in 1994) could end Mr Fox's honeymoon almost before it has begun.

Such worries are not far-fetched. A lot could go wrong before Mr Fox is inaugurated on December 1; and the willingness of the PRI to facilitate a smooth transition of power has yet to be demon strated in practice. Nor is the PAN likely to have things all its own way politically. Despite losing the presidency, the PRI may have sufficient congressional seats, when combined with those of smaller parties, to block the constitutional and structural reforms that are the crux of Mr Fox's legislative programme. The PRI retains control of half the country's 32 state governorships and numerous municipalities.

Mr Fox also has to contend with the 3.5m-strong federal bureaucracy. Many officials owe their livelihoods to PRI patronage and cronyism. Then there are the public sector trade unions, worried about jobs and wages.

All the same, in the battles that lie ahead, Mr Fox has a powerful ally in the US, to which Mexico sends 90% of its exports. That bilateral trading relationship is worth nearly $300bn annually. Apparently unfazed by historical and nationalist concerns about Mexico's independence from its domineering neighbour, Mr Fox seems keen to cement the relationship. And in the White House, on Capitol Hill, and on Wall Street, amid warm applause for his electoral success, the feeling is fully reciprocated.

The reasons for American enthusiasm are straightforward enough. In the state department's global view, democracy and free trade are the new credo for a post-ideological world. This has been Washington's consistent message to Latin America since Bill Clinton took office in 1993. It is unlikely to change, whoever succeeds him. And Mr Fox is speaking America's language.

In Nafta, the US has a blueprint for the sort of economic-strategic relationships it wishes to build elsewhere, not just more widely in Latin America but also, for example, in east Asia. Mr Fox not only backs Nafta, he wants to expand and deepen the treaty. One reason is to resolve the problem of migrant Mexican workers who cross the border to work illegally in the US.

Mr Fox's pledges to balance the budget and to deregulate or liberalise public sector industries such as oil, electricity and petrochemicals are music to the ears of American investment bankers. He has also com mitted himself to a sweeping reorganisation of Mexican federal law enforcement - which amounts to an oblique admission that American complaints about official connivance in drug-trafficking have been justified.

The president-elect even announced this week that he will travel to the US to consult Mr Clinton and both his would-be successors, Al Gore and George W Bush, before he embarks on his own grand crusade. From the perspective of Washington DC, Mr Fox combines sound democratic credentials, political can-do and the correct economic instincts. It is a perfect mix. Whether it will serve equally well the interests of the Mexican people, to whom he has promised so much, so quickly, is far less certain.

simon.tisdall@theguardian.com

fields.headline: West Bank settlers furious at 'betrayal'
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: When the cabinet minister came calling at this isolated Jewish outpost, settler Dvir Grünzweig did not bother to conceal his disgust, venting anger liberally on the virtual captive plonked on the sofa of his spanking new semi-detached home.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Psagot, West Bank
fields.body:
When the cabinet minister came calling at this isolated Jewish outpost, settler Dvir Grünzweig did not bother to conceal his disgust, venting anger liberally on the virtual captive plonked on the sofa of his spanking new semi-detached home.

"I told him that he was a puppet, that he had blood on his hands, and that I could not believe a word he said," Mr Grünzweig said yesterday.

Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, communications minister and a close ally of the prime minister, Ehud Barak, slunk home, having failed miserably in his mission to convince Jewish settlers on the West Bank that the government had their interests at heart in negotiations with the Palestinians.

Yesterday, the 231 families of Psagot, a hilltop settlement only yards from the urban sprawl of El-Bireh-Ramallah, the twin cities that are the centre of Palestinian life on the West Bank, could see only disaster ahead as Mr Barak prepares for next week's summit at Camp David.

The settlers are livid at Mr Barak's broad hints last month that some 20% of the 200,000 Jewish settlers on the West Bank and Gaza - especially those living in small, isolated outposts like Psagot - will be evacuated to Israel proper or forced to live under Palestinian sovereignty in an agreement with Yasser Arafat.

Subsequent government leaks have spoken of a return of more than 90% of the West Bank, and although the people of Psagot have yet to see maps of the proposed borders, they know they are vulnerable.

Many of the settlers, who arrived in lands occupied after the 1967 war, did so with government encouragement, and hefty subsidies.

Psagot, founded 20 years ago by religious nationalists, has a temporary feel. None of the settlers dare set foot in El-Bireh, which lies just beyond their electronic gates, and an army camp sits uneasily with the paddling pools, children's bicycles and other totems of the Israeli suburban dream.

The majority of Israelis see the settlers as land-grabbing opportunists, and a constant irritant to the Palestinians whose lands they occupy.

"They really believe that there is some kind of Utopian peace before us, and I think they are like ostriches burying their heads in the sand," said Devorah Dudovitz, a social worker who is employed in Jerusalem, about half an hour's drive away.

As Mr Barak heads off to Camp David, the settlers are gearing up for a campaign to persuade Israelis that the settlements are vital to the Zionist mission, and that abandoning them would polarise the country.

There are hectoring banners all around Psagot, reading: "Barak, you don't abandon your brothers" and "Barak is losing the state", and people have clambered on to buses to join protest rallies in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv.

Ms Dudovitz believes the Palestinians will never be satisfied with the forced evacuation of some settlements and is plotting for the annihilation of the entire state of Israel.

"This is the frontline for the rest of the country. If Psagot and the rest of the settlements go, it opens the whole country up to a dangerous situation. I do not think there can be peace here even if we give up everything."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article about Sigourney Weaver, In a galaxy of her own, Weekend, April 22, we said that "there was one long relationship lasting four years with the detective fiction writer James McClure". In fact, this James McClure was a writer and actor, and not the detective fiction writer who happens to have the same name. We apologise for any distress we may have caused to James McClure the detective fiction writer and his family.
fields.body:
In an article about Sigourney Weaver, In a galaxy of her own, Weekend, April 22, we said that "there was one long relationship lasting four years with the detective fiction writer James McClure". In fact, this James McClure was a writer and actor, and not the detective fiction writer who happens to have the same name. We apologise for any distress we may have caused to James McClure the detective fiction writer and his family.

An article by our architecture correspondent headed Do architects have a future? pages 10 and 11, G2, June 26, made use of two pieces in the magazine Building Design (its issue of June 16) but appeared without an acknowledge ment to the source. There should have been one. Apologies to Building Design.

In a column in Sport, page 7, July 3, we said that Stanley Matthews was knighted within weeks of the 1953 Cup Final. Not quite. He was knighted in 1965, the year he retired.

The photographer referred to in a piece headed Of mouths and men, page 8 (Women), G2 yesterday, is Robert Doisneau, not D'Oisneau.

English department, from a column, page 17, G2, July 5, where we referred to "a tough anti-drugs policy, which mitigates against mass oblivion". With or without drugs, it should still be mili tates; an error that resists oblivion.

Not even a homophone, from page 22 (Obituaries), yesterday, where we mentioned "the Abwehr officer who had reaped havoc among the French Resistance". Wreaked havoc.

webTitle: MP Follett backs husband on 'sneer and smear'

fields.headline: MP Follett backs husband on 'sneer and smear'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour MP, Barbara Follett, has publicly backed the outspoken attack on Tony Blair made by her novelist husband Ken, and called on the government and the Labour party to get rid of the "sneer and smear" culture in politics.
fields.body:
The Labour MP, Barbara Follett, has publicly backed the outspoken attack on Tony Blair made by her novelist husband Ken, and called on the government and the Labour party to get rid of the "sneer and smear" culture in politics.

Mrs Follett, until now a devoted Blairite MP, revealed that she argued for two weeks with her husband, the millionaire thriller writer and Labour fund raiser, over his plans to accuse the prime minister of allowing negative briefings against his own ministers by Downing Street spin doctors.

Mr Follett's scathing personal attack on Mr Blair accused him of being immoral, unmanly, and cowardly, and alleged that he tacitly supported the "malicious gossip" spread about ministers, including Mo Mowlam.The criticism was dismissed by Downing Street as "self-indulgent rant".

Now the novelist's wife, writing in the New Statesman magazine, has urged her party colleagues to admit that negative briefing exists and to make "real changes" to bring it to an end.

The Stevenage MP wrote: "Responsibility was the theme of Ken's article on negative briefing. We had talked and argued about it for two weeks. I understand his passionate dislike of the practice. I knew why he believed that it was necessary to bring it into the open. I would rather have dealt with it behind closed doors." She went on: "But, as Ken kept pointing out, people have been trying to do that for years and failed. In the end, Ken is his own person and has to do what he believes is right."

Mrs Follett, who was credited for giving Labour MPs a fashion makeover ahead of the 1997 election campaign, continued: "We have to change the sneer and smear culture of politics.

"People say to me: 'Well, it's a dirty old trade; if you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.' I say: 'New Labour, new kitchen.' We promised to make things better. We all have a part to play in this change. We all have to take responsibility for it.

"First and foremost, we must all admit, not just behind our hands, that negative briefing happens. Then we must make some real changes."

She went on to call for televised lobby briefings and an end to publication of unattributed remarks, and criticised newspapers for offering "bribes" to parliamentary staff in return for gossip, concluding: "Politics will always be rough, but it does not have to be dirty. It is time we cleaned up our act."

The MP also revealed her anxiety about seeing her colleagues at the Commons on Monday, the day after her husband's article was published.

Mrs Follett, until now a devoted Blairite MP, revealed that she argued for two weeks with her husband, the millionaire thriller writer and Labour fund raiser, over his plans to accuse the prime minister of allowing negative briefings against his own ministers by Downing Street spin doctors. Mr Follett's scathing personal attack on Mr Blair accused him of being immoral, unmanly, and cowardly, and alleged that he tacitly supported the "malicious gossip" spread about ministers, including Mo Mowlam.The criticism was dismissed by Downing Street as "self-indulgent rant". Now the novelist's wife, writing in the New Statesman magazine, has urged her party colleagues to admit that negative briefing exists and to make "real changes" to bring it to an end. The Stevenage MP wrote: "Responsibility was the theme of Ken's article on negative briefing. We had talked and argued about it for two weeks. I understand his passionate dislike of the practice. I knew why he believed that it was necessary to bring it into the open. I would rather have dealt with it behind closed doors." She went on: "But, as Ken kept pointing out, people have been trying to do that for years and failed. In the end, Ken is his own person and has to do what he believes is right." Mrs Follett, who was credited for giving Labour MPs a fashion makeover ahead of the 1997 election campaign, continued: "We have to change the sneer and smear culture of politics. "People say to me: 'Well, it's a dirty old trade; if you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.' I say: 'New Labour, new kitchen.' We promised to make things better. webTitle: The Orange Order have got the pip

fields.headline: The Orange Order have got the pip
fields.standfirst:
Their incoherent rage could yet threaten the peace process
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Drumcree has always been a means to take the temperature of the Protestant and unionist community in Northern Ireland. What the burnings, stonings and blocked roads of the past few nights reveal is that one of the major institutions of that community, the Orange Order, is in crisis.
fields.body:
Drumcree has always been a means to take the temperature of the Protestant and unionist community in Northern Ireland. What the burnings, stonings and blocked roads of the past few nights reveal is that one of the major institutions of that community, the Orange Order, is in crisis.

In the past, Orange aristocratic and capitalist grandees may have cynically manipulated the loyalist masses - but at least the grandees had some capacity for politics. Orangeism no longer has that sort of leadership. The new leaders, drawn principally from the lower middle class and upper working class, are hopelessly out of their depth. The strategy committee of the Orange Order has not met for months.

In some ways this is risible, but it also means that it is exceptionally difficult for the government - which may have been too sanguine going into this crisis - to plan against an incoherent and unpredictable threat.

In recent weeks, the intellectual and modernising wing of Orangeism around the Rev Brian Kennaway has resigned en masse from the order's education committee. Historians and commentators who have in the recent past written sympathetically of the Orange tradition have been repelled. The order, in compensation, has found a new public friend, Johnny Adair, who fills the Catholic community with loathing but also leaves a large part of respectable rural Orangeism feeling very uncomfortable.

The order enters this conflict armed, however, with two potent weapons. The first is that it is still the primary focus for the loyalism of tens of thousands of ordinary Protestants. They all consider the long-established Drumcree parade to be a basic civil right requiring tolerance from opponents - exactly the case made by the early civil rights marchers in the province.

Secondly, the order can exploit loyalists' belief that they have been betrayed by the prime minister, arguing that an implicit promise of a Drumcree parade this year - in exchange for good behaviour last - has not been kept.

In fact, matters are more complex: the new Parades Commission - as Brendan McKenna of the Garvaghy Road Residents' Coalition has nervously pointed out - is significantly different in composition from its predecessor. It gives an impression of having an ear for legitimate Orange concerns, though because it has not spelled this out categorically, those in the order who might want to de-escalate do not yet have a strong case.

Moralising about thuggery will have little effect. The peace process has saved hundreds of lives but it has done so at the cost of offering certain limited rewards to men of violence. Anyway, the rioters in Belfast come from communities that have long hated the police.

But the Orange Order itself has a more specific and genuine problem. How does it square current activities with its own proud traditions? The small church at Drumcree has seen dozens of parishioners, many of them Orangemen, die in British army uniform in the past century. They are honoured figures in the local Orange tradition. How can the order be happy with the slide into conflict with the same British army?

What does it all mean for the Good Friday agreement? From David Trimble's point of view, second time around, the institutions have worked more smoothly. There has been real movement by the IRA on arms. Most important, his "structural unionism" has appeared to have considerable force behind it. He insists that the agreement is essentially partitionist. There may be a Sinn Fein minister of health, but she spends her time attending meetings with Tony Blair on the new UK plans for the National Health Service.

But as his anti-agreement opponents do everything they can to fuel Protestant alienation, Mr Trimble is nowhere near the point where there is sufficient self-confidence within his own community to ignore street politics. Pro-agreement unionism has failed to convey the message that moderation is not defeatism.

The first minister, along with the prime minister, has put a lot of work behind the scenes into resolving the Drumcree issue, but they are both helpless now, unlike in 1998. Drumcree no longer has the capacity to destabilise the agreement on its own. The Orange Order, though important, is no longer a hegemonic force within unionism.

Even so, much depends on the answer to an awful question - if there is to be loss of life as the protests inevitably intensify, who will be the first martyr? The poison that flows out of this crisis could play a major role in destabilising the agreement in the autumn. That is why Peter Mandelson looks on so nervously.

The author is professor of Irish politics at Queen's University, Belfast.

fields.headline: Malice in Labour land
fields.trailText: Ben Bradshaw MP is either naive or a toady, or both (Letters, July 6). Instead of asking Ken Follett to provide evidence for his allegations of mischievous briefings against Labour ministers, he should be praising him for having had the courage to speak out.
fields.body:
Ben Bradshaw MP is either naive or a toady, or both (Letters, July 6). Instead of asking Ken Follett to provide evidence for his allegations of mischievous briefings against Labour ministers, he should be praising him for having had the courage to speak out.

Anyone closely involved with the Labour party knows that from about 1986 onwards the practice of briefing, often virulently and dishonestly, against certain then Labour shadow spokespeople and other perceived enemies of the "project" became common practice.

It was well known that David Clark was constantly undermined while a minister: Roy Hattersley has given evidence of this. Frank Field suffered similar treatment. Others who have displeased the New Labour machine, such as Greg Palast and Lord Winston, have been smeared and ridiculed.

I do not know whether Tony Blair encourages this practice, but he knows that it goes on and who is doing it; and, as Follett says, he could put an end to it. Similarly, newspaper editors and journalists could stop colluding with the malevolent briefers. They could make a start by refusing to publish unattributable briefings, as serious newspapers do in the US.
Stuart Weir
Wrington, Somerset

I believe Jonathan Freedland (Careless talk costs votes, July 5) and others make a big mistake in urging the left to support the government in order to prevent the Tories winning the next election. If the left remains silent over such issues as the government's treatment of asylum seekers, New Labour will pander more and more to Daily Mail readers and the whole political agenda will slide further to the right.

The question will become who can be toughest on asylum seekers, with no one challenging the prejudice facing some of the most vulnerable people in society. If we let Tony Blair and Jack Straw fight on the rightwing ground they favour, the Tories will always win the argument. To convince people the left needs to stand up for what we believe - or the Tories will the next election, whoever gets the most votes.
James Woodcock
London jdwoodcock@bmjgroup.com

If the choice is between expecting nothing and getting it, or expecting lots and being constantly disappointed then it is only sensible to manage your emotions, go for the former, and vote Tory. Fortunately there are other options, including staying at home on polling day.
Xavier Gallagher
London xavierg@dircon.co.uk

fields.headline: No battle lines here
fields.trailText: I would like to correct the impression given about the exchange between myself and John Battle after I raised the case of my constituent Mohammed Chaudhry, who has been detained without charge in a Saudi jail (Angry minister in SAS outburst, July 6).
fields.body:
I would like to correct the impression given about the exchange between myself and John Battle after I raised the case of my constituent Mohammed Chaudhry, who has been detained without charge in a Saudi jail (Angry minister in SAS outburst, July 6). He did not follow me to harangue me. I had asked John to stay for a few minutes after the debate to speak to Mrs Chaudhry and he kindly did so, even though he had another engagement. I attribute his loss of cool to his frustration at being caught between the need to respond to my questions and the need for him to be elsewhere.
Lynne Jones MP
House of Commons

It seems that we believe "previous Pakistani governments, though democratic in name, were shambolic" (Britain lifts ban on Pakistan arms sales, July 6). And Mussolini made the trains run on time. So that's alright then.
Ivan Pope
London ivan@pregenesis.com

So Mel Gibson's new film, The Patriot, about the American fight for independence shows the Brits as sadists (What the Americans really think of us, July 4). Let's find the container ship with the reels, dress up in disguises, and tip them into Tilbury Docks.
Duncan McKeown
Norwich, Norfolk duncan@thegamesroom.fsnet.co.uk

Where is the money Gordon Brown announced going (£1bn for science, July 6)? Oxford or Cambridge ?
Simon Nee
Loughborough, Leics
S.P.Nee1@lboro.ac.uk

There is an old conundrum about whether a tree makes a noise as it falls if no one is there to hear it. Would the Drumcree hooligans riot if there was no media there to report it?
Brian Robinson
Brentwood, Essex

webTitle: Fear can block even the information highway

fields.headline: Fear can block even the information highway
fields.standfirst:
Much of eastern Europe still hasn't got the hang of press freedom
Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: The wired world was supposed to be peculiarly resistant to attempts to hinder the free flow of information. In the old days, authoritarian states censored the press, padlocked telex machines, tapped phones, jammed broadcasts, and even went to such grotesque lengths as to register every typewriter. With the internet, and with allied changes in broadcasting and print publishing, this kind of crude control was going to go out of the window.
fields.body:
The wired world was supposed to be peculiarly resistant to attempts to hinder the free flow of information. In the old days, authoritarian states censored the press, padlocked telex machines, tapped phones, jammed broadcasts, and even went to such grotesque lengths as to register every typewriter. With the internet, and with allied changes in broadcasting and print publishing, this kind of crude control was going to go out of the window.

Sadly, while it is true that the new technology can be an aid to the critical journalism societies need if they are to become, or to remain, democratic, it is also true that the hardware matters much less than the software - in this case that softest and most vulnerable of stuffs, the individual human being. States have not ceased to try to control the hardware, as Russian and Chinese efforts to restrict the internet show. But the new strategies of information control target people even more than in the past, aiming to intimidate them into a self-censorship that can be frighteningly effective. Worse, such intimidation can also be effective in choking off those international efforts to bypass domestic information control which new technology was supposed to enhance. Those efforts depend on the readiness of journalists and others to transmit information out of their countries so that it can become internationally known, and, crucially, so that it can then be transmitted back to the country concerned. Here it is certainly the case that the net, as well as international broadcasting, cannot be as easily shut down as other information conduits in the past. But if you can frighten the information gatherers into silence, all the technical wizardry in the world will be to no avail. There is no electronic substitute for the human act of witness.

Last night in London Miroslav Filipovic was named European internet journalist of the year in the NetMedia awards at City University. The award was collected by his son and daughter, because their father is in jail in Nis on espionage charges. Filipovic worked for the Serbian paper Danas, for Agence France Presse, and for the London based Institute for War and Peace Reporting. The IWPR is a charitable organisation whose purpose is to support independent media in the Balkans, the Caucasus, Central Asia, and some other areas. The main form this support has taken has been the regular publication, in the early years on paper but now electronically, of critical reporting from these regions by local correspondents. Much of this work is of the kind that could not be published, or not published in such a complete way, in the countries of which the correspondents are citizens. It is intended for an international audience but also for "home" audiences. It has often been one of the few sources of reliable information when the local media have been stifled - information not only about their own societies but about neighbouring societies with which they have hostile or difficult relations. It may initially reach only a small, educated and computer literate group, but there are ways in which it then sometimes diffuses quite widely. This is the bypass technique referred to above. To use another metaphor, the idea is to provide a kind of iron lung, enabling a suppressed or enfeebled journalism to breathe - and to survive until better times.

Miroslav Filipovic's main crime in the eyes of the Serbian authorities was probably to file a story based on a Yugoslav army investigation into military behaviour in Kosovo. The story quoted testimony from officers who had been horrified by atrocities they saw committed, usually by reservists or irregulars. Other Filipovic stories may also have angered the regime. In any event, he was arrested, interrogated, released, and then rearrested. The charges he faces could lead to a sentence of up to 15 years. Needless to say, the law is so broadly drawn that there is no requirement to prove he was in contact with a foreign intelligence organisation. Using other catch-all statutes, the Milosevic government has in the past few months battered down the relatively free media which had somehow survived in Serbia. Independent radio and television stations have had their equipment destroyed or confiscated. Independent newspapers have been systematically fined, and some have been bankrupted. More than 20 journalists have been killed, 60 have been arrested, at least six have gone to prison. An even more sweeping law, supposedly aimed at combating "terrorism", has just been postponed for some reason, but waits in the wings in case more powers are needed.

In the context of this campaign, the fate of Filipovic suggests that the regime believes it has achieved its aim of inducing a fearful self-censorship by the remaining independent organs, and is now moving to close off the last remaining channels of information, those that work through foreign connections. The independent broadcaster Veran Matic has argued that Serbia is creating a model for "some new breed of east European democratic dictatorship". Certainly similar tendencies, if not always so far advanced, can be seen in a number of other countries. In Russia, the arrest of Vladimir Gusinsky, the media magnate whose programmes have criticised and mocked Vladimir Putin, and the detention of Andrei Babitsky after his reporting in Chechnya, suggest that the government intends to "manage" the media more ruthlessly. The corruption of much of the Russian media, which one critic has defined as 60% devoted to disinformation and slander, might make that task easier. In Belarus the independent media are under siege. In Central Asia, the media are expected to utter no word against the autocratic presidential rule that is standard in all five republics, with the partial exception of Kirgizstan. In Kazakhstan, one of the last independent papers, the wonderfully named Let's Survive till Monday, has unhappily not survived a legal assault which ended in the confiscation not only of the paper's assets but of the personal wealth of the editors. Some other former Soviet countries could be added to this list.

The efforts made by a number of media support organisations and by western governments have helped stave off the worst. But the interest of western governments, at least, may be waning, in the case of Serbia because they can see no easy means to influence the regime, and in the case of the Soviet successor states because of the desperate desire to "do business" with their governments, and particularly with Putin. Yet devising outside ways to keep independent media alive, and to help men like Miroslav Filipovic or Andrei Babitsky, is more critical today, when the shades are lengthening, than it was in the happy years of the early 90s when everyone wanted to do something for east European journalism.

Martin Woollacott is a board member of IWPR. martin.woollacott@theguardian.com

For information on the Filipovic case and on the defence and family support fund consult www.iwpr.net

fields.headline: In the centre
fields.trailText: Mathew Engel's idea for moving the politicians out of London (Chucking them out, July 4) sounds great. I thought I'd try to find the geographical centre of Britain for the site of a truly British parliament.
fields.body:
Mathew Engel's idea for moving the politicians out of London (Chucking them out, July 4) sounds great. I thought I'd try to find the geographical centre of Britain for the site of a truly British parliament. I took a line from Benbane Head in Northern Ireland to Dover and found the lines crossed on the Isle of Man just outside Douglas (Hume?) at a place called Baldwin, not so far from Ramsey. As for the Lords, why not Contrary Point near Peel.
FA Beal
Cardiff

fields.headline: Women are violent too
fields.trailText: Sue Lees (Letters, July 6) asks why "young women are immune" from committing acts of violence. Apart from suggesting it is a "disease" to which men are susceptible, she could blame a society which attempts to socialise women into being compliant and docile.
fields.body:
Sue Lees (Letters, July 6) asks why "young women are immune" from committing acts of violence. Apart from suggesting it is a "disease" to which men are susceptible, she could blame a society which attempts to socialise women into being compliant and docile. Claiming that centuries of gender stereotyping result in gender-specific genetic protection which can then be reclaimed as form of superior wisdom is not wise; after all, feminists proclaimed "biology is not destiny".
D Cameron
Stoke-on-Trent d.f.i.cameron@staffs.ac.uk

Evidence of increased violence among young women may be attributed to poverty. We should also be aware that women sometimes act differently to men. They may take drugs, enter prostitution, have illegitimate children, be unable to form stable relationships, or they may commit self harm. We should not allow outdated 70s feminist attitudes blind us to the damage caused to both sexes by poverty.
A James
Llandrindod Wells, Powys

Men are violent and women are passive: this may have been true 20 years ago but today there are rising gangs of young women and the domestic assaults in America are estimated to be almost 50% women against men, and much evidence shows that it is going the same way here.
Nick Fearns
Maldon, Essex pinkvinyl@hotmail.com

webTitle: Cars are not a luxury far from the tube

fields.headline: Cars are not a luxury far from the tube
fields.trailText: Do I detect in Catherine Bennett's article on fuel prices (Pump up those prices, July 6) the smug sneer of someone who lives a short walk from the nearest tube station? Life without a car is perfectly feasible where a regular and convenient public service exists.
fields.body:
Do I detect in Catherine Bennett's article on fuel prices (Pump up those prices, July 6) the smug sneer of someone who lives a short walk from the nearest tube station? Life without a car is perfectly feasible where a regular and convenient public service exists. For the rest of us, the reality is somewhat different. I'm sure Ms Bennett would no more wait an hour or so for a bus to take her four miles home from the railway station than I do.
Andrew Rose
Boughton under Blean, Kent

In case Catherine Bennett has not noticed, not all car owners are "city dwellers who drive cars with gargantuan engines" a large proportion of us live in the country where a car is no more a luxury than the food that we could not purchase without it.

I realise that the anti-pollution lobby makes sense, but when will something be done about the vast pollution caused by airliners rumbling across our skies?
Malcolm Collins
Stone Allerton, Somerset

Well done to Catherine Bennett for talking sense, in contrast to the likes of Steve Norris and the other car- monsters, who would have us believe that driving a car is our natural heritage (all the better to drive an expensive car dangerously).

We should go a stage further by insisting that all drivers requalify every two or three years. I wouldn't expect to be able to wear the same glasses that were prescribed even three years ago, never mind 15, 20 or more, so why should we imagine that drivers have the same level of ability as they did when they first passed their test?
Tom Locke
Burntisland, Fife Tom.Locke@kscl.com

I have just taken a short walk in Glasgow's west end to buy a lunchtime sandwich. On the walk back I counted no less than eight parked vehicles, all with engines left running with their occupiers variously reading newspapers, eating their lunch or just sitting waiting for something. Petrol too expensive? Obviously not for these people.
Dr Stephen Forrow
Glasgow smf10b@clinmed.gla.ac.uk

fields.headline: Not racists
fields.trailText: Your article on the community at Stentwood Farm in Devon (Racist sect digs in at rock festival, July 3) is filled with inflammatory half-truths.
fields.body:
Your article on the community at Stentwood Farm in Devon (Racist sect digs in at rock festival, July 3) is filled with inflammatory half-truths.

We are absolutely not "anti-semitic". In fact our Messiah and all of his first apostles were Jews. Many of our people are from a Jewish background.

What we do not like is the murderous aspect of most of the major organised religions of today, which have approved the slaughter of those who do not agree with their beliefs. The killing of Jesus Christ was only one of these incidents. To mention this fact should not be considered anti-semitic.
Yael Stagg
Stentwood Farm, Dunkeswell, Devon

fields.trailText: Silver tongued David Blunkett managed to overheat somewhat while at the despatch box laying into Conservative policies. The education and employment secretary accused the Tories of doing "sod all" about literacy standards. Before the deputy speaker could tick him off Mr Blunkett realised   his error. "That was entirely unparliamentary language and I have corrected myself," he said.
fields.body:
Retraction of day

Silver tongued David Blunkett managed to overheat somewhat while at the despatch box laying into Conservative policies. The education and employment secretary accused the Tories of doing "sod all" about literacy standards. Before the deputy speaker could tick him off Mr Blunkett realised his error. "That was entirely unparliamentary language and I have corrected myself," he said.

Haute cuisine

There has been a surprise for MPs on top of the discovery of marijuana plants growing in Parliament Square next to the House of Commons. May Day guerrilla gardeners who planted the dope seeds also planted a few others. Royal Parks police say horticulturists have identified gladioli, marigold, carrots, onions, barley, broad beans and potatoes.

Today

Commons: Debate on report of the committee of inquiry into hunting with dogs in England and Wales. Backbench debate on installation of safe cells to prevent suicides in prison. Lords: Life peerages (appointments commission) bill, third reading. Health services commissioners (amendment) bill, second reading.

webTitle: Hit or miss trial for son of Star Wars

fields.headline: Hit or miss trial for son of Star Wars
fields.standfirst: Clinton quietly hopes for failure in test on US missile defence system
fields.trailText: It has a record of dismal failure. Fifty Nobel laureates have called it a waste of money that will jeopardise world peace. The White House privately hopes it will not work. But the US national missile defence project (NMD) is proceeding at full steam.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
It has a record of dismal failure. Fifty Nobel laureates have called it a waste of money that will jeopardise world peace. The White House privately hopes it will not work. But the US national missile defence project (NMD) is proceeding at full steam.

In a test late tonight, the Pentagon will make its third attempt to shoot down a mock warhead over the Pacific Ocean.

If the test works there will be intense pressure on President Clinton to approve the first phase of the $60bn programme - known as the "son of Star Wars" - which comprises an array of radars, missiles and computers supposed to provide the US with a shield against missile attack by "rogue states".

The test has been manipulated to give it every possible chance of success. The $30m interceptor launched from Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific will "know" where the target is coming from and where it is heading. The mock warhead, which will take off 125 miles north of Los Angeles, will be travelling relatively slowly and will continually broadcast its position to the interceptor.

"It will be liking shooting ducks at a funfair," said Chris Hellman, a senior analyst at the Centre for Defence Information thinktank in Washington.

In the last try-out in January, the interceptor missed its target because of a cooling malfunction. According to critics and some of the Pentagon's own analysts, other tests have been rigged to cover up the fact that the interceptor has been unable to distinguish between warheads and decoys.

The vested interests in a success this time are enormous. No one wants to look "soft on defence" in an election year, and the lobbyists for the four major contractors, Boeing, Raytheon, TRW and Lockheed Martin, are lubricating its passage through an already enthusiastic Congress. A live broadcast at the test is to be hosted by Boeing.

"This thing is running us," said Alan Kliegerman, a leading Democratic party donor, and a board member of Business Leaders for Social Priorities. "Almost in its totality it's being pushed because the companies need the business."

Mr Clinton was initially opposed to resurrecting President Reagan's Star Wars nuclear umbrella scheme, but adopted a scaled-down version of the plan to steal the thunder of a rightwing Republican challenge in the wake of the 1994 congressional elections.

That plan envisaged an anti-missile shield based only in one place - in Grand Forks, North Dakota - where it would theoretically be allowed by the Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) treaty, one of the main pillars of global nuclear arms control.

But when it was discovered that that shield would not cover remote islands in Alaska, the Alaskan Republican senator, Ted Stevens, led a campaign for a bigger, far more expensive plan, with key installations in Alaska's Aleutian islands.

The NMD project in its current form would violate the ABM treaty. It has generated anger in Russia and China, unease in Europe, and alarm among many US scientists.

Fifty US Nobel laureates signed an open letter to President Clinton yesterday urging him to scrap the scheme.

"The system would offer little protection and would do grave harm to this nation's core security interests," the laureates wrote. The first to sign was Hans Bethe, a physicist who was one of the main architects of the atom bomb.

White House officials privately agree with many of the misgivings, and say that a failure tomorrow would be welcome, as it would make it easier for Mr Clinton to delay a decision committing the country to the scheme.

European governments, including the British, are desperately hoping that Mr Clinton will put off the decision on whether the test is deemed a success. Whitehall officials say that opposition within Europe to the project is increasing rather than diminishing, despite Washington's claims to the contrary.

Faced with the prospect of having to allow the US to build a radar system at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire, British ministers have refused to comment publicly on the project in an attempt to stifle debate.

Both the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, repeat the mantra that they will "consider" proposals to build new US radar systems in Britain when they receive a formal request from the US.

But privately, Mr Cook and military chiefs are hostile to the NMD project. They believe that it will threaten existing arms control agreements, as well as being unnecessary and not technologically feasible.

In common with other European allies - notably Germany and France - Britain does not share the assessment by some elements in the US intelligence and military community of the threat posed by such countries as North Korea, Iran, and Iraq.

Mr Hoon came close to distancing himself from US calculations when he told the Commons this week that according to British assessments there was no significant threat to the UK from weapons of mass destruction.

A decision by Mr Clinton to leave a decision on NMD to his successor will give Europeans much-needed breathing space, said one Whitehall official. He conceded that a British decision to allow the US to upgrade Fylingdales would be "very difficult".

The US is already upgrading its eavesdropping base at Menwith Hill, near Harrogate in North Yorkshire, to install a space-based infrared radar system for the NMD project. But that base is already substantial. Building a large new radar system at Fylingdales will invite more protests, officials says.

British MPs are becoming increasingly unhappy about the government's continuing refusal to engage in a public debate on such a controversial development.

"NMD is a mad idea; it is unlikely to work technically and it will have a destabilising effect on world security", Phyllis Starkey, a Labour member of the Commons foreign relations committee, said yesterday. "America's 'rogue state' hypothesis just not credible."

The committee is expected to deliver a strong critique of NMD in a report due to be published next month.

America's European allies believe that the NMD project would provoke Russia into taking countermeasures. The latest issue of the authoritative US publication, Defence News, says that Moscow is seriously considering abrogating the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces treaty which led to the scrapping of many US and Soviet intermediate-range nuclear missiles in the 1980s.

The Europeans believe NMD would prompt China into building more long-range missiles which would provoke an arms race in south Asia.

They privately welcome the proposal from the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, for a system - to cover the whole of Europe - designed to attack incoming missiles soon after they have been fired.

Though this would be even more difficult technologically than Washington's NMD project, it would prolong the debate, and put off difficult decisions, Europeans hope.

NMD reflects an "erosion of the belief in deterrence", Dan Plesch, director of the British American Security Information Council, said yesterday. "The choice is between a new arms race or disarmament."

Europeans fear that the US has already taken the route leading to the former.

Assessing the threat
by Richard Norton-Taylor and Ewen MacAskill

The US justification for developing the new anti-ballistic missile system is a perceived threat from countries such as North Korea, Iraq, Iran and Libya. Throughout the 90s, these countries were labelled by the US as "rogue states", a term recently downgraded to "countries of concern". But how realistic is the threat?

Iraq: As a result of disarmament and international sanctions after the Gulf war, Saddam Hussein's arsenal has been severely depleted. Although it has short-range missiles, it does not possess long-range ones, nor does it have a nuclear capability. The only threat that could be posed to the US by Iraq is from chemical or biological weapons, which are unlikely to be delivered by missiles.

Iran: Claims not to be developing nuclear weapons. A senior Pentagon official acknowledged this week that Iran's ballistic missile programme had problems and was "certainly not clicking along really fast". Some US intelligence officials say Iran could threaten the US "before 2010".

North Korea: Even US experts are divided about the danger this nation presents. Some, like Europeans, point to its suspension of missile tests last year and recent talks with South Korea as positive signs.

Libya: It is fast losing its pariah image, with Britain taking a lead in moving towards normalisation of relations. Now seen as the least likely of the four to mount an attack on the US.

webTitle: Ministers offer minimum wage link to earnings

fields.headline: Ministers offer minimum wage link to earnings
fields.standfirst:
More about the minimum wage
The minimum wage explained
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership is to pledge to link the minimum wage with average earnings in a bid to fend off union hostility at this weekend's Labour national policy forum.
fields.body:
The Labour leadership is to pledge to link the minimum wage with average earnings in a bid to fend off union hostility at this weekend's Labour national policy forum.

The party hierarchy will make the promise as well as committing itself to making the low pay commission a permanent body.

At present, the minimum wage can only be increased if ministers refer it to the commission and the body has historically been required to take account of inflation, rather than earnings.

With average earnings far outstripping inflation unions feel that more has to be done for the lower paid and ministers were well aware a concession on this issue could prevent a showdown with the unions in other key policy areas.

The three-day policy forum starting today in Exeter and addressed by a galaxy of ministers will see rows over issues kept off the agenda, including welfare and hunting.

There is also likely to be a strong push to change the franchise for ballots to scrap grammar schools.

Party activists believe ballots, such as at Ripon in North Yorkshire, have been loaded in favour of retention of selective education. In a bid to dampen anger over asylum seekers, ministers have agreed to evaluate the current voucher system against principles of integrating asylum seekers into the community and the need to eradicate child poverty.

The leadership has also promised to coordinate centrally the dispersal system for asylum seekers.

The proposal to link the minimum wage with earnings, rather than just inflation, has the support of the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers.

Both ministers think the link should be with earnings, rather than inflation, since it is not a welfare benefit, but income linked to the workplace. Earnings are rising at over 5%, but inflation is closer to 2%.

Cabinet sources said the low pay commission under its terms of reference would still be entitled to vary the regular rise to take account of the possible impact on jobs, or pressure on particular sectors.

Ministers insist there will still be no automatic annual rise.

The low pay proposal is one of a small number of concessions which party officials believe will prevent a showdown with the unions in other key policy areas. The GMB general workers union is expected to pull back from trying to force Labour to drop its pledge to hold a referendum on electoral reform if elected to a second term.

John Edmonds, the GMB general secretary, has received assurances that any such referendum will not be held until after the planned referendum on a single currency.

Mr Edmonds thinks there is no realistic lilklihood of such a second referendum being held since the party rank and file would not tolerate it.

Some policy forum delegates argued yesterday that any move to drop the referendum pledge would be a breach of faith with the electorate.

Party officials have ruled out of order all amendments from constituencies on welfare and benefits, including pensions, on the grounds that these issues were discussed in a separate policy document last year.

Ministers hope the weekend forum with 170 delegates will in effect agree the outline of Labour's manifesto.

In the process, the leadership hope to lower the tensions with the rank and file. The cabinet office minster, Ian McCartney, a key architect of the forum, said the message was: "It is important to take part, you can make a difference and you can influence policy."

Party officials have ruled out of order all amendments from constituencies on welfare and benefits, including pensions, on the grounds that these issues were discussed in a separate policy document last year. Ministers hope the weekend forum with 170 delegates will in effect agree the outline of Labour's manifesto. In the process, the leadership hope to lower the tensions with the rank and file. The cabinet office minster, Ian McCartney, a key architect of the forum, said the message was: "It is important to take part, you can make a difference and you can influence policy."

webTitle: Barak plays for high stakes at summit

fields.headline: Barak plays for high stakes at summit
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday gave himself only an even chance of pulling off the biggest gamble of his career: reaching a peace agreement with the Palestinians at the Camp David summit.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday gave himself only an even chance of pulling off the biggest gamble of his career: reaching a peace agreement with the Palestinians at the Camp David summit.

As he struggles to keep his coalition from collapse, Mr Barak is acutely conscious of warnings from Palestinian officials and his own security chiefs that the consequences of failure at Camp David could be bloodshed on a large scale.

Mr Barak told Israel Radio he could not be certain of coming to an agreement with Mr Arafat as the Palestinian leader faces a public which is also in no mood for compromise. "It is not possible to assess - 50%, like the toss of a coin," Mr Barak said.

The Israeli prime minister is taking an additional gamble in believing that he can outmanoeuvre rebellion-minded members of his coalition, who have threatened to bolt in advance of the summit, accusing him of contemplating deep concessions to the Palestinians on territory.

On Wednesday, Mr Barak said that if his coalition does collapse, he will appeal directly to the Israeli public in a national referendum.

The calculation is based on Mr Barak's historic mandate in elections last year. However, an opinion poll published in the Ma'ariv newspaper last Friday showed his popularity was fast eroding.

The Palestinian predictions for the summit yesterday were even gloomier, with the lead negotiator predicting outright failure after Mr Barak went on to reveal the five "red lines", which define the extent to which he is willing to compromise.

Yesterday, to the evident frustration of Palestinians, Mr Barak said he would refuse to consider a full Israeli withdrawal from territory on the West Bank occupied after the 1967 war, or yielding Jewish control over Jerusalem.

He also ruled out a wholesale recognition of the right of return for Palestinian refugees, and a Palestinian state which controls its own border on the Jordan river.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Vidocq And The Last Right | United We Fall
fields.body:
After a career as a soldier, acrobat, forger, swindler, thief and highwayman, François Eugene Vidocq became a police informer and went on to found the French Sreté. The first policeman to investigate crime scientifically, Edgar Allen Poe drew extensively on his memoirs. Now RJ Gallagher has resurrected him to wind up the Conan Doyle season. The Vidocq And The Last Right (2.15pm, Radio 4) is fiction, but this chilling tale of a priest's apparent suicide draws on the detective's known methods.

There was no preview tape of United We Fall (9.0pm, Radio 4) but the advance billing sounds promising. This devolutionary satire (attributed to Shakespeare, helped by Paul Stephenson) chronicles the amalgamation of Notton (whose citizens always speak in blank verse) with Sutton (addicted to rhyming couplets). The resulting borough of Snotton is soon steeped in tribal rivalries, corruption and wild tabloid excitement. Contemporary parallels are entirely coincidental.

fields.headline: Hooligans' pictures published
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: A rogues' gallery of suspected football hooligans was published by police yesterday as part of a campaign to drive offenders out of the game. The 29 high-resolution stills of Leeds United supporters - all men - were copied from hundreds of hours of security video and police photographs taken at the home leg of the club's Uefa Cup defeat by Turkish side Galatasaray.
fields.body:
A rogues' gallery of suspected football hooligans was published by police yesterday as part of a campaign to drive offenders out of the game. The 29 high-resolution stills of Leeds United supporters - all men - were copied from hundreds of hours of security video and police photographs taken at the home leg of the club's Uefa Cup defeat by Turkish side Galatasaray.

Detectives, who arrested four other men in Leeds early yesterday, said the clear and recognisable pictures sounded a warning to violent fans that they could no longer get away unpunished.

"If those who cause problems are not arrested on the day, it is now very likely that they will be in the weeks which follow," said Chief Insp Sam Warmington, of West Yorkshire police.

Emotions were high at the game, after the death of two Leeds fans before the fixture's first leg the previous week in Istanbul, where provocative behaviour by supporters of both teams led to running street battles. Eighteen men were arrested during the Leeds leg and charged with public order offences, and another is on remand charged with robbery and threatening behaviour.

Mr Warmington said: "We want to hear from anyone who recognises any of these men, and we will certainly seek to ban anyone convicted from all football games."
