fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Nimbly taking the role adopted by Sammy Davis Jnr in so many 70s Hollywood spectaculars, my old friend Alastair Campbell graced Wednesday's lobby briefing with a special guest appearance. His absence from the frontline, conducting "long-term strategic planning", has not blunted the PM's official spokesman's rare gift for handling enquiries.
fields.body:
Nimbly taking the role adopted by Sammy Davis Jnr in so many 70s Hollywood spectaculars, my old friend Alastair Campbell graced Wednesday's lobby briefing with a special guest appearance. His absence from the frontline, conducting "long-term strategic planning", has not blunted the PM's official spokesman's rare gift for handling enquiries. "Asked whether Roger Liddle would be sacked for his comment about the prime minister and the chancellor as related in the Guardian Diary," reports the Downing Street website (Mr Liddle said that they loathe each other), "the PMOS said that if we were to rely on the Guardian Diary for our assessment of what people did or did not say at dinner parties or anywhere else we would be in big trouble." Insolence. But there's more: "Asked if he was the author of the 'cash dispenser' policy, as alleged by the Guardian Diary, the PMOS said the prime minister had made the speech in Tübingen in which he had first put forward the proposal. Ministers decided policy . . ." blah blah. Ladies and gentleman, that's the paradigm of the non-denial denial.

 We may have been right about the Liddle stuff, but it isn't always so. A letter arrives from the BBC's political department about the item here concerning Fatty Oakley's aquatic leaving do - yet another triumph for our fact checkers. This points out, with understandable irritation, that 1) the boat trip isn't on the Thames, but the Regent's Canal; 2) rather than Robin hiring the boat, as we stated, admiring colleagues did so to lay on a surprise party; and 3) the £20 charge is because it is not an official BBC party. Our apologies for ruining the surprise.

 This column is, quite frankly, above speculating about Euan Blair - it's a private family matter - so let's hear no more about it, except to congratulate Euan for having the wit to give a false name when nicked. Anyone wondering where he got the idea is reminded that whenever Bertie Wooster was arrested, generally for trying to remove a policeman's helmet on boat-race night, he invariably gave a false name too (more than once he was addressed from the bench as "the prisoner Leon Trotsky"). Can it be pure coincidence that Mr Tony Blair is president of the Wodehouse Society?

 We don't want to make much of the Euan story, as I say, except to mull over this: senior Scotland Yard people say that the Sun had official confirmation of the news at 2am on Thursday - plenty of time to make the last edition - and were staggered when nothing appeared yesterday. Whether this was down to a loss of nerve, pressure from Alastair or some other reason is unclear, but since editor David Yelland resolutely refuses to talk, there is no point trying to ask him about that; or indeed whether David has had any special thoughts about how best to handle people who are publicly prostrate through drink.

 I don't wish to dwell on the Euan Blair story, but within minutes of learning the news we ring the Treasury press office to ask if anyone has heard singing and loud whistling coming from the chancellor's office. "We have nothing to say about that," they reply.

 Hats off to all involved in the England 2006 World Cup bid, especially Mr T's "football envoy" Tony Banks, who told Uefa to support England on the grounds that the German bid had no chance, because it had zero support outside Europe. Very good. Now shut your mouth, Mr Banks, and don't say another word for the next 10 to 15 years.

 We end as we began with Number's 10 website, which fights to assuage wounded Aussie feelings after Mr T's double cock-up on Wednesday when he twice referred mistakenly to "American" war heroes. "Today the PM met John Howard," the site reported yesterday, "the Austrailian PM . . ."

fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: Should I have an affair - or pull back for the sake of my children?
fields.trailText: Should I have an affair - or pull back for the sake of my children?
fields.body:
After 25 years of an outwardly contented marriage, I find myself in love with an unattached woman and she with me. She was one of my wife's best friends. My wife, very successful in her job (with attendant single-mindedness and fatigue), closed the bedroom door many years ago, before our much loved but mechanically conceived children (now 15, 13 and 10) were born. We are friends, with sex being the one area my wife will not discuss.

I had hoped that "things would get better". I have willingly been the practical housemaker with my job taking second place. I now feel newly awake and see my future away from my wife, who has been told of the new relationship. Unamused, she tolerates it within limits while regarding her former friend as a home destroyer. A difficult atmosphere prevails. All three parties are concerned about the effects of a break-up on the children. I'm from a single-parent home.

With great restraint shown, the new relationship is not yet physical, although my wife does not believe this. Should I take cold showers and pull back, for the sake of the children, from something that promises me so much?

Name and address withheld

Time to get a life

To read this makes me sad. Children should be the bi-product of a loving physical relationship not mechanically produced to fit the "outwardly contented" package of successfully life/job/marriage. You were not truly happy before your children came along and should have addressed this issue then, but no, you were willing to sacrifice so much (16+ years of no intimacy) in order not to repeat the mistakes of your parents.

The end of the physical side of a relationship is the beginning of the end, however long it takes to play it out. This may be reading between the lines, but you seem to rank third in your wife's list of priorities. She is "unamused" and "tolerates" her ex-friend, regarding her as a "home destroyer". This is strange as you don't even seem to be credited with any free will or responsibility in the matter. You only have one life, and we are all responsible for our happiness: maybe it's time for you to do what you want.

Don't do it

My advice is: don't do it. So many men who leave their wives admit within a few years that it was the worst mistake they'd made. Commitment and faithfulness are rare and important qualities to demonstrate to children, who are bombarded with the seductions of instant gratification from all sides. Any relationship takes some effort, so any energy available for starting a new relationship would be better expended in redeveloping the old one.

The day after our 23rd wedding anniversary, my husband told me he wanted to devote his effort to developing an, as yet platonic, relationship with another woman. I was not particularly surprised as, although we had both been entirely faithful, we had failed to be entirely loving to each other. In fact, like your wife, I had asked him to refrain from touching me about four years previously as I felt he simply used me for sex in much the same way as a cat uses a scratching post.

I was aware that I was somewhat uptight, convinced that sex was the greatest con of all, with nobody daring to admit it wasn't actually much good. We lost our marriage, and the clear memories of our past and the future we had been working towards for 23 years. I still find it hard not to hate him for removing any hope there may have been of making the marriage better.

Feeling released from obligations of faithfulness, I allowed a man who I had fallen for to seduce me and was introduced to the amazing, ecstatic, wonderful, exhilarating joyfulness of sex. I now have some inkling or understanding of people's preoccupations with sex. The difference between my lover's approach to sex and my husband's was simply that my lover focused on arousing my desires and giving me pleasure.

From this experience, I would suggest that you devote yourself to learning what your wife enjoys. I believe that if you could do this (even with the help of books or a therapist) you would together discover the wonder of sex and renewed contentment in each other's company without destroying anything except your fantasy that a fresh start would be better.

Try a new partner

As an oldie (60), I remember a saying common from my youth: "The road to hell is paved with good intentions." So get off yours. You are an example of a responsible adult reared in a single-parent family. What you did not have was the example of parents well-matched emotionally and physically to guide you in your choice of mate. With a new partner, you now have the chance to demonstrate such a relationship to your children as they mature. Maybe your wife, when free of your current set up, will also find a more fulfilling relationship, but if not, it is up to you to show your children.

Just one thing - a man's satisfaction does not mean a woman is satisfied or aroused. My new partner (70) has learned much for the first time over the past two years and we are happy. Good luck.

No going back

You have fallen in love but you appear to have a limited understanding of the nature of romantic love. Of course, love is vitally important to you. You want a happy relationship which includes physical gratification, and you romantically feel that your new relationship could offer you this. Adulterous love is often judged harshly but it can provide a "satisfactory" solution to some unhappily married people.

I found that falling in love in mid-life allowed me to undo many of the disappointments of my early life. It released me from the emotional and sexual repression of my past, helped me face the demands of middle age, and gave me a new kind of serenity. However, it was a complex and difficult journey and caused a lot of pain to the man I had lived with for 13 years.

You already know that there is no going back. You may feel that getting into a sexual relationship is a significant step for you, but in reality your marriage has already ended. The real issue is whether you will be able to handle the intimacy and to open up emotionally with another woman.

Talk frankly about sex

After 25 years of marriage all or most long-term relationships become mechanical - it's nothing new. What is remarkable is that you are good friends whereas many people merely tolerate one another.

Have a long and frank talk with your wife about your sex life. If she refuses to discuss this issue then suggest bringing in a third party, such as a marriage guidance counsellor. I speak with much experience, having spent 15 years on the singles scene. Falling in love is just the beginning of a relationship and is very different to real friendship. A passionate love life is all very well but it will not last. I could write a book on the misery marriage break-ups bring to the child.

Stop thinking of yourself and get your marriage sorted out. Better that you buy your wife a dozen red roses and tell her what a good friend she is to you. Remember that the grass is always greener on the other side until you get there.

Next week

 My partner and I do not live together (by choice) and so do not share any household expenses. Our financial circumstances are also very different: neither of us is in full-time paid work, but whereas her income is relatively meagre (comprising a small pension and disability benefits), I am able to live on income from capital supplemented by occasional part-time earnings. I pay my partner an allowance of £200 monthly, I also sometimes pay additional costs when we go out together, and I have paid air fare and other costs towards a special holiday.

Neither of us is happy with the financial imbalance, but cannot think of how to improve it. We will both reach official retirement age in approximately five years, and at this point neither of us is able to earn substantially more, nor do we expect to in future. I am not happy to share all my income and/or capital, and she is unhappy about being "dependent". Both of us feel guilty!

How have others coped with a situation of unequal earnings or other resources? Is there an answer?

Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020 7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

The sands of Morecambe Bay may seem an unlikely venue to launch a rocket into space.

But yesterday an amateur rocket scientist successfully fired the Starchase Discovery 19,000ft into orbit, leaving a huge plume of smoke and bringing him one step closer to his childhood dream of becoming the first amateur in space.

Inventor Steve Bennett, who modestly describes himself as Britain's answer to Nasa, watched the rocket as it accelerated to 700 mph in less than three seconds.

The rocket separated into two parts before it reached its altitude. "The rocket did exactly what we wanted it to do," said Mr Bennett, a former toothpaste technician from Dukinfield, Manchester. "We're going to put Britain back in space. We're going to build a bigger rocket capable of carrying a person into space. That's what we're looking at now.

Mr Bennett built his first rocket in 1977 when he was 13 and is determined to send a manned launch into space, perhaps next year. His team of 35 employees, based at Starchase Industries at Salford University, hopes to be the first non government organisation to send a manned launch into space.

If the three-man craft is a success, the team will collect a $10m prize from an American foundation.

He said he was confident that the team could win the prize. "You have to put three people 100 kilo metres up and bring them back - you don't have to put them into orbit. It will be a 15-minute journey," he said.

The team has already started work on the new craft.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Terry Wogan is in the headlines again. No, not because he's threatening a TV comeback three, four or even five nights a week. It's just that he thinks the BBC hasn't got any decent talent on its screens. Or at least, the Beeb isn't going the right way about getting new talent.

Speaking at a radio conference this week, our Tel laid into Auntie Beeb, condemning its BBC Talent initiative as "window dressing" and "nonsense". Surely this is a little unfair about what is a nationwide scheme to get spotty young hopefuls queuing around local blocks for hours in the hope of being picked up in random auditions as the latest incarnation of Peter Duncan or Janice Long. And, to be fair to the Beeb, they are looking for more than just new presenters - comedy writers and would-be directors and producers are all invited to contact the corporation in the hope that theirs is the next idea to set BBC1 Saturday night entertainment alight once again.

What we're fascinated to know is why Terry doesn't make more of his son's career. Mark has just fetched up in a new job in the media, combining the limitless radio legacy of his father with a keen eye for new media. Wogan Jr is to run a digital radio outfit in London as part of Switch Digital. This may not make him sound like great presenting material of the type Terry believes is needed to save the BBC. But it can be exclusively revealed that Mark has a dance-tastic past which would qualify him to run against even the most Jamie Theakstonesque new Jamie Theakston in a bid to host the next TOTP show.

Mark, it seems, spent many summers of his youth at the Wogan family villa in Torre Vieja, south of Alicante in Spain. Year after year he could be seen tripping the light fantastic at the deliciously named Teklas disco (groovy Spanish spelling for keyboard). What a guy.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Contentious? Moi?
fields.standfirst: Eurotrash is back for a 13th series, with its cheerful recipe of jolly foreign smut. But Antoine and friends are struggling to keep up with the excesses of their competitors.  Charlie Brooker thinks it's time for them to fight back
fields.trailText: Eurotrash is back for a 13th series, with its cheerful recipe of jolly foreign smut. But Antoine and friends are struggling to keep up with the excesses of their competitors. Charlie Brooker thinks it's time for them to fight back
fields.body:
Tonight sees the start of the 13th series of Eurotrash. Yes, the 13th. Channel Four's high-camp helping of sleaze, sex and undulating silicone returns once more, providing queasy chuckles for an audience of boggle-eyed stoners, simultaneously saving the nation's most desperate bachelors the bother of having to use their own imaginations (although the show is an onanist's minefield - one minute the screen's full of trampolining supermodels, the next there's a Scandinavian Chuckle Brother lookalike unblocking a sink in the nude).

For tonight's curtain-raiser, it's a case of same old, same old: there's a look at the world of erotic lingerie, an artist who paints with his own semen, a magician placing his penis in a guillotine and a lengthy report on a female wrestler whose breasts are covered with oil. As ever, it's linked - at considerable length - by the ever-likeable Antoine De Caunes (minus the late Lolo Ferrari), and enlivened with appealingly garish graphics and sarcastic voice-overs.

But there's a problem. Eurotrash simply doesn't outrage any more, and not just because it has reached season 13. No. The trouble is that in the years since the programme first spurted onto our screens, everything else on television has steadily degenerated into a slew of dead-eyed, opportunistic, utterly heartless quasi-porn, which leaves Eurotrash's recipe of cheerful, cheesy smut looking positively archaic.

On any commercial station you care to mention, unashamedly lecherous programming piles up in the schedule like sour-smelling refuse sacks in a midnight alleyway. ITV brings us documentaries on sex, swinging and strippers (well, they look like strippers - and since they were renamed "lapdancers", it's apparently OK to show them on TV every 67 seconds). Channel 4 parades Caribbean Uncovered, Something For The Weekend, and Naked Elvis. The whole of Channel Five feels like nothing but a single nightmarish, drawn-out edition of Eurotrash, complete with unconvincing voices (Sunset Beach), harrowing male nudity (Keith Chegwin's Naked Jungle) and profoundly dispiriting "erotica" (courtesy of about a zillion assorted pornographic schedule-pluggers with titles like Nude Saxophone Cops and When Checkout Girls Bend Over). Digital and cable viewers, meanwhile, can wallow in the nightly shock-o-rama of Bravo or the joyless Granada Men And Motors (demographic: underachieving loners interested in motoring, glamour photography and self-abuse).

These days, watching television is like sitting in Travis Bickle's taxicab, staring through the window at a world of relentless, churning shod. Some day a real rain's going to come and wash the scum off the screens. Until then, sit back and gawp in slack-jawed indifference as television slowly disappears up a lapdancer's bottom. In close-up. To the echoing strains of Roll With It.

The upshot is we've become hopelessly desensitised - but it's not just the box that's to blame. Consider the impact of technology. The past five years have seen a dramatic increase in the number of people with internet connections in the workplace, enabling office-bound tragi-bores to access and distribute stomach-churning muck with tiresome ease and gusto. Once you've got accustomed to having your attention regularly drawn to the kind of extreme imagery previously reserved for the racier shop windows of Amsterdam, all pornography rapidly becomes a crashing bore, no matter how bizarre. Hey, look - an MPEG clip of a circus clown sodomising a wolf on the deck of a Mississippi steamboat. Yawwwwn. Seen it before. Seen it twice. Rather watch a bit more Microsoft Excel, thanks.

So, faced with competition from a bottomless technological smutweb on one hand, and a range of post-ironic pornorific TV programming on the other, what chance does Eurotrash have? Not much. To compete in the current climate it needs to grow harsher, less affectionate, more ruthless. Scrap the Euro prefix; have the show re-christened just "Trash". Ditch the wacky German fetish bars and Dutch pot-smoking contests; shoot each edition in the seediest quarter of Bangkok. Throw out the irony and humour; exchange it for eerie, misplaced fascination. Replace Antoine with a naked amputee who sits on a barbed-wire toilet seat repeatedly threatening to murder members of the audience, reading their addresses out on air and nonchalantly toying with a bloodied switchblade. Broadcast the entire show in 3D, pumping each and every image directly into the viewer's cerebellum via a length of magic spacewire connected to the internet.

Sorry Rapido, but that's it. That's the only way to restore the outrage. That's how low we've all sunk. It's either that or you have to kill the whole thing off. Who'd have thought it? Sleazy, scampish little Eurotrash - slowly rendered far too innocent to survive. These are dark days, readers. Dark days.

Now wash your hands.

 Eurotrash, tonight, 10.30pm, Channel 4

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.body:
On the menu: sea trout

What is it?
Also known as salmon trout, white trout, and sewin. Technically, salmo trutta.

So what's with this old trout then?
As farmed salmon is suspect and wild salmon increasingly hard to come by, discerning chefs and cooks are turning to the trout to provide the wild pink protein.

Well, what is it - salmon or trout?
A bit of both. It's a brown trout that has swum downstream, gone out to sea, and stayed there for a couple of years before returning to breed.

Sounds like salmon to me.
Genetically quite different.

And gastronomically?
A finer flesh and flavour, more suited to sauce mousseline than hollandaise.

So you can cook it the same way?
Yes, but with shorter cooking times.

Cheat's kitchen

Perfect pesto Med-style chicken breasts

4 ready-roasted chicken breasts, 2 aubergines, 1 pot pesto, and olive oil.

1 Cut each aubergine lengthways to give 4 slices about 2cm thick.

2 Heat plenty of olive oil in a frying pan and fry the aubergine slices until cooked through - about two minutes on each side.

3 Drain on kitchen towel.

4 Either heat chicken in microwave or fry gently in pan with a little more olive oil until warmed through.

5 Spread a good dessert-spoonful of pesto on each aubergine slice. Place breasts on top and serve. (Serves four.)

Mrs J Clancy, Belfast

Food on the net

www.norburys.co.uk

Fine foods from this Norfolk-based specialist deli. Presumably the range on offer in King's Lynn is more extensive than what you see online, but it's all quality stuff: hunks of pies, cheeses, and whole boiled hams at unalarming prices.

Pros: Well-sourced foods - cheeses from across Europe, including some organic, and pork pies hand-made to order. The site is upfront with information on delivery and costs.

Cons: The site layout can be frustrating, with text falling off the edge of the window.

Delivery: Within 24 hours; you may have to wait longer for made-to-order foods, but they'll email you to let you know when it's on its way.

Charges: £4.95 per order.

Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Village Restaurant and Ramson's Enoteca , 18 Market Place, Ramsbottom, Lancs.

Tel: 01706 825070

Inspirational novelty; Brit/Italian on two floors. Downstairs you'll find the delights of Italy with bruschette, cured meats and Italian artisan cheeses. Upstairs are trad-Brit favourites - potted shrimps, organic trout, cold roasts and salads. Earlybird menus (two courses, £7.25; three courses, £9.75) offer cold minestrone, mortadella with goat's cheese and balsamic onions, stir-fry of goosnargh chicken and duckling, then Robbiola cheese, washed down with something from a distinctly Italian wine list. Follow up with espresso and imported grappa.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Barbakan Delicatessen , 67-69 Manchester Road, Chorlton, Manchester M21. Tel: 0161-881 7053

Award-winning Polish bakery and deli serving up an encyclopedia of sandwiches, continental cakes and pastries. Lunchtime offers more than 20 breads and a vast range of Polish and continental cooked and cured meats, cheeses, and marinated and pickled veg. Throw together personal combos, or pick 'n' mix from the sandwich menu: hot and cold ciabatta specials, salami from Italy, prawns from Greenland, feta from Greece, breakfast from Britain and meatloaf from Germany. Soon you'll be buying your own delicacies to experiment with at home. Mega-popular, surprise, surprise, so be prepared to queue.

 If you have any hints for Cheat's kitchen, send them to: The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

fields.headline: Night of the hunter
fields.trailText: Deadly Sharks Down Under | Burnside
fields.body:
As Frank Austen, Jane's brother, called to a shipmate swimming over the side, "Mr Pakenham! You are in danger of a shark - a shark of the blue species!" Acute observation clearly ran in the family. In Deadly Sharks Down Under (ITV) we saw a shark of the blue species and it did not encourage us to rate Mr Pakenham's chances as rosy. It was not only blue, it was ballistic.

Steve Irwin called it "a beautiful, torpedo-shaped animal". Steve, who has a heart like butter in the sun, never met an animal he didn't like. He is always the first to see the bad guy's point of view. Despite its title, Deadly Sharks Down Under was dedicated to the proposition that most sharks are bonzer if not riled.

Take the wobbegong.

The wobbegong looks like something which has been run over in the road. This implausible shark spends a lot of time lying on the sea-floor, hence its other name, carpet shark. It does seem to be woven in a jacquard pattern with tassels round its mouth like well-worn, though not necessarily well-loved, rug. With the bearded ghoul, the fangtooth and the Turkish toilet sponge, the wobbegong would be eliminated in the early heats of Miss Fish 2000. Unlike Mr Pakenham's swimming companion, it is loath to take any exercise and prefers to lie about in the same place for years getting fat. Steve is on first-name terms with three: Wendy, Clark and Dan.

You would be looking at a wobbegong for some time before the word streamlined occurred to you. Wendy was heavily pregnant. Clark had no such excuse. ("There's Clark! He's fat as mud!") Clark, who had a bit of a belly on him, moved off in a miffed manner.

The wobbegong, though easygoing as sharks go, has been known to bite if actually walked on, which seems reasonable. Presuming on their long acquaintance, Steve started to haul one out of its hidey-hole by the tail. There was a sudden flurry of fins and flippers. He surfaced looking older than his customary seven years or so, and held up a bloodied hand. "Wobbegong just grabbed me. Stupid mistake. Grabbed his tail and tried to pull him out from under a rock. Whoo! Bit hold of my hand. Lucky enough, he let go."

If the blue shark is the supermodel of the sea, the whale shark is the supertanker. Though they are the biggest fish in the sea, little is known about them. Not even why they are camouflaged with dots and stripes. "Who," asked Steve unanswerably, "are they hiding from?"

This is one of those questions which trouble your rest. Like what was the good news they brought from Aix to Ghent, and how do seedless grapes propagate? I used to wonder how pole-vaulters got on the bus but, apparently, they haul the pole through an upper window. I saw that on television.

Burnside (ITV) is a chip off the old Bill. As his super says, "You've got what you wanted. Our attention. Everyone's watching you. You'd better get a result."

Burnside (Chris Ellison) is not a man to go for a quiet drink with. The place is immediately in a splintered uproar. He is what an old-fashioned gangster, now reinvented as a media darling, calls "a copper from the old days". No decimal coinage here, mush. The stories seem to wind up over the first week then go off like an alarm clock in the second. Next week this bloke's bloke will be in direct competition with a female football team. It is Playing The Field (BBC 1) which, The Radio Times warns us, contains strong language.

webTitle: Ministers plan new job-related GCSE courses

fields.headline: Ministers plan new job-related GCSE courses
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teenagers are to be able to study new-look "vocational" GCSEs in catering, engineering and health care, the government said yesterday, in a drive to put job-related courses on an equal footing with academic qualifications.
fields.body:
Teenagers are to be able to study new-look "vocational" GCSEs in catering, engineering and health care, the government said yesterday, in a drive to put job-related courses on an equal footing with academic qualifications.

Ministers want to make it easier for youngsters to "mix and match" job-related and academic courses to try to bridge the increasingly serious skills gap in Britain.

Speaking at a conference in Birmingham yesterday, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said the lower levels of the existing General National Vocational Qualification (GNVQ) - currently offered mainly by sixth form and further education colleges - would be replaced by the new-look "vocational GCSE" from September 2002 in a range of subjects. These are likely to include manufacturing, information technology, health care, engineering, art and design and will enable young people to move on to apprenticeships and into jobs.

The move follows the government's earlier decision to replace advanced GNVQs with new-look "vocational A-levels" from September this year. That means that by 2002 GNVQs - introduced by the Tories but failing to attract a large take-up - will disappear.

In the short term, the government has asked the qualifications and curriculum authority to consult with schools on the range of subjects that should be offered, and how the courses can be brought into line with the A-G grading used for GCSEs. Some adjustment of course content will be necessary, as the content of one GNVQ is broadly equivalent to the content of two GCSEs.

Mr Blunkett said yesterday: "Vocational GCSEs mark an important milestone in our continuing commitment to ensuring that young people have access to high standard vocational qualifications. The vocational GCSE will make it easier for young people to get good jobs or to go on to college or university. They will offer a powerful new tool for motivating young people and raising standards."

Mr Blunkett said traditional training routes had failed to motivate and engage many bright youngsters. "We need to think imaginatively now about using their talent and creativity in meeting the craft skills needs of the future. We also need to match the status and commitment to vocational education and lifelong learning that exists in other developed countries."

A recent survey for the gov ernment's skills task force found that 40% of all skills shortages were in craft and technician-type jobs, requiring high-level skills gained through specialist work-based training.

Teaching unions broadly welcomed the changes. John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "Anything that leads to greater parity of esteem between vocational and academic qualifications is long overdue. The vocational is always regarded as second best, and this is a logical move to rename the GNVQ, which is a title which has never caught on. But rather than a new initiative for 14- to 16-year-olds, we need a unified qualifications framework which also takes on board the needs of those post 16."

Kay Driver, general secretary of the Professional Association of Teachers, added: "We welcome the general principle of these new qualifications. We are in favour of a more flexible curriculum which is able to develop the skills and meet the needs of all pupils.

"Some pupils are engaged by purely 'academic' subjects, while vocational subjects, or a mixture of the two, are more appropriate for others. It is important for both pupils and employers that there is clear parity between 'academic' and 'vocational' qualifications."

fields.headline: Albright 'snub' incenses Japanese
fields.trailText: The decision by the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, to stay away from next week's pre-G8 foreign ministers' meeting in southern Japan has enraged her jilted hosts.
fields.body:
The decision by the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, to stay away from next week's pre-G8 foreign ministers' meeting in southern Japan has enraged her jilted hosts.

Having spent more time and money on the summit than any other hosts in the history of the G8, the inhabitants of the rural area of Miyazaki were not impressed to learn yesterday that Mrs Albright has decided to concentrate instead on the Middle East peace talks.

In her place, the US is sending the deputy secretary of state, Strobe Talbott.

Ms Albright's decision is a setback for Japan, which has had to fend off criticism recently that it is losing ground to China as Washington's main ally in Asia.

Political leaders have expressed outrage at the perceived snub, organisers have thrown up their hands in disbelief and Japanese diplomats have muttered darkly that US interests could be harmed.

"I wonder how much the US view will be reflected when everyone else attending is a foreign minister," said the deputy foreign minister, Yoshiji Nogami. "I think the United States will suffer a loss."

The local city mayor immediately cancelled plans to name a hall in honour of Mrs Albright, who had promised to give a speech at the building.

Local politicians and businesses had squandered billions of pounds on the G8 summit in the hope that it would put this little-known district on the world map.

A huge swath was cut out of a seaside pine forest to build the £1.6bn Seagaia resort complex, which was supposed to host Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and the other summit leaders until Okinawa stepped in with a more successful bid.

As a consolation, it was awarded the foreign ministers' meeting, meaning that Robin Cook will now be among the most senior guests at the complex.

webTitle: Dyke reform set to cost 300 jobs at BBC

fields.headline: Dyke reform set to cost 300 jobs at BBC
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke stepped up the process of stripping away the "dafter aspects" of the BBC's internal market yesterday, dismantling a key element of the reforms inherited from his predecessor, the former director general Lord Birt.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke stepped up the process of stripping away the "dafter aspects" of the BBC's internal market yesterday, dismantling a key element of the reforms inherited from his predecessor, the former director general Lord Birt.

Up to 300 jobs will go as part of a slimming down of the corporation's technical division, BBC Resources, designed to maximise the income generated by hiring out its facilities to other broadcasters.

Some departments, including BBC News, will no longer have to "buy" studio facilities from other parts of the corporation. The process, condemned by Mr Dyke when he took over earlier this year, took on near farcical proportions in areas where production facilities had only one "customer" another part of the BBC.

Mr Dyke yesterday revealed that the corporation had rejected a suggestion, made by the government panel that considered the future of the licence fee last year, that BBC Resources should be privatised. Margaret Salmon, the chief executive of BBC Resources, said 200 jobs would go in the short term. Negotiations will begin with unions next week. Staff representatives fear another 100 may go later.

The future of the BBC's studio and technical facilities at Pebble Mill in Birmingham, currently under-used, is also being reviewed. A new division, BBC Technology Limited, has been created to provide the BBC's telephony, IT and communication services, which previously came under BBC Resources.

Mr Dyke hopes the changes can provide up to £200m extra cash for the BBC over the next six years. As part of last year's licence fee agreement with the government, the BBC has agreed to find £1.1bn in savings and extra revenue over the next five years.

webTitle: Whites try to forestall farm seizures

fields.headline: Whites try to forestall farm seizures
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Facing continuing threats of violence and land seizures, Zimbabwe's beleaguered white farmers yesterday offered 600 farms for sale to President Robert Mugabe's government for redistribution to poor blacks.
fields.body:
Facing continuing threats of violence and land seizures, Zimbabwe's beleaguered white farmers yesterday offered 600 farms for sale to President Robert Mugabe's government for redistribution to poor blacks.

The government is expected to confiscate hundreds of white-owned farms in the next few weeks to fulfil promises made to rural blacks in the general election two weeks ago. Despite the pledges of land and widespread state-sponsored violence which took 32 lives, Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party won only 62 of the 120 elected seats.

In a desperate bid to avert the impending seizure of 804 farms, the Commercial Farmers Union (CFU) said yesterday that it had identified 600 farms that were either derelict or the property of people who owned several farms. The CFU said if the government "does things properly" it could purchase the 600 farms and then resettle them with land-hungry black peasants.

"We must get the politics out of the land issue and deal with it as an economic issue," said Jerry Grant, the CFU's deputy director. "We must be worried about production, exports and foreign currency generation. We do not want to obstruct the government's resettlement programme, but productive farms should be left to those fully utilising them."

However, there is little chance that the Mugabe government will take up the farmers' offer or take land in a way the farmers consider "proper".

Officials at the ministry of lands and agriculture refused to comment on the last-minute proposal. Instead they were busy looking at the 804 farms already listed for confiscation.

More than 500 of those farms have lodged legal appeals against the seizures, while nearly 300 farmers are not contesting them. Under Mr Mugabe's newly-installed land acquisition act the government can immediately take possession of those farms that have not appealed.

Mr Mugabe is expected to take farms quickly and move thousands of his supporters on to the land. "There is a great expectation amongst the people around the land issue and land will soon come to the people in a big way," Mr Mugabe said after the elections.

During the violent campaign, Mr Mugabe pledged to seize white-owned farms "without paying a penny for the land that was stolen from the African people by British colonialists". His supporters illegally invaded 1,400 farms and five white farmers were killed.

The land issue did not appeal to Zimbabwe's city dwellers, who were more concerned with the country's economic decline and who voted solidly for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

Mr Mugabe's party squeaked in with support from the rural areas, but many analysts say that vote was influenced more by Zanu-PF's widespread use of violence and threats than by enthusiasm for the land issue.

Before dissolving parliament in April for the elections, Mr Mugabe pushed through a constitutional amendment which states that Britain is obliged to pay compensation for land taken from Africans during the colonial period.

If the British government does not pay, states the amendment, the Zimbabwe government does not have to pay any compensation for the land.

Mr Mugabe said peasants would be settled on the newly-acquired land without special training or the development of new roads and services necessary to convert the properties for small-scale agriculture.

"Such a rushed settlement of rural people without proper training and no infrastructure will condemn them to continue as peasant farmers," said Tendai Biti, a newly-elected MP for the MDC.

webTitle: Mother under stress tells of family ordeal six days after Sarah, 8, disappeared

fields.headline: Mother under stress tells of family ordeal six days after Sarah, 8, disappeared
fields.trailText: The mother of Sarah Payne let the strain of the past six days show yesterday when she broke down in public for the first time since her "little princess" vanished.
fields.body:
The mother of Sarah Payne let the strain of the past six days show yesterday when she broke down in public for the first time since her "little princess" vanished.

Tears welled in her eyes as she spoke of her eternally happy little girl and showed felt-tipped messages offering sympathy from the local school.

Sara Payne, 31, finally collapsed in the arms of her husband, Michael, also 31, at the end of a press conference.

Speaking about her eight-year-old daughter, she said: "She loves her dance classes after school. She loves her dance music. She likes to dress up like a lady and play around with makeup. She's just always happy, always bouncing around. She's just terrific."

She said the family, who are from Surrey, had no fixed eating or sleeping routine at the moment. She added: "We're just doing whatever we can during the day. The nights are long, very long. Personally I don't sleep. I collapse when the body has had enough at about 3am and then I get up at about six."

Gesturing to a bouquet of flowers sent by an anonymous well-wisher, and holding up the messages of support from children, she spoke once more through the cameras to her daughter.

"Darling, look. Look, Sarah. Look at all these people looking for you. Sarah, you will be home soon, I promise you. You really will. Someone's going to tell us something."

Detectives yesterday received a message from her brothers and sister thanking them for their "help and support". As the search enters its sixth day the 150 officers on Operation Maple are turning to the heartfelt plea, hand-written by her eldest brother, Lee, who had inadvertently begun to write the name of his sister alongside those of Luke, 11, and Charlotte, six.

The message, at Littlehampton police station, West Sussex, was released with a short family video of Sarah taken a week before she disappeared from a cornfield near her grandparents' home in Kingston, near Littlehampton, last Saturday at 8.45pm.

The clip shows the girl playing in a garden after a family christening. A reconstruction of the moments leading up to her disappearance - to be filmed this morning in the country lane where she is believed to have been snatched - will be transmitted tomorrow.

As the fingertip search by volunteers of the predominantly rural area ended, police said every force in the country was involved in the hunt, with alleged sightings as far afield as Lancashire and south Wales. Each force is checking its high-risk sex offenders, while West Sussex has questioned most known paedophiles in the immediate area.

Police, aware that known paedophiles might be unwilling to approach them with information, have enlisted the help of two anonymous telephone lines: Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111, and the National Missing Persons helpline on 0500 700 700.

fields.headline: Charity plea for £32m 'lost' coins
fields.trailText: A £32m "lost bounty" of foreign coins gathering dust in the dark recesses of British homes could be used to support causes such as cancer research, a survey revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A £32m "lost bounty" of foreign coins gathering dust in the dark recesses of British homes could be used to support causes such as cancer research, a survey revealed yesterday.

A quarter of holidaymakers stuff unwanted currency into drawers and other hiding places after trips abroad, amassing £31.9m in wasted cash between them, according to the NOP survey for the Cancer Research Campaign.

The survey found 28% of travelling Britons dump an average of £3.90 worth of coins when they return home, while a further 1% throw away the equivalent of £1m in foreign exchange every year.

According to the campaign, the hidden millions amount to half of its entire cancer research budget for a year.

Launching a drive to mobilise the potential of this leftover cash, Gordon McVie, director general of the campaign, said: "Every penny donated to the Cancer Research Campaign counts.

"There is a huge treasure trove waiting to be tapped."

The Foreign Coin Appeal 2000, a joint initiative between the campaign and Boots the Chemist, urges travellers to take their foreign coins to collection points in campaign shops and Boots stores around the country.

Last year, the campaign exchanged £100,000 of foreign coins for cash which went directly to fund research.

Professor McVie said: "We hope the penny has dropped with the holidaying public that their foreign coins could play a massive part in funding the fight against cancer."

His message was echoed by Victoria Rae of Unicef, who urged passengers travelling on British Airways to take part in the Change for Good scheme.

Passengers are encouraged to make their pockets a little lighter by putting leftover currency of any denomination in Change for Good envelopes.

The campaign has raised almost £10m since it was launched in April 1994, with donations amounting on average to £180,000 a month.

Ms Rae said: "The success of Change for Good is that it is dead money that can be put to help children's lives in a practical way."

Money has been allocated to children's projects in more than 40 countries, including health care in Tanzania and work with homeless children in Mexico and Brazil.

webTitle: Back diamond ban, Cook urges traders

fields.headline: Back diamond ban, Cook urges traders
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, appealed to the diamond industry to cooperate yesterday after the UN security council imposed a ban on the sale of illicit diamonds from Sierra Leone.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, appealed to the diamond industry to cooperate yesterday after the UN security council imposed a ban on the sale of illicit diamonds from Sierra Leone.

The sanction will be ineffective unless diamond traders in Antwerp, Tel Aviv and Bombay stop dealing in diamonds from the conflict zone.

The resolution bans the purchase of all rough diamonds - uncut stones - from Sierra Leone until its government can set up a proper certification system for the gems and regain access to diamond-mining areas under rebel control.

Meanwhile, a UN panel is to look at the connection between diamonds and the arms trade.

Many diamond traders, while claiming to be sympathetic to the plight of those caught in conflict zones, have been happy to turn a blind eye to the origin of the diamonds.

Mr Cook, who proposed the ban, said: "I call on the whole of the industry to join us in seeking ways to track the origin of diamonds. We want the genuine diamond industry to flourish and avoid the tarnished reputation brought by illicit diamonds which fund death and destruction in conflict zones."

The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain is planning a visit to speak directly to the Diamond High Council, which governs the trade in Antwerp. Mr Cook is to raise the issue next week at a meeting of the G8 industrialised countries.

The embargo expires after 18 months, but could be renewed if Revolutionary United Front rebels still control the mines.

The vote was 14-0 with Mali abstaining because of the naming of Liberia as a conduit for the diamonds. Mali's UN ambassador, Moctar Ouane, said the reference was "unacceptable" because he claimed Liberia was trying to mediate a peace in Sierra Leone.

Welcoming the resolution, Sierra Leone's ambassador, Ibrahim Kamara, told the council: "The root of the conflict is and remains diamonds, diamonds and diamonds."

The US ambassador, Nancy Soderberg, backed the resolution but opposed the time limit that France, Russia and China insisted on. She called it too short, too arbitrary and said those engaged in illegal activities could simply sit out the embargo.

fields.headline: Tom Wheldon
fields.standfirst: A pioneering crusader against cancer
fields.trailText: Professor Tom Wheldon, who has himself died of cancer aged 56, was credited with a major contribution to cancer treatment. He devised a new method of joining radioactive isotopes to tumour-seeking drugs - thus ensuring tumours effectively destroy themselves.
fields.body:
Professor Tom Wheldon, who has himself died of cancer aged 56, was credited with a major contribution to cancer treatment. He devised a new method of joining radioactive isotopes to tumour-seeking drugs - thus ensuring tumours effectively destroy themselves.

It was in 1983 that Tom, a medical physicist and radiation biologist, moved from Hammersmith hospital's medical research council cyclotron unit to head Glasgow University's radio biology unit, then based at Belvidere hospital.

Tom began at the unit with two technicians. Under his leadership it moved to the Cancer Research Campaign Beatson Laboratories in Bearsden and - with Tom by now head of Glasgow Institute's radiation biology department - it expanded to employ 12 research workers.

Tom wrote two books and more than 150 papers. He also demonstrated that the p53 gene (one of those associated with some cancers, including that of the breast) is in that group particularly sensitive to radiotherapy. But this apparent good news was paradoxically counterbalanced by his significant finding that the p53 gene resulted in the lack of the normal ability of a cell regularly to destroy itself ( apoptosis ).

Tom was born in Glasgow, and educated at the local secondary school in Shettlestone. To save enough money to support himself at university he joined the metallurgy laboratory at Clydebridge steelworks, and in his spare time took a Higher National Certificate in metallurgy.

He started at Strathclyde University, reading engineering, but then discovered the delights of physics and mathematics. He graduated in these subjects in 1968. At Strathclyde he met his lifelong companion and support, Liz McLafferty.

After graduating, Tom joined Glasgow's Institute of Radiotherapeutics and Oncology as a medical physicist in the department of medical physics and bio-engineering.

The specialist treating cancer needs the help of a team. This includes radiographers to operate X-ray units and physicists, supervising the operation of complex machines, advising, and calculating on the treatment-planning computers which had been pioneered in Glasgow. Tom excelled in all these fields.

In 1968 he took his PhD, married Liz and moved to London and Hammersmith's cyclotron unit, At Hammersmith the cyclotron - an "atom smasher - is used for experimental treatment of cancer and for production of radioactive compounds used in scanning to show up brain function. The unit there is also renowned for its work on radiation biology and it was this that interested Tom. Then came Glasgow.

In 1999 Tom was diagnosed as suffering from a cancer of the colon that had already spread to the liver. It was incurable by surgery. He suggested that his own method of treatment should be tried, but it was insufficiently effective. During this final period, he continued to write papers and lecture and was awarded a personal chair by Glasgow University.

He received many honours, including the Institute of Physical Sciences in Medicine's Founders prize and the Douglas Lea lectureship, and the British Institute of Radiology's Roentgen prize. He was awarded honorary membership of the Royal College of Radiologists.

Tom was a fine teacher - his jokes made difficult points simple - and his work was always his main interest. He was also a keen walker in the Scottish hills.

He is survived by his wife.

 Thomas Edward Wheldon, scientist, born May 12 1944; died June 4 2000

webTitle: Lords dismiss Roma asylum test case

fields.headline: Lords dismiss Roma asylum test case
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A Slovakian Roma appealing for asylum in Britain following attacks by skinheads in Slovakia yesterday lost a crucial House of Lords test case.
fields.body:
A Slovakian Roma appealing for asylum in Britain following attacks by skinheads in Slovakia yesterday lost a crucial House of Lords test case.

Five Law Lords unanimously dismissed Milan Horvath's appeal in a judgment which will have implications for hundreds of other Roma or Gypsy asylum seekers in Britain who are waiting to hear the outcome of their cases. It is likely to lead to their removal from Britain.

The ruling also has implications for many other asylum cases, as it clearly draws the line that people suffering persecution from groups other than their own state authorities are unlikely to get asylum if it can be shown that the authorities have tried to provide protection.

The Law Lords heard that Horvath, who comes from the village of Palin, in Michalovce, Slovakia, came to Britain in October 1997 with his wife and child and claimed asylum on the grounds that they were being persecuted by skinheads.

But they upheld a decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to refuse him asylum on the grounds that there was evidence that the Slovak police had intervened to provide protection in some cases when they had been asked to do so and stiff sentences had been imposed for racially motivated attacks.

The judges accepted that Slovak Roma are the victims of racial violence by skinheads and that the police did not conduct proper investigations into every case.

But they argued that this did not demonstrate that the Slovak authorities were unwilling or unable to provide protection against such attacks.

"There are parts of London or New York where one may indeed have a well found fear of being attacked in the street. But that does not mean there is not an efficient police force and an impartial judiciary," said Lord Lloyd of Berwick.

He said it may well be that Horvath had a well founded fear of persecution should he take his family back to Slovakia, but added that "the authorities in Slovakia are willing and able to provide protection to the required standard, and Gypsies as a class are not exempt from that protection".

A home office spokesman welcomed the ruling upholding Mr Straw's original decision and said the judgment would be studied in detail.

webTitle: Southern Europe swelters in African heat

fields.headline: Southern Europe swelters in African heat
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: A freak heat blast from the Sahara subjected south-eastern Europe to sweltering temperatures yesterday with countries from Greece to Romania reporting heat-related deaths as the thermometer broke century-old records climbing to 45C (113F).
fields.body:
A freak heat blast from the Sahara subjected south-eastern Europe to sweltering temperatures yesterday with countries from Greece to Romania reporting heat-related deaths as the thermometer broke century-old records climbing to 45C (113F).

In a rare show of unanimity, governments across the baking Balkans advised people to stay indoors, and in some cases avoid work altogether, as the death toll rose to 23. Croatia is investigating a further 40 possibly heat related deaths.

From Athens to Zagreb the dark side of the sun caused deaths, not least among farmers tending shrivelled crops. As forest fires erupted, tens of thousands of people rushed to hospitals with respiratory, heart and heatstroke problems.

The sight of people seeking solace by the sea was particularly prevalent in Greece where the government put hospitals on alert and opened air-conditioned schools and indoor stadiums. There were surreal scenes of people bathing at midnight as thousands flocked to the coast.

State-run media, mindful of tourist sun-worshippers, took the unprecedented step of issuing English-language warnings.

"We don't want foreigner vacationers to be caught by surprise," said Dimitris Katrivanos, who heads Greece's civil protection agency. "This is a crisis situation we are taking emergency measures."

But even the professional sunning brigade was finding the heat a tad unpleasant yesterday - even those who had impetuously thrown themselves into the fountains that now grace most Athenian squares.

With average temperatures of 42C in the shade some grumbled that they had dug deep into their pockets to fly into a furnace.

"When you're at home you dream of the sun but this isn't fun, this is hell," gasped Geraldine Houghton, a shop assistant from Sutton Coldfield. "If I could, I'd get on the next plane back," she said.

With very little green space, and far too many people, overcrowded Athens always suffers in the heat. Yesterday, the environment ministry said the appearance of high levels of pollution had made the atmosphere even more unbearable. Athens resembles a ghost town. Short of heading for the beach or their workplaces, Athenians only make for the great outdoors if it is to sleep on their roofs and balconies.

The heat is such that crimes of passion have not increased, in part, police believe, because people are just too hot to get het up.

Attributing the freak temperatures to a "thermal invasion" of hot air masses moving north from Africa, meteorologists say southern Europe will have to sweat it out until well into next week.

"We foresee the temperatures remaining around and above 40C for the next week," said Haris Kabetzidis at the Greek weather service. "This is a very unusual phenomenon."

It is a prospect that has sparked widespread panic-buying of air-conditioners. The use of air-conditioners has been blamed for record levels of energy consumption. The public power corporation has reported blackouts as a result of the overburdening of the network in Athens. Hundreds of technicians from across the country were dispatched to the capital yesterday.

With the heatwave straining the country's resources, the government announced that it would begin importing energy from its neighbours.

fields.headline: Pregnant student 'wrongly excluded'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A mature student yesterday won a high court ruling on sex discrimination in education, after claiming she was unlawfully excluded from the final year of a university degree course because of pregnancy-related illness.
fields.body:
A mature student yesterday won a high court ruling on sex discrimination in education, after claiming she was unlawfully excluded from the final year of a university degree course because of pregnancy-related illness.

A judge described how Valerie Coggeran, who wished to qualify as a radiographer, was absent from her studies at South Bank University, London, and missed a number of examinations because of her illness.

The university's examination board terminated her studies in July last year and an appeal board upheld its decision a month later.

Quashing both those decisions, Mr Justice Munby yesterday ruled that the examination board had "wholly misunderstood" the basis of her case, and must reconsider whether or not Ms Coggeran, 32, should now have a chance to resume her Bachelor of Science (Hons) degree course in diagnostic imaging (radiography).

Of wider importance was the judge's additional ruling that Ms Coggeran had a right to bring an action against the university authorities under the 1975 Sex Discrimination Act.

Domestic law protected not only women employees from dismissal but also women students from "exclusion from an educational establishment" if they suffered pregnancy-related illness, said the judge.

Asking for permission to appeal, John Lofthouse, appearing for the university, said: "Your lordship's judgment could scarcely be more important for educational institutions - indeed for educational institutions of almost any sort.

"There are several points on sex discrimination where your lordship has given landmark rulings which are going to be applied and looked to for guidance."

But the judge refused permission, and said he was concerned that Ms Coggeran's case should be reconsidered as a matter of urgency by the university authorities so that, if she were successful, she could be re-admitted to her course in September.

The university can apply directly to the court of appeal to hear the case.

Later, Ms Coggeran's solicitor, Richard Scrase, described yesterday's ruling as "a useful stepping stone" to the action for damages for unlawful sex discrimination she intended to bring against the university's governing body at Lambeth county court.

Mr Scrase said: "Ms Coggeran is of the view that she was poorly treated by South Bank University and that she is looking towards being properly treated so that she may resume her studies and in time qualify and practise as a radiographer."

Ms Coggeran, of Tottenham, north London, who gave birth to a son in November last year, had satisfactorily completed the first two years of her three-year vocational course at the City University. She then enrolled in September 1998 at the South Bank to take the third year.

She was initially absent for a period in November-December 1998 undergoing surgery for endometriosis, a condition of the womb.

In January 1999, she failed part of her course work assessment but was allowed to take the unit again provided she did so by the following July.

In February she was surprised to learn she was pregnant after being earlier advised that her health problems meant it was unlikely that she would be able to conceive.

On March 3 last year she became sick with pregnancy-related illness.

During a recent high court hearing, Mr Lofthouse had argued on behalf of the university that the leading cases under the Sex Discrimination Act arose in the field of employment and the anti-discrimination legislation could not be applied to the university student.

He submitted the law was inapplicable under the European equal treatment directive, or the pregnancy directive, and because the law had been decided in the leading cases which had gone before the European court of justice.

Yesterday Mr Justice Munby disagreed. He ruled there was nothing in European law to stop Britain going further than the two directives. "The fact is our domestic law protects women against sex discrimination, not merely in the employment context but also, subject to the limits spelt out (in the 1975 Act), in the educational context," he said.

fields.headline: 'No lookout' on trawler that sank
fields.trailText: A trawler which collided with a container vessel and sank with all hands had no proper lookout and was apparently overloaded with fish, according to an official accident report.
fields.body:
A trawler which collided with a container vessel and sank with all hands had no proper lookout and was apparently overloaded with fish, according to an official accident report.

The Silvery Sea, registered at Mallaig on the west coast of Scotland, went down off Denmark in June 1998. The marine accident investigation report, released yesterday, said the cause of the collision with the Merkur, a German vessel, was twofold: there was no effective watch on the Silvery Sea and the Merkur did not take evasive action early enough.

The report also concluded that the Silvery Sea, which had been heading for Esbjerg with five crew, all from Mallaig, and 530 tonnes of fish aboard, was overloaded. However, it would probably not have sunk if one of the starboard doors had been properly secured and if its collision bulkheads had been extended. The branch has recommended the extension of such bulkheads in fishing vessels.

The Merkur had been travelling in fine weather at 15 knots when the trawler appeared on its radar screen. The container vessel did not change course because it was the Silvery Sea's responsibility to keep out of the way under international regulations. When it became clear that the trawler had not spotted them, the Merkur sounded a warning bell, but there was no response.

The report said the Merkur's chief officer had wrongly assumed the Silvery Sea was keeping a proper lookout; as a result evasive action was left too late.

The branch said there was no way to ascertain why the Silvery Sea did not have an effective watch. "It can only be assumed that the watchkeeper on Silvery Sea had become incapacitated, or left the wheelhouse and allowed the vessel to continue on automatic helm."

fields.headline: Asthma doubles in adults
fields.trailText: Asthma rates among adults have more than doubled in the past two decades, research shows.
fields.body:
Asthma rates among adults have more than doubled in the past two decades, research shows.

The findings of a study into asthma levels in the Scottish towns of Renfrew and Paisley were published in the British Medical Journal yesterday.

Researchers found that asthma levels among non-smokers rose from 3% between 1972 and 1976 to 8.2% in 1996. Among smokers, levels rose from 1.6% in the 1970s to 5.3% 20 years later.

Hay fever rates have also increased over the last two decades, from 5.8% to 19.9% among non-smokers, and from 5.4% to 15.5% among smokers.

Experts are unsure why levels have soared, but increased pollution, modern living and changed diets have been blamed.

Researchers of the study said that the rise in rates was mainly due to increases in allergy-triggered (atopic) asthma rather than non-atopic asthma, which is triggered by colds, chest infections or cigarette smoke.

Fiona Costello, manager of the National Asthma Campaign's helpline, said: "We still do not know enough about the condition, although we know that modern living in homes with double glazing and fitted carpets has led to an increase in house mites, which can trigger atopic asthma."

fields.headline: Football club's flats plan fails
fields.trailText: A long-running battle over the legality of planning permission granted four years ago for the redevelopment of Fulham Football Club's Craven Cottage ground ended yesterday in victory for local objectors, led by Lady Berkeley.
fields.body:
A long-running battle over the legality of planning permission granted four years ago for the redevelopment of Fulham Football Club's Craven Cottage ground ended yesterday in victory for local objectors, led by Lady Berkeley.

Five law lords upheld her claim that the failure of the former environment secretary John Gummer to call for an assessment of the impact of the scheme on the Thames river frontage - part of a nature conservation area - was a fatal flaw in the planning process. The House of Lords quashed the August 1996 planning consent, leaving the west London club to press ahead with a new scheme, currently before Hammersmith and Fulham council, backed by a full environmental impact assessment.

Lady Berkeley's objections related to the part of the plan involving construction of a new river wall, riverside walk and parking for residents of the planned 142 apartments. She said building blocks of luxury flats along the river banks threatened to turn stretches into exclusive haunts of the rich.

webTitle: Food inquiry into deaths of 136 cows

fields.headline: Food inquiry into deaths of 136 cows
fields.trailText: Government vets are investigating the deaths of 136 cows on one farm in a suspected food poisoning incident.
fields.body:
Government vets are investigating the deaths of 136 cows on one farm in a suspected food poisoning incident.

Authorities are refusing to name the farm in Leicestershire, but milk and 2,000 litres of vanilla and chocolate ice cream have been destroyed to prevent risk to humans.

Some of the remaining 28 cows and one bull on the farm are said to be displaying symptoms and may die from the illness that claimed its first victim on June 20.

The dead animals lost co-ordination and suffered partial paralysis. Officials for the food standards agency have not confirmed the nature of the illness, nor its source, but they think the cattle may have contracted botulism. Investigators are checking whether commercial animal feed, water troughs or other parts of the farm may have been accidentally contaminated. Pigs and geese on the farm have shown no sign of illness. The agency said there was "no risk" to the human food chain.

The Ministry of Agriculture said last night that the outbreak was believed to be an isolated case.
fields.bodyText: Government vets are investigating the deaths of 136 cows on one farm in a suspected food poisoning incident. Authorities are refusing to name the farm in Leicestershire, but milk and 2,000 litres of vanilla and chocolate ice cream have been destroyed to prevent risk to humans. Some of the remaining 28 cows and one bull on the farm are said to be displaying symptoms and may die from the illness that claimed its first victim on June 20. The dead animals lost co-ordination and suffered partial paralysis. Officials for the food standards agency have not confirmed the nature of the illness, nor its source, but they think the cattle may have contracted botulism. Investigators are checking whether commercial animal feed, water troughs or other parts of the farm may have been accidentally contaminated. Pigs and geese on the farm have shown no sign of illness. The agency said there was "no risk" to the human food chain. The Ministry of Agriculture said last night that the outbreak was believed to be an isolated case.

webTitle: Motor-boots will rush walkers off their feet

fields.headline: Motor-boots will rush walkers off their feet
fields.trailText: A prototype pair of petrol-driven walking boots - originally designed by aviation specialists for the Soviet army - is set to be mass produced as Russia's answer to rollerskates.
fields.body:
A prototype pair of petrol-driven walking boots - originally designed by aviation specialists for the Soviet army - is set to be mass produced as Russia's answer to rollerskates.

The boots, which look like futuristic platform shoes on pistons, are strapped to the calves of the walker, enabling him to take strides of up to four metres and accelerate to a speed of around 25mph. Their creators claim that wearing the shoes reduces the effort of walking by up to 75%.

Conceived in the last years of the cold war as a potent new addition to the Soviet Union's military might, the boots were designed to allow infantry soldiers to cross large distances of off-track terrain without becoming exhausted.

But the concept was never adopted and the designs lay dormant in defence archives for over a decade, stamped Top Secret.

It was only when the military files were declassified recently that the inventors of this bizarre high-speed footwear were able to reclaim their creation for civilian use. They say that the high-speed boot can be used on any surface and takes only five minutes to master.

They expect that most demand will come from rich, offbeat sports enthusiasts willing to meet the £250 estimated price tag, but hope the concept may still find a useful civilian application.

"Postmen who have to deliver to places where there are no roads could use them. We have also had some interest from the local police force," said Professor Rustem Enikeyev, from the Aviation Technical university in Ufa, southern Russia, who worked on the project.

Each shoe incorporates a 30cm piston, which fires downwards with each step, pushing a metal platform away from the bottom of the shoes and the wearer up into the air.

To start the boots, the wearer simply takes a step; to stop, he has to tread more lightly. Every boot has a carburettor, spark plug and a mini fuel tank, and can be adapted to take diesel or petrol.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Gunmen kill 2 before giving up
fields.body:
Gunmen kill 2 before giving up

Gunmen in Malaysia who raided army depots before killing two hostages surrendered yesterday after a five-day stand-off. The whereabouts of a third hostage is unknown.

The gunmen, believed to be members of a martial arts cult, seized three hostages after stealing a large cache of weapons on Sunday in a move that embarrassed the army and government.
Reuters, Kati

Tropical storm batters Luzon

A tropical storm that battered the Philippine island of Luzon killed 14 people and forced 80,000 from their homes. It was heading for China yesterday.

Most of the 14 dead were drowned and four were killed by landslides.
Reuters, Manila

Jaws author in shark appeal

On the anniversary of the release of the film Jaws, Peter Benchley, the author of the original book, made a passionate appeal to the world on behalf of sharks. He joined WildAid to protest at what they say is "massive exploitation" of the shark population.
Reuters

webTitle: Africans say UN must pay for genocide

fields.headline: Africans say UN must pay for genocide
fields.trailText: The Organisation of African Unity is demanding payment of "significant reparations" to Rwanda by the countries that failed to prevent the genocide of 1994, when 800,000 people are believed to have died.
fields.body:
The Organisation of African Unity is demanding payment of "significant reparations" to Rwanda by the countries that failed to prevent the genocide of 1994, when 800,000 people are believed to have died.

A special report released today for the July 10-12 opening of this year's annual OAU summit parallels the requested reparations with the $13bn Marshall Plan, which rebuilt Europe after the second world war; at today's value that would be more than £60bn.

The uncompromising report names the United States and France in particular, along with the UN security council as a whole, as guilty parties who allowed "this terrible conspiracy to go ahead".

It is written by a team headed by two former African heads of state, three former UN officials and a high court judge, and makes searing criticism of "the international betrayal of Rwanda".

"The United States had the influence within the security council to ensure the authorisation of a military mission that could have prevented the genocide...but the US made sure that no such force would ever reach Rwanda, even after it was known beyond question that one of the 20th century's greatest tragedies was unfolding," the report says.

"The French had unrivalled influence at the very highest levels of the Rwandan government and Rwandan military...[but] they chose never to exert that influence," it said.

This is the first time that the OAU has committed itself to such a high-profile political intervention on behalf of one of its members. "This is a real landmark for the OAU, of unprecedented boldness," said one African official.

After two years of research, the report's authors go much further than was expected in their demand for reparations.

The document will carry considerable weight well beyond Africa because of the influence of its signatories; Sir Quett Masire was president of Botswana from 1980 to 1997, General Ahmadou Touré was the president of Mali for 15 months from March 1991, Justice P N Bhagwati is a former chief justice of the Indian supreme court, while Stephen Lewis of Canada, Lisbet Palme of Sweden, senator Hocine Djoudi of Algeria, and Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf of Liberia have all had distinguished careers in UN circles.

"Apologies alone are not adequate. In the name of both justice and accountability, reparations are owed to Rwanda by actors in the international community for their roles before, during, and since the genocide," the report finds.

Besides the 800,000 people murdered, the report says that, "hundreds of thousands more suffered unimaginable suffering and suffer still".

To bring survivors a measure of peace, the report says that all leaders of the genocide should be brought to justice, extradited from the countries - 11 of which are OAU members, plus France and Belgium - which are thought to be harbouring them.

The report also calls for the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda in Arusha, Tanzania, to be transferred to Rwanda - a long-standing demand of the Rwandan government.

The OAU urges the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, to establish a commission to work out a formula for reparations, and says the money should go to urgently needed infrastructure and social services. In addition, the government's survivors' fund, which takes 5% of the annual budget, should receive generous contributions from the international community, the report says. And the special needs of women should take priority.

It also urges the immediate cancellation of all Rwanda's debt, saying much of it was accumulated by the governments that planned and executed the genocide.

The Rwanda report is sure to be the highlight of next week's summit in the Togolese capital, Lome. The summit's main focus will be on the dramatic situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo which has split the continent; the continued fighting in the country involves a dozen countries, but has at its heart the aftermath of Rwanda's genocide.
