fields.headline: Minette Walters: my cultural life
fields.standfirst: Minette Walters has a strict working pattern: I usually finish around 9pm. Then I watch whatever's on Channel 4 (which is completely brilliant) or BBC2. I like factual and historical programmes, anything that gives me information which I can feed off and use in my work.
fields.trailText: Minette Walters has a strict working pattern: I usually finish around 9pm. Then I watch whatever's on Channel 4 (which is completely brilliant) or BBC2. I like factual and historical programmes, anything that gives me information which I can feed off and use in my work.
fields.body:
I'm interested in youth culture. It's so dynamic. I would love to be young again. I want to go to the Reading Festival - I probably will one day.

I'm a movie addict and would rather spend a night at the cinema than anything else. You have more senses assaulted with a film. You sit there in the dark and can forget anyone else is there. I watch anything for bit of escapism and entertainment.

There was a perfect little movie on Sky the other night called The Alarmist, a black comedy, very understated, which was surprising for an American film. I like action films - anything with Arnie in. I never used to watch that stuff but then one day my kids said I was mad not to. It's hardly great art but it is fun. Theatre is an intellectual event, but with cinema there's more action and I don't mean in an Arnie kind of way.

I have a strict working pattern, usually finishing around 9pm. Then I watch whatever's on Channel 4 (which is completely brilliant) or BBC2. I like factual and historical programmes, anything that gives me information which I can feed off and use in my work.

What turns me off are all the gardening, cooking and house style programmes - they're very tedious. We do all that at home anyway so why watch it on telly? I watch UK Gold all the time just to see the funnies - all the tried-and-trusted greats. I'd love to get hold of the film version of One Foot In The Grave, filmed in Portugal. It's guaranteed to make me laugh every time.

Every afternoon I watch Countdown - TV scrabble and the best game show on TV. I enjoyed the Frances Fyfield adaptation recently on TV. Crime fiction does travel well and adapts for TV if the suspense and characters are kept. Of course, one always weeps because 75% of the book is lost.

I'm dying to go to Tate Modern. The local contemporary art in Dorsetshire, where I live, is very good.

My husband and I collect marine paintings - we both sail. I used my first bonus to buy a painting. We bought our first joint painting on honeymoon in Bali. Whenever we go abroad, we buy a painting instead of a postcard. There's one room at home dedicated to all our foreign travel - it's a lovely way to remember places.

When I've finished a book, I relax by doing something physical, like building a cupboard or painting with Radio 4 on in the background (though I have just discovered Radio 5 Live).

My boys turned up their noses at crime fiction because, like most people, they associate it with Agatha Christie. Finally they agreed to read one of mine and now they like it.

webTitle: Sometimes it's hard to be a Limey

fields.headline: Sometimes it's hard to be a Limey
fields.trailText: Sometimes it's hard to be a Limey
fields.body:
My, what a patriotic day I've had. First, the morning matinée of The Patriot, which we shall return to presently, then several beery barbecues in the hot afternoon sun to celebrate the birthday of the most gorgeous and grotesque social experiment in world history: the young American Republic.

Let's face it: July the 4th is not a great day to be British in America. I got an email from a British friend asking if, "like all Limeys", I would be "locking myself in a closet for the day?" Well, of course not, but note the use of terms associated with shame and self-hatred, and further mark the use of the word "closet" instead of "cupboard". My friend has lived here for 20 years and is now legally, linguistically and emotionally a US citizen, but July 4th is still a mild ordeal.

Not for me. Come Independence Day I like to get out and about, mingling with my neighbours by their pools and barbecues and generally making like Banquo's ghost at the feast. Every poolside barbecue features some drunk brother-in-law or uncle who likes to get after The Limey. Every year without fail, the same joke, "Uh-oh, the British are coming!"

Inevitably, as the beer takes hold, the Special Relationship begins to fray at the edges. You can usually have some good-natured fun with these jingoistic pillocks, once they've roused your inner Limey Erectus. Ask them for instance, since they're such good Americans, if they know who Lafayette was. No one ever has a clue. Or "What was Billy The Kid's real name?"

"William Bonney, dumbshit!"

"Henry McGrath."

"See, that's the problem with you limeys, man. Y'all think you're sooo fuckin' smart."

That's not it, though. The immigrant is always hungrier for knowledge of his adopted country's history than the citizen who can take it all for granted. In America, the past is something that recedes in the rear-view mirror, whereas in England it fills the whole windscreen. Drill a 20-ft core sample out of the floor of Westminster Abbey and all the way down you'll get the same boring old cathedral. Blah.

Drill a five-ft core sample from any parking lot in Los Angeles and you'll get layers of gas station, drive-thru chilli-cheeseburger outlet, picture house, office building, dirty bookstore, Mexican bakery, rail yard, brothel, saloon, blacksmith, pueblo dwelling and finally the mingled bones of Indians, missionaries, conquistadors, and the jaguars that once roamed as far north as San Francisco. Who says America has no history?

Well, Americans, mainly. Venerability and historic associations are no guarantee of anything ("the past? That shit is, like, so over"). There used to be a lovely old 50s 24-hour diner on the Sunset Strip called Ben Franks. It was the epicentre of the Strip in the psychedelic mid-60s. Neil Young and Stephen Stills met there in 1965 and founded Buffalo Springfield over waffles and syrup. The Doors hung out in its narcotic fug, as did Gram Parsons, the Byrds, the Bobby Fuller Four and Charles Manson, alongside the movie and music-biz aristocracy of nearby Laurel Canyon. Ben Franks was the focus of an entirely unique cultural moment, and last year it was torn down. In its place there now stands a retro-1950s 24-hour diner, Mel's. Whenever I drive past, I burst out laughing.

The other response to historic sites is to build gruesome theme parks and populate them, according to location and degree of antiquity, with high-school kids dressed as pilgrim fathers, civil war soldiers, cavalry officers, Indians, riverboat gamblers or gun fighters. The Colonial Jamestown Experience, The Little Bighorn Massacre Experience, The Japanese-American Internment Experience.

Mind you, with history like this... Slavery, witch-hunts, lynching, Manifest Destiny, the Great Plain strewn with the corpses of massacred Indians and littered with pyramids of buffalo skulls, the annexation of Cuba and the Philipines, McCarthyism, J Edgar Hoover, Jim Crow, Vietnam and Cambodia, Guatemala and Chile. Americans, it has been said, are "nostalgic for the future", and with that kind of legacy, who wouldn't be?

Far better, as the newspaper editor puts it in The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance, to forget historical facts and "print the legend". That's pretty much what Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich have done with The Patriot, which, being a period picture, didn't make it to number one this weekend.

Mel is again doing another country's national myths, much as he did for lucky old Scotland in Braveheart. Can we soon expect to see him playing St George or King Alfred? What about Kemal Ataturk, Garibaldi, Gough Whitlam, Jomo Kenyatta or Boadicea? The possibilities are endless. As is The Patriot.

It's written by Robert Rodat, who gave us the saccharine hyperrealism of Saving Private Ryan. He hasn't changed his recipe: war is hell, a man's gotta do, etc. History is craftily tailored to make us believe that yeoman-farmer Mel could have owned a South Carolina tobacco plantation yet kept no slaves (a likely story), and that slaves were overjoyed at the chance to fight on behalf of their owners.

There are some vivid battle scenes (someone's been watching Barry Lyndon), and the location scouts, set decorators and CGI geeks have obviously flayed a lot of books on early American landscape painting, but the foreground is all misty-eyed family melodrama and cheesy flag-waving. The big villain is - who else? - a church-burning, child-shooting British officer. He comes on like a combination of My Lai's Lt William Calley and Adolf Eichmann in redcoat and pantaloons. After a while, just for the hell of it, I started rooting for him.

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: Bringing Out the Dead | The Muse | Man with a Movie Camera
fields.trailText: Bringing Out the Dead | The Muse | Man with a Movie Camera
fields.body:
Bringing Out the Dead
Rental and DVD (£15.99)
Buena Vista/ Warner Cert 18
*****

A long dark night of the soul for Nicolas Cage and a trip and a half through neon-drenched New York for the rest of us as Cage's paramedic angel of mercy and "grief mop" does the rounds of cardiac arrests, junkies and failed sucides that make up his shift. If this sounds too gloomy to contemplate, fear not. There's a rumbustious gallows humour underpinning the drama as surely as Van Morrison's TB Sheets, which runs through it like a Greek chorus.

This is Martin Scorsese's first collaboration with writer Paul Schrader since Taxi Driver and the parallels are obvious but what hits you is how fresh a film this is: there's never a hint of the tired re-tread that was Casino and the acting from Cage and his partners - John Goodman, Tom Sizemore and especially an exuberant Ving Rhames - feels like a joyous release from multiplex fodder into the real, and surreal, world. Cage is saving lives, but can he save his own? He gets the full Scorsese range of guilt, redemption and demons from the past (Scorsese and Schrader's past includes narcotic near-death experiences - they've been there, now it's our turn.) A seamless plot includes a doomed affair for Cage and Arquette (life? art? who knows?) and Cage's Catch-22-style attempts to get himself fired.

The Muse
Retail and DVD (£19.99)
Entertainment in Video Cert PG
**

How to make a muse amusing? Albert Brooks, in one of his occasional actor-co-writer-director roles, has a go in a sketchy little film that's more a Hollywood in-joke than a full-blown comedy. It starts as our hero, a screenwriter, wins a humanitarian award. "What exactly is a humanitarian?" his daughter asks. "It's someone who's never won the Oscar," she is told. That sets the tone for humour based entirely on Hollywood's rampant paranoia and insecurity.

Despite the award, Brooks finds everyone suddenly feels that he's "lost his edge". Panicking, he goes to see successful old friend Jeff Bridges, who lets him in on the secret, a muse played by Sharon Stone as an impossibly demanding, fan-fluttering diva and daughter of Zeus (or Zoose, as they call it). Brooks's idea doesn't go much further than that as the plot trundles towards a rather lame twist, but there are incidental pleasures as she is visited by James Cameron and a wonderfully parodic Martin Scorsese as they anguish over a sequel to Titanic or a remake of Raging Bull. Amiable stuff, then, but for a film about screenwriters and muses, it's begging for a little divine inspiration.

Man with a Movie Camera
DVD (£19.99)
BFI Cert E
****

Dziga Vertov is a name from the distant documentary past that film students like to drop. This 1929 film about a Russian city shows why the name survives. It is a stunning display of one man trying out a new toy and celebrating the modern; and, 80 years later, it is weirdly postmodern. Vertov put himself (or his cameraman) in the film lugging his tripod through the streets or filming from a car driving alongside the action.

His pyrotechnic montages and frantic splicing of images must have come as a shock to contemporary audiences. Film editing has rarely been as skilful or as frenetic and some tricks, like making a building collapse by folding the screen in the middle, seem more like 1999. His speeding up citizens in motion to look like ants might have been a first too.

The film loves motion. Trams, trains and cars, big machines and factory production lines chug endlessly, sometimes contrasted with ancient-looking peasant faces. The film lends itself to musical accompaniment and has a choice of alternative scores, one from In the Nursery, who toured with the film last year. It builds to a raving climax, as if he saw modern life spinning out of control (the commentary tells us that Dziga Vertov is a made-up name translating roughly as Spinning Top.)

webTitle: The day they blew up John Ford

fields.headline: The day they blew up John Ford
fields.standfirst: In this extract from his biography of the legendary director, Scott Eyman describes John Ford's days as prop boy - and stuntman
fields.trailText: In this extract from his biography of the legendary director, Scott Eyman describes John Ford's days as prop boy - and stuntman
fields.body:
John Ford usually asserted that he did no acting whatever in his early days in the movies, but surviving stills clearly show him working as an actor in some of his brother's films, and trade paper reviews prove that he even starred in a couple of now lost two-reelers. He would also claim that he was one of the hooded klansmen in The Birth of a Nation [in 1915], but that the hood interfered with his sight and he fell off his horse, knocking himself unconscious. He awoke to find DW Griffith bending over him, calling for whiskey. Telling Griffith that he felt OK, the director responded by saying the whiskey was for him.

Around Universal, Jack - as he was known - was a general dogsbody, doing what he was told, working as a propman, assistant director, stuntman, bit actor. He was learning the movie business from the ground up, learning all facets of it as a craft, without which no art can be made.

"He brought a very strange language into pictures, due, no doubt, to his ignorance of the business," remembered the writer Grover Jones. "When [his brother, Francis] Ford would send him to the prop shop to get something, it was his lack of knowledge that made him refer to the thing as a 'razz-a-ma-tazz,' a 'thing-a-ma-bob, you-know-what-I-mean,' 'what-cha-ma-callit,' or a 'hootenanny.' He had 1,000 other expressions, but once he pointed to something that resembled the thing he was after and went through a few pantomimic gestures, the experienced man in the prop shop would put two and two together and finally supply him with the necessary article."

Any gift Jack might have had for acting was hampered by the fact that he couldn't see without his glasses, which didn't stop Francis from calling on him for stunt work. "Yeah, a sissy like you might get hurt," Francis would say to a worried actor. "I'll have my little brother do it for you." At whatever he did, he was "a hell of a smart cookie", as propman Lefty Hough remembered. But his essentially covert personality was already firmly in place. "[He was] a mysterious sort of guy," said Hough. "Nobody ever got close to him."

Jack was young and engaged in a great adventure: the romance of the movies, the birth of an art form. "Those were great days," Ford wrote in 1946. "We rode out in the morning in blue uniforms and army forage caps, while tied to our saddles would be grey blouses and black plumed slough hats. We would charge as Union soldiers, pull up and change into the grey blouses and charge back as Confederate soldiers... We used very few close-ups in those days. Nearly everything was played on horseback. It was all very fast moving. Motion, action, was the keynote of the times."

Jack doubled for his brother and other actors in serials like Lucille Love. "I had to drive over bridges, jump over ravines on horseback and things like that. I had just finished school and was fairly sprightly. I did everything." Once, he was doubling for his brother in a civil war picture, when a little bit too much gunpowder was used in a battle scene. The explosion, recalled Hough, "put him in the hospital for six weeks. He never got over that. He blamed it on me, and I didn't do it, I had nothing to do with it, but he claimed that I was the instigator. [Actually] his brother Francis did it."

Jack woke in the hospital with a broken arm. "That was a close thing," Francis blithely said to his bruised younger brother. "Another second and audiences would have realised I was using a double."

John Ford was a man who remembered - no, who nurtured - a grievance. Nearly 20 years later, during the production of Judge Priest, he had Francis play a scene in a wheelbarrow in front of a general store. When Francis was distracted, Ford had an assistant tie a rope from the wheelbarrow to the axle of a prop carriage. As the heroine rode off in the carriage, Frank had his perch yanked out from under him and took a hard fall, swallowing his tobacco. "That was for the grenade," Ford said shaking his finger under his brother's nose, as if Francis had pulled his stunt the previous week.

At this point in his life, Jack appears to have been fairly social and very responsible; in September 1916, he joined the Knights of Columbus, and a month later he took out another insurance policy, paying $18 for $3,000 worth of coverage, again payable to his mother. Under "Occupation" he wrote: "assistant motion picture director, not acrobat or gymnast".

His relationship to Francis didn't insulate him from the vicissitudes of studio life; there were frequent lay-offs at Universal, so he had to look elsewhere for work. He preserved a dismissal letter from LKO, a lowly comedy studio, dated February 3, 1917. Things couldn't have been too grim, for that same month he was purchasing two custom shirts for $10 apiece.

To a great extent, the Jack Ford of this period was the John Ford who would be a world-famous film director in 1940. Even as a young man, he was very obviously Irish, and he had a crusty aura that signalled that he wasn't to be trifled with. "There wasn't any 'Please step over this way'," remembered [director] Allan Dwan. "It was, 'Come on you bastards, get in line and shut up.' He was only 20 years old, but there was no doubt about who the boss was..."

Hollywood was full of Irish directors in the silent days - Rex Ingram, Herbert Brenon, William Desmond Taylor, Marshall Neilan, Allan Dwan, Joseph Henabery, William Wellman, Raoul Walsh - but Ford would be the only one to consistently play the professional Irishman, as if he was in the Foreign Legion without a countryman in sight. There was an element of performance in this, but Ford's assertiveness would also be a form of compensation for his insecurity.

There are several variant versions of how Ford made the jump to the ranks of director. Ford's own version, repeated both to Peter Bogdanovich and others, was that he was pressed into service as a prop director, using a camera without film, to impress [the producer] Carl Laemmle, who had suddenly appeared from New York. "I was just the prop boy... [but] I told the cowboys to go down to the end of the street and come back toward the camera riding fast and yelling like hell. Laemmle came up with his entourage and I had the cowboys do their stuff. Laemmle seemed to like it."

Ford improvised some more action, even having some of the cowboys fall off their horses on cue. "A little later, they needed a director for a two-reeler and Laemmle said: "Try Ford. He yells loud."

 Scott Eyman's Print The Legend: The Life and Times of John Ford, is published by Simon and Schuster, price £25. A season of John Ford films runs from July 11-30 at the NFT, London (box office: 020-7928 3232).

fields.headline: Jesus and the second coming
fields.standfirst: She's done Homicide. She's done Sex and the City. But now Alison Maclean's back doing what she loves - movies
fields.trailText: She's done Homicide. She's done Sex and the City. But now Alison Maclean's back doing what she loves - movies
fields.body:
Jesus' Son, an episodic saga of drug life in early-70s America, is fresh enough to feel like Alison Maclean's first film, but in fact she made her debut in 1992 with Crush, a sombre, perverse drama about an American intruder's sexual manipulation of a New Zealand household. Crush was distinctive for its mood of sexual foreboding, and for the way Maclean filmed the touristic backwaters of New Zealand, especially the ominously gurgling mud geysers of Rotorua.

So what happened after Crush? It's a long story, so long that Maclean looks fatigued and relieved to have made it through. Born in Ottawa, she moved to New Zealand in her teens, and was already living in Sydney when she wrote Crush. That film was well received just about everywhere except New Zealand, where it was "savaged". She got a deal with Disney subsidiary Touchstone Pictures, and went to New York to look into filming Joan Didion's newsroom drama Up Close and Personal. It never happened, and the tear-jerking Michelle Pfeiffer vehicle it became shows Maclean was well out of it.

Next Maclean devoted herself to projects that nearly came off. One was Bedlam, a remake of Val Lewton's 1946 Hogarthian chiller, a project intended by Martin Scorsese as a vehicle for his then partner Illeana Douglas. Then there was an offer from Wayne Wang and Tom Luddy (Francis Coppola's partner at Zoetrope) to contribute to a series of low-budget Asian pictures.

"I had a script for a Thai action film, not that I've ever seen a Thai action film," Maclean admits. She went to Bangkok to write it, but says: "I shot myself in the foot and wrote it a little too expensive." Was she getting restless? "That's an understatement. It's been nearly seven years. I've spent that time writing three feature scripts, going up the wall trying to get them financed."

Ironically, it was someone else's script that got her started again. Jesus' Son is an unlikely adaptation, coming not from a novel but a short story collection. The connecting thread is narrator Fuckhead, a young junkie who drifts in and out of his own and other people's lives in early-70s midwest. Maclean read the book when it was published in 1992, and contacted its author Denis Johnson. But the project really kicked off three years later, when she got a call "out of left field" from the film's co-writers Elizabeth Cuthrell and David Urrutia.

The film is remarkably true to the book's flavour and structure - a string of anecdotes which fade in and out, lose their drift, then abruptly find it again, moving in and out of sync with Fuckhead's addled brain. Author Johnson helped compile its soundtrack of ancient soul and bubblegum pop, and took a cameo as a man with a hunting knife jammed in his eye.

Johnson's vision, trailerpark realism with hallucinatory metaphysical underpinnings, comes across intact. "He actually thinks of himself as a Christian writer," Maclean says, "but in a way that would compare to Flannery O'Connor, in that there's nothing pious about his writing. There's a lot of cruelty and extremes, yet it's concerned with questions of faith. He has his own mythology which comes out again and again, these angel and devil figures."

Jesus' Son catches that other-worldly drift with its imagistic slips: a drive-in cinema becoming a haunted graveyard, a tattooed, snakeskinned Jesus (or Satan?) manifesting himself in a laundromat. Maclean's film stands out as one of the most convincing and non-sensationalist drug films, alongside Drugstore Cowboy.

Following a spell in the glossy realms of TV drama, Jesus' Son takes Maclean back to the rough side. After a shaky start, she managed to establish herself as an American director with episodes of Homicide and Sex and the City: "Homicide was a blast. You come into this well-oiled machine and there's a tremendous looseness about how they film it. You're for hire, you come in and do your best, then they want you out fast. You're not welcome any more. It's liberating not to be so personally invested in the content."

Directing the first two episodes of Sex and the City, Maclean and illustrious cinematographer Maryse Alberti had a little more leeway to help invent the series' style: "We worked out a look. They presumably hired us because they wanted something more cinematic. I felt that the producers got cold feet halfway through. They pretty much said, 'Look, just shoot them in close-up, all we care about is the humour and the lines.' But I think we were spoiled doing the first two. We had extra time and resources."

As a writer-director, it must have been frustrating working on other people's material for so long - although on Jesus' Son, Maclean found it had its advantages. "It's a relief because it's less intense. It's exciting to enter into someone else's sensibility and try to interpret things you're personally incapable of writing. In another way, it's a little harder. When you're working from your own material, you just know it on such a deep level."

There's also the fact that on Jesus' Son the writers also controlled the pursestrings: two of them were also the producers. "That's why it was more of a collaboration than anything I'd experienced. We had arguments, but amicable ones." Now, Maclean says: "I'm dying to do my own material again. That's my highest priority." She hopes her next film will be Iris, a thriller about false memory that she is dusting down for another draft. Maybe we shouldn't hold our breath - but a year, or two, or seven from now, Maclean could surprise us again.

 On general release.

fields.headline: Bullets for breakfast
fields.standfirst: Alan Rudolph's latest movie is the demented tale of a used car salesman, a dyspeptic sci-fi writer and the meaning of life. And it stars Bruce Willis, Nick Nolte and Albert Finney. So how could it possibly fail? Danny Leigh on the curse of the nearly man
fields.trailText: Alan Rudolph's latest movie is the demented tale of a used car salesman, a dyspeptic sci-fi writer and the meaning of life. And it stars Bruce Willis, Nick Nolte and Albert Finney. So how could it possibly fail? Danny Leigh on the curse of the nearly man
fields.body:
At one point during an hour of conversation, Alan Rudolph seems happy. Not what you might call ecstatic; just quietly, unaffectedly happy. It doesn't happen much more than once. But it happens. This is what it sounds like.

"You know, I've never been so proud of any of my films as I am of this. I mean, we did it in six weeks, with a dream cast, none of whom were really making any money and, well... making it was a magic carpet ride. A real magic carpet ride." He's talking about Breakfast of Champions, his impressively demented adaptation of the equally outlandish novel by Kurt Vonnegut concerning - in essence - a depressed used-car salesman, a dyspeptic sci-fi writer, and the meaning of life.

It stars Bruce Willis, Nick Nolte and Albert Finney and, as a purely cinematic experience, it's about as wildly baroque as it gets. As a contender at US box offices, however, it sank faster than lead. Which, when he gets around to mentioning it, is roughly the moment where he stops sounding happy at all.

"Unfortunately, of course, the magic carpet then crashed horribly to the ground when the film actually came out." And, in the space of a sentence, that's really the whole Alan Rudolph story. For almost 30 years, the California-bred son of a TV director has been ploughing his singular - and singularly unregarded - furrow on the Hollywood margins, first assisting his long-time mentor Robert Altman, then heading off to hone his own laidback, vaguely literary technique.

Sure, many of the results have been critically well-received: his whimsical 1976 debut Welcome to LA, the quintessential mid-80s art-flick Trouble in Mind, 1997's mordant drama Afterglow. Now and then, he's even had the faintest of brushes with commercial success (or at least non-disaster). Mortal Thoughts, the 1991 thriller starring Bruce Willis and Demi Moore? Nearly made it. Mrs Parker and the Vicious Circle, his deft, empathetic portrait of the eponymous Dorothy? Almost got there.

But only nearly. Because, while Rudolph's films have grown better and more interesting as the years have passed, his elegant signature style has never quite registered beyond the art cinema. He remains the last great(ish) American director no one's ever heard of - or, as he puts it, "someone who can't even blow his own trumpet, because he's always playing out of tune".

You can't help feeling that, while glumly accustomed to mass indifference, the combination of his zeal for the material - he first drafted the script in 1975 - and Willis's pulling power coming to nought got to him in a way he hadn't been got to in decades.

Slowly, he exhales. "I mean, to me, Breakfast had really become a way of looking at life. And people say the movie is dated, but I think if they didn't know the book was written in the 70s, that wouldn't even enter their minds. I mean, maybe it's because it's about a used-car salesman - people say it's been done before, but so has New York cop and no one raises an eyebrow at that. And to me a used-car salesman is still the single greatest symbol of, you know... good old American bullshit."

There are two targets in his sights: the mainstream US critics "who still have the power to destroy a little movie, and who used that power to blast the hell out of Breakfast", and Disney, the film's American distributors. A snarl - small, but definite - enters his voice at their name: "It was actually very ingenious and duplicitous the way Disney suppressed it because they suppressed it by releasing it. I mean, they released it in such a derisory fashion that no one knew it existed. In my opinion, they only wanted it so they could keep it quiet."

No matter how circuitous the route, he keeps returning to the same bitter territory. I tell him the defiantly unhinged Breakfast reminded me of Terry Gilliam's similarly maligned take on another seminal counter-cultural bible, Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas. And back we come.

"Well, I deliberately avoided seeing that because I knew there would be comparisons. Having said that, once again I could tell it was a good picture, just because of the way the establishment press slammed it." There's the briefest of pauses. "I mean, what I will say is that we got great reactions from directors and actors. [Steven] Soderbergh saw it at the only screening we were ever given, and he's been trying to get Confederacy of Dunces made for years, and he told me, 'Now I know how to make it.' But critics" - he gives a verbal shudder - "really are a lazy, shallow, myopic and unenlightened band of people these days." He's got a point. Because, while it's hardly the most sophisticated film you're ever likely to see, neither is Breakfast the dumb, lysergic mess it could easily have dissolved into.

And, with his evident fondness for his actors (he routinely describes them as "the only artists in the process") Rudolph teases out perhaps Willis's best performance since his flirtation with credibility in Gilliam's Twelve Monkeys. The director's affection for his leading man, whose clout ensured the film actually got made, sweetens the bile.

"I mean, here's Bruce," he declares, "playing this character who's an icon in his community, who everyone thinks they know, and who's going through absolute turmoil. And for Bruce to select that role, and to play it so self-effacingly, and to make a connection between that character and his own life - that to me is amazing. One guy asked him why he wanted the part, and he said, 'Oh, because obviously I wouldn't know what it's like to have the whole world staring at you, and be screaming inside.' And for this cultural icon, whose fame has come from films which are basically mindless escapism, to have gone public and say to the world that he's trapped in a cage, then for the distributors and the critics not to allow people to hear him... well, that's criminal."

Like I said, he's not happy. It's only when the talk turns to his place, or rather lack of one, in the film-business food chain that his tone softens, the anger replaced by a wry shrug. Operating without the cosy sanction of the indie pacesetters - "I guess I'm just not very hip that way" - he's also fully aware he's never likely to find himself fighting off ardent executives. The thought genuinely doesn't seem to bother him.

"No, I think I'm probably, as they would say, just completely off their radar. I mean, Altman always says that he makes hats and Hollywood makes shoes, but for me it's like Hollywood makes shoes and I grow asparagus. You know? I'm not even in the same simile. I mean, it's funny, because I'll have a script and I won't even think of taking it to a studio. They really haven't been part of my thought process for over 20 years. So I just try and get the financing and make these movies on my own."

Even in the face of duplicitous distributors and shallow, unenlightened critics? He sniggers at his own adjectives. "Oh, I don't think there's any great conspiracy," he says. "I wouldn't flatter myself by thinking anyone's paying that much attention. You know, executives are afraid, and critics are afraid, so they play safe. I mean, merchandising is the biggest part of the movie industry, and the movie industry is one of America's biggest exports, and America leads the world in exports, so you see how important merchandising is and how much people's jobs depend on it. I mean, someone like me is always going to be hanging on my fingerprints - how could I ever compete with Mickey Mouse?" I let him answer his own question. "So... I don't."

 Breakfast of Champions is released next Friday.

fields.headline: Sophie Thompson
fields.trailText: Sophie Thompson
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw? Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. I was quite small and it was very scary.

What's your favourite film and why? Dougal and the Blue Cat which my father [Eric Thompson] narrated. It's the film version of Magic Roundabout - a wonderful film but rarely seen. I wish they'd show it again.

When did you last walk out of the movies? At Toy Story 2. I took my son Ernie but he was trembling with fear.

What's the most erotic moment you've seen? Amanda Root and Ciaran Hinds in Persuasion when their hands touch. So exciting.

What's the most annoying thing you see in cinemas? I can't bear people leaving early. I've got to stay till the very end - till after the music.

When was the last time you snogged at the movies? I can't possibly divulge.

Favourite dialogue? From A Close Shave. Wallace: "Do you want to come in? We're just about to have some cheese." The woman: "Oh no, not cheese, it brings me out in a rash." He says: "Not even Wensleydale?" It says a lot, and not just about cheese.

Which actor would you like to be? Michael Gambon. I wrote my first fan letter to him. He's a remarkable actor and has amazing hands.

Which actress? Linda Bassett. She's so touching. I remember her in Frost on TV. She had a tiny scene but got it all without doing a lot.

Which film character? The cowardly lion in the Wizard of Oz.

What movie last made you cry? Saving Grace which starred my mother [Phyllida Law] but she always makes me cry when I watch her.

When was the last time you hid under your seat? All the time. It's easier to say when I didn't hide.

Has it been hard to carve out an individual career coming from such a famous family? I've been acting since I was very young so I've not thought about it.

What was it like working with Julie Andrews in Relative Values? She was gorgeous. The whole cast was a bit nervous of working with her but she was so professional. If she hadn't been nice she would have shattered all our childhood dreams.

 Sophie Thompson stars in Relative Values, on general release.

fields.headline: Milwaukee's finest
fields.standfirst: Will Hodgkinson on the rise of Mark and Mike, film-makers and vodka-drinkers
fields.trailText: Will Hodgkinson on the rise of Mark and Mike, film-makers and vodka-drinkers
fields.body:
For every indie auteur waiting for their credit-card-financed first movie to provoke a bidding war at Sundance, there's a Super 8-nurtured soul out there for whom the language of Hollywood is as indecipherable as ancient Greek. Mark Borchardt, a long-haired, goatee-bearded Milwaukee dude, is one such soul, and his crusade to make a horror movie - and use his family and friends as cast and crew - is spotlighted in American Movie, a documentary by Chris Smith and Sarah Price.

American Movie is the story of Borchardt fighting, against the odds, to complete a movie called Coven, about an Alcoholics Anonymous group who are secret devil-worshippers. Over the two years that director Smith and producer Price spend with Borchardt, he deals with paternity suits, too much boozing, his uncle (and main financial backer) showing scepticism at his abilities, leading men being jailed, and his mum showing more interest in shopping than in being one of the coven's victims.

Then, in the background, there's Borchardt's magnum opus, Northwestern, a portrait of his life yet to be made. He shares his problems with Mike Schank, an amiable, guitar-playing, heavy metal fan whose prodigious drug and alcohol intake a few years back has left him fried, but still capable of a well-timed pithy comment.

In the wrong hands, this story could have been a voyeuristic look at the eccentricities of the mid-western working class, but Smith is smart enough to recognise Borchardt's intelligence and dignity. "I met Mark in 1995 in Milwaukee, when he was abandoning Coven to make Northwestern," Smith explains. "In his own esoteric way, he gave me a description of what the film would be. I thought if he could do half of what he's planning, it would be really interesting - he was so sincere about what he was trying to do. So I wanted to document that process, and capture his energy."

Smith's original plan was to follow Borchardt as he travelled with his mum and dad to the Toronto film festival to raise money for Northwestern. One thing led to another, Northwestern never got made, and American Movie evolved into a portrait of Borchardt's life.

"Mark quit Northwestern to make Coven," explains Price. "He said, 'I'm just going to finish off this other film, it'll only take a couple of weeks.' A couple of weeks turned into two years. My first impression was that he had an urgency about his life. He feels that he's already wasted a lot of time and that now he has to get on with it. When he was younger, he ran with a group of kids who all dropped out of school and spent their time drinking and getting into trouble, and he was just coming out of that world when we met him, and he was highly philosophical and articulate about it."

But despite diverting influences, Borchardt knew his destiny from a young age. "I could never relate to other people. I thought, 'Wow, this is a trip being alive,' and other people were just talking about what they saw on TV last night. Then one day when I was 14, I was walking to school and this dude had a Super 8 and he was filming all this stuff and I said, 'Wait a second. I can record all these ideas about the world on that film camera right there.' So I whipped out two 20s, man, and from that day on it was over, man, this is what I was going to do all my life."

Borchardt's distinctive charm shines throughout the film. "When I first met him, I had a stereotyped image of how someone who looked like that would be," says Smith. "But there was a lot that surprised me, like the way he includes his mom in everything, and of how he places value on shovelling the snow from the sidewalk or mowing the lawn because he feels that's the right thing to do. He was constantly surprising and impressing us."

For Borchardt and his friend Schank, the experience of being filmed for two years was, apparently, no big deal. "It was totally cool," says Borchardt of the experience. "That's me up there, man." Schank adds: "Not only does Sarah look really good but they're really great, nice people and it's good to have their company."

What Borchardt is most pleased about is that American Movie has helped him move closer to achieving his goal for Coven: selling 3,000 copies of the film on video. "I've sold 2,500 of the 3,000 and they're going like nuts, so it did the trick, man. But let me explain something. People can not only earn money but maintain it and make more of it, or they can have goals in life, you know, to be bodybuilders and stuff like that, but you can go out at any time in life, so what I'd like to do is make the most out of each day, to eat good, to have some water and coffee and beer, to read, to write and all that stuff. So that's what I'm trying to learn, man. Making films has just got to be a part of my life. That's why I can never get into the film industry because that's just like having a factory job. I don't wanna work for somebody. Because believe it or not, this is the only one shot you get, dude."

You can't help but wonder if the success of American Movie has changed Borchardt and Schank, but they seem to be taking it all in their stride. "I've got an old girlfriend emailing me, and I've got a phone in my room which people can call, area code 414 466 M-I-K-E, and it's really fun talking to people all over the country and the world," says Mike Schank in monotone.

"The only reason I'd be in another movie is if, a) Mark was doing it and Mark is my friend and I think I'd have a good time, or b) it's like these people in Los Angeles are offering me $749 a day... well, what am I supposed to do? Am I meant to stay home and work for the neighbour for $30 a day busting my ass, or do something easy for $750 a day? I don't really care about their movies, I don't know what their goal is. But if they want me to be in their movie, whatever, you know. They're even offering to fly Mark out there and pay him $110 to hang out with me."

For Borchardt, the goalposts haven't moved. Although he is pleased that the success of American Movie has helped him meet his hero, Dawn of the Dead director George Romero. "I'm really, really not into Hollywood films because they're entertainment, and I'm not interested in entertaining people. I've seen two films this year and they were both critically acclaimed and I just thought, 'Oh man. I can't handle this crap any more.'

"There are beautiful films out there by Fellini, Godard - Alphaville blows me away, man - or the beauty of Rosemary's Baby. That Cassavetes is just in it to make money for his own films, and then you see his films and they're so cool... just two hours of this couple just arguing, man, it's amazing. I'd only do a film for someone else for a nice sum of money, man. People send me scripts and want me to star in stuff and it's all bullshit, it's all garbage, man. It's like Mike says, 'I'll take the money but I won't take their goal.' "

One of the best aspects of American Movie is its portrayal of the duo's friendship. Borchardt describes Schank as the nicest person he has ever met, and seems prepared to do anything to help out his friend. The two bonded over their love of drinking litres of vodka together, at a time when Schank was taking prodigious amounts of acid and smoking pot. He's been clean for five years, having given up drink and drugs just before filming began.

"A lot of people can really relate to the drug aspect of myself," says Borchardt of the film. "I had one dude who called me and he did five hits of acid and watched American Movie and now I'm his god. All I do now is nicotine, caffeine and what the doctor gives me. I used to think things look better when you're on acid, but actually things look better when you're straight. Although a lot of people say they got burnt out after they smoked a lot of weed and acid, I never did. I never had any bad effects from partying."

"You never had any bad effects from partying? Dude, you almost died! What are you talking about?"

Smith and Price have stayed friends with Borchardt and Schank. American Movie has meant that Borchardt no longer has to do factory jobs, while Schank can now sell his audiocassettes of his guitar-playing through his special phone line. Apart from that, life goes on. Most importantly, Northwestern has yet to be completed.

"I wrote five drafts of the stuff, and it's all garbage, only a couple of pages are good," says Borchardt, shaking his head. "It's so hard to write and concentrate on a daily basis, there is so much drama and weirdness every day that it's really hard to find quiet time to write. So I'm starting in the fall, because after a time you get to a point when you have to say, 'I'm putting film in the camera and I'm starting. I don't care about script or no script, I'm starting, dude.' I'll be 34 and time is going by real quick."

 American Movie is released today.

"But there was a lot that surprised me, like the way he includes his mom in everything, and of how he places value on shovelling the snow from the sidewalk or mowing the lawn because he feels that's the right thing to do. He was constantly surprising and impressing us." For Borchardt and his friend Schank, the experience of being filmed for two years was, apparently, no big deal. "It was totally cool," says Borchardt of the experience. "That's me up there, man." Schank adds: "Not only does Sarah look really good but they're really great, nice people and it's good to have their company." What Borchardt is most pleased about is that American Movie has helped him move closer to achieving his goal for Coven: selling 3,000 copies of the film on video. "I've sold 2,500 of the 3,000 and they're going like nuts, so it did the trick, man. But let me explain something. People can not only earn money but maintain it and make more of it, or they can have goals in life, you know, to be bodybuilders and stuff like that, but you can go out at any time in life, so what I'd like to do is make the most out of each day, to eat good, to have some water and coffee and beer, to read, to write and all that stuff. So that's what I'm trying to learn, man. Making films has just got to be a part of my life. That's why I can never get into the film industry because that's just like having a factory job. I don't wanna work for somebody. Because believe it or not, this is the only one shot you get, dude." You can't help but wonder if the success of American Movie has changed Borchardt and Schank, but they seem to be taking it all in their stride. "I've got an old girlfriend emailing me, and I've got a phone in my room which people can call, area code 414 466 M-I-K-E, and it's really fun talking to people all over the country and the world," says Mike Schank in monotone. "The only reason I'd be in another movie is if, a) Mark was doing it and Mark is my friend and I think I'd have a good time, or b) it's like these people in Los Angeles are offering me $749 a day... well, what am I supposed to do? Am I meant to stay home and work for the neighbour for $30 a day busting my ass, or do something easy for $750 a day? I don't really care about their movies, I don't know what their goal is. But if they want me to be in their movie, whatever, you know. They're even offering to fly Mark out there and pay him $110 to hang out with me." For Borchardt, the goalposts haven't moved. Although he is pleased that the success of American Movie has helped him meet his hero, Dawn of the Dead director George Romero. "I'm really, really not into Hollywood films because they're entertainment, and I'm not interested in entertaining people. I've seen two films this year and they were both critically acclaimed and I just thought, 'Oh man. I can't handle this crap any more.' "There are beautiful films out there by Fellini, Godard - Alphaville blows me away, man - or the beauty of Rosemary's Baby. That Cassavetes is just in it to make money for his own films, and then you see his films and they're so cool... just two hours of this couple just arguing, man, it's amazing. I'd only do a film for someone else for a nice sum of money, man. People send me scripts and want me to star in stuff and it's all bullshit, it's all garbage, man. It's like Mike says, 'I'll take the money but I won't take their goal.' " One of the best aspects of American Movie is its portrayal of the duo's friendship. Borchardt describes Schank as the nicest person he has ever met, and seems prepared to do anything to help out his friend. The two bonded over their love of drinking litres of vodka together, at a time when Schank was taking prodigious amounts of acid and smoking pot. He's been clean for five years, having given up drink and drugs just before filming began. "A lot of people can really relate to the drug aspect of myself," says Borchardt of the film. "I had one dude who called me and he did five hits of acid and watched American Movie and now I'm his god. All I do now is nicotine, caffeine and what the doctor gives me. I used to think things look better when you're on acid, but actually things look better when you're straight. Although a lot of people say they got burnt out after they smoked a lot of weed and acid, I never did. I never had any bad effects from partying." "You never had any bad effects from partying? Dude, you almost died! What are you talking about?" Smith and Price have stayed friends with Borchardt and Schank. American Movie has meant that Borchardt no longer has to do factory jobs, while Schank can now sell his audiocassettes of his guitar-playing through his special phone line. Apart from that, life goes on. Most importantly, Northwestern has yet to be completed. "I wrote five drafts of the stuff, and it's all garbage, only a couple of pages are good," says Borchardt, shaking his head. "It's so hard to write and concentrate on a daily basis, there is so much drama and weirdness every day that it's really hard to find quiet time to write. So I'm starting in the fall, because after a time you get to a point when you have to say, 'I'm putting film in the camera and I'm starting. I don't care about script or no script, I'm starting, dude.' I'll be 34 and time is going by real quick."  American Movie is released today.

fields.standfirst:
(Blake, £16.99). Condensed in the style of the original

fields.trailText: Whenever Debbie and I give a party for our envious showbiz pals in our beautiful riverside home with 12 acres of formal gardens and stunning woodlands, I think of how far I have come from my humble Yorkshire origins.
fields.body:
Whenever Debbie and I give a party for our envious showbiz pals in our beautiful riverside home with 12 acres of formal gardens and stunning woodlands, I think of how far I have come from my humble Yorkshire origins.

My Mum and Dad were brilliant at everything. We were very poor, mind, but we never complained about our lot. We loved our nigger brown door - you could use words like that back then and no one took offence. Happy days.

I became interested in magic at an early age when I took out a book on the subject from the library. I must give it back some time!!!!! It's the way I tell 'em.

National Service made a man of me and taught me respect. The government should bring it back for the youth of today. Only for men, though. Soldiering isn't for women or poofs.

I couldn't get beyond kissing in my teens. But after I picked up a prostitute in Hong Kong there was no looking back and I had dozens of affairs throughout my unhappy marriage to Jackie. I guess I'm not small in all departments. D'you geddit? Small!

All this time I was doing the clubs in the evening and working for the council in the day. It was tough but worth it, as everyone agreed I was the best magician in the world. Well, nearly everyone. The odd person didn't understand what I was doing; they've probably gone on to be big in BBC light entertainment!!!

In the early 70s, I decided to concentrate on show BUSINESS rather than SHOW business and it soon paid off. I'm very, very rich now and I'm great to my family. I even let my brother, Trevor, drive my Ferrari sometimes. It does sadden me, though, that some people have said they couldn't work with me because I was a conceited know-all.

Throughout the 70s, my TV career took off and in 1979 we began the first of FIFTEEN series of the Paul Daniels Show. You heard me, FIFTEEN. It was here that I met a petite, lithe dancer called Debbie. She didn't fancy me at first but I took her on a boat and tidal waves of passion soon followed. Tidal waves. Geddit?

We're a great team. Apart from my son, whose problems are absolutely nothing to do with me, life is great and I could give you anecdote after anecdote of my amusing showbiz lifestyle. In fact, I will.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested...

Magician's autobiography that ought to have been sawn in half and made to disappear. Will you like it? Not a lot.

fields.headline: Nodding off
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole aged 33
fields.trailText: The secret diary of a provincial man: Adrian Mole aged 33.
fields.body:
Saturday, July 1, Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire

To kill two birds with one stone, I decided to read the opening chapter of Sty! to William as a bedtime story. The political and philosophical sub-text will be beyond him, but I hoped that the narrative would grip him. After a few paragraphs, he bleated that he wanted a Noddy And Big Ears story, but I persevered.

Peter Pig lifted his porcine head from the trough and looked up at the mercilessly grey East-Midlands sky. A cloud, which looked like a Boots cotton-wool ball, scudded across the aforementioned sky like a Eurostar train leaving Waterloo station.

Peter sighed and walked around the sty. The filth and mud oozed between his trotters. It was disgusting, the condition he had to live in, he thought. Why should farmer Hogg and his wife, Pamela, enjoy the comfort of carpets and vinyl tiles under foot while he and his fellow pigs be condemned to wading through their own excrement.

Peter looked over the sty, towards the patio where farmer Hogg and Pamela were holding a barbecue for their friends.

The foul stench caused by pork fat dripping on Do It All charcoal briquettes drifted over to him, causing his eyes to run.

He listened to the conversations of the humans as they gorged on their buffet, which Pamela had been preparing since the Archers finished on the radio.

Peter watched the guests quaffing Bucks Fizz and longed to feel the liquid in his own mouth. He looked across the sty to where his fellow pigs, Antonia and Miles, were having a heated discussion about the nature of existence. Peter sighed, he was sick of philosophical debate. It was just his luck to be trapped in a sty with two intellectuals. How he craved for small talk! He twitched his ears towards the patio. He strained to hear the conversation.

'Well, I'm sick of it,' said a grey-haired man called Ken, 'after all Mo's been through.'

A well-presented woman called Barbara hissed: 'Not here, Ken, there's a chap called Derek from the Ashby Gazette standing by the gherkin jar.'

'I won't be silenced,' Ken thundered. 'It's unmanly of Tony to stab her in the back.'

From the sty, Peter watched as Derek turned from the pickle jar, took out his reporter's notebook and edged towards Ken and Barbara .

It was at this point that William started whining about wanting a Noddy story. However, I continued with Sty! for a few more lines.

Another group of people provided the small talk that Peter thirsted for. From a woman in white jeans, he heard: 'We do support the comprehensive system, but our children are terribly sensitive, so.' And a man wearing wire Raybans opined:

'House prices have got to come down soon. We bought ours for...'

Peter was in heaven. Later that night, the barbecue long extinguished, Peter looked up at the stars and ruminated on the nature of small talk. To help him sleep, he practised the art. He selected one of his favourite topics: 'Call this a summer? I can't remember the last time the sun shone.'

Within minutes, William was asleep.

Sunday, July 2

I loathe Noddy, but I had promised William, so I made up the following story.

It was Big Ears' birthday, so, to celebrate, Noddy drove his car to Toytown. The pals went from pub to pub, drinking pints of beer. Big Ears' face got very red and the bell on Noddy's hat rang like mad. When they came out of the last pub, a gang of Skittles accused Big Ears of being a pervert, and started a fight. Mr Plod was called and saw Noddy head-butting the largest Skittle.

'Hi ham takin' you to the nearest cash point,' said Mr Plod. 'Tell me your PIN number Noddy.' But, sadly, Noddy was too drunk to remember, so Mr Plod hit him hard on the head with his truncheon instead.

Good night.

fields.headline: Internet spy bill set at £20m
fields.standfirst: Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to hand business £20m to cover the cost of installing "black box recorders" from which the security services will be able to intercept internet traffic, including emails.
fields.body:
The government is to hand business £20m to cover the cost of installing "black box recorders" from which the security services will be able to intercept internet traffic, including emails.

The announcement, due shortly, follows protests from businesses that burgeoning e-commerce will leave Britain because of the crippling costs of installing and maintaining the boxes.

One report by a group including the London Scool of Economics which was dismissed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, claimed the new surveillance burdens on companies will run to over £46bn over five years, including the estimated cost of lost internet business.

A report compiled for the Home Office by the Smith Group, an e-business consultancy, puts the cost of installing the capital equipment and the first four years' running costs closer to £20m.

Ministers have come up with the offer following talks with the Internet Service Providers Association. They have also sought to reassure business by saying they will only require the boxes on about 10% of internet service providers. Use of the intercept capacity will still require the warrant of the home secretary.

The regulation of investigatory powers bill, imposing the requirement on business, is facing attacks in the Lords. Critics say the bill provides a snoopers' charter for the intelligence services.

The bill also includes powers to compel companies to surrender software keys for encoding private electronic documents.

The Home Office minister, Lord Bassam, has sought to allay fears that the security of UK businesses and overseas business partners will be compromised by this requirement.

A new amendment tabled by Lord Bassam will require government to keep such keys in a secure place at the highest possible classification. They are likely to be kept at M15 headquarters.
